HEADLINE: Dow Rises 32.51 Points to Another High Close

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks staged a strong rally late yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its eighth record high in nine sessions. But a weakness in the technology sector pushed the Nasdaq composite index lower.
The gains also included new highs in three broader market indexes and came despite jitters about the economy that sent investors seeking consumer stalwarts and selling economically sensitive shares. 
 The Dow ended 32.51 points higher, closing at 5,492.12.
Additionally, the New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 1.64 points, to 346.32; the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 3.60 points, to 649.93, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index rose 2.63, to 562.59. All three indexes broke records for the third consecutive session.
But the Nasdaq index fell 4.20 points, to 1,084.88, as technology shares came under pressure.
Stocks meandered, mostly in positive territory, for much of yesterday's session, held down by a declining bond market.
Bond prices fell as the market absorbed new supply, including yesterday's auction of $14 billion of 10-year Government notes and the sale of $30 billion of 30-year Treasury bonds that is scheduled for today. The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 11/32 in price; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, rose to 6.15 percent.
But stocks shook off the doldrums late in the session, with the Dow making nearly all of the day's gains in the final 45 minutes of trading.
In a reversal of Tuesday's record-breaking session, investors shed economically sensitive stocks in favor of consumer issues and more recession-resistant names.
"There is some backing and filling going on into consumer stocks, which had been weak, and some retail names." said John Church, chief investment officer at the Glenmede Trust Company in Philadephia.
But Mr. Church said he was optimistic about the stock market. "Stocks aren't cheap on the basis of yields, and certainly after the 30-something-percent rally last year, you can't say they're really cheap," he said. "But I think there's an equal risk attached to being out of the market. In 1987, when the market crashed, you had the competition from bonds at 10 percent; today they're at 6" percent.
Among retailers, Sears, Roebuck & Company rose 1 3/4, to 44 3/8, and J. C. Penney added 1 1/2, to 49 3/8. Drug makers also gained, with Merck & Company rising 1 5/8 a share, to 69, and Pharmacia Upjohn up 1 1/2, to 43 1/2. McDonald's, another high-profile consumer stock, rose 1 5/8, to 53 1/4, while Coca-Cola added 1 3/8 a share, to 78.
But technology stocks retreated from gains earlier in the week, after Montgomery Securities downgraded several of them, saying the group had "limited upside potential and heightened uncertainty."
On the Big Board, I.B.M. dropped 1 7/8, to 112 5/8; Micron Technology fell 1/2, to 41 3/8; Texas Instruments lost 1 1/4, to 53 3/8, and Compaq Computer declined 3/8, to 50 3/4.
Semiconductor stocks sank ahead of the Semiconductor Association's announcement of its January report on sales and new orders. The release of the figures had been expected late yesterday but was postponed until after the close of trading today.
Neither the bond nor stock markets were much impressed yesterday with a Commerce Department report that the nation's trade deficit declined 13.5 percent in November to $7.06 billion.
Economists said the number was not important, since it indicated that a softening United States economy had lowered demand for imports.

HEADLINE: Rowland Budget Retreats From Sharp Cuts of Last Year

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Stepping back from the sharp cuts he offered last year, Gov. John G. Rowland today proposed a budget that features a modest reduction in overall spending and increased aid for the elderly, children and the state's ailing cities.
"I believe in a government that is bold enough to be basic," Mr. Rowland said in his second annual address to the Legislature. "It must help to care for the children and the elderly who are alone or who are endangered." 
 Although the budget includes substantial cuts in several social service programs, the Governor's speech focused instead on programs where he intended to spend more.
For example, he promised to rescind one of last year's most controversial cuts, a $40 million reduction in nursing home programs. And he called for an additional $12 million for a program that helps disabled children, as well as adding 219 employees to the agency that oversees children in troubled families.
He also unveiled a much-anticipated urban agenda that includes $78 million in bonding for projects in the cities, an amount that some criticized as too little to have any impact.
But at the same time, Mr. Rowland did not abandon the tough changes to the state welfare system that he considers among the top accomplishments of his first year in office. Following up on the state's new 21-month limit on welfare benefits to families, the shortest time limit in the nation, Mr. Rowland said today that families whose children fail to attend school should have their welfare checks withheld.
The 35-minute address was largely free of any partisan appeals. Instead, Mr. Rowland, a Republican, praised the cooperation between the Republican-controlled Senate and the Democratic-controlled House during the last session and said he hoped it would continue.
"What we ought to do is let the Washington spectacle be an example of what we will never tolerate as Democrats and Republicans governing here in Connecticut," he said.
To some extent, today's presentation was by its very nature unlikely to produce any dramatic new directions for the budget. Connecticut has two-year budgets, and the legislative session that convened today is intended to make needed adjustments to the budget passed last session, not chart a new course.
For the next fiscal year, which starts on July 1 and runs through June 30, 1997, Mr. Rowland proposed additional spending cuts of $72.9 million, a change of less than 1 percent from the spending outlined in the current biennial budget. If these cuts were enacted, total state spending would increase by 2.2 percent to about $10.1 billion next year, from $9.9 billion this year.
This growth in spending, while small, is a departure from last year's budget address when Mr. Rowland insisted that total state spending had to be reduced and that 31 state agencies must be consolidated into 14, ideas the Legislature largely rejected.
It remains to be seen whether Mr. Rowland's budget will succeed in addressing the state's fiscal problems.
Last month, the Office of Fiscal Analysis, a nonpartisan legislative agency, projected a $224 million deficit in the next fiscal year if the state were to continue on the path set by the biennial budget. That change was largely attributable to unanticipated spending increases in social service programs and to a forecast that tax revenues would be smaller than expected because a substantial improvement in the state economy is no longer predicted.
Potentially making matters worse, Mr. Rowland's budget is based on the assumption that there will be no changes in Federal aid, changes that State Comptroller Nancy Wyman has said will cost the state at least $30 million.
Reginald L. Jones, the Governor's budget chief, defended the decision, saying it was impossible to forecast such changes. "New York State developed their budget, in contrast, for the next fiscal year based on a projection of Federal changes, and it now is facing a potential list of problems," he said, referring to Gov. George Pataki's plan to achieve more than $1.1 billion in savings in Medicaid and welfare as a result of the proposed lifting of certain Federal restrictions.
"A New York Times editorial says Governor Pataki is not sleeping too well at nights," Mr. Jones added.
The prospects for Mr. Rowland's plan to cut off welfare checks to families whose children don't attend school also was unclear. In an interview last week,, he said such a move would probably require a waiver from the Federal Government. There is no guarantee that such a waiver would be forthcoming though one was granted in Wisconsin. The proposal drew loud applause from legislators, mainly Republicans.
There are also other questions about Mr. Rowland's proposal. At the heart of his budget is a plan to privatize the state lottery and sell shares in it next year. While that sale is expected to produce about $160 million -- money needed to carry out a tax cut that takes effect next year -- Mr. Rowland has proposed borrowing money in the meantime by issuing short-term "lottery notes" on Wall Street.
That idea met a chilly reception from Moody's Investors Service, the bond-rating agency, which called them "deficit notes" and said the move could affect the state's bond rating.
William A. DiBella, the Senate Democratic Minority Leader, said today, "In order to pay for this budget, instead of selling the lottery, we're going to have to win it."
Indeed, Democrats said many of Mr. Rowland's proposed cuts and plans to increase revenues were not realistic and had been sent to the Legislature in the past and failed to win support.
Mr. Rowland's proposed cuts in social service programs also were received unenthusiastically by Democrats. A plan to save $13.5 million by eliminating rental subsidies for poor families was rejected by Thomas D. Ritter, the Speaker of the House.
Still, Mr. Ritter said that he was not displeased by Mr. Rowland's speech. "I thought the tone was good," he said. "It did not articulate many details, a lot of the ugly things, but it set the tone for reasoned discussion."

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Gap Narrows Again In Export Boom

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Strong exports and a weakening economy at home brought the nation's trade deficit to its lowest total in nearly two years in November, as the gap shrank by 13.5 percent, to $7.06 billion. It was the fifth consecutive month of improvement.
The figures, reported today by the Commerce Department, showed that the two-year boom in exports was still fueling the economy and that America's trade woes with Japan were easing. 
 But the report also provided new signs of an economy that is slowing. Not only is the rate of growth in exports slipping, but imports fell for the second consecutive month as consumers and many businesses cut back on purchases of a wide range of goods and services.
"The bottom line is that it's a good news/bad news type of story," said Michael P. Niemira, an economist at the Mitsubishi Bank in New York. "The good news is that we're starting to see shrinkage in the trade gap. But the reason we're starting to see it is that the domestic economy is slowing."
Still, most economists think the trade deficit will keep falling in 1996, and that would be welcome news for President Clinton. Some of his Republican challengers have questioned his trade policies and argue that the United States needs to crack down harder on Japan and other trading partners. The President's harshest trade critic, Patrick J. Buchanan, won an upset victory in Louisiana's Republican caucuses on Tuesday; exit polls indicated that the appeal of such a message played a role.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, countered today that the latest figures showed "solid, steady progress" in bringing down both the overall trade deficit and the one with Japan, which also fell more than 13 percent in November.
"Trade is becoming an ever-increasing part of the U.S. economy," he added in an interview. "And we've got to keep playing and trying to open markets, because the alternative, hiding behind people's fears, is only a prescription for failure."
Other economists said the nation's economic growth rate would play a more critical role in election-year politics than trade results, and some said the most important question about figures like today's was whether exports would remain strong enough to keep the economy from stalling.
"The biggest challenge to Clinton is from the Republicans who are focused on economic growth, like Steve Forbes, and not from the insular, turn-your-back-on-the-world wing of the party led by Pat Buchanan," said John Ryding, senior economist with Bear, Stearns & Company in New York.
Mr. Ryding said he believed that the relatively weak dollar, and a gradual pickup in economic activity overseas, would keep American exports at a level high enough to push the economy along at a moderate clip in 1996.
But Mr. Niemira said that his bank had found in a recent survey that transportation executives expected the growth in exports to slow significantly this year as most of America's top trading partners also grappled with sluggish economies.
The Commerce Department report showed that the overall trade deficit dropped to $7.06 billion in November from a revised total of $8.16 billion in October. The November figure was the lowest monthly total since $6.5 billion in March 1994, and it represented a 38 percent drop from $11.39 billion last June.
The deficit with Japan also fell sharply in November, to $4.13 billion, the lowest level since May 1993, from $4.79 billion in October. America's deficits with two other leading trade partners -- China and Canada -- also narrowed in November.
Even with such striking improvements, today's figures suggested that the overall deficit for 1995 would total about $112 billion to $113 billion, up from $106.2 billion in 1994.
And while exports rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in November, imports dropped by seventh-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said.
Indeed, the decline in imports accounted for nearly all of the improvement in the trade balance with Japan in November, though American exports to Japan have also risen sharply in the last year.
Most economists expect to see even steeper drops in import levels if the faltering economy makes business and consumers more wary about making major purchases during the next few months.
Indeed, the Federal Reserve reported today that consumer debt expanded at a slower pace in December, perhaps reflecting the household retrenchment that seems to be holding down demand for imported goods.
Outstanding credit swelled at a 9.3 percent annual rate in the final month of the year, compared with 11.8 percent in November and 13.7 percent in October, the Fed found.
Both automobile and revolving, or credit card, debt increased at double-digit rates. But the "other" category, which includes loans for education, boats and vacations, contracted at a 3.2 percent pace, the first decline since July and the largest since February 1995.
While a further decline in imports would signal a weakening in the economy, it would also help lower the overall trade deficit. And most economists think imports will drop enough in 1996 to cut the trade deficit to anywhere from $75 billion to $90 billion.

Murdoch Cuts On-Line Unit
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is planning to shelve its on-line service and convert the unit into an Internet-based service. The cutback is part of a broader shake-out in the on-line industry. Page D1.
 
U.S. Trade Deficit Narrows
The United States trade deficit shrank by 13.5 percent in November, to its lowest total in nearly two years. But the Government's report also provided new evidence of an economic slowdown. Page D1.
 
Law Files Were Moved
A former law partner of Hillary Rodham Clinton's said he removed an array of files on Mrs. Clinton's legal work from the Rose Law Firm in Arkansas shortly before Bill Clinton's inauguration. Page B10.
 
New Education Yardstick
Confronting a perceived decline in academic standards, officials in New Jersey and New York released statewide guidelines to improve the quality of public education. Page B8.

HEADLINE: The Trickle-Up Economy;
Poor Areas Fear a Disaster if Welfare Is Cut

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Shortly after 9 A.M., the security screens roll up at a handful of discount furniture stores at the intersection of Fulton Street and Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn. At the Krusty Bakery, coffee is sold through a bulletproof glass partition, and elsewhere, mothers roam the aisles of cut-rate clothing stores. A closed bank building has become a big billboard for a 99-cent sale. Veteran street vendors hawk hats and perfume.
The engine that drives much of the energy of this intersection's fragile mini-economy is welfare money, for more than a third of the neighborhood's residents receive public assistance. 
 For that reason, the various proposals for cutting welfare benefits now under active discussion in New York City, Albany and Washington have sent a shiver of fear through the network of shops and businesses at Nostrand and Fulton. One recent study by advocates for the poor projected that Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to cut welfare benefits would remove $33 million from the neighborhood. Whether or not the estimate is accurate, the study illustrates a a little-discussed fact: changes in welfare policy can affect local economies independently of the debate about the morality or social wisdom of welfare.
"Ross Perot would miss $33 million," noted Robert Broadnax, an employee of S & S Discount Furniture on Nostrand Avenue.
Economists and other analysts say it is difficult to measure the full economic life of a neighborhood. And so no one can really say how big a part of that economic activity stands to be erased or compromised by Mr. Pataki's proposed rollback of welfare spending.
But in this section of Bedford-Stuyvesant, where more than 40,000 of the 115,000 residents receive public assistance, where pizza parlors advertise that they accept food stamps and nearly 10 percent of the members of a local credit union make deposits from their welfare checks, no one much disputes the notion that they will feel the impact.
"Almost all of our customers are from the neighborhood," said Barbara Smith, an employee at DLW Travel. "I would think the stores in the neighborhood would be leaving if that kind of money is taken out of it."
Thomas Diaz, the manager of the Bravo supermarket on Fulton Street, is not so sure the results will be all bad if benefits are cut.
"If people can't shop, it can't be good for me," Mr. Diaz conceded. "But maybe they will change the way they have led their lives. Maybe they will work."
Mr. Diaz, though, did concede the risk. Welfare recipients, after all, are almost exclusively local customers. They generally use their limited benefits to pay rent to landlords and to spend cash at clothing outlets and grocery stores.
"They are talking about taking millions of dollars out of an already underdeveloped neighborhood," said Margo Butts, an official with the Bedford-Stuyvesant Community Conference, a local economic planning organization. "I think you have to consider, then, that what they might be talking about is economic devastation."
The recent study by a nonprofit advocacy group for the poor offers what it says is a frank formula for figuring the potential economic challenge many neighborhoods would face as a result of the state's proposed welfare reductions. Basing its projections on Mr. Pataki's plan to cut the basic welfare grant by 26.5 percent, eliminate other emergency benefits and set limits on home relief, the study by the Community Food Resource Center Inc. estimates that tens of millions of dollars will be taken from individual neighborhood economies across the city.
"We decided to take a different route from what poverty advocates usually do," said Liz Krueger, executive director of the organization. "We decided to follow the money."
Examining the city by State Assembly districts -- roughly 120,000 people live in each one -- the study calculated how many people in each district received public assistance. Then it used the state's own figures for average welfare payments to estimate how much less would be paid out to people in those districts.
As an example, in Ridgewood, Queens, a mostly working-class neighborhood, the reductions would remove $15 million in disposable income; in Washington Heights and Inwood in Manhattan, where greater numbers of welfare recipients live, the total would be more than $28 million; in the South Bronx, where more people live on public assistance than anywhere else in the city, $47 million would be gone.
But Ms. Kreuger and other economists note that it is impossible to know how large the total community economies might be, and so understand how damaging the cuts would be over all.
It is easier to see the potential effects at street level. At the intersection of Nostrand and Fulton, in a district that receives nearly $110 million in public assistance payments a year, those on welfare spend their money at telephone calling centers and in a modest mall.
"This is an all-cash economy around here," said Mark Sing, a street vendor who has sold cosmetics and scarves on Fulton Street for years. "Take that much cash out, it is going to kill me. To be honest, it feels like revenge."
Pataki administration officials, while not disputing the raw numbers, reject any implication that the reductions mean permanently lost resources. The officials say they intend to increase the state's share of food stamp allotments next year. That, they contend, will offset the damage of welfare cuts. The officials also say the measures will force people into jobs, and that private money will take over.
Mr. Pataki's first set of proposed cuts in welfare last year, put forth with some of the same arguments, died in the face of Democratic opposition. And this year's cuts are contingent, in part, on changes in welfare policy now under discussion in Washington.
Still, contended Brian Wing, the acting Commissioner for the State Department of Social Services, "those dollars can be earned back."
"People can refill the gap with work," Mr. Wing said. "The money will be lost permanently only to those people who take no steps to take care of themselves."
But that argument is the subject of dispute.
The Pataki administration says job training and development programs will be enhanced as part of the welfare reform effort. It claims that 100,000 new private jobs were created across the state last year. Legislators and other labor analysts, though, say the job gains were in fact half that number, and note that unemployment in the state rose to 6.4 percent from 5.7 percent during 1995, the Governor's first year.
In the 56th Assembly District in Bedford-Stuyvesant, only 12.8 percent of the residents 25 years or older have more than a high school education. Albert Vann, the Democratic Assemblyman who represents the 56th, said the unemployment rate for black men ages 17 to 24 is 37 percent.
"People suddenly working in this neighborhood -- that's a farce," Mr. Vann said. "There is no such job creation."
Some economic analysts say counting the welfare reductions as lost income to communities is an important way of fully appreciating the economic fallout of a policy decision. Others call it nonsense.
"We can all have biases about certain parts of the debate on welfare, but the argument that there is going to be an economic ripple effect for certain neighborhoods is real," said Russell Sykes, an official with the State Communities Aid Association, a research organization that has advocated welfare reform. "You can count on one truth: welfare benefits are spent in the neighborhood. And you are not replacing those dollars instantly."
But Abe Lackman, the former budget director for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani who is now secretary to the State Senate Finance Committee, disagreed.
"The argument that the money is drained and forever lost, by its nature, is specious," Mr. Lackman said. "The welfare money, in a sense, is coming from taxes in those neighborhoods. And so the key question people should be asking themselves is, Are they receiving proper return on their tax dollars that fund welfare and other programs?"
Still, the prospect of radical welfare reductions' damaging the city's struggling, discrete neighborhood economies has caused all sorts of people to ask questions.
At Nostrand and Fulton, most people seemed convinced of the potential peril. Joe Long, who has run Birdy's Record Shop since 1969, winced when he theorized about the loss of $33 million in his district.
"Where are we going without consumers?" he said. "It's going to be rough. If money isn't back in circulation quick, you can wrap it up here as a neighborhood by the year 2000."
Meyer Sakkal, staring out over the rows of bins of discount clothing at the Ray department store, which he manages, said the city's tightening of welfare benefits had already hurt his business.
"We've had days, he said, "where more is stolen from here than bought."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Mutual fund investors primarily took world tours last month.

BYLINE: By Edward Wyatt 

 BODY:
USING the investment vehicle that served them so well in the United States stock market last year -- mutual funds -- individual investors turned their attentions overseas last month, putting a record amount of money into funds that invest both here and abroad and pushing foreign markets up sharply in the process.
The broad American market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's Corporation index of 500 stocks, is up 5.5 percent this year, and yesterday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 32.51 points, to 5,492.14, its eighth record high in nine sessions. But other markets around the globe have recorded similar -- or better -- gains. 
 For example, Germany's DAX index has risen 8.5 percent, or 5.5 percent in United States dollars, while Mexico's Bolsa index has gained 8.3 percent, or 11.7 percent in American dollars. In the Far East, the Hang Seng index, which measures the Hong Kong stock exchange, is up 13 percent since the start of the year.
According to estimates released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute, roughly $24.5 billion in net new cash flowed into domestic and international stock funds in January -- a third more than the previous one-month record of $18.3 billion, set in January 1994, and 44 percent more than in December, which was the best month of cash flows in 1995.
About half of the growth in fund flows last month went to international funds, which in 1995 lagged far behind domestic stock funds in attracting new investment. Bond funds, meanwhile, which suffered net outflows for much of last year, took in an estimated $3 billion last month, their biggest month since January 1994, when inflows totaled $11.0 billion.
The combined monthly total for stock and bond funds of $27.5 billion, up from $17.8 billion in December, was the largest net inflow to long-term mutual funds since January 1994, when funds took in $29.4 billion in new cash.
The January data are the first released by the institute under a new format of estimated cash flows it adopted this month. The preliminary estimates, which will be reported about seven business days after the end of each month, is based on a survey of mutual funds that account for about 97 percent of mutual fund assets, the institute said. Previously, the trade group has waited to report monthly cash flow data until the end of the following month, when all fund companies have compiled final results.
January is traditionally a big month for mutual fund cash flows, because of corporate payments of employee bonuses and distributions to pension and profit-sharing funds. Inflows also tend to rise in the January following a year of particularly strong performance, as occurred in the stock and bond markets in 1995, because individual investors tend to favor those investments that have already performed the best.
John Rea, chief economist at the Investment Company Institute, said international and global stock funds, which invest all or most of their assets abroad, showed particular strength last month, taking in "well over half" of the $7.5 billion increase in inflows that stock funds recorded in January over December.
If that estimate is correct, that would mean international funds took in somewhat more than $6 billion in January, which would be their biggest month since February 1994. Around the end of 1995, following two years of tough times for international investors, many market strategists predicted that overseas bourses were likely to outperform the United States stock market this year.
Mr. Rea said municipal bond funds showed little change in their recent trends, in which net flows have bounced from slightly negative to slightly positive and back again for most of the last year.
The trade group's data on mutual fund flows agree with what fund company officials have been saying for weeks -- that January was the best month for new investment they had ever seen.
Steve Norwitz, a spokesman for T. Rowe Price, said that company took in $1.6 billion in new cash in January, equivalent to nearly a third of its total net inflows for all of 1995. "We definitely saw a rebound in interest in international investing," he said. "What was a moderately positive cash flow at the end of the year picked up significantly in January."
At the Vanguard Group, more than $4 billion in net new cash surged into accounts in January, burying the company's previous best month of $2.6 billion, set in March 1993, according to Brian Mattes, a spokesman. "And February appears to be a repeat of that," he said, with $1 billion in more cash coming into funds of all types in the first week of this month.
Charles Biderman, editor of Liquidity Trim Tabs and two other newsletters based in Santa Rosa, Calif. that track cash flow and liquidity data, has been predicting for nearly a month that a surge of fresh cash into mutual funds would cause an "upside explosion" in stock prices.
Bob Adler of AMG Data Services in Arcata, Calif., which also makes its own estimates of mutual fund cash flow, reported that in addition to international funds, cash has flowed most quickly in recent weeks to aggressive growth funds, which invest in the riskest category of United States stocks.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "In January, A Jump in Stock Funds" shows monthly cash flows into stock mutual funds for 1994 and 1995. (Source: Investment Companty Institute)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE SCENE;
Forbes? The Enemy Camp Turns Joyful

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: AMES, Iowa, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The very idea that President Clinton might eventually run against Steve Forbes and his flat-tax platform sends Margo McNabb, career Democrat, into a Joycean ecstasy of Molly Bloom dimensions.
"Yes, yes, oh, yes!" Mrs. McNabb crooned, uninhibited in the outsized joy she envisions in Mr. Clinton's going to the people and denouncing the flat tax as the ultimate measure of just how reactionary a spectacle the Republicans are presenting this year as they elbow their way through the Iowa Presidential nominating competition and beyond. 
 "And I read that Steve the Boy Wonder has a Robert Mapplethorpe print on his yacht!" added Mrs. McNabb, delightedly swirling the Mapplethorpe taboo, dear to the Republican Christian right, into the plutocrat image of Mr. Forbes that she craves to see the President set up and smash like a November pinata.
A former Democratic state committeewoman and Story County chairwoman, Mrs. McNabb has no internecine fight on her hands this year. But like most other Democrats, she is thoroughly enjoying the mixed enthusiasm and shock of Republicans at the high polling tides of the Forbes phenomenon. For fun, she concocts attack commercials that seem little more exaggerated than the dirk-and-blunderbuss appeals already blanketing this state like the season's tiresome, mud-spattered snows.
"One would open with a coupon-clipping, bonbon-eating dowager as the maid comes in," Mrs. McNabb fantasized, cackling at her imaginary 30-second spot, Bubba versus the Plutocrat. "The President would wipe up the floor with him," she concluded, asking what could be better for a Democratic candidate than reducing things to the issue of poor versus rich?
But Mr. Forbes continues to fairly mesmerize Iowa audiences with his single-theme denunciation of the Internal Revenue code, an attack that always draws on the same Dracula specter that, word for word, he first raised at his campaign opening last year. "Kill it, drive a stake through its heart, bury it and hope it never rises again to terrorize the American people!" he advises in his familiar peroration with his familiar unblinking smile of delight. He prescribes all but a clove of garlic, and inevitably audiences burst into applause at his imagery-filled message that a money-sucking "monstrosity," the graduated income tax, can be exterminated.
His stump appearances lately are more remarkable for what the audiences do not ask about the flat tax than for the dedicated repetitiousness of Mr. Forbes's performance.
There seems little voter memory of the recent history of supply-side economics. Rather, there is the fun of Mr. Forbes's fresh face looming at the center of what is the biggest clot of reeling, pushing news media gangs currently in motion in Iowa. There is the simple optimism generated by a four-piece band playing "The Battle Hymn of the Republic" at the very entrance of the $4 million Iowa candidate: a personally financed self-proclaimed nonpolitician with four times the spending power of any of his rivals, those accused politicians who somehow seem sheepish in competing under fund-raising strictures.
"I worked out the flat-tax formulas," said John Babyar, a Republican caucus-goer who nodded approvingly at Mr. Forbes's speech on Tuesday night at the library in the town of Indianola. "And his leaves me $800 richer. What's wrong with being rich? I'd like to see all Americans rich."
Mr. Forbes is counting on testimonials like Mr. Babyar's to prove stronger at the caucuses on Monday than are the increasing jabs his rivals are throwing at his family fortune. "He has 520 acres there in New Jersey, and 439 are zoned agricultural," Senator Phil Gramm tells Iowa farmers, his twang extra cynical in enumeration of the tax shelters that Mr. Forbes enjoys even as he demonizes the system. "You know what he grows on his farm? Polo ponies."
Particularly notable is the precision of Forbes rivals in their criticisms. "Even his 441-foot yacht is tax deductible," says Lamar Alexander. These knocks draw approving leers and laughter. Then again, Mr. Babyar and countless others are out there listening, appreciating a rich role model.
The Republican candidates, for all their lacerating competitiveness, touch on one strangely similar aside: China's emerging market for farm imports. Mr. Forbes hypothesizes that "if all the people in China ate two more eggs" a week, it would take "all the grain produced in a year in Australia" to feed the egg-layers. Mr. Gramm: "If everybody in China ate one more chicken a year, it would take the entire soybean crop of Illinois to feed that chicken."
Just as a listener is deciding, "That's some chicken," Mr. Alexander offers a slightly more complex hypothesis, about the Chinese eating just a bit more chicken and pork and thereby needing the entire Nebraskan grain crop to fatten the export bonanza.
After days of these crop references, a listener can pause and wonder whether this is something Oliver Stone should look into: a Chinese Menu Stump Conspiracy, with the System's irrepressibly ambitious politicians in cahoots. But no.
"Iowans aren't stupid, you know," contended Margo McNabb, stoking her reveries on the Forbes candidacy.

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

PATRICK J. BUCHANAN
 
From a press conference yesterday in Des Moines:
" The argument we're going to make for the rest of this campaign here in Iowa is this: Pat Buchanan is the conservative who can win this race. It is time for conservatives to unite behind him, and, I believe, carry the day in Iowa. And let me say this: more than a fighting chance -- who has an excellent chance today to win the Republican nomination and win the election in November. 
 Finally, we're going to ask Democrats and independents to come out and help us out in the Iowa caucuses, and join this new coalition we're trying to build -- of traditional social conservatives, economic conservatives and populists, the Perot folks, the Reagan Democrats and the Republicans. "

HEADLINE: POLITICS: IN THE PACK;
Unbowed but Disappointed, Gramm Pushes On in Iowa

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Feb. 7

 BODY:
When Senator Phil Gramm returned to his chartered jet between visits to voting sites in Louisiana on Tuesday night, the stewardess, Lisa Dinsmoor, complimented him on his extensive police escort.
"Isn't it great?" exulted Mr. Gramm, who is from neighboring Texas. "I tell you, there's nothing like being back in your own country." 
 He did not know it yet -- and would not accept it even long after the first returns had come in -- but Mr. Gramm was losing in his own country, defeated by a Northerner in the Louisiana caucuses, which, only an hour before the polling precincts closed, he was still predicting he would win.
In a contest that most of the Republican Presidential field bypassed, the victor, Patrick J. Buchanan, had ridiculed Mr. Gramm's devotion to free trade and questioned the depth of his opposition to abortion. Buchanan aides in Louisiana said that by raising doubts about Mr. Gramm's anti-abortion commitment, Mr. Buchanan had been able to draw away Christian conservatives, voters who also form a powerful bloc in the Iowa caucuses next Monday.
At a rally here today, Mr. Gramm tried to reassure Iowans that he was unbowed in defeat. Speaking at the State Capitol, he never mentioned Louisiana. Instead, he delivered a rousing speech that he had scribbled during his flight from New Orleans, dwelling on social issues that he had rarely mentioned in recent weeks here: welfare, immigration, crime and, perhaps most significantly, abortion.
"Today the 1.5 million abortions that occur in our country every year represent a national disgrace and a national tragedy," he declared, "and I'm committed to remove that blot from our national character."
Addressing about 200 supporters -- who frequently interrupted him with chants of "Phil '96!" -- Mr. Gramm said he remained the logical conservative choice. "I am the only candidate," he said, "who can bring together the social conservatives and the economic conservatives and beat Bill Clinton."
Mr. Gramm's strategists had hoped that this claim would gain force with a victory in Louisiana. Instead, they acknowledged today, its power has diminished.
But rather than lick his wounds, Mr. Gramm pressed ahead, appearing on all the television networks' morning shows to acknowledge his disappointment while displaying his determination to fight on.
As he flew from Louisiana to Iowa, the Senator said he needed to finish third or higher in the caucuses here on Monday. "If I can run in the top three, we're very much in this race," he said. "If I don't run in the top three, we're out of this race. So it's clear-cut." But he declined to say he would drop out if he finished fourth or worse.
Mr. Gramm also declined to discuss in detail what had gone wrong in Louisiana. "That just too much borders on excuse-making," he said.
But he did say he believed that Senator Bob Dole, the Republican front-runner, had worked against him there and that supporters of David Duke, the former Klansman and onetime candidate for Louisiana governor, had been "a big factor" in Mr. Buchanan's success.
Mr. Gramm's campaign chairman, Charles Black, said the Gramm organization had miscalculated on several fronts.
Mr. Black said he had underestimated the turnout, as well as the high proportion of religious conservatives among caucus-goers. He also said Gramm supporters had become demoralized because the candidate had rarely visited the state. To revitalize them, the campaign renewed television commercials in the last five days. But it was too late.
"We all have egg on our faces," Mr. Black said.
Mr. Gramm said the loss would not cause him to alter his message. "I'm not going to try to deceive people about who I am and what I want to do," he said.
He said that in particular he did not intend to stop preaching free trade. "This idea promoted by Pat Buchanan and Dick Gephardt that somehow we can build a wall around America and go hide under a rock somewhere is totally unrealistic," he said.
At the rally here today, Mr. Gramm again proclaimed the virtues of free trade. But he set aside his usual stump speech in favor of themes he had struck only softly for weeks.
"Today 40 million Americans have their lives diminished by being dependent on the Federal Government," he said. "We have made mothers dependent, we have driven fathers out of the household, we have denied people access to the American dream with a welfare program that does not work."
Mr. Gramm resurrected an image he once employed frequently, drawing a distinction between Americans who "ride in the wagon" and those who pull it.
Someone who pulls, he said, "not only loves himself but loves his country and is part of it, and I want people to pull because I love them."
The Senator sketched a vision of the United States on Jan. 1, 2001, after four years of a Gramm Presidency: crime diminished, affirmative action ended, the Department of Education abolished and abortion banished.
"I know that there are those who will say that listening to Phil Gramm talk about the year 2001, it sounds an awful lot like a Norman Rockwell painting," he said. "Norman Rockwell did not paint America exactly as it was. He painted it as we wanted it to be, and as we knew it could be."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After a disappointing loss in Louisiana on Tuesday, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas met with supporters in Des Moines yesterday. "I am the only candidate," he told them, "who can bring together the social conservatives and the economic conservatives and beat Bill Clinton." (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Aristide Hands Power to Successor in Haiti

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 7

 BODY:
In subdued, even somber ceremonies here today, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide ended a turbulent five-year term by becoming the first elected head of state in nearly 200 years of Haitian history to peacefully transfer power to a popularly chosen successor.
To the applause of Haitian and foreign dignitaries well aware of both the significance and the high cost of his investiture by democratic means, the country's new President, Rene Garcia Preval, promised to duplicate Mr. Aristide's achievement. 
 "I swear to obey and make sure others obey the Constitution of the nation, and its laws," the new President said in taking his oath of office.
Mr. Aristide, in his last official act as President, tweaked the United States and spared Mr. Preval from taking a step that might undermine his relationship with Washington. Late Tuesday night, Haiti announced that it was re-establishing diplomatic relations with Cuba, broken by the dictator Francois (Papa Doc) Duvalier more than 30 years ago in response to American pressure.
This morning, arriving at Parliament nearly an hour behind schedule for the swearing in, Mr. Aristide was greeted by a military band, the only remnant of the disbanded Haitian armed forces, which overthrew him in a coup in September 1991.
Afterward a small group of onlookers sang "Auld Lang Syne" and complained of Mr. Aristide's decision to step down, in keeping with a constitutional prohibition on Haitian presidents succeeding themselves in office.
"We want Titid! We want Titid!" some chanted, using Mr. Aristide's nickname. In an indication of the narrow political maneuverability and autonomy Mr. Preval may have, others shouted that they were eager for Mr. Aristide to run for president again in five years.
Today also marked the 10th anniversary of the day Jean-Claude Duvalier was toppled from power, ending a 30-year family dictatorship and ushering in a period of political instability and state-sponsored violence that concluded only with Mr. Aristide's restoration to power by 20,000 American troops in the fall of 1994.
Nevertheless, few people took to the streets to mark the occasion, in contrast to Mr. Aristide's inauguration five years ago today. And there were virtually no public festivities.
"Today doesn't really mean a lot to me, because there are still no jobs and I don't have enough to eat," said Felix Joseph, who described himself as an unemployed mason.
In his inaugural address, delivered this afternoon on the lawn of the National Palace, Mr. Preval vowed to remedy that situation, calling on Haitians to "join intelligences and unite efforts" in order to do away with "the profound inequities of our society."
The strongest public reaction, however, came in response to Mr. Preval's pledge to "restore the authority of the state," which has traditionally governed for the benefit of an elite few since Haiti became an independent nation in 1804.
In an indication of the diminishing commitment of world powers to Haiti, most of the foreign delegations attending the inauguration ceremonies were of low rank.
No heads of state attended, and United Nations Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali also stayed away. The senior foreign official present was Taiwan's Vice President, Li Juan-zu.
On earlier occasions over the last 16 months on which it wished to trumpet its Haiti venture as a foreign policy success, the Clinton Administration has been represented here by the President, Vice President Al Gore or Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
This time, however, the American delegation, which flew in this morning and departed this afternoon, was led by Madeleine K. Albright, the American representative to the United Nations.
Mr. Aristide's decision to revive relations with Cuba in the last hours of his term led to a delicate diplomatic minuet at the inaugural ceremony. Ms. Albright found herself sitting directly behind Cuba's Foreign Minister, Roberto Robaina, whom she pointedly ignored. For his part Mr. Robaina, seated alongside the Taiwanese delegation, strained and shifted position in order to avoid them.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Rene Preval, facing the camera, was embraced by his predecessor, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, yesterday at ceremonies in Port-au-Prince. Mr. Aristide's final act was to restore relations with Cuba. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CAUCUSES;
Louisiana Catapults Buchanan Into Iowa

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
With Senator Phil Gramm thrown off stride and Patrick J. Buchanan heartened by the results of Tuesday's Louisiana caucuses, the Republican Presidential hopefuls plunged today into the final round of campaigning before the closely watched Iowa caucuses next Monday.
The Louisiana contest was an innovation this year, seized upon by Mr. Gramm, who comes from neighboring Texas, to try to gain impetus for Iowa. Only 21,500 people took part, a mere 5 percent of the Republican registration, which robbed the event of much of its luster. In a state with 4,000 precincts, there were only 42 caucus sites. 
 But the outcome, following a similar surprising reversal last week in an Alaska straw poll, hurt Mr. Gramm all the same, not least because it was he who had touted the contest's importance. In political circles, he was seen as having outsmarted himself.
Mr. Buchanan, who took 13 of the 21 delegates at stake in Louisiana, said in an interview as he flew from New Orleans to Iowa that his victory had demonstrated that "Pat Buchanan can win this nomination and put together a coalition to win the election." But most leading Republicans remained dubious. Party elders consider his diatribes against abortion, recent trade agreements and American involvement abroad too extreme for many voters.
Although Dick Bennett, a leading New Hampshire pollster, said Mr. Buchanan's victory "solidifies his position as the real conservative in the race," other professionals argued that the real significance of the outcome lay in the harm it did to Mr. Gramm rather than the help it gave to Mr. Buchanan.
New Iowa polls show a large bloc of voters still undecided, at least partly because of dismay over the negativism of the campaign. Mr. Buchanan asserted that he now has "a fighting chance" in the state if the race is still fluid enough, although he expressed concern about the millions of dollars spent on television advertising by Steve Forbes, the publishing mogul. Mr. Buchanan is one of the least well-financed candidates; he has said he can win if he is outspent 5 to 1, "but I don't know what happens if it goes to 10 to 1."
For his part, Mr. Gramm insisted in television appearances and in a speech at the Iowa Capitol that he had not been knocked out of the race, even though he took only eight delegates in Louisiana, where he and his handlers had predicted a sweep as recently as last weekend. He said his strong grass-roots organization would help him rebound in Iowa to finish at least third.
"We have a long way to go and a short time to get there," he conceded.
Overconfident, Mr. Gramm spent last week in Iowa while Mr. Buchanan sneaked up on him in Louisiana, and the commentator asserted today that he had proved he was much the strongest conservative in the race. Half the participants in the caucuses, according to an exit poll, identified themselves as members of the religious right, and they went to Mr. Buchanan by almost 2 to 1.
The poll, taken by Voter News Service, a consortium of the networks and The Associated Press, showed Mr. Buchanan winning handily among older voters, foes of abortion and those who called themselves very conservative. The pattern of returns, with Mr. Buchanan running strongly in the heavily Catholic parishes of southwestern Louisiana, the Cajun country, suggested that he was helped by his own Catholicism.
Alan Keyes, the third active candidate in Louisiana, won no delegates.
Neither Senator Bob Dole nor Mr. Forbes competed in the state, which Mr. Gramm had recently called "a race to determine the true conservative in the field." They are considered the front-runners in Iowa, whose caucuses mark the quasi-official opening of the nominating process, and in New Hampshire, whose first-in-the-nation primary comes eight days later, on Feb. 20.
Compounding Mr. Gramm's problems, he has been counting on Christian conservatives to help power his operation on caucus night in Iowa. The movement there is already divided among Mr. Gramm, Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Dole, and defections from Mr. Gramm to Mr. Buchanan would hurt. If Mr. Gramm finishes fourth in the Midwest, he conceded today, he will be done for.
Even a third-place finish would be problematical, given his weakness in New Hampshire, where he has attracted little support either among political professionals or rank-and-file voters. Mr. Gramm's hopes had seemed to depend on his doing well enough early to survive until the contests in the Southern states come up, starting with the South Carolina primary on March 2. But his setback in Louisiana cast doubt on his potential all across that region.
The Texan has also run into trouble in Arizona, according to politicians there. Backed by the popular Senator John McCain, Mr. Gramm managed to get the primary date there set for Feb. 27, and had predicted that he would sweep the state. But Mr. Forbes has mounted a $2 million advertising blitz.
Mr. Gramm dismissed criticism from Mr. Dole and Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, who faulted him for missing a Senate vote on the farm bill on Tuesday. Needing 60 votes to move the bill to the floor, the Republicans could muster only 59. Mr. Lugar, also a Presidential candidate, is chairman of the Agriculture Committee and Mr. Dole is the majority leader; Mr. Gramm said the vote had been timed to embarrass him and complained of "petty politics."
"Everyone knew what the vote was and everyone knew its importance," Mr. Lugar said, and Mr. Gramm's failure to appear for it was criticized by some farm officials in Iowa, one of the nation's leading agricultural states.
Mr. Buchanan, who four years ago ran for the Republican nomination against President George Bush, has been considered a rank outsider in this year's race. In the early polls he consistently languished in the single digits. But Louisiana, he said, "was perfect for us, because it's a state where my message resonates."
Specifically, he said he had scored with his message of "economic patriotism" -- his charge that President Clinton had "sold out our workers" in negotiating and signing the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Mr. Buchanan ran more strongly among those without college degrees and among lower-income voters, according to the exit poll, in which 1,389 caucus-goers took part. He said on CBS News this morning that he had done "tremendously well" among "the working people that we need to bring back to our party to defeat Bill Clinton."

(Todd Buhanan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On Social Policy, Governors Quietly Split the Difference

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The welfare and Medicaid proposals endorsed by the nation's governors this week lack detail and have a long way to go if they are ever to become law. But if approved, such changes would revolutionize social policy by shifting large amounts of money and decision-making power to the states.
It is not surprising that governors would recommend changes that enhance their own authority. What is surprising is what they have accepted in exchange: a continuation of many Federal standards and requirements. 
 Larry J. Sabato, a professor of government at the University of Virginia who chronicled the transformation of governors from political hacks to professional managers in a 1978 book, "Goodbye to Good-Time Charlie," said: "Governors are can-do executives. What they've done in the last few days proves that they can get together across party lines and reach compromises that seem to elude the political actors in Washington. I think the governors made both President Clinton and Congress look very petty, very political and also ineffective."
For the last 60 years, social welfare policy has been built on the concept of entitlement: the idea that certain people have political, legal and moral rights to certain types of help from the Federal Government.
Many Democrats want to retain this framework. But in an effort to decentralize power and control costs, Republicans now seek profound changes in it. They want to give each state a lump sum of Federal money, a block grant, to design and operate its own programs of aid to the poor.
In policy statements approved on Tuesday, the National Governors' Association tried to split the difference between entitlements and block grants, giving states more flexibility while preserving Federal guarantees.
Whether such a hybrid is feasible remains to be seen. The very features that appeal to the governors outrage liberal advocates for the poor, who tend to distrust state officials.
Here is a description of some of the changes the governors have endorsed:
The governors' proposal on welfare would eliminate the Federal guarantee of assistance to needy children. Instead, each state would receive a fixed amount of Federal money to help the poor.
States would have "broad discretion in the design of their programs." Poor people now entitled to cash assistance would not necessarily receive it in the future.
States would lose up to 5 percent of their Federal money if they failed to meet Federal standards for placing welfare recipients in jobs or training programs. States could cut off benefits for people who refused to work. In general, families could not receive Federal welfare benefits for more than five years. States could exempt 20 percent of welfare families from the five-year limit and could set stricter time limits if they wanted.
Under current law, there is no time limit. Many families receive welfare for more than five years, and Federal welfare spending increases automatically when more people need assistance -- in a recession or after a hurricane, for example.
The governors' proposal has no mechanism for such automatic adjustments, but would establish a $2 billion contingency fund to help states with high unemployment or increased rates of child poverty.
States could reduce their own welfare spending by 25 percent without losing any Federal money. The governors' proposal would require states to spend 75 percent of what they spent in 1994 for cash assistance, child care, education, job training and work programs for welfare recipients.
The governors' proposal could end cash benefits for one-fourth of the one million children under 18 who receive Supplemental Security Income because of physical or mental disabilities. The governors would establish a stricter, narrower test of disability, based mainly on medical evidence rather than on a comprehensive assessment of each child's ability to perform ordinary daily activities like eating and dressing.
 
Medicaid
The governors' proposal would guarantee health care for many -- but not all -- of the children, elderly people and pregnant women who are now covered. Each state would receive a lump sum of Federal money to finance such care. But hospitals and nursing homes might be less willing to care for Medicaid patients because the Federal law guaranteeing "reasonable and adequate" reimbursement would be repealed. States would have complete authority to set Medicaid payment rates for health plans, doctors and hospitals.
Detailed Federal standards for nursing homes, set by Congress in 1987, would stay on the books. But states would decide how they should be enforced. "You could have very strong national standards, but no teeth behind them," said Martin A. Corry, director of Federal affairs for the American Association of Retired Persons, who asserted that "states did a poor job of enforcement before 1987."
The governors specify a package of benefits that would be available to Medicaid recipients. But states would have complete freedom to limit the "amount, duration and scope of services," thus restricting the number of doctors' visits and hospital days for which Medicaid would pay. States would still have to screen poor children for medical problems, but would no longer have to cover all medically necessary care. They could cut back coverage of eyeglasses, hearing aids, dental care, mental health care and prescription drugs.
More generally, the governors' proposal would guarantee Medicaid for poor children through the age of 12. It would, in effect, repeal a 1990 law that eventually guarantees Medicaid coverage for poor children from the age of 13 through 18.
The Federal Government and the states now share the cost of Medicaid. The governors' proposal would reduce the fiscal burden on states like New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, where per-capita income is relatively high. Those states would pay 40 percent of Medicaid costs, rather than the current 50 percent.
States could once again finance their share of Medicaid by imposing special taxes on hospitals. Congress severely restricted the use of such taxes in 1991 after finding that states used them in fund-raising swindles: Hospitals typically got back much more than they paid, and Washington bore most of the cost.
 
Nutrition
The governors would keep food stamps as an entitlement program, financed entirely by the Federal Government. But their proposals would cut projected spending by $25 billion over seven years. The cuts average 12 percent, but are deeper in later years, reaching 17 percent in the year 2002.
The governors would allow states to take their food stamp money in the form of a block grant if they took steps to curtail fraud by issuing all benefits electronically, with debit cards instead of coupons.
Under current law, food stamps increase automatically when a person's income declines, offsetting the effects of reductions in cash assistance. Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research and advocacy group, said that one of the governors' proposals would allow states to link the two programs so that "food stamp benefits for welfare families would be frozen if the state instituted an across-the-board reduction" in cash assistance. In other words, their food stamp benefits would not rise, even if they received less income from welfare.
The governors would preserve the school lunch program as an entitlement for children, but would allow seven states to take part of the Federal money, for administrative expenses, in the form of block grants. Presumbaly, these states could eliminate much of the paperwork now required.
 
Child Protection
Under current law, the Federal Government helps pay for foster care and adoption of poor children who have been abused or neglected. The governors would keep these payments as an "open-ended entitlement," but would allow states to use some of the money for programs intended to prevent child abuse and neglect.
States want additional flexibility. But Mary Lee Allen, an expert on child welfare programs at the Children's Defense Fund, said it was "unclear whether the governors would guarantee continued aid for every child now entitled to foster care and adoption assistance."
 
Outlook
Congressional leaders of both parties promise to give serious attention to the governors' proposals, and President Clinton welcomed them without endorsing them.
Lawmakers say the chances for enactment of the proposals this year are probably less than 50-50. But the governors' unanimous support for the proposals signals a political turning point. Democratic governors are now on record in favor of major changes in antipoverty programs, to the dismay of their usual allies.
Edward M. Cooney, deputy director of the Food Research and Action Center, an advocacy group for low-income families, said, "We are very disappointed in Democratic governors who agreed to a reformulated version of what the President has already vetoed."
But Mr. Sabato, the political scientist, said: "The governors' plan would be perfectly acceptable to most Americans. Many public opinion surveys show that people have more trust in state government than in the Federal Government."

HEADLINE: Harvard Lures Scholar to Join a 'Dream Team' on Social Policy

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Feb. 7

 BODY:
William Julius Wilson, the sociologist whose writings on race, class and poverty have influenced policy makers, including President Clinton, has taken a top appointment at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government.
Professor Wilson, one of the country's leading sociologists, has taught sociology and public policy at the University of Chicago since 1972. He will also join Harvard's Department of Afro-American Studies, the university said in its announcement today. 
 He is the author of several books, including "The Truly Disadvantaged: The Inner City, The Underclass and Public Policy," published in 1987, a pioneering work that reshaped academic thinking and government policy on race and urban poverty.
Professor Wilson joins a department that includes Cornel West, the author of "Race Matters," one of America's most prominent black intellectuals. The chairman of the department is Henry Louis Gates Jr., the literary critic. Professor Gates has rebuilt the department, which just five years ago had only one professor and one student majoring in Afro-American studies. "It was near death," Professor Gates said. The department has since raised $6.2 million, and this year 40 students have chosen Afro-American studies as their concentration.
"This is a major moment in the history of Afro-American studies," Professor Gates said today. "Along with the appointment of Cornel West, William Julius Wilson's appointment positions us to take a major place in public policy analysis." And, he added, "For me, it's like being coach of the dream team."
Another prominent sociologist, Prof. Lawrence Bobo of the University of California at Los Angeles, a visiting scholar at the Russell Sage Foundation, in New York City, said that with today's appointment, "Harvard is far and away now the pre-eminent institution for the study of African-American experience."
In a telephone interview, Professor Wilson, 60, who has been named the Malcolm Wiener Professor of Social Policy at the Kennedy School, said today, "Harvard now has a community of scholars working on national public policy issues the likes of which you haven't seen anywhere."
His decision to leave the University of Chicago was "very, very difficult," he said. What prompted it, he said, was his concern about the direction in which he sees the country heading, and his belief that Harvard would provide "an outstanding forum" for scholars like himself.
"Cornel and I are both progressive," he said, referring to Professor West. "We're both liberals. We're both committed to addressing the problems of inequality."
Professor Wilson also becomes a member of the board of directors of Harvard's 21-year-old W. E. B. Du Bois Institute for Afro-American Research, one of the oldest black research institutes in the country -- of which Professor Gates is director.
"We're going to build our public policy thinking around him," Professor Gates said.
Professor Wilson has written that not just issues involving race, but also broader economic and political changes created the growing urban underclass.

HEADLINE: CHINA SOLD PARTS FOR NUCLEAR ARMS, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
China secretly sold nuclear-weapons technology to Pakistan last year and could face the loss of billions of dollars in business deals under United States law, Administration officials said today. But, they said, President Clinton may waive the penalties to ease tensions with Beijing.
China sold Pakistan magnets used to refine bomb-grade uranium, the Central Intelligence Agency told the Administration late last year. State Department officials said today they had concluded that the evidence regarding the magnets was strong enough to trigger the penalties. 
 "We regard it as very serious," said a senior State Department official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "The next question is what do we do about it.
"We're going to find that the Chinese have acted in violation of our own laws," he predicted, adding that the White House had not yet made a formal decision.
The sale China made would violate a 1994 law instructing the President to suspend United States Export-Import Bank financing to nations that sell nuclear-weapons information and technology.
But the White House can waive the penalties by weighing the alternatives and making a formal finding that sanctions would go against the national interest.
If the President does not waive the penalties, the United States would have to suspend nearly $10 billion in loan guarantees for American corporations doing business in China.
If he does waive them, arms-control advocates said today, he will leave the impression that American business interests in China outweigh the threat posed by the spread of nuclear arms.
Imposing penalties would deepen tensions between Washington and Beijing over economic, diplomatic, military, commercial and human-rights issues, State Department officials said. Failing to impose them "will make the world a more dangerous place," said Representative Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat on the House intelligence committee who follows Chinese arms sales.
The Administration is in a tug-of-war with itself over China policy. While it wants to continue its multi-billion-dollar business dealings with Beijing, it must also respect American laws calling for restrictions on economic assistance and trade with nations secretly selling the technology of mass destruction.
The issue is made trickier by the Administration's threat to impose more than $1 billion in trade sanctions on Beijing for its piracy of American compact discs, computer software and videotapes. The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, told Chinese officials last week that they must abide by promises to stop pirating or face 100 percent trade tariffs on imports.
These tensions are aggravated by China's military and political maneuvers aimed at influencing presidential elections next month in Taiwan, the seat of the Nationalist Government that fled China's mainland in 1949 after losing to Communist forces.
The C.I.A.'s warning that China sold 5,000 ring magnets to a state-run nuclear-weapons laboratory in Pakistan last year was first reported on Monday by The Washington Times.
In the past, arms-control advocates and intelligence officials said, the State Department, seeking to accommodate China, not antagonize it, has overlooked compelling evidence that Beijing was violating weapons-proliferation laws and agreements.
"The State Department has put its head in the sand and refused to acknowledge the continuous pattern of violations by the Chinese in clandestine exports of nuclear, chemical and missile technology to Iran and Pakistan," said Gary Milhollin, a weapons-technology expert who runs the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control. Senior United States Navy officers said last week that Iran had tested a sea-based cruise missile acquired from China.
The Commerce Department has also argued against sanctions. In 1994, it approved exports to China of about $1 billion worth of technology that can be used in developing nuclear weapons, the Wisconsin Project reported in testimony to Congress in October.
Sanctions against China for weapons-technology sales have been imposed in the past, but they have not stuck.
In 1991, the C.I.A. caught China shipping components for missiles to Pakistan, which has continuous nuclear tensions with its neighbor, India. The Bush Administration suspended United States missile technology sales to the two Chinese state companies that shipped the components. The ban was lifted less than a year later after China pledged to follow an international accord, the Missile Technology Control Regime.
But by 1993, the C.I.A. again was reporting that the Chinese were shipping missile components to Pakistan. Such reports can be based on images collected by satellites, electronic eavesdropping, foreign spies or even a copy of a bill of lading supplied by a friendly shipping agent.
Responding to the report, the United States blocked the sale of $500 million of communications satellites and satellite technology to Beijing. Today the sanctions were lifted, and President Clinton approved selling the satellites.
Ms. Pelosi, who has used her seat on the intelligence committee to keep track of the issue, said today she was disappointed and puzzled by the Administration's approach.
"It's hard to understand why the U.S. wants to appear weak to the Chinese as regards our laws on nuclear weapons proliferation," she said. "There is a clear, verifiable transfer of nuclear and missile technology to Pakistan here. And the Administration has chosen a course that the Chinese can view as folding. If we ever stood up to the Chinese in terms of trade issues, human rights or proliferation, we would be in a less dangerous situation now."

HEADLINE: Ralph I. Straus, 92, Adviser to Government

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Ralph I. Straus, a prominent New York City merchant and philanthropist and a frequent consultant to the Federal Government on foreign economic policy, died on Monday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 92.
He died after a fall, his wife, Katherine, said. 
Mr. Straus, who was born in Red Bank, N.J., attended the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn., and Harvard, where he received a bachelor's degree and an M.B.A.
After graduating from Harvard in 1927, he formally joined R. H. Macy & Company, which was built by his great-grandfather, Bernard Straus.
From 1928 to 1941 Mr. Straus held several positions at Macy's, including corporate secretary, member of the executive committee and director. During that period, he was also active in charitable affairs organized by New York retailers, including the Greater New York Fund.
Mr. Straus's Government service began in April 1941, when he was named a consultant to the administrator of export control. After the United States entered World War II, he served with the Board of Economic Warfare, the War Production Board and the Allied Military Government in Italy as Military Governor of Naples.
After the war, instead of returning to retailing, Mr. Straus divided his time between numerous charitable and civic pursuits as well as the promotion and development of free trade. In 1950, he was appointed special assistant to W. Averell Harriman, who was then a roving ambassador, to head up a trade promotion section for the countries receiving aid under the Marshall Plan.
Mr. Straus then served as a consultant or director of a wide variety of organizations devoted to trade, including a stint in the mid-1950's as vice chairman and treasurer of the National Trade Committee. In 1968 he was named by President Lyndon B. Johnson to a 34-member public committee to recommend improvements in the nation's foreign trade.
Mr. Straus's charitable interests included the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, which he served as president and board member. He was a trustee of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies and served as a director of the 1964/1965 New York World's Fair.
Mr. Straus and Mrs. Straus maintained homes in Carefree, Ariz., and Southampton, L.I. His first marriage, to the former Matilda Bradfor Day, ended in divorce.
In addition to his wife, the former Katherine Mulvane Maffit, Mr. Straus is survived by two sons, Thomas P., of Rye, N.Y., and Bradford, of Winthrop, Mass.; eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

Wildcat Strike at 8 Schools

The engine that drives much of the fragile mini-economy of a commercial strip in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, is welfare money. For that reason, the various proposals for cutting welfare benefits have sent a shiver of fear through the shops and businesses. [B1.]

New Jersey Water Mains Break
 
Some 750,000 people in northern New Jersey found themselves with little or no water after two large water mains beneath Main Street in New Milford ruptured before dawn, causing some schools to close, hospitals to postpone operations and firefighters to resort to portable water tanks. [A1.]
 
Standards Set in Trenton . . .
 
New Jersey released a revision of its public school curriculum, listing standards in seven fields of study that education officials hope will reverse what they called a longstanding decline in learning. [B8.]
 
. . . and Albany for Schools
 
The New York State Board of Regents issued a set of guidelines that school districts are to use to improve the level of instruction, an early step in a sweeping plan to revamp the basic curriculum. [B8.]
 
Rowland Retreats From Cuts
 
Gov. John G. Rowland proposed a budget that features a modest reduction in overall spending and increased aid for the elderly, children and Connecticut's ailing cities. [B8.]
 
Clerical Workers Strike at Yale
 
Clerical workers at Yale University went on strike, setting up picket lines that led many professors to hold classes in churches, movie theaters and private homes. [B8.]
 
Kosher Laws Are Challenged
 
The proprietors of a Long Island butcher shop have filed the first lawsuit in New York State history to challenge the constitutionality of its kosher laws. [B7.]
 
Political Feud Over G.E. Deal
 
An unusually vitriolic dispute broke out in Albany between a Republican Congressman and a Democratic Assemblyman over a deal that the Pataki administration reached to settle pollution charges against an upstate plant owned by the General Electric Company. [B4.]
