HEADLINE: From Mr. Spud to Mr. Chips;
The Potato Tycoon Who Is the Force Behind Micron

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho

 BODY:
From practically anywhere in this city, you can see the mansion on the hilltop, with its 100-foot flagpole stabbing the sky. Up there, anyone can tell you, lives Jack Simplot, the billionaire who has dominated the local economy for seven decades and is responsible for the jobs of more than 14,000 people in this part of America.
He has also been embroiled in one of the oddest melodramas in the computer industry: the recent ouster, and reinstatement eight days later, of the chairman and chief executive of the chip maker Micron Technology Inc. 
 It is an episode that still defies comprehension. But it is perhaps best understood as the latest installment in the saga of a patriarchal 20th-century industrialist, a life story that might read like the script treatment for a TV series like "Dallas" or "Dynasty" -- if it did not happen to be true.
Celebrated in Boise as a living legend, 87-year-old John R. Simplot, describes himself as "an old potato farmer" and drives a white Lincoln Town Car with "MR SPUD" on its license plates. Still vigorous, he skis, plays cards with his buddies and, above all, does deals.
Always one to seize the opportunities presented by each era's technological marvels, Mr. Simplot got his start in 1923 at the age of 14. After storming out of his father's house in a huff, young Jack set himself up as a hog farmer. His break came during a harsh winter, when feed grain was in short supply, but potato scraps and wild horse meat were plentiful. He adapted the latest boiler technology into a rendering vat that produced a fortified hog slop. The next spring, when his competitors led their scrawny survivors to market, Jack Simplot made a killing with his fat hogs.
From this start evolved the J. R. Simplot Company, now one of the largest private enterprises in the country, with interests in farming, food processing, mining and transportation and annual sales of $2.5 billion. And then, in 1980, at age 71, in what must be one of the greatest second acts in business history, Mr. Simplot decided to help a pair of local businessmen -- twin brothers, who against all odds, wanted to make computer chips here in the heart of potato country.
Having yet again seized an era's technological moment, Mr. Simplot today is the single-largest shareholder in Micron Technology, one of the world's most efficient makers of the memory chips found in computers and other electronic devices. The 22 percent of the company's shares he controls is worth $1.8 billion.
"We make the best dang digits in the world," he bellowed in a recent interview in his corner office atop one of the nondescript office towers on Main Street. He was referring to Micron's chips and, though he himself does not own a personal computer, sounded like an avid reader of Wired magazine. "We're going to digitize the world," he declared.
Assuming, that is, that Micron's stock can pull out of the nose dive that has seen the shares plummet from more than $94 last September.
[After rising $4.25 on Tuesday, the shares pulled back on Wednesday, closing at $41.125, off 62.5 cents, on volume of more than 20 million shares on the Big Board, where it was the most active issue.]
As the man who pulls the strings at Micron, Mr. Simplot has the self-made man's deep-set ideas about how businessmen should demonstrate their commitment to an enterprise -- even if Micron is a publicly held corporation and Mr. Simplot has spent the bulk of his career running his own private empire.
These attitudes were apparently at play in January, when Steve Appleton, Micron's 35-year-old chairman and chief executive, was dismissed by the board and then rehired little more than a week later.
Although Mr. Appleton and Micron have yet to offer any more than the vaguest of explanations, people familiar with the circumstances say the incident involved a clash of personalities on Micron's board, which has been dominated by Mr. Simplot and two other wealthy farmers.
The uprising is said to have been fomented by one of those farmers, Allen T. Noble, 66, who had had long championed young Tyler Lowrey, Micron's 42-year-old vice chairman and chief technologist, who is responsible for the company's edge in semiconductor production.
Mr. Noble apparently learned that Mr. Appleton was about to sell some Micron shares, a move that would be anathema to Mr. Simplot, who is known for holding on to his Micron stock. Though there is no evidence that Mr. Appleton has sold his stock recently, people say Mr. Simplot was outraged.
But soon after the low-key Mr. Lowrey was named to succeed Mr. Appleton, he himself asked the board to bring the executive back. Several other members of the management team also turned up the pressure by threatening to quit.
Mr. Noble denied that he had been the cause of the rift, saying that the board decided unanimously both to accept Mr. Appleton's resignation and to bring him back. But in an interview, his affection for Mr. Lowrey was clear. "Tyler is to me like flesh and blood, even more so," Mr. Noble said, tears welling in his eyes. "He's an unusual person."
[On Monday, Mr. Noble, who owns two million Micron shares, resigned from the Micron board, saying that he wanted to spend more time with his sick wife and daughter.]
Mr. Simplot declines to discuss details, other than to say: "Noble pulled a bad one. I put it back together." If only the fissures in his personal empire were as easy to patch.
Mr. Simplot's first wife, Ruby, the mother of his four children, left him for her best friend's husband in 1946. A decade later, Mr. Simplot married his current wife, Esther, who was an opera singer.
Two years ago, at 85, Mr. Simplot passed the reins of the J. R. Simplot Company to an office of the chairman, comprising three of his children and a grandchild. According to the company, the idea was Mr. Simplot's. But people close to the family said that the billionaire was pushed out by his youngest son, Scott, 49, who controls slightly more than a quarter of Simplot's voting stock.
The elder Mr. Simplot said that he had agreed to give his son the larger share of the stock if he would run the business. But after spending some time at the company as a vice president, Scott, who has an M.B.A. from Wharton, showed little interest in following in his father's footsteps.
"He's smarter than I am," Mr. Simplot said of Scott, barely concealing his disappointment. "He doesn't want to work that hard."
Within the family, the billionaire does not appear to have any other suitable candidates. His eldest son, Richard, who battled an alcohol problem, died of diabetes in 1993. Richard's son, Ted Simplot, 40, now represents that wing of the family in the office of the chairman.
Don, Mr. Simplot's next child, 60, who serves on Micron's board, has been involved in several failing business ventures as well as marriages. A daughter, Gay, 51, who is divorced from Idaho's Lieutenant Governor, C. L. (Butch) Otter, has been more of the public face of the company in recent years but does not have much business experience.
Scott Simplot, who is divorced with two grown daughters, declined a request for an interview. But his father expressed confidence that one day his younger son would step up to the plate. "He'll work when he has to," he said.
His troubles with Scott are a sad reprise of Mr. Simplot's difficulties with his own father.
After an argument one day in 1923, when his father refused to let him attend a basketball game, Jack Simplot, packed his bags. More than 70 years later, that headstrong 14-year-old young man is now a headstrong octogenarian.
Micron has to be one of Mr. Simplot's biggest long shots. The company was founded in 1978 by Ward and Joe Parkinson, twins born in Blackfoot, Idaho. Many people thought the brothers were crazy to try to make semiconductors in Idaho. In 1980, Mr. Simplot joined three other local investors in backing the venture, but as the company struggled his stake increased.
Micron, which went public in 1984, finally hit it big three years ago when demand for its memory chips began to rise. While memory chip prices usually fall quickly, a shortage kept prices high at a time when Micron was one of the few suppliers. Profits soared. Lately, however, with new memory-chip factories springing up around the world, analysts have been forecasting an eventual glut that will plunge companies like Micron into a fierce price war.
Throughout its many early years of losses, the company was sustained by its devoted board, which was made up of management, the four original investors and other local businessmen.
But the lack of any directors from outside the small Boise business community has made for some unusual dynamics. Two years ago, a long-simmering feud between Mr. Simplot and Joe Parkinson, then Micron's chief executive, flared into a formal confrontation.
At a board meeting in September 1994 Mr. Parkinson, now 50, accused Mr. Simplot of leaking inside information -- a accusation he denied -- and moved that he be removed from the next slate of directors. When no one seconded his motion, Mr. Parkinson and two other top executives resigned.
And so, in January, when young Mr. Appleton was let go, then reeled back, by the old boys in Boise, some financial analysts saw it as another example of the local money men running this publicly held company as they do their private fiefs.
At the company's annual meeting on Jan. 29, three days after Mr. Appleton's return was announced, Mr. Simplot gave the executive a ringing endorsement and assured shareholders that the board had things all worked out.
And though Mr. Noble may have bowed out, Mr. Simplot has no intention of leaving the Micron board anytime soon. "It's my baby, I guess," he said. "I'm going to stick with it as long as I can."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 9, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Jack Simplot, the Idaho billionaire who is the largest shareholder in Micron Technology Inc., referred incorrectly in some editions to his action at the company's September 1994 board meeting. Mr. Simplot remained a director of Micron; he did not resign.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Drop by 21,000

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
The number of first-time claims for jobless benefits dropped by 21,000 last week, continuing to fall from heights reached in the aftermath of the January blizzard.
The Labor Department said today that new applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 368,000, down from a revised 389,000 the previous week, when they fell by 23,000. The Jan. 27 total was originally estimated at 388,000. 
 The latest number was the lowest since 316,000 new claims were filed in the week of Jan. 13.
Claims had jumped by 96,000, to 412,000, in the week that ended Jan. 20. Analysts attributed the steep increase to filings that had been delayed when winter snowstorms closed many claims offices.
The four-week moving average of new claims fell by 6,500, to 371,250 from 377,750.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
A Forbes in Our Future?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
A political analyst said the other day with a certain awe in his voice: "You know, Forbes really could be the nominee. And if he is willing to pop $40 million of his own money in the six weeks before Election Day, he could be President."
It sounds like the next anonymous novel, and it is not fantasy. Bob Dole and the other Republicans know now that Steve Forbes is for real. He even has possibilities in the New York primary, despite all the machinations of Senator Alfonse D'Amato. 
 Mr. Forbes deserves a good deal of intellectual credit for breaking through the field. He offered voters what it turns out many of them wanted: an outsider with genuinely different ideas. But he was able to do that effectively only because of money -- his own. And that raises profound concerns.
On the economy, Mr. Forbes has shown that the public wants to hear something else than the whining monotone of budget-balancing that Newt Gingrich and his colleagues sang and President Clinton mimicked.
Though he has not exactly come out and said this, Mr. Forbes plainly believes that an expanding economy is more important than a balanced Federal budget. If he gets even braver, he might tell people the truth that all government budgets must be unbalanced some of the time -- that the issue is reasonable control of the deficit, not absolute balance.
Unfortunately, the Big Idea offered by Mr. Forbes to make the economy grow faster -- the flat tax -- is out of the Land of Oz. In the form he proposes, a 17 percent tax rate with no deductions, it would either land the Federal Government with a deficit out of control or force it to stop Social Security, Medicare or most essential services.
His tax talk has gone from irresponsible to pie in the sky. "We should not stop at 17," he said in New Hampshire this week. "Once the American economy is moving again, I want to reduce the rate further and further and further. We won't get it to zero emissions, you might say, but that wouldn't be a bad goal."
Though he has made himself the flat-tax candidate, Mr. Forbes does in fact stand for something more. His past statements on social issues paint him as a libertarian, opposed to the repressive ideas of the Christian right. In a Republican Party increasingly dominated by fundamentalists, that is a striking difference, and one with considerable appeal. On abortion, he has supported only modest restraints on women's right to choose, such as barring late-term abortions. He has opposed cutbacks on legal immigration. He has called the demand for a two-year limit on any family's receiving welfare a sham, because "we are not going to let a young mother and her children freeze and starve on the streets."
On the campaign trail in recent weeks Mr. Forbes has tried to make some gestures to the Christian right. For example, he used to say that he would not change the "don't ask, don't tell" policy for homosexuals in the military. Now he says that he will change it as President if the military asks him to. Even so, he comes on as less of a social conservative than other Republicans.
Money is the worrying question about Steve Forbes. Do we really want to let a rich man buy his way into the Presidency?
He has run almost 100 30-second television spot advertisements a day on Boston stations seen in New Hampshire -- and many radio spots too. In the last three months of 1995 he spent $14 million of his own money in his campaign for the nomination.
Some New Hampshire citizens, questioned in polls, say they like the fact that Mr. Forbes is rich because it means he will not try to make money out of governing. That is not an unusual feeling in American history. Franklin Roosevelt, among others, was trusted by ordinary people as a patrician. But he did not overwhelm elections with his own money.
Senator Arlen Specter, the Pennsylvania Republican, has introduced a constitutional amendment to overrule the 1976 Supreme Court decision that limiting what a candidate may spend on himself violates the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech. Reform of that or some other kind will become irresistible if Steve Forbes and his money continue to skew the election process.

HEADLINE: In America;
Politics of Meanness

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
You have to wonder about the Republicans. From what region of exceedingly bad karma did they recruit their latest crop of Presidential candidates and Congressional leaders?
The party is dominated by characters like Phil Gramm, Pat Buchanan, Bob Dole, Newt Gingrich, Dick Armey and Alfonse D'Amato. When they gallop across the national landscape they remind you of the Wild Bunch. You couldn't extract a half-pint of compassion from the entire assemblage. Small children run at the first sight of them. 
 An editorial in The Boston Herald said Mr. Dole's candidacy may ultimately be saved by "the cannibalism among his rivals." Pat Buchanan, in an interview with the paper, compared criticism of him by Phil Gramm to attacks on Eliot Ness by Al Capone.
Senator Dole used to stand virtually alone among national politicians in his willingness to be unabashedly mean in public. As Gerald Ford's running mate and designated hatchet man in 1976 he denounced the Democrats for being the party of war, growling, "If we added up all the killed and wounded in Democrat wars in this century, it would be about 1.6 million Americans, enough to fill the city of Detroit."
But Mr. Dole has mellowed. And it's a measure of how mean politics has become, especially Republican politics, that he has been surpassed in orneriness by many of his fellow party members. (Mr. Dole has his own hatchet man in Senator D'Amato, who, as chairman of the Whitewater Committee, has been given a job for which, by talent and temperament, he is perfectly suited -- full-time tormentor of the First Lady.)
The politics of meanness is sinking the Republican Party, which seemed unassailable just months ago. The movement toward Steve Forbes is based primarily on the fact that so many voters are without a clue as to who he is. They just know he's somebody else. A woman who shifted her support from Senator Dole to Mr. Forbes told Time magazine, "Can't say exactly why except that he has some very good ideas -- although I can't tell you exactly what they are right now."
Mr. Forbes, who has purchased a huge amount of name recognition, has been trying to look like Mr. Nice Guy. That won't last. Viciousness is deeply embedded in his campaign. In any event, Mr. Forbes is not likely to be carried into the White House on a tax plan that is guaranteed to help him and hammer the middle class.
So where does that leave voters, who have already demonstrated their disenchantment with the Democrats and Bill Clinton?
"There's a real restlessness and grumpiness that's out there," said Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute of Public Opinion. "People are lurching about because the leadership isn't there. It goes back to '92 and the rejection of George Bush, and then the rejection of Clinton in '94, and an hour and a half later the rejection of Gingrich."
American voters are crying out, but for the most part the politicians are not listening. Mr. Miringoff said he was "absolutely struck" by the economic concerns expressed by respondents to his latest poll. The equivalent of one-third of all American workers are worried that someone in their household will lose a job in the next year, he said. The poll shows that more than 100 million Americans are worried that their total family income is not enough to meet expenses. At the same time, the cost of health insurance is going up and payroll benefits are going down.
"we're talking about huge numbers of people who are hurting," said Mr. Miringoff. But these issues are not being widely discussed in a campaign season that he described as "dismal."
The Republicans, especially, are ill equipped to respond to people in economic distress. Huge numbers of Americans who bought into the hoopla surrounding the Contract With America were dismayed to wake up and find that not only were they no better off financially, but they were unwittingly supporting attacks on Medicare, Medicaid, student loans, school lunches, workplace safety, the environment, etc.
It's anybody's guess where the voters will lurch next. The Republicans could win with a candidate who is cheerful, moderate and willing to exhibit a dollop of compassion. Maybe they should draft Bill Clinton.

HEADLINE: Justice Department Approves L'Oreal Bid for Maybelline

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
L'Oreal S.A., the French cosmetics giant, received approval yesterday from the Justice Department for its acquisition of Maybelline Inc., clearing the way for the $758 million buyout.
The approval was the last barrier to the sale of Maybelline, the maker of mass-market cosmetics sold through drug and discount stores. The purchase of Maybelline, based in Memphis, would give L'Oreal, which sells Lancome and other higher-priced cosmetics, a broader presence in American stores. 
 L'Oreal's tender offer of $44 a share for Maybelline stock ends at 5 P.M. today. Shares of Maybelline rose 37.5 cents, to $44 yesterday.
Joh. A. Benckiser G.m.b.H., a German cosmetics company that made a rival bid of $42 a share, repeated yesterday that it would not top L'Oreal's bid. Benckiser had said that it might come back with a bid for Maybelline, but only if L'Oreal failed to receive approval from American antitrust officials.
Already, about seven million shares, or 49 percent, of Maybelline's outstanding shares have been tendered to L'Oreal. The largest single Maybelline shareholder is Wasserstein Perella & Company, the New York investment bank, which held nearly 30 percent of the company and whose executives hold key positions on Maybelline's board.
In late December, Wasserstein entered into a binding agreement with L'Oreal to sell its Maybelline shares only to the French company. That put a large block of shares into L'Oreal's hands, but did not discourage Benckiser from entering the fray and forcing L'Oreal to increase its bid from an original $36.75 a share.
L'Oreal's $758 million purchase price for Maybelline includes slightly more than $600 million in equity and the assumption of roughly $150 million in debt. The final offer is about $100 million higher than L'Oreal's original bid. It also increases the amount Wasserstein Perella will receive for its shares -- the firm is now expected to receive around $170 million.
Guy Peyrelongue, the chief executive of Cosmair, L'Oreal's American subsidiary, said that the higher price L'Oreal offered was offset by a decline in interest rates since last summer, when L'Oreal first began to estimate how much a Maybelline acquisition would cost.
"When we made our first studies last June, we had a cost of financing that used interest rates significantly higher than today," he said. "Even at $44 a share, with the drop in interest rates, Maybelline won't cost us more than what we anticipated last June."
Mr. Peyrelongue said that Maybelline would operate as a separate division of Cosmair, which already has several American divisions including Lancome and Redken hair care products. He has no plans to change Maybelline's management, marketing or sales operations.
"We feel that Maybelline is doing very well and we want to build on that," Mr. Peyrelongue said. Maybelline will have access to L'Oreal's research laboratories and L'Oreal plans to expand Maybelline's sales overseas, especially in Latin American and the Far East.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
In courting black consumers, some marketers don't have to check their calendars anymore.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
CONSUMERS could be excused for thinking the Madison Avenue calendar includes an annual winter festival of black advertising that begins in mid-January with earnest advertisements from mainstream marketers "saluting the legacy" of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. -- timed for the holiday in his honor -- and continues through February with campaigns "celebrating Black History Month."
Then on March 1, the festival ends. And so, it seems, do many of the efforts to cultivate black consumers, who spend an estimated $250 billion to $300 billion each year in the American economy. That occurs despite the results of surveys like a recent study by Paul Sladkus International in New York, which found that more than 70 percent of blacks agreed they were more likely to buy a product if its ads showed people of their race. 
 "There's this period we call the freedom window," said Howard Buford, president of Prime Access, a New York agency that specializes in marketing to blacks, homosexuals and people who speak Spanish. Ken Smikle, president of Target Market News, a marketing newsletter in Chicago, describes it as the "black window."
Whatever it is called, it is difficult to ignore.
"You definitely get a bulge in January and February," said Caroline R. Jones, president and creative director at Caroline Jones Inc., a New York agency specializing in marketing to black consumers. "People come out of the woodwork who aren't there the rest of the year."
Mr. Buford suggested such rationed advertising might stem from "discomfort with the African-American market and not having people high in a company who know how to handle it." Those marketers, he added, would perceive ads honoring Dr. King or Garrett A. Morgan, who received a patent for the three-way automatic traffic signal in 1923, as a safe way to "try making meaningful connections" with black consumers.
Teri Williams, senior vice president for marketing at the Boston Bank of Commerce, which is introducing a Unity Visa credit card that donates 1 percent of card holder charges to organizations like the Jackie Robinson Foundation, said: "It's not that one ad isn't a good thing. But if a company is really trying to be effective, it should recognize that African-Americans understand who really supports the community."
And Mr. Smikle warned that marketing executives who limit their black-oriented campaigns to six weeks in winter "run the risk of being held accountable the rest of the year by people who say: 'You took out an ad saluting Dr. King's legacy. Part of that legacy is economic empowerment.' "
Indeed, there are signs that ads aimed at blacks from mainstream marketers are not just for wintertime anymore, according to executives at agencies and media that specialize in this market segment as well as advertising managers at mainstream consumer companies.
"We are now involved in at least six separate, and I would consider legitimate and serious, inquiries about our services" for year-round campaigns, Ms. Jones said.
Roger Greene, district manager for corporate advertising at the AT&T Corporation in New York, said: "We create a special ad for Black History Month or Dr. King's birthday. But we also have an ongoing program that runs in flights during the year, and the budget for that has grown a little more than fourfold since February 1990."
Indicative of AT&T's efforts, he added, is a print ad by the Uniworld Group in New York that asserts, "At AT&T, black history wasn't born yesterday." The ad features photographs of the actress Ruby Dee today and in 1942, when she worked for the Western Electric unit of AT[T] it appears in black-owned magazines and newspapers as well as in Time and USA Today.
The General Motors Corporation has agreed to be the exclusive automotive advertiser for 1996 in American Legacy, a quarterly magazine that describes itself as "a celebration of African-American history and culture." American Legacy is being introduced with a spring issue by RJR Communications and the American Heritage unit of Forbes Inc.
"We're talking to advertisers about reaching this marketplace" on a regular basis, said Rodney J. Reynolds, president at RJR Communications in Cleveland and publisher of American Legacy, "rather than trying to develop opportunities in terms of the time of the year."
The spring issue of American Legacy carries 24.5 ad pages from marketers that besides General Motors include AT&T, with the ad featuring Ms. Dee; the American Express Company; General Mills, for Honey Nut Cheerios cereal; the Philip Morris Companies, and the State Farm Insurance Companies. Only two focus on Black History Month.
"There's a significant long-term opportunity," said Tim Forbes, president of American Heritage and acting chief executive of Forbes Inc. in New York. "Clearly there's a recognition that there's a very significant population that has in many respects been overlooked."

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
Apartments Built to Rent Rise on River At Jersey City

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Pilings are being driven deep into a slice of Jersey City's waterfront for the foundation of Riverside Tower, the first new residential construction at the huge Newport complex in six years.
The $50 million building is being developed by the Lefrak Organization of Rego Park, Queens. It will have 346 apartments, from studios to three-bedroom layouts, in a 33-story building on land that juts into the Hudson and offers clear views of lower Manhattan. 
 The new building underscores renewed interest in rental housing for Jersey City's riverfront. There are two other new and revived developments, recently completed or under way, and their developers are planning additional rental buildings. All told, the projects will produce more than 1,500 apartments.
The activity is being stoked by demand for market-rate rentals. The vacancy rate for the more than 2,000 existing waterfront residences is about 1 percent; for Jersey City it is about 8 percent, according to the ACI Group, a real estate services concern that manages 1,000 rentals in the city.
The demand is coming from the thousands of workers employed by companies that have filled most of the city's 6.5 million square feet of prime waterfront office space. It is also coming from local renters looking to trade up, empty-nesters from the suburbs and people from Manhattan drawn by amenities like parking and lower rents, said Robert P. Antonicello, ACI's president. He said rents averaged $18 to $24 a square foot a year, compared with $20 to $30 a square foot for comparable rents in Manhattan.
A 1995 survey by the firm forecasts that the activity will continue. Of a projected 11,688 residences to be built by 2005 on the Hudson County portion of the Hudson's west shore, about one-third will rise in Jersey City, which still has a supply of former industrial land that was the old waterfront. Indeed, the Newport complex, where much of the housing now exists, can fit 7,000 additional residences.
More waterfront housing is good news for Jersey City. "It will put people on the street" after offices close and spur additional amenities like restuarants and "watering holes" to open, said Robert Cotter, its director of planning.
Mr. Antonicello said the demand for the near term would be for rentals and barring an economic downturn "the market will be able to absorb all those under way and planned."
Developers like Richard S. LeFrak, president of the Lefrak Organization, agree. He said his company had conceived and designed Riverside Tower as a condominium but switched to rentals because of the strength of the market. Financing, which is coming from a pension fund, also opened up, making it a propitious time to move ahead, Mr. LeFrak added.
Monthly rents for the apartments, from 520 to 1,500 square feet, will be $825 to $2,600. Leasing at Riverside, with features like high-ceilinged apartments and a concierge, is to begin late this spring, Mr. LeFrak said.
Mr. LeFrak said a second 454-apartment building was planned and whether it would be a rental or condominum would be determined by the market. Construction on that building would begin after the first is completed in about a year.
Work also continues at Avalon Cove, with 504 rentals in two five-story buildings on 11 acres just south of Newport. The developer, Avalon Properties Inc., based in New Canaan, Conn., with offices in Princeton, N.J., is to begin marketing the project next month with occupancy on some apartments to start in April. Monthly rents for the one- to three-bedroom apartments, plus fifth-floor duplexes are $1,100 to $3,100.
Jeffrey B. Albert, an Avalon vice president, said his company had acquired three adjacent acres to build some 220 more rentals because "the demand has not yet been satisfied." He said construction on those rentals would start when the first 504 were leased, which is expected by the start of 1997.
At another project, the owners revived a 229-apartment condominium as a rental last year and leased the apartments -- studios to three bedrooms and penthouses -- at $900 to $3,000 in four months. Now the owners are moving up the construction date of a second 299-apartment rental building to June from December, said Michael Barry, vice president at the Applied Companies in Hoboken. Applied, together with partners, bought the project on Washington Street in 1994.
The new rentals will be slightly smaller than the earlier ones, with 600 to 2,200 square feet of space, and the number of studios will be decreased in favor of more three-bedroom apartments, Mr. Barry said.

HEADLINE: MARATHON;
Parenthood On the Run

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: BOULDER, Colo.

 BODY:
Gwyn and Mark Coogan are the first married contenders in the United States Olympic marathon trials, though daily life can feel more like a frantic relay race in which their 26-month-old daughter, Katrina, plays the part of the baton.
"One person's in the door, the next one's out the door," Mark said. "We hand her off." 
 Gwyn, 30, will be a favorite tomorrow in the women's trials in Columbia, S.C. Mark, 29, will be a contender Feb. 17 at the men's trials in Charlotte, N.C. If the Coogans finish among the top three, they would be the first married American runners to compete in the same Olympics since Francie Larrieu (1,500 meters) and Mark Lutz (200 meters) at the 1976 Montreal Games.
"We both have a legitimate shot," Mark Coogan said. "We might come in fourth, but we could also win."
Their success as elite distance runners has required an intricate, if sometimes harried, balancing of their roles as partners, parents, athletes and in Gwyn's case, as a scholar. She is a Ph.D. candidate in mathematics at the University of Colorado, a dissertation away from her doctorate in number theory. Until this semester, she also taught calculus at the university, while putting 90 miles a week on her distance-running odometer.
Mark, who holds an economics degree, has inquired about law school at Colorado, but the requirement that he be a full-time student is at the moment incompatible with a training schedule of 130 miles a week. He does the laundry, the grocery shopping and half of the cleaning, while Gwyn does most of the cooking and studies before dawn and after dark.
Last semester, she set the alarm for 5 A.M., studied until Katrina awakened for breakfast at 6:30, headed out the door at 7 for a 10-mile run, then returned home to shower and bike two miles to school for a 9 A.M. class. With Katrina in the care of a baby-sitter, Mark then did a morning run of 10 to 12 miles. When Gwyn returned from school, they alternated workouts again in the afternoon.
After Katrina was put to bed, Gwyn studied from 7:30 until 10. Like some intellectual Wallenda, she adroitly balanced her high-wire life of running, academics and motherhood. A former national road-racing champion and a 1992 Olympian at 10,000 meters, Gwyn ran her first race of 26.2 miles last October, winning the Twin Cities Marathon in the encouraging time of 2 hours 32 minutes 58 seconds.
Two other married couples will compete in the trials -- Michelle Petrus-Simonaitus and Dennis Simonaitus of Salt Lake City and Rebecca and Tom Redding of Tampa, Fla. -- but none of these runners is expected to qualify for the Olympics or the top prize money, which begins at $100,000 for the men's winner and $45,000 for the women's winner.
It would satisfy her just as much, Gwyn Coogan said, to have her friends read about her in the science section of the newspaper instead of the sports section. She wrestles with questions that have elusive answers: What can she realistically expect from a triangular life of motherhood, theoretical mathematics and world-class running? Has parenthood made her more, or less, productive as a worker? Can she reach her potential in all three endeavors?
"I want to be a fulfilled person," Gwyn said. "I have to ask myself, what is the best way? Is it by pursuing all these activities or pursuing one activity and doing it to the fullest?"
Three years ago, Gwyn won the national 15-kilometer road racing championship, unaware that she was pregnant, Mark said. Several weeks later, he said, she felt poorly at the world cross-country championships and went to see a doctor, thinking she was getting an ulcer. "The doctor said, 'You're not getting an ulcer, you're getting a baby,' " Mark said.
She continued to train, he said, and a day before giving birth, Gwyn biked to school and swam a mile. Two months ago, when she suffered a stress fracture that kept her from running for 16 days, she diligently ran in a pool, wearing a flotation device.
"She likes to have a lot of things going on," Mark said of Gwyn. "She's good at concentrating. I think school is good for her. It takes her mind off running and other things."
This semester, with the Olympic trials on the calendar, inevitable concessions have been made. Gwyn has pared teaching from her schedule. Katrina has been placed in day care three mornings a week. On weekends, when the Coogans alternately take runs of more than 20 miles, one drives the car while the other one trains, placing water bottles on the route, picking up discarded layers of clothing, offering encouragement while Katrina rides along in the child seat.
"I like to compete," Gwyn said. "You learn something about yourself. But there are other things I like to do. I want to do it and see my child. I love to walk in the park, to see her swing to her heart's desire. I run, I bike to school, bike home again, run again, and I've been outside, but I haven't been able to share it with my daughter. I can understand why people get up at five in the morning, so they can see their children wake up."
A native of Morrisville, Pa., Gwyn did not run while at Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire, and took up the sport only as a diversion at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., where she would win three Division III collegiate titles at 3,000 meters. Mark, on the other hand, was an all-round athlete from Attleboro, Mass., who would become an all-America steeplechaser at the University of Maryland. Even in high school, he talked of competing in the Olympics.
"When Gwyn was in high school, I'm not even sure she knew what the Olympics were," Mark joked.
Married five years, they met in 1988 in Boston, where Gwyn worked for a high-tech computer firm. Gwyn competed in the 1992 Barcelona Olympics, though she said she felt overwhelmed by the experience, especially when she was caught in a crush of autograph seekers who pushed toward Magic Johnson and other members of the Dream Team during opening ceremonies. Unnerved by the scope of the Olympics, she did not qualify for the 10,000-meter final.
"I felt like I was at a mall at Christmastime, trying to find a last-minute gift for my sister," Gwyn said. "I wasn't prepared; I was scrambling around trying to get things together."
Having suffered a deflating hamstring injury, Mark finished 10th at the 1992 Olympic trials in the steeplechase. Since then, he has become one of the country's most resourceful distance runners, with 3:58 capability in the mile, 13:23 speed at 5,000 meters and an impressive 2:13:24 debut at the 1994 Boston Marathon, followed by a second-place finish at the 1995 Pan American Games in 2:15:21.
"I was really sad in 1992," Mark said. "We have the baby now. If I don't make it this time, Katrina will still be happy to see me. But I still want to crush those guys if I can."
First things first. While Gwyn runs this weekend, Mark will stay home and baby-sit.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The marathoners Gwyn and Mark Coogan with Katrina, their 2-year-old daughter, at home in Boulder, Colo. (David Zalubowski for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 543 words

HEADLINE: Another Chinese Provocation

 BODY:
Every week seems to bring a new Chinese challenge to President Clinton's stewardship of American foreign policy. There have been Chinese military threats against Taiwan, Chinese repression of dissidents and Chinese indifference to trade agreements with the United States. Now comes word from the Central Intelligence Agency that Beijing has secretly sold sensitive nuclear weapons technology to Pakistan.
The Clinton Administration, in its eagerness to prevent relations with China from taking another tumble, has watched this pattern with dismay but done little so far to make China pay a price. Passivity in the face of belligerence is a dangerous course. Washington must not let the latest Chinese provocation go unanswered. 
 Under United States anti-proliferation law, the sale of 500 magnets to Pakistan that can be used to refine bomb-grade uranium would normally trigger an economic penalty -- a cutoff of nearly $10 billion in loan guarantees for American corporations doing business in China. The Clinton Administration is now debating whether it should waive this penalty, to avoid hurting American businesses and damaging relations with Beijing. A waiver would be a mistake.
Punishment of China may chill discussions between the two countries at a moment when the United States needs to use its influence to reduce the heat building between China and Taiwan. But waiving the legal penalty for such a flagrant sale of weapons technology to Pakistan, a country whose nuclear program Washington has been trying to freeze for years, would undercut America's anti-proliferation efforts around the world.
It would also reinforce China's suspicion that America's policies, warnings and even laws can be ignored with impunity because Washington will always back off to preserve diplomatic harmony and protect business profits. Washington should not encourage that view while China is gauging how hard it can push against Taiwan without provoking an American response.
This is not the first time the United States has tried to improve relations by deliberately overlooking Chinese misconduct, in areas from human rights to weapons proliferation. That course has usually proven ineffective, even counterproductive. The Clinton Administration has recently threatened retaliation for China's continued piracy of American intellectual property like compact disks and computer software. It would be odd to confront China over copyrights while ignoring the sale of dangerous nuclear weapons technology.
American economic penalties against Beijing have often been threatened but rarely applied, so it is hard to know how much they would influence the Chinese and how easily China could replace American business deals. Ideally, all major trading nations should apply coordinated economic penalties against countries that spread nuclear weapons technology and materials.
If American economic penalties do not deflect Beijing from its present policies, Washington may have to consider tougher economic and diplomatic sanctions, and persuade its major allies to support them. The first step is to cut off the loan guarantees. To waive this legally prescribed penalty would only encourage Beijing to risk even more reckless international behavior.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Government Securities Prices Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of government securities rose yesterday following a bond auction that traders described as fairly successful.
The 30-year bond at auction had an average yield of 6.119 percent, down from 6.906 percent in August and the lowest yield since the Treasury began selling that maturity in 1977. By the close of the New York market, the currently traded 30-year issue was up 6/32 , to 10930/32 for a yield of 6.14 percent, down from 6.15 percent on Wednesday. 
 Analysts said that now that the quarterly auction was over, bond prices might be ready to move higher as the focus shifted back to the weak economy and low inflationary pressures, both of which are ingredients for further Fed interest rate cuts to spur the economy.
In the limited data released yesterday, nonfarm productivity was up 1.4 percent and initial jobless claims for the week ended Feb 3 were down by 21,000, to 368,000, from the revised figure of the previous week.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said he was impressed with the results of the auction. "It tells us where investors assign value along the various maturities," he said. "Today we saw a yield of 6 1/8 percent deemed very attactive."
Mr. Alexy seemed impressed with the refunding and said that "for this stage of the process much of the securities are in the hands of the end users." The drop in yield, Mr. Alexy said, suggests that people probably did not get at all the bonds they wanted.
"I find this auction similar to the August auction," Mr., Alexy said. "It is at the top of its trading range, and, more significantly, the market was also worrying about supply, only the economy is now in worse shape. We won't be surprised to see today's 30- year bond a month from now trading at a price of 5.75 percent and at about 5.50 percent by the summer."
There is nothing in the wind to change the economic fundamentals, he says, with next week's Philadlephia Fed survey of business activity the only key data outstanding.
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, added some backdrop to market activity when business wires reported that he said the housing market has been stable for the last three years, and that the Fed could best aid the economy by providing a "stable platform" for growth, with a budget deal essential.
Elsewhere in the corporate bond market, the Export-Import Bank of Korea led borrowers yesterday selling $500 billion of 10-year global bonds through underwriters led by the joint managers, Lehamn Brothers and Salomon Brothers.
According to the underwriters, demand was solid as investors placed three times as many orders as there were securities available, which allowed the securities to narrow the yield spread between the Korean securities and United States Treasuries with a similar maturity.
The bonds were priced to yield 6.451 percent, or about 77 basis points more than United States securities.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Sony Profit Up in Quarter; Forecast for Year Lowered

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 8

 BODY:
The Sony Corporation said today that group pretax profit rose 25 percent in its fiscal third quarter, aided by the popularity of the company's video-game machine and movies, but it lowered its earnings forecast for the full fiscal year because of slowing demand for computer equipment and recorded music in the United States.
The giant Japanese company had increased its forecast for the fiscal year, which ends March 31, in November because of expectations that sales of computer equipment in the United States would continue to grow sharply. But Christmas sales were weak. 
 "The U.S. computer business has been slowing down since late last year, but we see this as a temporary correction," Sony's managing director, Sumio Sano, said at a news conference today. He said Sony continued to believe that sales of such products as computer monitors and CD-ROM drives would climb over the long term.
The weaker consumer spending in the United States is also hurting Sony's sales of recorded music, a company spokesman said.
In the fiscal third quarter, which ended Dec. 31, Sony's group pretax earnings rose to 73.96 billion yen, or $693 million at current exchange rates, up 25 percent from 59.16 billion yen in the corresponding 1994 period. Net income increased 47 percent, to 37.14 billion yen from 25.26 billion yen.
Sales rose 17.5 percent, to 1.343 trillion yen from 1.143 trillion yen. Mr. Sano said sales were increased nearly 3 percent by the yen's decline against other major currencies. As the yen falls, sales denominated in foreign currencies convert into greater amounts of the Japanese currency. Sony sells more than two-thirds of its products outside Japan.
For the full fiscal year, Sony now expects pretax profit of 145 billion yen. That is below Sony's November forecast of 155 billion yen but still in contrast to the pretax loss of 220.95 billion yen in the prior fiscal year, when Sony took a write-down of 265 billion yen to account for losses from its Hollywood business.
The company said it expected net income in the fiscal year to be 54 billion yen, down from the earlier forecast of 65 billion yen but in contrast to the loss of 293.36 billion yen a year earlier. It expects sales of 4.5 trillion yen, up from the earlier forecast of 4.4 trillion yen and the figure a year earlier of 3.98 trillion yen.
Sony announced its third-quarter results and its new forecasts after the close of trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Its shares closed in Tokyo today at 6,650 yen, or $62.27, up 130 yen.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Sony's American depository receipts fell $1, to $61.625. Each depository receipt equals one ordinary share in the Japanese company.
Sony said its third-quarter profit amounted to 88 cents a depository receipt. It based that calculation on a rate of 103 yen to the dollar; the dollar was trading today at more than 106.5 yen.
In reporting its results for the latest quarter, Sony said sales by its movie group, which includes Columbia Pictures and Tri-Star Pictures, rose 17 percent. It also cited strong sales of its Playstation game machine in the United States and Europe and particularly in Japan.
Despite the gloomy outlook for sales in the United States, Sony said it expected sales of computer-related products to remain strong in Japan, where sales of personal computers have been booming.

HEADLINE: NYC;
These Clothes Make the Man And the City

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
IF you're of the opinion that all is glitter and stardust in sending chiseled male models down a runway dressed in, oh, let's say a double-breasted lame jacket worn over charcoal wool stretch pants, you've got another think coming.
This is serious work, putting on a fashion show. 
 "For buyers, it's a necessity," the designer Donna Karan said yesterday in an old warehouse on West 16th Street, where she had just shown her fall men's line to store representatives and the fashion press. Just choosing the right display space is crucial, Ms. Karan observed. "They need to be up close to see the fabric, because in men's wear it's all about fabric and cut," she said. "We're constantly trying to figure out how to get people in touch with the clothes."
There you have it. And if you're not sure what that all means, don't waste time worrying about it.
What you need to focus on is that everyone there -- designers, buyers, models, tailors, writers, photographers -- is a cog in a multimillion-dollar machine called Men's Fashion Week in New York. It is a semiannual event, first organized last winter to put big-name clothes makers on display in a bunch, the hope being that it would add oomph to an apparel industry whose worth to the city's economy is estimated by experts at $27 billion a year.
That's billion with a "B," as in Big Bucks. It bears remembering that the Donna Karans and Calvin Kleins are far more than filler for people columns. They are star attractions of an enterprise that, according to the Fashion Center Business Improvement District, brings 23,000 buyers a year to the city (and to its hotels and restaurants) and accounts for 225,000 local jobs, from gorgeous models to less glamorous fellows who make the coat racks.
"IT is a huge industry," Barbara Randall, a spokeswoman for the improvement district, said with understatement. Its importance was underlined last week when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed getting rid of the city sales tax on clothing purchases under $500. The city may lose revenue, the Mayor acknowledged. But he asserted that the change would keep many shoppers from running off to New Jersey, and ultimately would increase retail sales.
"Love that idea," said Fern Mallis, executive director of Seventh on Sixth, the company that organized the fashion week and its 19 shows. "How can anybody object?"
For its megadollars, the industry must traffic in image and fantasy, and the shows become "essential to build excitement for the marketplace," said Lavelle Olexa, a senior vice president of Lord & Taylor. To a novice, these displays can be a hoot, from the moment you enter the Sony Music Studios on West 54th Street, to name one location this week, and have a bottle of designer water thrust into your hand.
The audience is filled with industry types who travel from runway to runway and know one another well. There are endless hugs and kisses blown across cheeks (both the left and the right, European-style). The background music is often bone-jarring, and a sprinkling of celebrities enhances the finger-snap pace. At the Tommy Hilfiger show the other morning, Tommy Tune spotted Gregory Hines. "I thought I would see you today," Mr. Tune exclaimed, sounding as though he couldn't have been more delighted.
As for the clothes, they provide entertainment, too. Some of Mr. Hilfiger's unsmiling models looked as if they had just left a sherbet factory that exploded, such as the fellow in a pink shirt with french cuffs, orange checked tie and yellow corduroy jeans.
SERIOUSLY now, is there a big market for that sort of get-up?
"These outfits show our creative side, letting people see how far we can stretch it," Mr. Hilfiger said to an interviewer who has been told that his clothes could put coffee to sleep (they're that dull). "If I showed what you're wearing on the runway, people would yawn and walk out."
No offense seemed to be meant, and none was taken.
For buyers, even those who have seen it all hundreds of times, the shows remain an indispensable trend-spotting tool. "If 20 designers are using velvet or Ultrasuede, buyers have a chance to see what the clothes look like on real people and not hangers," said Kalman Ruttenstein, the men's and women's fashion director at Bloomingdale's.
But the fashion parades go by so fast! Weeks and months of preparation go into shows that typically last 15 minutes. Brevity, however, is not always a shortcoming, the pros advise.
"In men's wear, it can get boring, and you don't want to bore the audience," Mr. Ruttenstein said. "How many suits can you sit and look at?"

HEADLINE: Retail Chain Sales Show Modest Gain

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Sales at the nation's biggest retail chains rose tepidly in January, according to figures released yesterday, but analysts said the horrible winter in the Northeast and Midwest held down the numbers.
The Goldman, Sachs retail composite index, which reflects sales data from about 60 companies, rose by 1.1 percent in January, following a 2 percent increase in December. In January 1995, when the weather was better and consumer balance sheets were a bit healthier, the index was up 4.7 percent. 
 "The figures were not all that great," said Richard Baum, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs. "But they are not all that much different from what we have been seeing for the last several months."
Still, Mr. Baum said that without the inclement weather the index would "probably" have been about three to four percentage points higher.
"January did mark some turnaround from the very depressed Christmas sales numbers," said Jeffrey Feiner, a retailing analyst at Salomon Brothers. "But the conditions that have adversely effected retailing are still with us."
For virtually all retailers, January is the last and slowest month of the fiscal year. Since post-Christmas discounting is almost always prevalent -- and was particularly pronounced last month -- January usually represents only 4 percent of annual sales, and 10 to 20 percent of fourth-quarter earnings, Mr. Baum said.
"January is always a very bad month, because of clearance sales," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, a Scotch Plains, N.J., forecasting firm. "But the price reductions this year went far beyond what we have seen in the past."
Investor reaction to the sales reports was mixed. Federated Department Stores, which registered strong growth in sales, nevertheless saw its share price dip 25 cents, to $27.125. But the Gap Inc. rose by $2 a share, to $51, and Talbots gained $1.625, to $30.75.
The discounting was fierce among specialty apparel and off-price chains.
Over all, this group saw sales rise by one-tenth of 1 percent, according to the Goldman, Sachs index. But that meager increase masks what was almost certainly a drop in profitability.
At Talbots, for instance, comparable store sales rose 13.1 percent in January. But Mr. Barnard said the impressive gain was almost entirely due to deep price cuts that would do little to help the bottom line.
Still, analysts said there were some pockets of strength.
Among department stores, Federated, where comparable store sales rose by 5.1 percent, and Kohl's, which registered a 5 percent increase, were seen as positives.
Apparel sales at the Gap, which posted a 6 percent increase in comparable store sales, were better than expected.
And among discounters, analysts said that KMart, which saw comparable store sales for the entire company rise by 5.5 percent, and Target, where sales rose by 8.4 percent, were fairly strong.
But sales at Wal-Mart, the nation's biggest retailer, rose by only 1.3 percent. And sales at specialty hard goods retailers like Circuit City, Best Buy and Lowe's were almost universally disappointing.
According to the Goldman, Sachs composite index, department store sales fell by 1.1 percent during January, discount stores rose by 4.5 percent and specialty hard goods retailers fell 4.7 percent.
In short, for many retailers January was the bleak end to a brutal year. And expectations for 1996 are not high.
"There is no question that consolidation in the industry is going to continue, certainly in the specialty apparel and off-price sectors," Mr. Baum at Goldman, Sachs said. "These are two sectors that continued to add square footage in the first half of the 1990's in the face of sales that were not growing that rapidly."
And then there is the demand side of the equation.
Although there are a few positive signs in consumer spending -- a recent surge in mortgage refinancings and some modest growth in real wages, to name two -- Mr. Baum and other analysts are not sanguine about the prospects of a sudden boom.
Consumer spending is rising at an annual rate of 2 percent to 4 percent, ignoring the effects of inflation, Mr. Baum said. That is well below the normal increase of 4 percent to 6 percent.
And Mr. Barnard said: "With total consumer installment debt approaching $1 trillion and millions in the shadow of corporate downsizing, Americans today are reluctant to spend.
"The weather will get better, but consumer demand won't."

HEADLINE: Whatever Happened to Venezuela's Middle Class?

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela

 BODY:
The snapshot that emerged from Luis Sandoval's pocket showed the 34-year-old former administrator for a manufacturer of heavy machinery standing in a driveway by his sparkling white Chevrolet Impala, his wife and daughter by his side.
Now, years later, when Government exchange controls have crippled business and squeezed him out of his job, the family car has become another of Caracas's rattle-trap taxis, and Mr. Sandoval's livelihood. The car's right headlight is gone, and the alignment is so bad the car seems to ski down the streets, trailing a spume of black smoke. 
 There are two children now, who get by on the same amount of milk one used to drink, diluted to go twice as far. Last Christmas, Mr. Sandoval, a graduate of Venezuela's most prestigious university, could only afford to buy a single toy for the two of them. There is three months' rent due at the end of the week, and this one-time paragon of the prosperous middle class has become desperate.
"We're living hand to mouth," Mr. Sandoval said.
At a time when the rest of South America is paring down public spending and opening up markets in the quest for foreign investment, Venezuela stands as a peculiarly enduring throwback to an age of excessive government economic intervention, and a reminder of its perils.
This Caribbean country of 24 million people, blessed with the world's largest oil reserves outside the Persian Gulf, last year became the largest foreign supplier of oil to the United States. But its economy is in a shambles and its public payroll so bloated that hospitals cannot afford to buy medicine or equipment, while the Government remains unable -- or unwilling -- to trim its work force.
The country is entering its fourth year of recession, and the inflation rate, at 54 percent last year, is the highest in South America. Venezuela's middle class, once accustomed to shopping sprees in Miami, has been reduced to near-poverty.
"The middle class is disappearing," said Andres Serbin, president of the Venezuelan Institute for Social and Political Studies, a private research institute. "Now you have a clear polarization between the people who have and the people who don't have."
Juan Carlos Navarro, coordinator of the Center for Public Policy at the Institute for Advanced Administrative Studies, agreed. "People feel that every day they're getting poorer, and they're right," he said.
At the start of the 1990's, Venezuela appeared to be well on its way toward the free-market economic reforms that other parts of Latin America have since embraced. But austerity measures that were endured elsewhere in the continent proved too difficult an adjustment for Venezuelans who, thanks to a $10-billion-a-year cushion of oil revenues, had grown accustomed to government largess.
The backlash against the free-market reforms instituted by Carlos Andres Perez, who was then President, included looting and two attempted military coups in 1992. Although the coups failed, they proved fatal to the economic policies and to the presidency of Mr. Perez, who was impeached in 1993 and charged with stealing $17 million in public funds. He remains under house arrest.
As the country awaited Mr. Perez's reaction to the second 1992 coup attempt in a televised message from Congress, Rafael Caldera, a former president, unexpectedly took the microphone to voice understanding for the frustrations of the military men who led the coup attempts.
Swept back into the presidency by a mass yearning for less corrupt, more generous past, Mr. Caldera pledged to restore the kind of state-financed populism that had marked his administration in the 1970's, but he did not address the country's ability to finance such grand promises in the economy of the 1990's
His measures have failed to check Venezuela's economic slide.
According to a recent report by Data Information Resources to the Venezuelan-American Chamber of Commerce, in the last 25 years the share of household income spent on food has shot up to 72 percent, from 28 percent. The middle class has shrunk by a third. An estimated 53 percent of jobs are now classified as "informal" -- in the underground economy -- as compared with 33 percent in the late 1970's.
Economists complain that the country has functioned under Mr. Caldera without a coherent and consistent economic program, relying instead on emergency measures. The latest is a plan to compensate working people for rising prices with a system of modified indexation, which will raise wages every few months to help keep up with inflation. In Brazil, this approach led from double- to triple-digit inflation before it was abandoned in 1994.
The country is struggling back from a banking crisis that was five times the size of the savings and loan collapse in the United States, in terms of the percentage of gross national product. No sooner had Venezuela won plaudits for coming through the banking debacle, however, than it had to confront a scandal involving the system of severance payments for public employees, in which billions of dollars contributed to the system have disappeared.
That is one reason the Government has not concentrated on trimming the public sector, although Labor Minister Juan N. Carrido, and most analysts of Venezuela, agree the need is strong.
"The question of where you're going to get the money for severance payments is relevant only if you do the layoffs," said Fernando Egana, the Government spokesman. "Reduction of the public sector," he added pointedly, "is very much related to the growth of the private sector."
Although Mr. Caldera came into office denouncing the austerity measures that were imposed by Mr. Perez (partly to conform with directives from the International Monetary Fund), his own administration has been negotiating for a $3 billion loan from the I.M.F. since last year. Economists here say Venezuela does not need the money as much as it needs the credibility that such a loan would convey. The country has also been negotiating a second loan of undisclosed size to ease the social impact of any hardships imposed by an I.M.F. agreement.
Politically, President Caldera's reputation for personal honesty has brought the Government some measure of credibility, and pulling back from the austerity measures of his predecessor has helped build stability. A slew of state and local elected offices, created over the last half-dozen years, have also provided the country with a fresh crop of potential national leaders, like the highly popular Irene Saez, a former Miss Universe recently re-elected mayor of Chacao, a neighborhood in Caracas.
Another promising sign was the opening last month of the oil sector to private investment -- by the same President who nationalized it 20 years earlier. Industry executives flocked to Caracas to bid on exploration rights in 10 regions, using a formula that guarantees Venezuela at least 85 percent of the profits. But Juan Szabo, who put together the opening, said it would probably be three to four years before the country sees any revenues from privatization.
"I don't think Venezuela's problem is really one of income," said Mr. Szabo. "It's getting the housekeeping done and getting the economic process in line."
Paradoxically, some here feel the oil revenues will only delay the day of reckoning for President Caldera, putting off further the tough decisions he has been avoiding. The trouble, they say, is that while oil revenues give the President a reprieve, the money is never used "to accumulate capital and develop social programs that are not politically motivated," said Mr. Serbin, of the Institute for Social and Political Studies.
As Monsignor Baltazar Porros, vice president of Venezuela's Episcopal Confederation, prepares for the arrival of Pope John Paul II, he says the crisis Venezuelans are encountering is as much emotional and spiritual as economic.
The 1950's to 1980's, he said, were marked by "a kind of looting of the oil wealth, so young people have never lived in hard times." The loss of prosperity is more shattering than never having known it at all, he said. "Now, we see that our lives are the same as in any other country in Latin America."

HEADLINE: In Missouri, Good Times or Bad?;
Working but Not Spending in a Microcosm of the Nation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
Churning out goods from pickup trucks to refrigerator magnets, factories across this Midwestern heartland are hiring so many workers that labor shortages are developing in some areas.
But the consumers who are supposed to be buying these products are holding back, anxious about their jobs and fearful of piling up more debt. 
 These midwinter crosscurrents, swirling around the national economy as well as Missouri's, are proving both a puzzle and a worry. Economic statistics show the same clashing trends as those that emerged from a five-day trip across the state, which included interviews with shoppers, salespeople, executives, bankers and plant managers. Missouri is judged by Regional Financial Associates, a consulting group, to be the closest state to being a microcosm of the overall American economy.
The contradictions raise some intriguing questions:
With jobs here plentiful, why are consumers in such a funk?
Is their mood of retrenchment now so embedded that it could pull the economy into recession, or will the solid level of business spending and profits eventually lift Americans' spirits and open their pocketbooks?
And, finally, will President Clinton find himself hobbled in his re-election bid by an aging economic recovery, just as President George Bush was hurt four years ago by an economy whose recovery was not yet apparent?
Chats with shoppers suggest that the root of the malaise is job insecurity. After all the corporate downsizings of recent years, some people are earning less than they used to and a lot of others are fearful of losing the jobs they have. As a result, millions of Americans are putting off major expenses.
On a recent trip to the Metro North Shopping Center here, for example, Ron and Vernita Riley said they were planning to limit their spending to the basics, like shoes for their 1-year-old daughter Annie, and skip big-ticket purchases like televisions and new winter coats. The larger home the young couple had hoped to buy this year will have to wait, they said.
"We're cutting back a lot," Mrs. Riley said, because her truck-driver husband recently took a lower-paying job after being laid off. "We don't feel secure."
Not that Mr. Riley, 30, would have much time to enjoy new acquisitions even if he could afford them; he now works five 16-hour days a week instead of four 10-hour days. Despite the grueling schedule, he makes about 10 percent less than before because he is paid by the mile instead of the hour. 'It's pretty easy to find a job," he said, but much harder to find one that's "steady."
For Ron Varley, steady jobs may be a thing of the past. On a recent evening, he took a stroll with his wife, Nancy, through the Greater St. Louis International Auto Show.
"I've been through a bank closedown, a bank merger and a bank reorganization in the past five years," said Mr. Varley, 58, who was laid off each time. He now works as a manager in the personnel department at United Van Lines, earning 10 percent less then he did at his previous job. The Varleys, who canceled a new-car order in 1995, are only looking this year.
Another sign of consumer cautiousness is the growing popularity of used cars. Thomas K. Sight, president of Bob Sight Ford in Lee's Summit, a Kansas City suburb, said last year's upbeat buying pattern had been reversed. Reflecting high prices, he said his dealership sold about 95 used vehicles and 75 new ones last month, compared with 75 used and 85 new in January 1995. "We had a very tough month," Mr. Sight said.
In fact, the overall growth in retail sales is slowing. While retail sales in Missouri rose 9 percent in 1994, they increased 7 percent last year and are expected to slow further to 5.4 percent this year, according to Regional Financial Associates. And consumers appear to have put the brakes on in recent months, according to figures from Telecheck Services Inc., which show purchases by check down on a year-over-year basis in October through January after rising modestly in earlier months.
If consumers are already a drag on the economy, Vicki Jacobson fears they might soon get even stingier. Ms. Jacobson, the director of education at the St. Louis-based Consumer Credit Counseling Service, says the number of people seeking help with credit problems has surged by 25 percent last month compared with a year earlier. The number of people participating in its debt-management programs was up 21 percent, she added.
A lot of homeowners went on buying binges after refinancing their mortgages in 1993 and 1994, Ms. Jacobson said, spending more than they could afford. Now, she said, those excesses are forcing them to put on the brakes. "Some people are not fully aware of the kind of situation they may be getting themselves into," she said.
The economic paradox of all this is that in the midst of consumer constraint, many businesses are bursting at the seams and cannot seem to produce their goods and services fast enough.
"I'm looking to hire drivers in the wintertime," said an amazed David Potts, general manager of Bulk Haulers Inc., a St. Louis company that transports structural steel and pipe and is involved in installing a sewer system for the Anheuser-Busch brewery there. Ordinarily, the winter months are slack for Bulk Haulers and, if anything, Mr. Potts has to lay off drivers.
Statewide, the unemployment rate sank to 3.7 percent in the last quarter of 1995 from around 5 percent in the first three quarters. With the eighth-lowest jobless rate in the country, unemployment is the one key measure in which Missouri differs significantly from the national average. The rate is the lowest for Missouri since the late 1970's, according to William C. Niblack, head of research at the Missouri Department of Labor and Industrial Relations.
This made Missouri one of the tightest labor markets in the country, where the jobless rate has been about 5.5 percent since late 1994. The worker shortage is particularly painful to employers in smaller cities and towns, such as Washington, a quaint town perched on a bank of the Missouri River. Washington is home to Magnet Inc., a maker of specialty advertising magnets that in its 11 years has become the world's No. 1 producer. When it sought to expand, however, it was forced to build a second plant in Illinois because it could not find workers locally.
"The problem my customers have is finding enough employees," said Dick Mayer, president of the 119-year old Bank of Washington. Mr. Mayer projects a decline of between 5 and 10 percent in motor-vehicle loans this year -- but expects business lending to surge by 10 percent, identical to last year's pace.
Missouri, which trails only Michigan as an assembler of motor vehicles, benefits from the popularity of the pickup trucks, vans and other products made by General Motors, Ford and Chrysler in the St. Louis area and by Ford in Kansas City.
"The vehicles we produce happen to be in strong demand," said Russell Signorino, work force coordinator for the St. Louis County Economic Council. Mr. Signorino noted that the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the St. Louis-based aircraft company, went through a major downsizing in the early 1990's, shedding some 17,000 jobs, but has now stabilized.
The other evening, in fact, the company took over the entire lobby of the Hyatt Regency St. Louis, which occupies the painstakingly restored former Union Station, to celebrate delivery of the first F/A-18 Hornet fighter-bombers to the Swiss Air Force.
If consumers in a state with such a buoyant economy as Missouri's continue to scrimp, some economists wonder what this implies for the national economy. If their behavior is duplicated throughout the country, they ask, could it nudge an economy that is already showing signs of weakness into recession?
Laurence H. Meyer, a St. Louis economic consultant who does work for the Clinton Administration, does not think so.
While he describes consumer retrenchment as "the leading edge" of the current slowdown in the economy's growth rate, he doubts it will become severe enough to set off a recession. That is mainly because the economy is being propped up by both robust business spending and a surge in American exports, which were up 12.2 percent in the first 11 months of 1995 from a year earlier.
Other economists warn that the danger of recession is real. James E. Annable, chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago, points to two signs of economic fragility: Disposable personal income was up just 1.9 percent between January and November of last year, and household installment debt as a share of disposable income hit a new peak of 18.8 percent in November, surpassing a previous high in 1989.
Consumers "are two-thirds of total spending, and it's a tricky stabilization problem" for policy makers, essentially the Federal Reserve, to try to throttle the economy down to a sustainable pace when vulnerable consumers leave no margin for error, Mr. Annable said.
"This is a cycle that is behaving differently than expansion cycles usually behave," he added. "You could get an accidental recession."
That, of course, would be very bad news for Mr. Clinton. While inflation and unemployment remain low, Mr. Clinton appears vulnerable to charges that income growth has been sluggish and the economy is slowing down. These two factorsmay become the ammunition that Republicans have been seeking.
