HEADLINE: Late Advance Drives Dow Above 5,500

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Stocks continued to rise yesterday, pushing stock indexes to record highs for the fourth consecutive session, even as the market confounded professional investors who have been baffled by its recent gains.
The Dow Jones industrial average moved above the 5,500-point level for the first time, finishing ahead 47.33 at 5,539.45. Records were also set by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which closed at 656.07, up 6.14, and by the Nasdaq composite index, which was up 8.29, to 1,093.17. 
 Following a recent trading pattern, prices yesterday weakened in the morning, stabilized in the early afternoon and then surged -- especially in the larger, blue-chip stocks -- just before the close.
"What is interesting is that the focus changes every day," said E. Wayne Nordberg, equity partner at Lord, Abbett & Company in New York. "It's extremely volatile on a day-to-day basis. There is no real leadership that has emerged in the advance this year."
Mr. Nordberg credited lower interest rates and a sluggish economy with creating a large pool of cash with little place to go but the financial markets. As consumers pay their debts and companies sell off inventories of goods, the money is flowing into stocks, a situation he does not see changing until the economy begins to pick up perhaps later this year.
"This is a classic liquidity-driven market," he said.
Advancing stocks outpaced decliners on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, 1,330 to 953. Issues reaching new highs totaled 230, while only 14 set new lows.
The New York Stock Exchange Index was up 2.83 points, to 349.15. The American Stock Exchange composite index closed at 564.66, up 2.07.
The market's strength so far this year -- the Dow is up 8.3 percent since Jan. 1 -- has wreaked havoc on the full-year forecasts of several of Wall Street's most well-known strategists. Many had predicted that share prices, which soared in 1995, would level off this year as corporate earnings growth declined.
"The amateurs are outdoing the professional so far this year," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers in New York.
With interest rates declining, shares of banking companies were strong. Wells Fargo rose 5, to 258 1/4, and Nationsbank, added 3, to 73 1/2.
Investors also favored consumer goods companies like Coca-Cola, which closed at a record 80 1/4, up 2 1/4. Gillette rose 1, to 56 1/4, while Kellogg gained 2 to close at 78 7/8.
Oil companies were also among the big winners yesterday. Exxon gained 1 7/8, to 82 5/8, while Chevron was up 11/64 , to 53.
Normally when energy companies gain, industrial stocks slide. But some of the biggest industrials were up yesterday, including Caterpillar, which gained 1 1/4, to 65 1/8, and Allied Signal, which was up 1 1/8, to 54 5/8.
Telephone companies, which were among the big gainers in Wednesday's trading, slipped back yesterday. Nynex was off 3 3/8, to 55 7/8, on reports that it was joining Bell Atlantic to offer long-distance service. Bell Atlantic lost 1/2 to close at 71 7/8.
Technology stocks, which also had a big rise earlier in the week, were down for the second consecutive day. Micron Technology, which was the day's most active issue, fell 1 1/2, to 39 7/8; Intel was down 3/8, to 57 7/8 in Nasdaq trading, while Motorola, which makes both semiconductors and cellular phones, fell 5/8, to 57.
Not all technology issues stumbled. I.B.M., which has seen a strong rise since its fourth-quarter results were announced in mid-January, rose again yesterday, closing at 113 1/2, up 7/8.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC EMPLOYEES VOTE 5-YEAR DEAL IN NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
New York City's largest municipal employees' union announced yesterday that its 120,000 members had approved a five-year contract with the city that promises job security and bolsters Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's efforts to maintain labor peace as he reduces the size of city government.
The Mayor and other city officials had voiced deep concerns about the prospects for approval after the teachers' union rejected a broadly similar contract in December. 
 Word of the contract's approval provoked open warfare within the union as some members charged vote fraud. The union had been deeply divided over the pact, with many members angry that it provides for no wage increases for the first two years even though the Mayor and City Council granted themselves raises in December.
But the contract includes a 13 percent pay increase in the accord's last three years, and will make it harder to close the gaping budget deficits projected for the city later this decade.
The union vote, 57 percent to 43 percent in favor of the contract, is a significant victory for Mr. Giuliani because it buys him five years of labor peace with the politically potent union, which represents about half the city's work force. It also gives him new leverage to pressure the suddenly isolated teachers' union to rethink its contract rejection.
While Mr. Giuliani trumpeted the contract as a money-saving, pattern-setting deal for the city, the union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, was bitterly divided yesterday, with some officials charging the union leadership with fraud in counting votes.
At the union's executive board meeting yesterday, the leader of a hospital workers' local angrily accused the union's executive director, Stanley Hill, of stealing the election and questioned why he would not release a breakdown of how each of the union's 56 locals had voted.
Just as angrily, Mr. Hill rejected accusations of fraud, asserting that the members approved the contract for a simple reason: it promises most of his members three years of job security at a time when governments and companies around the country are shedding workers.
Mr. Hill said his union, which includes accountants, clerical workers, engineers, librarians, social service workers, zookeepers and other nonuniformed city workers, voted 19,513 for ratification and 14,438 against.
"Our members will not only have job security, but economic benefits from this contract," Mr. Hill said in an interview. "The Mayor's not here for layoffs. He's here to work with us."
The ratification vote, the closest in District Council 37's history, had been in doubt until recent days because many members were angry at having to wait two years for raises while the Mayor, his top aides and City Council members received substantial salary increases.
Mr. Giuliani said the union's contract, including its two-year wage freeze, would set the pattern for the police and firefighters, who are at an impasse in their talks with the city after their contracts expired. Mr. Giuliani also said that District Council 37's accord could influence a possible arbitration decision on the teacher's union contract.
At a news conference, Mr. Giuliani said, "This goes a long way to setting the pattern for the city, because this covers virtually half the work force of the City of New York."
But the contract could prove a major fiscal headache for whoever is mayor in three years, when the raises begin. In its recently released financial plan, the Giuliani administration calculates that the District Council 37 contract, along with other labor contracts, will cost the city an additional $690 million in the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1998, swelling to $2.2 billion in the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2000. In fact, the city is still grappling with significant problems in the shorter term, with the city's budget director yesterday ordering city agencies to propose cuts totaling $500 million.
"It's a terrible contract for New Yorkers as a whole," Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, said of the District Council 37 agreement. "Obviously, the city can't afford it because the city is projecting a $5.2 billion deficit in 2000, including $2.2 billion in increased labor costs."
But the Mayor and Mr. Hill emphatically disagreed.
"This contract helps the city save money," Mr. Hill said. "Remember, we've given the city a 24-month wage freeze. That's nothing to sneeze at."
Mr. Horton and many business leaders have faulted the contract for not including any concessions by the union on work rules.
Mr. Giuliani acted yesterday as if the District Council 37 vote strengthened his position against the 90,000-member United Federation of Teachers. Sandra Feldman, the union's president, has asked to go back to the bargaining table, but Mr. Giuliani has refused, saying he will not offer the teachers a better pact than the one they rejected.
Ms. Feldman, who had urged her members to ratify, said in an interview yesterday that District Council 37's vote would not pressure her into resubmitting the proposed teachers' contract to her members for a second vote.
"Ultimately, the Mayor has to go back to the bargaining table," she said of the teachers' dispute, although she acknowledged it might first go to a neutral fact-finder.
When District Council 37 members started voting on their contract in early December, it looked like an uphill battle. Many members were upset that Mr. Giuliani received a raise of $35,000, to $165,000. In addition, many members questioned how ironclad the contract's job security promises were, since Mr. Giuliani kept the right to order layoffs if the city plunged into a fiscal emergency.
Lastly, James Butler, president of the local representing aides at municipal hospitals, campaigned against it because Mr. Giuliani would not promise his members the same job security promised other workers, out of concern that Federal cuts would severely squeeze the city hospitals.
"This contract is very unhealthy for my members," Mr. Butler said. "It offers them no job security and it makes them wait 24 months for a raise."
It was Mr. Butler who said at yesterday's union board meeting, "They stole the election."
Accusations of fraud have swirled around District 37's downtown headquarters in recent days as the leaders of several locals questioned why such a large percentage of members in certain locals had cast mail ballots and why several locals waited weeks after mail ballots were turned in before announcing their results.
Mr. Hill said he could release a breakdown of how each local voted only after all the local presidents authorized him to do so.
One reason for all the mistrust is that District Council 37 gives its locals much leeway in how they vote. Some locals vote in members' meetings, some allow balloting at workplaces, some do mail ballots and have local officers count the votes and some have the American Arbitration Association count mail ballots to insure honesty.
Notwithstanding the divisions the contract created within the union, many labor experts said the ratification was a triumph for Mr. Hill, who has sought to position himself as the city's pre-eminent labor leader.
"This vote affirms Hill's power as a guy who can deliver his union," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center.
If District Council 37 had followed the teachers' lead and rejected the agreement, Mr. Giuliani's strategy of building close ties with the unions, to help him in the 1997 elections, would have been a shambles.
For months before the teachers and municipal workers voted, he had courted the leaders of those two unions; for their part, Mr. Hill and Ms. Feldman, despite their Democratic backgrounds, had worked closely with him. They said they were pleased that he was able to reduce the size of the city government by more than 15,000 workers through attrition rather than layoffs.
But relations between the Mayor and Ms. Feldman soured badly after her union rejected the contract. She angrily accused the Mayor of unwittingly undermining the contract by announcing his planned raise in the middle of the teachers' vote.
Despite Mr. Giuliani's original warm ties with the police, his relations with the police union have also grown strained. Many police officers have expressed unhappiness with the Mayor's plans to reduce the size of the police force by 1,500, while Mr. Giuliani and the police have clashed over a police-backed bill in Albany that would have a state board, rather than a city one, arbitrate police contract disputes. And the police, convinced that they deserve a raise because of their success in pushing down the crime rate, are also frustrated at the deadlock in their contract talks with the city.
"Every union is going to make an argument that they deserve more," said Norman Adler, a political consultant. "But once you have an agreement like the District Council 37 agreement, it will be very hard for any other union to move beyond it."

HEADLINE: Help Companies That Treat Workers Well, Kennedy Says

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Attacking corporate behavior in what he called the nation's "quiet depression," Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the Government should use tax breaks and penalties to encourage companies to look out for their workers.
The Senator, a Massachusetts Democrat, also proposed expanding antitrust laws to bar mergers that harmed communities and workers, broadening labor laws to protect temporary workers, and barring Government contracts to companies that repeatedly violated their workers' rights. 
 Mr. Kennedy's proposals were the first of several initiatives that Democrats plan to offer this spring although Congressional leaders acknowledge that their plans will not pass in a Republican-controlled Congress. Instead, as they argue that Democrats should be returned to power, they are seeking to move away from an essentially defensive stance of simply condemning Republican proposals to offering solutions of their own.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader in the Senate, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, his counterpart in the House, said the economy would be the focus of these efforts.
Mr. Kennedy said the steps he proposed were needed because even though many economic statistics looked good, "Americans are working more and earning less." He said, "Today's rising tide is lifting only some of the boats, primarily the yachts."
"Flat or falling wages," he said, "are compounded by the ever-present specter of layoffs. Once, corporations reduced their work forces only when they were in trouble. But now profitable companies are laying off good workers, at a time of increasing sales, in an endless quest for ever-fatter profits and ever-higher stock prices."
In a speech to the Center for National Policy, a Democratic issues forum, Mr. Kennedy called for using the tax laws to recognize corporate good citizens as "most favored companies," just as the Government gives tariff breaks to most-favored nations. These companies should pay lower corporate taxes, he said, and incentives should be created to encourage investment in them.
Businesses would earn "most favored company" status for their record in "creating jobs, avoiding layoffs simply to maximize profits, paying adequate wages, sharing gains, training and upgrading skills and providing decent health care and retirement benefits."
Mr. Daschle called Mr. Kennedy's speech "an example of the affirmative approach we need to be taking." He said Democrats needed to offer policies "to create and sustain good-paying jobs."
Mr. Gephardt, with whom Mr. Kennedy had also discussed his speech in advance, said House Democrats were preparing a legislative agenda, too. Not only would it focus on individual needs like health care, training and education, he said, but it would also try to find ways to encourage business to think of its workers as well as its shareholders.
He said the economic changes of today were as wrenching as those of a century ago. Just as Government then battled trusts and protected consumers, Mr. Gephardt said, today it must find ways to address "a stagnant economy," layoffs and "the erosion of the American dream."
Mr. Kennedy attacked Republicans as "bashing Medicare, slashing education and trashing the environment." But he argued that while some people in both parties argued that values, not economic issues, were the key to political success, the two could not be separated and that economic questions were paramount.
"We cannot solve great social problems by instructing people to be good while their financial situation is going from bad to worse," he said. "We have no chance of restoring values if we don't improve the lives of working Americans."
Mr. Kennedy said chief executives of typical corporations earn 190 times as much as their companies' average workers, and declared that it was time to "end the income gap, to put the American dream back in the dreams of all Americans."
Along with tax preferences for "responsible" corporations, Mr. Kennedy proposed eliminating provisions in tax law that he said "encourage layoffs, discourage job creation and reward companies for moving American jobs overseas."
He also called for an end to "tax deductions for expenses for mergers and acquisitions that result in substantial layoffs."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CAUCUSES;
Issues New, Iowa Returns to Spotlight

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Feb. 8

 BODY:
After an eight-year hiatus, Iowa has returned to center stage in the country's Presidential contest, and in the intervening years, prosperity and confidence have swept across the state like a prairie wind.
Having weathered the farm crisis of the 1980's and the recession of the early part this decade, Iowa's economy is booming. Businesses have flocked to the state in recent years, pushing unemployment down to 3.3 percent, far below the current national average, 5.8 percent. Per capita income rose by 40.8 percent from 1988 through 1994, a higher rate of growth than in the country as a whole. Exports are hitting record highs. And tax revenues have doubled since 1988, leaving the state with a $434 million surplus. 
 "You go all over the place and there are help-wanted signs everywhere," said Karla Underwood, Republican chairwoman for Linn County, which embraces Cedar Rapids in the north-central part of the state.
The state's turnaround goes beyond robust economic figures or the surge in home construction west of Des Moines and along the corridor from Iowa City to Cedar Rapids. In the last three years more people have moved to Iowa than have left, reversing two decades of population losses. And in an opinion survey conducted earlier this month by the Social Science Institute at the University of Iowa, only 11 percent of respondents said they felt that their condition would be worse in a year.
Iowa thus presents a markedly different picture than it did in 1988, the last time there was a hotly contested fight in the state's caucuses. Then, economic issues predominated, and the state's mood was sullen and angry. In 1992, Iowans were deprived of a national platform to express their views when President George Bush ran uncontested in the Republican race and Democratic hopefuls conceded to Senator Tom Harkin, a favorite son.
"The early to mid-80's were really tough times," said Thomas J. Miller, Iowa's Attorney General, remembering the economic and psychological climate that surrounded the 1988 caucuses. "We were just coming out of it, and we really didn't have a whole lot of confidence in light of what we had just gone through."
But if times are rosier now, many Iowans are concerned about issues like crime and remain mistrustful of politicians and the Federal Government, which played a pivotal role in bringing the state through its economic difficulties.
In the crisis of the 1980's, commodity prices dipped, farm values plummeted and bankruptcies soared. Iowa's farmers, whose output constituted about 45 percent of the overall economy, received an average of $1 billion annually in the form of Federal subsidies, said Mike Duffy, an economist at Iowa State University.
Still, when asked in the University of Iowa poll how much they trusted the Federal Government to do the right thing, only 20 percent of respondents said just about always or most of the time.
"They're all a bunch of ex-lawyers who are nothing but real good liars, whether they are Republicans or Democrats," said Paul Hynick, the 59-year-old manager of the sea food department at the Hy-Vee grocery store near Ottumwa. "I think people ought to be involved in politics on the local level. But nationally? Forget it. Money pays for all of it."
But if the good times have relegated the economy to the backburner, a number of other things are on people's minds.
Although crime rates are much lower than in metropolitan areas, the fear of crime remains pervasive. "Crime -- the gangs in their children's schools," said Linda Baker a customer service representative at a Cedar Rapids printing plant, when asked what she and her friends talk about. "We have a gentleman here at work whose son was killed in April by a random bullet in a school yard."
As a result of the loss of population in the 1980's -- mainly younger people who fled what they saw as a bleak future -- Iowa's population is significantly older than the country as a whole. According to the State Health Department, 15.4 percent of Iowans are more than 65 years old compared with 12.6 percent of the total United States population.
While the state has stanched the exodus of people, the newcomers have changed the mix of many Iowa cities. "There aren't any Iowans in my neighborhood," said Richard Schwab, dean of the School of Education at Drake University in Des Moines who moved here from New Hampshire six years ago. "My running buddy's from California. My neighbor next door is from Pennsylvania. The other one's from Minnesota."
Some Iowans remain concerned over the continued concentration of farming in fewer and fewer operations. Today, Iowa has about 100,000 farms, down from 145,000 in 1970.
And the growth of hog farming is causing environmental problems in several rural areas, especially in the north-central part of the state. In the last five years, more than 500 large-scale hog farms -- some with more than 20,000 mature pigs -- have begun operations in the state. Unlike waste products of chickens or cattle that are dried and sold as fertilizer, hog manure remains wet and is often stored in large open-air lagoons, some as long as football fields and as deep as 25 feet.
"Hogs have a smell to them, and always have had a smell," said Jim Braun, a farmer in Lattimer, about 80 miles north of Des Moines. "Usually it has just affected the farm, and once in a awhile, the neighbor might get a whiff. But what's happening now is that they're concentrating from 15,000 to 25,000 head of finishing hogs on one site."
With a population that is nearly 97 percent white, Iowa remains a state was less ethnic diversity than most others. In recent years, the state has seen an influx of Hispanic residents that has placed some strains, at times, on small rural communities.
Increasingly, these immigrants are taking jobs in small towns like Perry, West Liberty and Storm Lake, where nonunionized meat packing plants have found it difficult to recruit local people for the relatively low wages and tough working conditions involved.

NEW YORK CITY
 
Biggest City Union Votes Pact
 
 New York City's largest municipal employees' union has announced that its 120,000 members had approved a five-year contract with the city that promises job security and bolsters Mayor Giuliani's efforts to maintain labor peace as he reduces the size of city government. The Mayor and other city officials had been deeply worried about the prospects for approval after the teachers' union in December rejected their own contract, which had many similar provisions. [Page A1.]
 
Borough Hall for the Homeless
 Staten Island's Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, is allowing a handful of homeless men to spend nights in the 90-year-old French Renaissance-style Borough Hall. The men are sleeping among murals and mahogany, as well as the scent of old grandeur and maybe a bit of political opportunism. [B1.]
 
Man Questioned in Fatal Blaze
 Investigators were questioning a suspect last night in connection with the fire that killed a firefighter in a Brooklyn building identified by officials as a "chop shop" for stolen cars, a police spokesman said. Detectives said that the man being questioned was a 32-year-old Queens resident and that witnesses had seen him running from the makeshift garage. [B1.]
 
Clothes Make the Economy
 It is serious work, putting on a fashion show. Designers, buyers, models, tailors, writers and photographers are all cogs in a multimillion-dollar machine called Men's Fashion Week in New York. It is a semiannual event intended to add oomph to an apparel industry whose worth to the city's economy is estimated at $27 billion a year. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
School Workers Settle a Strike
 School custodial helpers and a private company that provides custodial services at eight Brooklyn schools reached an agreement yesterday on a new labor contract, a day after the workers walked off the job, leaving 10,000 students and their teachers without heat for several hours. [B3.]
 
Lay Teachers Resist Clause
 Contract talks between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and several hundred high school teachers have taken a contentious turn with the archdiocese's insistence that the teachers accept new language on the "religious mission" of the church or face dismissal. [B3.]
 
Pass Tissues: Collins Testifies
 A lawyer for Random House, which is suing the actress Joan Collins for breaking a two-book contract, confronted Miss Collins in court with some potentially damaging testimony she had given in another lawsuit. In 1992, the actress testified that a traumatizing event had prevented her from completing the novel she had been contractually obligated to write. [B3.]
 
Agencies Ordered to Plan Cuts
 New York City's budget director has sent a directive to city agencies ordering all of them to propose cuts to their budgets that together will total $500 million. The notice was a clear sign that the preliminary budget Mayor Giuliani proposed just last week includes many risky fiscal assumptions that could leave the city seriously short of money. [B2.]
 
Man Kills and Then Drops Dead
 A former New York City police officer was shot to death in his Brooklyn apartment by the father of a former colleague he had once been arrested for stalking, the police said. Then the father, after fleeing the former officer's basement apartment, suffered a heart attack on a street corner and died, the police said. [B4.]
 
REGION
 
Governors' Plans Aid Budget
 After a long year of budget debates in Washington, the Medicaid and welfare proposals endorsed by the nation's governors would represent by far the best fiscal deal yet for New York State's own fragile financial plan. Despite the governors' willingness to accept some continued Federal oversight, their proposals could still give state officials the tools to redefine the generous package of health care services that New York has traditionally provided to poor people. [A1.]
 
Dry Faucets Plague New Jersey
 The source of the concern in northeastern New Jersey was water, and the lack of it. For the second day in a row, thousands of residents in the region endured dry faucets brought about by the rupture of two water pipelines. [B1.]
 
 Two water main breaks that left New Jersey residents with little or no water may have stemmed from a chain of events that began a month ago, an engineer said. [B5.]
 
Democrats Claim Kickbacks
 The District Attorney's office in Nassau County is looking into allegations by three Democratic party members that they were pressured to donate to the party under the threat of losing their patronage jobs. The case echoes one from 11 years ago in which a group of Nassau County employees won a class action suit in Federal Court forcing the county's Republican Party to return $1.3 million in illegal kickbacks to county workers. [B4.]
 
2 Are Named to SUNY Board
 Governor Pataki is appointing a new chairman and vice chairman of the State University of New York Board of Trustees, further consolidating his control over the governing board for the 64-campus system. The Pataki appointees have been vocal advocates of a state university system that would be run according to "market forces." They want the campuses to have greater autonomy and to be able to set their tuition according to what the market will bear. [B4.]

HEADLINE: Bonds Mixed as Profit Taking Cuts Short Potential Rallies

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
As concerns eased somewhat over the credit market's ability to absorb the week's $44.5 billion in new notes and bonds, prices of Treasury securities finished mixed yesterday in a choppy trading session.
Profit taking for the most part cut short potential rallies, a couple of which were fueled by speculation that the Federal Reserve was in the market yesterday buying 2-year, 5-year and 10-year notes. It is not unusual for talk of a ready buyer in the market, like the Fed, to cause prices to rise and yields to fall. 
 Analysts said they believed that the Fed, which does not comment on such actions, was in the market buying notes on behalf of some foreign central banks.
The price of the newly issued 30-year bond fell 3/32, to 9823/32, for a yield of 6.09 percent.
Tony Crescenzi, director of fixed-income trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company, a New York brokerage firm, said the market activity reflected efforts by dealers to lighten their holdings of newly issued securities. Dealers typically reduce prices on the new securities to make them attractive and clear out inventory accumulated from the auctions.
"Today's price action is consistent with the bond market's behavior since early December," Mr. Crescenzi said, "and that is we are in a relatively narrow trading range, whether it is price or yield."
On Thursday, the Treasury completed its quarterly auction, selling a record amount of new 3-year and 5-year notes and 30-year bonds.
In the eight refundings since 1993, the price of the long bond has in six instances gained almost half a point within a week of the refunding's end.
Many traders expect yields to decline further next week as the market remains optimistic that the Fed will continue to cut short-term interest rates, with the objective of stimulating a weak economy. And as long as inflation remains low there is room for interest rates to go lower.
Larry Berman, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said the market's next step was to look toward future releases of economic data. "The market is trading with some breathing room, so it's now time to establish some upside momentum," he said. "With no data and no auctions, only customer flows, some buyers may step in to get their feet wet to do some buying."
Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said the trading range in bonds would continue until economic weakness became pronounced or a credible agreement to balance the Federal budget was reached.
"There is a tug-of-war in the bond market," Mr. Sohn said. "Cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve in the face of a worrisome economic condition support bonds. On the other hand, lack of progress in Washington over budget matters is eroding confidence."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Edges Up Against Yen And Mark in Choppy Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed yesterday after a day of choppy trading.
The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen and the German mark after its fluctuations through Asian, European and North American trading. 
 Much of the day's activity focused on mark-yen trading, with the dollar caught in the middle. Fluctuating United States stock, bond and gold markets also buffeted the dollar.
"It was a tug-of-war for the dollar," said Charles Spence, the director of Treasury sales for the Standard Chartered Bank.
In other trading, the British pound fell sharply against the mark and the dollar late in the day after news of a bomb blast in London, which came shortly after an Irish radio report that the Irish Republican Army had ended its cease-fire.
At 4 P.M. in New York, the British pound was at $1.5305, down from $1.5378 on Thursday. In later trading, the pound fell as low as $1.5310.
The pound had been weaker earlier in the day on profit taking and concerns about Britain's Conservative Government remaining in power.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar was trading at 1.4872 marks, up from 1.4755 on Thursday and slightly higher than last Friday. It finished at 107.05 yen, up from 106.95 yen on Thursday and about half a yen higher than a week earlier.
"The dollar got a good rise after going through its weeklong correction" on concerns about the United States economy, Mr. Spence of Standard Chartered said. "Then it slowly clawed its way up."
Active trading among foreign currencies "was part of the reason we saw some of the moves" that kept the dollar bouncing, he said.
Thursday's announcement of Japanese Government efforts to send more investments abroad continued to hurt the yen. Yen sales bolstered the mark and gave the dollar some of its support.
"That's what pushed the dollar over 107 yen" and initially "kept the dollar from breaching 1.48 on the mark," he added.
Also underpinning the dollar was the mark's fall in trades with the Finnish markka as the Finns intervened in the market to bolster their currency, Mr. Spence said.
Comments by German monetary officials concerning interest rate cuts there wound up having little if any impact on the market, analysts said.

HEADLINE: NATO's Plans Threaten Start II

BYLINE: By Mikhail S. Gorbachev; Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former Soviet President, heads the Gorbachev Foundation, a research institute.

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
The Senate's ratification of the Start II treaty is supposedly a sign that the United States respects its nuclear disarmament commitments and that it intends to push Russia to do the same. But many in Moscow think the real objective is to disarm Russia as soon as possible.
The problem is the American double standard: a demand for disarmament while disrupting the balance of power by pushing NATO's ill-conceived plans to march toward Russia. 
 Expanding NATO's umbrella, including its nuclear weapons, to cover Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Hungary -- moving NATO's frontiers some 400 miles closer to Moscow and the Russian heartland -- is seen as a fundamental violation of Western guarantees after Russia dissolved the Warsaw Pact and agreed to German unification.
Many in the West see NATO as benign. But Russians see it as something that didn't change with the end of the cold war -- as a war machine that is trying to take advantage of our troubled political and economic situation. The fear, realistic or not, is that the West or some politicians in the West want to deliver a coup de grace to the Russian Federation and eliminate forever a Russian challenge to United States dominance.
The result, of course, is that Russian defense officials are loath to endorse any new cuts in their missile forces. Not surprisingly, the Russian Parliament may refuse to ratify Start II, which calls for slashing the American and Russian strategic nuclear arsenals to about a third of their cold war levels.
Although some hard-liners in Washington and Moscow might welcome this, the demise of Start II would be a terrible blow to nuclear disarmament and worldwide hopes for nonproliferation. Already the friction over NATO and Start II is undermining what is left of Russia's confidence in the West and helping our ultra-nationalists in their bid for presidential power.
There is a real danger that we'll restart the arms race. I wouldn't be surprised if the nuclear-security card was resurrected in the coming elections in both Russia and the United States.
Legitimate questions remain to be answered. In particular is the question of the role to be assigned to Russia in the so-called Partnership for Peace.
Disarmament continues to follow the logic of the negotiations begun in Geneva and Reykjavik from the reduction of medium-range missiles to Start I. This approach had a positive effect on all the other international actors, including those tempted by nuclear ambitions.
The two great superpowers stipulated rules of conduct that the others could not overlook. But since then we have witnessed the disappearance of the Soviet Union. The consequences have been destabilizing. The geopolitical role of Russia has changed drastically. But instead of working together to handle this new situation, some in the West have attempted to ruthlessly exploit the strains and weaknesses in Russian policy.
On top of this, France has resumed nuclear testing, China has reserved the right to test and even the United States is considering the possibility of new underground explosions. (Incidentally, why did America react so feebly to the French tests? Could the Americans have used the French tests to perfect their own nuclear weapons?) Why should other countries adhere to nonproliferation if the main members of the nuclear club continue to rely on atomic bombs as a way of achieving their objectives?
If smaller nations see the big powers engaged unscrupulously in the arms trade, it should come as no surprise that they do the same, as buyers and producers. Not to mention that a buildup of arms in one place leads to a race to rearm in another place, especially if the countries have a common border.
If the United States sells arms to Pakistan, it should not be surprised when India responds by testing missiles capable of carrying nuclear warheads and with a show of modern weapons. And we shouldn't be surprised by a New York Times headline on Feb. 7: "China to Buy 72 Advanced Fighter Planes From Russia."
What is to be done? Pursue policies that genuinely correspond to the challenges of the time, mobilize the United Nations and repudiate saber-rattling. We must continue nonstop with disarmament, adhere strictly to nonproliferation treaties and make their verification provisions even tighter, put an end to the uncertainties concerning the prohibition on new nuclear testing and avoid provocative moves such as the development of an anti-missile defense system.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: No Big Bank to Call Its Own;
Does Los Angeles Need a Financial Powerhouse?

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9

 BODY:
A pall descended over this usually upbeat city after Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco succeeded in its hostile takeover of the First Interstate Bancorporation, the last big bank based here. Coming on top of a series of natural and man-made disasters, and the departure last year of the area's two professional football teams, it seemed like the final insult.
The initial result will be predictable and unpleasant. About 8,000 to 10,000 well-paying jobs will evaporate just as the Southern California economy is emerging from a painful recession. Floors will be vacated in First Interstate's office towers downtown, where the commercial real estate vacancy rate is already a hazardous 20 percent. 
 Then, there is the feared loss of the bank's financial support of community institutions, as well as millions of dollars of work for lawyers, accountants and other suppliers of services.
These days, the largest locally controlled commercial bank based in Los Angeles County -- which has a population of 9.2 million -- is City National, an institution one-fourteenth the size of First Interstate. Many out-of state and foreign banks also have large operations here.
But to a surprising degree, there are people who regard the takeover as almost a positive reflection of a deep transformation of the region's economy. On balance, they say, it does not bode ill for the future of Los Angeles, the nation's second-largest city -- even if it has become a satellite city in financial industries dominated by New York, Chicago and San Francisco.
"Over the next three to five years, we'll see this as part of a process of creating a more diverse economic base, a more diverse employment base, a more diverse credit base," said Stephen J. Trafton, chairman of Glendale Federal Bank, a savings and loan institution that expects to capitalize on the banking shake-up.
The business landscape of greater Los Angeles has moved from a centralized economy dominated by big companies like aerospace manufacturers -- and banks -- toward a highly dispersed economy propelled by small businesses, many in entertainment and the electronic media.
Certainly, a strong financial presence here would add jobs, but the lack of a big financial headquarters is not holding the area's economy back, experts say.
And that touches on the deeper lesson in the takeover: the experience of Los Angeles is foreshadowing developments that will influence the American economy in the years ahead, with growth and innovation coming increasingly from smaller, younger businesses.
"Given a choice, sure, I'd like to see Wells Fargo headquartered here," said Eli Broad, a civic leader and chairman of the SunAmerica Corporation, a big insurance and financial-services company. "But they're smart enough to understand this area. They're going to have offices where the business is. Ultimately, it will have little, if any, impact on the community."
Many here say that at one time Los Angeles would have been in trouble if it had just lost its last big banking headquarters. Large banks financed large companies in a way more modest-sized banks could not.
But times have clearly changed. Now, big companies go to the markets for most of their capital needs, and heightened competition means that they can pick up the telephone and approach just about any bank when they need credit or other banking services. Many big banks are dispersing their operations in pursuit of lower costs, which means that they are less concentrated in their hometowns than they had been years ago. First Interstate, for instance, has had its computer center in Arizona and its loan-processing center in Oregon.
Some executives here say that Los Angeles was probably a little crowded with banks, anyway. Certain other big markets, including metropolitan areas in Texas and Arizona, have seen their leading local banks acquired by outsiders, and those economies have thrived and banking services improved with new services and competition.
For individual customers, the competition here is so keen here that most people will probably not feel much of a difference.
Glendale Federal has been running humorous radio ads trying to win customers away from the merged banks, saying that service will deteriorate and emphasizing its own cool Southern California agility.
"This is one of the most competitive banking markets in the country, and we've been trying to turn the heat up," Mr. Trafton said.
Robert S. Attiyeh personifies the civic and business difficulty that the First Interstate takeover represents here. He is president of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Association, and he fears that Wells Fargo will not support the Music Center or local cultural institutions, preferring to put its money into its hometown.
And Mayor Richard J. Riordan has said he is concerned that the bank will support more activities near its San Francisco headquarters. "I think he's right," William F. Zuendt, the Wells Fargo president, conceded in an interview.
But Mr. Attiyeh is also the chief financial officer at Amgen, a leading biotechnology company that typifies the new, knowledge-intensive economy, and in that role he said that the news is not necessarily bad.
"Will we get by" at Amgen? he asked. "Yes. "Other major national players are going to be much more aggressive here, and smaller banks are going to grow. The city is not going to be underbanked, and we may even benefit from the competition."
And he added that though the downtown area might be hurt, the notion of a city's downtown was becoming something of a relic. "Is there a downtown in Silicon Valley?" he asked. "There's a lot of wealth creation, a lot of innovation, but there's no real center, no downtown. Los Angeles is a lot like that."
Indeed, Mr. Attiyeh's own company, less than 16 years old, is situated in Thousand Oaks, an outlying area just beyond the San Fernando Valley and about 40 miles from downtown.
And Mr. Zuendt of Wells Fargo said: "My personal opinion is that a place like Los Angeles should not be focused on major companies. Its growth is coming from the huge number of smaller companies."
Wells Fargo has adapted to that pattern by becoming the country's largest lender to small business in recent years, and it intends to continue the push, he said.
Still, it may take residents some time to accept the loss.
"It's all about the aura of Los Angeles," said Carol E. Schatz, president of the Central City Association. "It just looks like a loss of prestige for us."

HEADLINE: Stock Up on Rumors At Warner-Lambert

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The stock of the Warner-Lambert Company jumped yesterday on takeover speculation, but the company, a drug and consumer products concern, merely reiterated that it was reviewing some of its smaller business lines for possible sale.
Warner-Lambert ended up $5.75, to $98.75, after rising as high as $100 on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 A company spokeswoman declined to comment on the takeover speculation. The company, based in Morris Plains, N.J., has said it is determined to remain independent.
Analysts also linked the stock's rise to a presentation by company executives on Thursday at an investment conference, and to investors' purchases of so-called defensive issues, including drug makers, that would fare better if the economy slowed further.
At the conference, executives outlined the drugs Warner-Lambert is developing and focused on two for which they will seek regulatory approval later this year: troglitazone for diabetes and atorvastatin, which lowers cholesterol, analysts said.
Aside from the vague takeover rumors, investors speculated about a possible sale of Warner-Lambert's Tetra, a maker of food for pet fish, which had sales of $230 million in 1995.
Reiterating statements company executives made last April, a spokeswoman said the company was considering selling Tetra and other noncore assets to focus on its pharmaceutical, consumer health care and confectionery businesses.
In addition to drugs, Warner-Lambert makes Halls cough drops, Listerine mouthwash, Schick and Wilkinson Sword razors and Trident, Chiclets and Dentyne gum.

LENGTH: 338 words

HEADLINE: No Time to Cut Head Start

 BODY:
A new report reconfirms the long-term benefits of early childhood programs like Head Start that Congress is trying to cut. Lawmakers should study it before slashing these programs.
Head Start is a comprehensive early childhood development program that gives low-income children educational and social skills needed to succeed in school. The program gives its 3-to-5-year-old participants health and nutrition services and offers social services to their families. It also places heavy emphasis on parent involvement. 
 Even though Head Start is the most successful of the Great Society programs, it has come under attack over the years. Several studies have indicated that initial gains made by Head Start children on intelligence tests are not sustained.
That was not the program's promise. The new report, by the David and Lucile Packard Foundation's Center for the Future of Children, emphasizes the long-term educational and economic gains that make Head Start and other preschool programs for disadvantaged children worth the investment.
The foundation's researchers culled results of nearly 150 studies to conclude that children exposed to early childhood education have higher reading scores, are less likely to be held back a grade or put into expensive special education classes and are more likely to graduate from high school than those who are not. In addition, participants in preschool programs are less likely to go on welfare or become involved in the criminal justice system.
Still, only 35 percent of all low-income children are enrolled in preschool programs. But the need continues to grow. Thirty years ago, only 19 percent of children under the age of 6 needed additional care because one or both parents worked. In 1995, the figure had jumped to 66 percent.
Congress wants to cut Head Start's $3.5 billion budget by 4 percent, or $137 million, this year. By contrast, President Clinton proposed a $400 million increase. The Packard Foundation report indicates Mr. Clinton is right.

HEADLINE: South Africa Campuses Reap Racial Enmity

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Timing their protest with a meeting of the directors of Witwatersrand University, a group of black students and university workers gathered recently in the administration building on campus here.
While they ululated and waved signs with slogans like "Stop Ethnic Cleansing at Wits Now," a group of white students leaned over a balcony high above and watched for a while. Then, indifferent, they walked away. 
 During this country's many years under an apartheid Government, the white professors and students at "Wits" often allied themselves with blacks, speaking out even when it was dangerous to do so. The school's administrators risked jail to keep black students, albeit a small number, in the classrooms and dormitories, and it was routine for them to be hauled before bureaucrats who threatened to cut off their financing.
But these days, as South Africa blossoms under its first freely elected black-led Government, students, faculty members and administrators say that South Africa's most prestigious university has never been more divided racially.
Across the country, many of South Africa's key institutions, for decades under white leadership, are trying to fit into a South Africa where the black majority is finally coming into power. But it is often a painful process, exposing the huge financial and cultural gaps that have existed between the races in this country and leaving raw feeling on both sides.
Many blacks say they feel the campus -- with an overwhelmingly white faculty and administration -- has not done enough fast enough. They want more remedial help. They also want a new structure for the school that will give them and the other large black campus constituency -- the janitors and cafeteria workers -- a say in how it is run.
At Witwatersrand the transformation process has grown especially vicious, with some professors and a black administrator now feuding almost daily in the newspapers, accusing each other of everything from racism to lying on their resumes to tax evasion. The disputes have attracted the attention of Government officials and prompted newspaper columnists to thunder both for and against how the university's administration is handling change.
The turmoil recently led the university to take out advertisements to reassure prospective students. The ads said that, as in the United States, the universities that first committed themselves to civil rights were the ones with the worst ethnic tensions.
Part of the problem is that the two sides have utterly different perspectives. The administrators think they are being generous. The students find them patronizing, saying that Wits, despite its liberal bent, thrived under apartheid and has a lot to make up for.
"The problem with liberals is that they believe they are good people and that they shouldn't be questioned," said Russell Ally, a history professor who supports the black students. "Some of them really believe they led the struggle. They don't think they have to change.
"On the other side are the students, who say: 'Stop wanting to be congratulated. If not for apartheid, black students wouldn't need all this and the money you have is made from the work of our parents. This is reparations, not a favor.' "
Wits has changed a lot in the last few years. The number of blacks enrolling has grown steadily; nearly 40 percent of the newest class is black. (Blacks are about 73 percent of the population.) The university has created programs to help the black students bridge the gaps between the poor education they received under apartheid and the tough courses they are taking. This has been done without any extra Government financing, so the school has paid for it by cutting back departments, keeping faculty salary increases below the rate of inflation and trying to raise private donations.
In his 11th-floor office overlooking the sprawling campus, Robert Charlton, who has headed the university since 1988, recites these accomplishments with pride. He is confounded by the hostility.
"If you look at the halls of residence, they are pretty classy," he said. "They get enough to eat and they get money to spend. The contrast to what it is like at home for them is enormous. There are plenty of people around here who didn't have it all made for them."
But many blacks find the school insensitive. Kwena Mathatho, 26, the chairman of the student union, said his efforts to get financial aid are typical. He came here to study law in 1992, the year his father, a migrant worker, died. His mother lives in a rural area where few blacks have electricity and most survive on subsistence farming and a few cattle.
When he applied for financial aid, he found it difficult even to document his parents' income, as the school insisted, since copying machines and income tax returns were hardly part of his mother's world. When he finally submitted everything, he said, he was virtually called a liar. "They said they couldn't believe that anyone could live on this," he recalled.
Finally, he said, he was able to break the stalemate by having a white doctor who was treating his mother write a letter in his defense. But in the meantime he went eight months without any financial support. To eat, he said, he passed out leaflets on the street.
Mr. Mathatho said that although the school has greatly increased the number of blacks it accepts, the number that drop out without a degree is enormous -- he guessed 60 percent. The university says that it has no figures on this, but that no student who is passing is excluded for financial reasons.
Some of the worst disruptions on campus occurred last spring over the university's attempts to dismiss a black cafeteria worker who was accused of letting students through the line without paying. At one point, frustrated black students stormed the office of the registrar and held him hostage for most of the day.
They were arrested. Then, when the university tried to dismiss the worker and expel the students, there were more protests. Backing down, the university demoted the worker and suspended the students for a year.
Again, said Mr. Ally, the history professor, the two sides saw the incident very differently.
"The administration," he said, "thought this was an issue of principle: 'You take hostages, that's it.' But the students and workers were thinking: 'If black people are prepared to forgive you for apartheid and everything that went with it, why are you taking such a hard line? There was no loss of life.' "
More recently, much of the squabbling has surrounded the hiring of a black administrator, William Makgoba, a South African who had been head of research at the Royal Postgraduate Medical School in London. He was recruited in 1994 to help the university become more welcoming to blacks. But in October 13 faculty members sent Mr. Charlton a letter questioning Mr. Makgoba's competence and accusing him of falsifying his resume. The letter was leaked to the press.
In retaliation Mr. Makgoba, who as deputy vice chancellor for administration has access to personnel files, made them public and accused many of the complaining professors of dodging taxes and misusing research funds.
Arguing that Mr. Makgoba had abused his office, Mr. Charlton suspended him. But under a torrent of pressure from black students, workers, the Minister of Education and others, he reinstated him. The University is now setting up a panel to review the mess.
Wits is certainly not the only South African university in turmoil. Under apartheid, the country had separate high-quality English and Afrikaans universities and a host of universities for blacks, most of which were notoriously dysfunctional.
The Government has not yet decided what to do about all these schools. Some are struggling to reform on their own. Last week the University of the Western Cape, a traditionally black school, closed because of student protests. The university is in financial trouble because it has admitted many new students who cannot afford the tuition, and the student protests were over the school's announcement that it would bar delinquent payers from classes.
This week, protesters at the Afrikaans University of Stellenbosch trashed the campus over the university's efforts to cut costs by privatizing cafeteria services.
The one university that seems to have avoided major disruptions is Cape Town, another prestigious, formerly white-run university. Last October, the university chose Dr. Mamphela Ramphele to take over as head later this year. In Dr. Ramphele, the university was able to find a black woman of indisputable academic standing -- she is a medical doctor with a Ph.D. in social anthropology -- with an unquestionable record as an anti-apartheid activist.
The university began trying to remake itself more than 10 years ago and hired Dr. Ramphele to lead that effort five years ago. It has already set up a new governing system that gave all campus constituencies -- including students and workers -- a say in choosing Dr. Ramphele to head the school. But officials say they hardly feel out of the woods.
With eight applicants for every place, the Cape Town administration has decided to be tough on those who are not keeping up academically. This, they say, could easily lead to student unrest.
At Wits these days, Mr. Charlton consoles himself with the fact that the university has not yet missed a day of classes. But he still finds his new role -- no longer the liberal hero but now the administration bad guy -- befuddling.
"I just don't understand," he said. "Why should we be targets now? We were targets for 40 years. Maybe we need sensitivity training, I don't know."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Charlton, left, head of Witwatersrand University, listens as black students call for his ouster during a protest. The anti-apartheid alliance between blacks and whites at South Africa's colleges is on the rocks. (Greg Marinovich/Southlight)(pg. 3)

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
N.F.L. Gives Modell a Ticket to Baltimore

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 9

 BODY:
"Where've you guys been for the past three months?" Art Modell asked reporters today, in his first public appearance since November, following the National Football League owners' decision to let the team formerly known as the Cleveland Browns move to Baltimore. "It's good to be back."
The team's relocation, which goes into effect immediately, plus the N.F.L.'s promise to provide Cleveland with a new team called the Browns by 1999, was approved by 25 owners, 2 more than the required three-quarters majority of the 30 teams. Pittsburgh and Buffalo voted against the deal, while Oakland, St. Louis and Arizona abstained. 
 "It was a necessary evil," said Roger Headrick, president of the Minnesota Vikings.
Lamar Hunt, the Kansas City Chiefs' owner, added, "I was not in favor of the move, but I was in favor of the ultimate resolution."
Paul Tagliabue, the N.F.L. commissioner, called the deal "the end of a very emotional and difficult time."
"To the fans of the Browns, you can count on us that the Browns will be there in 1999," he said.
The deal nearly collapsed on Tuesday with Modell's resistance to paying Cleveland any more than $2.5 million in damages from lost rent, taxes and other revenue. "We had to be made whole," said Fred Nance, a lawyer for the city of Cleveland.
"I never thought it would get done," said Robert Weber, Modell's lawyer. "I wasn't impressed with the city's recognition of modern-day sports economics."
At his coming out, after a torrent of vitriol and numerous death threats sent him into exile in Palm Beach, Fla., Modell expressed a mixture of relief at the resolution and a continued belief that Cleveland's politicians failed him.
"I wouldn't do anything differently," he said. "I'm proud that I showed as much patience as I have."
Citing the city's financial commitments to build Jacobs Field, the Gund Arena and the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame, he said, "I wanted and was promised equal treatment and it wasn't forthcoming." He flayed the news media and politicians who "fed the passions of hate" against him.
Cleveland Mayor Michael R. White, a leader in the fight to keep the Browns in Cleveland, said: "What has been done has been done and has been rectified. We have received redress. It's time to look to a new day."
Modell said he did not expect the enormous outcry that followed the announcement that he would move.
"I didn't expect the outrage," he said. "I kid Bud Adams" -- the owner of the N.F.L.'s Houston team, who is moving his franchise to Nashville -- "that he had 65 people protesting the Oilers' move, and 30 were relatives looking for money."
Asked when moving vans would pack up the team's belongings for the trip to Baltimore, Modell said, "When they come back from L.A.," a reference to the Seattle Seahawks' proposed move to Southern California.
The league's nine-page agreement with Cleveland sets precedents that may have to be repeated as more N.F.L. teams seek their fortunes in other cities.
The league has agreed to borrow from $28 million to $48 million to help pay for construction of a 72,000-seat, natural-turf stadium in Cleveland, which an expansion or relocated team will make its home. The owner of a new Cleveland team will repay the loan with interest. The league has agreed to make "every effort" to tell Cleveland if it intends to expand there by Nov. 15, 1997.
"If you do it for the Browns, why don't you do it for the Seahawks?" said Marc Ganis, president of Sportscorp., a Chicago consulting firm. "What's interesting is the backfill. Do you put a team back into Houston after they move? Or Tampa Bay? Or Seattle?"
In Houston, the Oilers have a deal to move to a Nashville stadium in time for the 1998 season. Asked if the N.F.L. would lend money to help build a new stadium in Houston and guarantee a replacement team, Tagliabue said: "We'd consider it. The question is, are people prepared to do what Cleveland has done, to come through with funding and turn a renovation plan into a new stadium?"
Regarding Seattle, Tagliabue sounded bothered about the Seahawks' owner Kenneth Behring's abrupt decision, which violated a league resolution that Behring signed last year giving the N.F.L. control of the Southern California market.
"It's a serious concern on my part and by ownerships, picking up and moving their practice facility to Southern California," he said. "The Seahawks are the N.F.L. team in the Pacific Northwest. Practicing in Southern California doesn't go far in representing us in the Pacific Northwest."
Al Davis, the Raiders' president of the general partner, said the resolution was illegal "and I don't know if you are allowed to appropriate a market for yourself." Later, he said his team still controls that market.
Davis called the Cleveland deal "selective, discriminatory."
"Someone has got to pay for it," he said.
He said Cleveland did not meet the league's relocation guidelines, which Modell championed and used to argue against Raiders' moves around California. He said today's meeting grew contentious when he raised his objections. Tagliabue said Modell's petition to move "did not meet all the guidelines," but the deal with Cleveland overcame those problems.
Modell will pay the league a $29 million relocation fee -- paid for by the Maryland Stadium Authority's sale of $80 million in permanent seat licenses, or upfront payments to buy season tickets -- and forgo some future expansion fees.
Is it fair, Modell was asked, that his actions deprive Cleveland of N.F.L. action for three years?
"It's not the end of the world," he said. "Baltimore waited for 13 years."
 
 
 
EXTRA POINT
 In other business Friday, the N.F.L. owners approved extension of the collective bargaining agreement through 2002. It moves the uncapped year from 1999 to 2000 in time for the free-agent signing period, which begins Thursday.

HEADLINE: Police Arbitration Bill Deserves Pataki's Veto;
How Much Productivity?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Feb. 6 news article on anger expressed by New York City police officers at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani: Mr. Giuliani says the city cannot afford raises for its police officers, although he and his aides have now received theirs. As the wife of a police officer, I know that officers have not had a raise in about as many years. 
 Mayor Giuliani says that he would consider police raises in exchange for an increase in productivity, and applauds the police for the remarkable decrease in crime in New York City. How much productivity does he want before agreeing they merit a raise?
We still have a majority of ethical, hard-working police officers in the city, but as their rate of pay continues to lag behind inflation, we must remember that we get what we pay for.
 
CAROLINE SCHNEIDER
Rockaway Point, Queens, Feb. 6, 1996

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
U.S. Assails Japan Over Music Copyrights

 BODY:
The United States complained yesterday to the World Trade Organization that Japan was failing to comply with an accord to protect foreign music copyrights, costing American producers $500 million a year. The move starts a process than could lead to trade sanctions against Japanese exports to the United States. 
 The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, announcing the complaint, said in Washington that the United States had raised the issue with Japanese officials 13 times, "but to no avail." The complaint to the W.T.O. in Geneva is the first step in the trade group's dispute settlement procedure. If the claim is ultimately successful, the United State will be entitled to impose tariffs on Japanese imports to make up the $500 million loss. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: TELEVISION VIEW;
'Seinfeld,' an Odd Place That's Just Like Home

BYLINE: By Jeff MacGregor; Jeff MacGregor is a humorist who has written for and about television for 20 years.

 BODY:
THE COMMODIFICATION OF popular entertainment is as old as show business itself. Recent archeothespic investigations at the Globe Theater in London, for example, suggest that while on-site sales of Shakespeare's Tomorrow and Tomorrow and Tomorrow Perpetual Desk Calendar were quite strong, the post-performance numbers for his "My Progenitors Went to 'Coriolanus' and I Received Naught but This Motley Jerkin, Withal!" T-shirts were not what they might have been.
In post-modern Hollywood, of course, this noble tradition of peripheral profiteering long ago superseded the bothersome production of any actual entertainment. A movie or a television show is now just the ceremonial jeroboam broken across the bow of a newly launched merchandise Leviathan. Witness NBC's "Diet Coke Playhouse," formerly known as "Friends," the hairstyle-driven, self-cannibalizing hitcom that proves once and for all that in marketing, nothing exceeds like excess. 
 The business of America is, after all, show business, and all good citizens must do their bit to stimulate our nation's economy. Thus, it is alarming, and quite possibly seditious, that NBC is missing a sure bet by failing to exploit properly its recently renewed megamonster comedy "Seinfeld." While tremendously profitable, the show isn't nearly overexposed enough; hence its continued success as the zaniest Zeitgeist on prime time. But there's a lot more money to be made there, a golden goos' to be killed and cooked, so it's high time something be done about it. Herewith, then, a modest proposal that all NBC executives should clip and save for their next board meeting: Six Flags Jerry.
That's right, Six Flags Jerry. A "Seinfeld" theme park, where the theme is, naturally, absolutely nothing (unlike the Reality Tour being offered in Manhattan by the "real" Kramer -- which is, being a Reality Tour, about $27.50 worth of something).
Think of it. Millions of tourists and devoted fans flocking in year after year. And every one of them a high-rolling member of television advertising's most attractive demographic subset: 18 to 49. Expecting what? Expecting nothing, and lots of it! Once in Orlando (where else?), fun seekers would arrive at the park via Monolog rail, a newly refurbished subway car in which Jerry's irreverent show-opening observations are played continuously. By the time visitors land at Guest Services, they'll be repeating "Ever wonder why . . . ?" just like a pro. (But they had better keep their eyes peeled for that roly-poly ol' Animatronic Weatherman, Al Roker, or he just may steal their complimentary gyro!)
After queuing for several hours only to learn that their rental-car reservations didn't actually reserve them rental cars, guests will be whisked away in Jon Voight's old Chrysler to begin their stay in 5,000 deluxe replicas of Jerry's very own apartment.
Imagine their delight at being able to explore at last this simultaneously strange and familiar environment. To reach out and touch the hanging bike that Jerry never rides. To discover the titles in his 10-book library or play one of his never-opened CD's. Or to 'ine as they please at the in-room, all-U-can-eat cereal-and-bottled-water bar. To learn finally the forbidden secret of what lies hidden behind Jerry's bedroom door.
Following a good night's sleep (as Masters of Their Own Domain), the guests wil' be off to explore the 400-plus acres and 42 theme attractions that make up Six Flags Jerry. Each tour begins with an orientation lecture by the first-sacker-turned-socio psychologist Keith Hernandez, in addition to a written personality test (hint: the right answer is almost always "Junior Mints"). Lecture topics will include "The Cosmo, the Id and the Superego," "Men Are From Mars; Lainey's From Your Subconcious," "On Dating, Jerry and You: A Can't-Quite-Commitcom," "I Am Curious (George)" and " 'Seinfeld' at the Millennium: More Laughs or Just Prostate Trouble?"
For the less-athletic visitor, the next stop may be the Benesphere, a 20-story domed exhibition hall. Built in the shape of Elaine's diaphragm, it houses hundreds of interactive displays. Here one can visit the Hall of Mirrors That Make You Look Fat, or run screaming, with a pocketful of mutton, through a computer-generated kennel.
GUESTS CAN ALSO TRY THEIR hand at placating a holographic Mr. Pitt, experience what it's like to go slowly insane working for J. Peterman or let one of the perky Benesphere attendants show them how to toss their hair for distance and accuracy while saying "Hellooooo" to a handsome stranger. (Guests who plan to visit the 700,000-square-foot Gallery of Guys Who Got Away should allow two days. Special time must be set aside for the Meditation Gardens, site of the J. F. K. Jr. Eternal Torch.)
More adventurous souls may opt instead for a hair-raising thrill ride at Parking Space Mountain in Costanzaland. Or they can plumb the foul depths of George's self-esteem by plunging into the bowels of the Looks Don't Matterhorn. Only the very bravest among them will risk a voyage through the troubled waters of Parents of the Caribbean, a simulated two-week holiday cruise with George's mother and father. It's not all terry cloth and terror, though. There'll be daily betting pools for guesses on the exact time George will break his engagement. And every great day at Costanzaland ends at the band shell with a cocktail-hour performance of the all-new musical "Pride of the Damn Yankees," starring Jason Alexander as Lou Gehrig and Jerry Lewis as George Steinbrenner. (Mandy Patinkin appears as Billy Martin's ghost.)
Should a visitor to Six Flags Jerry ever feel peckish, he can visit one of the 19 Tom's/Monk's Restaurants throughout the park. From tuna sandwiches to chicken sandwiches and, well, back again, guests can enjoy the same fine food the "Seinfeld" cast eats every week. (This is also the best place to spot long-gone characters like Baboo!) A recommendation? Try the big salad! And for those on a tighter budget, three words: strolling soup Nazis.
The park's centerpiece will be the multimillion-dollar Cosmo's Cosmos. Based on a map of Columbus Avenue and CAT scans of Kramer's brain, Cosmo's Cosmos will be the nation's first and only wall-to-wall virtual-reality experience. After obtaining releases from their physicians and lawyers, visitors will receive sharp blows to the head with a persimmon 3-wood wielded by Newman (Newman!) and set loose on the streets. For the next several days, they'll see the world as an actual hipster doofus does. (Field trips to vintage-clothing stores, driving range and fruit stand included.)
And Jerry Seinfeld himself? He'd make just one live appearance a week, Mondays at 2:30 P.M., arguing with the park's dry cleaner about a broken button on his puffy shirt. That alone ought to be worth the price of admission.
On second thought, forget it. Six Flags Jerry already exists; it's called the Upper West Side. And 's Shakespeare teaches us, "All the world's a stage, but the real money's in feature films."
