SECTION: Section 5; Page 10; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1790 words

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN:;
Lima

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS; CALVIN SIMS is chief of the Buenos Aires bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
At the beginning of the 1990's, few foreigners dared set foot in Peru for fear of terrorism, cholera and street crime, all of which were rampant throughout this Andean nation. But now, with Peru undergoing a dramatic turnaround in its political and economic situation, tourists are arriving in droves. Last year, a record 485,000 foreigners visited Peru, a 26 percent increase over 1994. Cholera is under control, terrorism is in decline with the capture of the leaders of the Shining Path movement, and the economy is on the rebound.
Last year, after a government crackdown brought a sharp drop in the number of terrorist attacks, the State Department stopped warning American tourists of the dangers of travel in Peru. Although a New York woman was recently sentenced to life in prison for her illicit association with a Peruvian terrorist group, State Department officials said Americans have nothing to fear in visiting Peru and interacting with its citizens.
 
 While most tourists travel to Peru to see the lost Inca city of Machu Picchu, visitors must first pass through Lima, the capital, which is undergoing a rebirth that many Peruvians hope will restore the luster that terrorism dimmed.
Nowhere is this renewal more evident than in the Miraflores, San Isidro and Barranco districts, which are buzzing day and night and are full of surprises. New art galleries, bars, restaurants, taverns and night spots have opened in these districts, and there is now an active night life where several years ago many Limenos did not venture out after dark.
The best time to visit is during the Southern Hemisphere's summer, now through April, when the city enjoys bright sunshine and cool nights. Although most tourists pass through without incident, street crime, especially pickpocketing and purse-snatching, are still common. Lima officials advise tourists to travel in groups, and not to wear flashy jewelry or otherwise call attention to themselves.
 
 
 
Events
 The Peru Negro Ballet, acclaimed in Europe and Latin America, symbolizes the best in Peruvian black music and dance and is performing this year at the Manos Morenas restaurant, (511) 467-4902, fax (511) 467-0421, 409 Pedro de Osma, in Barranco, on Wednesday and Thursday nights at 10. Admission is $15 and includes a typical meal of fish, seafood or stewed meats.
In Peru, the grape is a cherished fruit, the source of fine wines and a classic cocktail called the pisco sour, which is prepared with grape brandy, lemon, sugar, egg white and ice. No wonder Lima's working-class district of Surco holds an annual grape harvest festival. This year's, from March 13 to 20, includes wine tastings and street fairs. For information, call (511) 477-2325.
 The Instituto Riva Aguero, 459 Camana, will present an exhibit entitled "The Blacks of Peru" during March, from 2 to 8 P.M. Monday to Friday. The exhibit will recount the experiences of the first blacks to arrive in Peru from the Antilles and the Caribbean.
Cultural and artistic events are often announced only a week or two before they occur, so visitors are advised to check listings in The Lima Times, published on Friday.
 
 
 
Sightseeing
 The heart of the city is the Plaza de Armas, or main square, which contains a variety of Colonial government buildings and churches, notably the Government Palace, also called Pizarro's House, which has a colorful changing of the presidential guard at 12:30 P.M. The plaza also contains a spectacular 17th-century cathedral, open Monday to Friday, 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. and 2 to 5 P.M., and Saturday 10 A.M. to 3:45 P.M. The cathedral is outstanding for its intricately carved choir chairs, 17th-and 18th-century paintings, and altars. On the streets surrounding the plaza are many Colonial buildings with exquisite wooden balconies.
Lima has a striking coastline, called the Costa Verde even though it is actually brown and not green. The best view is at the end of Ave nida Larco in Miraflores, where the entire Pacific coastline from Chorrillos to La Punta is visible. Down below is a succession of beaches with sports fields, private clubs, discos and expensive restaurants. In summer the beaches are packed with sunbathers and surfers, though some of the waters are not clean.
Perhaps Lima's most romantic neighborhood is Barranco, once a wealthy beach resort and now home to many of Peru's best known artists and writers. Its tree-lined streets leading to the sea front, Colonial-style mansions and houses, and tranquil plazas evoke times past. The Puente de Los Suspiros (Bridge of Sighs) is a picturesque lookout.
A good way to experience Peruvian folk music and dancing is to visit a pena, a small night club, open from 11:30 P.M. till dawn. Popular ones are: Sachun, 657 Avenida del Ejercito, (511) 441-0123, Miraflores; Brisas del Titicaca, 168 Jr. Wakulski, (511) 423,7405; and La Estacion de Barranco, 112 Pedro de Osma, Barranco; no telephone. Admission is $5 to $10.
Lima has many celebrated museums, including the splendid National Museum of Anthropology and Archeology and the Museo de Oro, a dazzling collection of Inca and pre-Inca gold. The most impressive of Lima's many archeological sites is Pachacamac, a vast pre-Inca and Inca site 18 miles south of Lima on the Pan American Highway. The spot is dedicated to the Pachacamac god known as the maker of universe, and has a large adobe pyramid built in A.D. 1350, a reconstructed "temple of the virgins," and a small museum. Pachacamac is reachable by car or taxi or with tours arranged at major hotels and travel agencies. The ruins, (511) 430-5607, are open daily from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission $1.50; there are guided tours in English.
If you fancy hand-carved, Colonial wooden furniture of the style that once graced Peru's castles and fine houses, visit the Taller de Arte Colonial, 110 Malecon Castilla in Barranco, (511) 467-7589. This factory, open Monday to Saturday 9 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. and from 3 to 7 P.M., has an impressive collection of chairs, chests, dining tables, picture frames, and other furniture at reasonable prices. Visitors can watch the craftsman at work or view a superb model collection of wooden passenger jets representing the major airlines of the world.
 
 
 
Where to Stay
 All hotel prices in Peru are subject to a value added tax of 28 percent.
The 134 spacious, pastel-toned rooms at El Olivar, 122 Merino, (511) 221-2121, fax (511) 221-2141, in a tranquil section of Miraflores, have a view of the Olivar Forest. Doubles are $180.
At Hotel Ariosto, 769 La Paz, Miraflores, (511) 444-1414, fax (511) 444-3955, a double room with breakfast and tax is $147. The clean, efficient hotel has a small but inviting lobby and 110 rooms simply decorated with Colonial furniture.
The Lima Sheraton, 170 Paseo de la Republica, (511) 433-3320, fax (511) 433-6344, has 498 rooms, at $185 for a double. It is downtown in a noisy, high-crime section.
Budget: The 83 rooms of Hotel Jose Antonio, 298 Avenida 28 de Julio, Miraflores, (511) 446-8295, fax (511) 446-6705, have double or king-size beds and basic furniture. Rooms on the seventh and eight floors have views of the ocean. The lobby is modern, with large windows. A double costs $121, including tax.
El Marques Hotel, 461 Chinchon, San Isidro, (511) 442-0047, fax (511) 442-0043, has 42 Spanish-style rooms with Colonial furniture. The hotel is in a quiet residential neighborhood but close to a commercial center. A double is $85.
Luxury: Hotel Las Americas, 415 Avenida Benavides, (511) 444-7272, fax (511) 444-1137, is a modern high-rise, centrally situated in the garden suburb of Miraflores. It has 151 pastel-colored rooms with teak furniture and Peruvian prints. The lobby bar and fifth-floor lounge are cozy. The hotel has a small gym and pool, and is a short walk to the beach. A double is $236, including tax.
Cesar's, corner of La Paz and Diez Canseco, (511) 444-1212, fax (511) 444-4440, is a quiet luxury hotel with a spacious lobby, homey tea room, a pool and sauna in Miraflores near shopping and business districts. Its 150 rooms have traditional wood and leather furniture. A double is $262, including tax.
 
 
 
Where to Eat
 Peru has a rich, diverse cuisine dating back to the ancient Incas, with Spanish, African, Chinese, Italian, Japanese and European influences. There are dozens of variations of spicy fish, shellfish, stewed meat, tamale and potato dishes. In the past few years, many excellent restaurants have opened in Lima.
Francesco, 524 Malecon de la Marina, (511) 442-8255, overlooking the beach in Miraflores, serves innovative seafood dishes. The seafood lasagna, fish in cognac sauce and octopus tamale are exceptional. Francesco is open Monday to Saturday noon to 5 P.M. A meal for two including drinks is about $50.
For ancient Lima cuisine, El Senorio de Sulco, 1470 Malecon Cisneros, (511) 441-0389, offers a sampler that includes cau-cau (tripe and potato stew), olluquito (a spicy vegetable stew), and sangrecita and frijoles (bull's blood and beans). The owner is an anthropologist devoted to preserving traditional Peruvian cooking. The restaurant, which has a grand ocean view and terrace, is open daily noon to midnight. Dinner for two with wine is about $60.
Costa Verde, Barranquito Beach in Barranco, (511) 477-2424, considered one of the best international restaurants in Lima, is right on the ocean. It has an enormous and varied buffet and also serves classic dishes like ceviches (sliced raw fish seasoned and marinated in lemon juice). The restaurant is open daily, noon to midnight, and dinner for two with wine is about $180.
Lima has hundreds of chifas -- restaurants serving Chinese food with a local twist. Royal, 231 Avenida Prescott, San Isidro, (511) 442-9547, serves Cantonese-Peruvian cuisine and is open daily 11 A.M. to midnight. Try the chicken rolls filled with asparagus in oyster sauce. A meal for two is $70, including wine.
Peruvians love chicken, especially roasted or fried, and Pardo's Chicken, 730 Avenida Benavides, (511) 446-4790, has a reputation for preparing some of the best. A complete chicken meal, with beer and dessert, costs about $17. Open Monday to Thursday and Sunday, noon to midnight; Friday and Saturday noon to 1 A.M.
From January to April, ice cream is an event unto itself at 4D (Cuatro D), 400 Avenida Angamos, (511) 447-1523, Miraflores. This ice cream factory and parlor offers rare fruits like maracuya, granadilla and guanabana, many of them available only in Peru because they are too fragile to ship abroad. A cone of this soft ambrosia costs about $1.50. Open Monday to Thursday and Sunday 8 A.M. to 12:30 A.M., and Friday and Saturday 9 A.M. to 1 A.M.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Chicago to Show Lincoln Collection

BYLINE: By JENNIFER WEITZMAN 

 BODY:
The Chicago Historical Society will be host to a yearlong exhibition of one of the largest and most comprehensive collections of Lincoln memorabilia ever assembled, "The Last Best Hope of Earth: Abraham Lincoln and the Promise of America." The exhibition will open tomorrow, on Lincoln's Birthday.
"The Last Best Hope" encompasses more than 200 objects, including Lincoln's stovepipe hat, the gloves Lincoln wore the night he was assassinated, a Gettysburg Address manuscript, nearly 100 letters and documents written by Lincoln, political campaign memorabilia and personal possessions. 
 In addition to the special exhibition, visitors may view the society's permanent exhibition "A House Divided: America in the Age of Lincoln," which explores slavery, the division of free and slave economies and the Civil War.
"The Last Best Hope" exhibition will be highlighted with such programs as a free lecture series by Lincoln scholars every other Tuesday evening, beginning March 12, gallery performances of the Lincoln-Douglas debates and Lincoln's speeches and writings.
The exhibition will be open daily. Admission is $7, $4 for children 12 and under. The Chicago Historical Society, (312) 642-5035, is on Clark Street at North Avenue on the south end of Lincoln Park. JENNIFER WEITZMAN

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
Quiet, Tender Moments Of Urban Melancholy

BYLINE: By Vicki Goldberg 

 BODY:
IF YOU DO NOT KNOW Roy DeCarava's name, you are probably in the majority. His only previous retrospective in a New York museum was 25 years ago at the Studio Museum in Harlem, although he has had shows since then in other cities, and even one in Sweden. A book of his photographs was published in 1981, and "The Sweet Flypaper of Life," his 1955 collaboration with Langston Hughes, was reprinted in 1984. Other than that, not much. He has been very particular about the conditions under which he would exhibit his work, so perhaps this neglect is not entirely th' fault of an ignorant world.
Whatever the reason for so glaring an absence, it has been amply repaired at the Museum of Modern Art with 184 pictures in "Roy DeCarava: A Retrospective," organized by Peter Galassi, chief curator of photography. (After the show closes on May 7, it will travel to Chicago, Los Angeles, St. Louis, Houston, San Francisco, Atlanta, Washington and Andover, Mass.) 
 This large dose of black-and-white photo graphs represents close to a half-century of continuous endeavor. The pictures, seldom grand in subject or sweep, are quiet, poised, bafflingly dark, suffused with stillness: glimmers of domestic gentleness and recurrent melancholy in metropolitan life. (Appropriately Metropolitan Life Foundation is the major sponsor of the show.)
They do not falter often, except perhaps in the nature studies and the more consciously arty pictures; most of them quietly and surely distill personality and emotional temperature from minor gesture and unthinking stance. In addition, DeCarava reads the city's small secrets as it goes about its business unawares, and comes in so close that everything outside his concentration falls away$ He has a knowing way with both acerbity and symbolism, but his tone is generally one of tender affection for, or resigned acceptance of, a decidedly imperfect world.
That world is mostly, though not exclusively, where blacks live and work. Roy DeCarava, an African-American and lifelong resident of New York City, has trained his lens primarily on black experience and to a lesser extent on city life in general. Today it is hardly unusual for black photographer-artists like Carrie Mae Weems and Adrian Piper to comment on African-American life and history, but DeCarava came out of an essentially silent era.
Born in 1919 and aware that he wanted to be an artist from the age of 9, he was a painter and printmaker of images of black life before switching to photography in the late 1940's. There were not many black photographers at the time, other than studio photographers like James VanDerZee and the late Austin Hansen, who performed a valuable function but made no claim to art. They were little known outside their community until the civil-rights movement and the "Harlem on My Mind" show at the Metropolitan Museum in 1969 brought black cultural history to the world's attention. Just about the only black photographer with any claim to national prominence in the 1940's and 50's was Gordon Parks, portraitist and photojournalist; art photographers were virtually unknown.
In fact, photojournalism and art photography were seldom ambitions of African-Americans until quite recently. Photography is an expensive habit and has not been much more available than tennis to city children of any color who were not solidly middle-class. Besides, there were not many role models to look up to. In 1952, DeCarava was the first black photographer to win a Guggenheim fellowship; one wonders how many had applied before. Black artists did not even regard photography as an art. As recently as 1993, Romare Bearden and Harry Henderson's history of African-American artists did not mention DeCarava.
Then there was his choice of subject matter. Harlem had been photographed frequently but, as his wife, Sherry Turner DeCarava, points out in her essay in the exhibition catalogue, only for commercial and documentary reasons. In his Guggenheim application, DeCarava wrote, "I do not want a documentary or sociological statement, I want a creative expression, the kind of penetrating insight and understanding of Negroes which I believe only a Negro photographer can interpret."
Of course, the camera is a documentary instrument by its very nature, but DeCarava's personal archives consist of interior states and evidence of individual character culled from the most minor and unexpected clues: the way a man plants his feet or climbs a stair, the distance between two people.
The question of whether only a black could tell the true story of Harlem I leave to those embroiled in the controversy over whether only a black director could film the life of Malcolm X (and who were unhappy with the movie). But DeCarava certainly had extraordinary access and shared experience, none of which would have mattered so much had he not had the talent as well.
DeCarava also wrote in his grant application that he wanted "to show the strength, the wisdom, the dignity of the Negro people." Like all insightful observations of groups, this enterprise ended up illuminating the human condition. His pictures of domestic life in the tenements are a fond poem to the tangled sweetness of family and daily existence. They moved Langston Hughes to write a story about a woman who refuses St. Peter's messenger because she wants to see "what this integration the Supreme Court has done decreed is going to be like."
DeCarava himself suffered plenty from discrimination and astutely compresses this communal history into individual glancing encounters on the street. "Boy, Man and Graffiti," 1966, catches a white boy moving forward, a black man turning his head, his mouth open in uncertainty, and a crudely drawn, weeping skull. In "Woman, White Scarf," 1961, a white woman seen up close in the light is wrapped in chiffon and smugness; a black woman's face, furrowed with worries, fills the darkness just behind her.
DeCarava clearly understood the aspirations, obstacles and psychological costs his subjects encountered; better still, he knew how to inscribe them within a small rectangle in a fragile state of poise. In "Graduation," 1949, a girl in a long dress and gloves walks in a wedge of sunlight past the litter and rubble of an abandoned lot; in the shadow she heads toward, a Chevrolet advertisement says "Style Star of an All-Star Line."
He understood the nature of achievement as well; witness a series of fine portraits of jazz musicians. Louis Armstrong, duded up, strides gigantically down a Harlem street with his mouth open in joy, a king sashaying across his concrete kingdom. "Coltrane on Soprano" shows the great saxophonist pouring his soul into his instrument, which has mutated into a dancing flicker of lights.
DeCarava's desire to show "the strength, the wisdom, the dignity of the Negro people" was the direct outgrowth of the first movement to proclaim black beautiful, in the first quarter of this century. As blacks moved out of the South en masse and discovered that discrimination was very much alive in the North as well, a heightened sense of common identity developed. Cutting across economic and class distinctions, this feeling of racial community helped foster a movement to establish the value of black culture for blacks and whites alike.
THE HARLEM RENAISSANCE of the 1920's, with its outburst of African-American writers and artists, was one result. In 1928, as George Hutchinson points out in his recent book, "The Harlem Renaissance in Black and White," the editor of the National Urban League's magazine said in a speech that younger black Americans had a "compulsion to find a new beauty in their own lives, ideals and feelings."
"The new generation of Negro writers and artists have led the way," the editor continued. For the poets among them, no life is without beauty and no beginning too low.
DeCarava, born as this movement was taking shape, was its natural heir. As he came of age in the 1930's, black visual artists were coming into their own. In 1935, the Museum of Modern Art mounted the first major American museum show of African art, a source of great pride among blacks. And in 1937, the Baltimore Museum of Art put on the first museum show of black American artists.
The Works Progress Administration, a Federally financed program, supported black artists as well (or as minimally) as white ones during the Depression and gave them long-denied opportunities for expert training and immersion in current esthetic issues. DeCarava himself obtained a position in the W.P.A. and for a time went to the Harlem Community Art Center, a genuinely communal center for all the arts, including drama and literature.
Once he found photography, in the 1940's, he gravitated toward a distinctive range of middle tones, nearly eliminating black. Such grays! Graphite and charcoal, the world seen through a glass darkly, the subjects slowly emerging to view, with gleams of isolated light like revelations, on a hand, a hanger, a watch band. Some of his pictures are so dark as to court invisibility; there are mysteries there that the glass over these pictures unfortunately makes even more difficult to plumb.
Yet the darkness speaks. "Hallway" is an image of an underlighted, dirty, slightly menacing tenement hall; somehow DeCarava has extracted a mournful lyricism from this unlikely source. He once said that he himself didn't understand how this thing that was "ugly and brutalizing" had turned into a beautiful photograph. He decided that the process was "part of the seduction that's involved in art, I think, when you start with reality and make something else of it." This is something else -- and so is DeCarava.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Through a Glass, Darkly "Coltrane on Soprano," 1963, above, and "Hallway," 1953, by Roy DeCarava -- In fleeting and fragile moments, the photographer has captured the aspirations, obstacles and psychological costs his subjects encountered.; "Boy, Man and Graffiti," 1966, by Roy DeCarava -- Compressing communal history into glancing encounters on the street. (Photographs from the DeCarava Archive courtesy of the Museum of Modern Art)

HEADLINE: FILM;
Into the Municipal Maelstrom

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
Ken Lipper, New York City's (and maybe the world's) best-connected screenwriter, tells a story about his introduction to the relentless deal-making that goes on behind the scenes in municipal politics, the milieu of his new film, "City Hall."
The year was 1983, and the scene was a small Italian restaurant in Greenwich Village. Mr. Lipper, just appointed deputy mayor for economic development by Edward I. Koch, had been invited to lunch by the legendary party boss of Brooklyn, Meade H. Esposito. 
 "An absolutely charming man, expansive, sweet, funny, a little wicked, one of the more beguiling people you'd want to meet," says Mr. Lipper, who has been a lawyer, investment banker, philanthropist, chief executive and gazillionaire -- not, in other words, someone likely to need a beginner's lesson in anything.
But Esposito saw otherwise. His agenda that day, apparently, was to persuade Mr. Lipper to support a city subsidy for a Brooklyn boat builder, Coastal Dry Dock, which was threatening to leave New York for Alabama unless it received help in paying its electrical bills. But Esposito barely mentioned Coastal, except, Mr. Lipper recalls, for a brief moment of gentle pressure: " 'Ken,' he said, 'I'm not telling you what to do, but you should at least go out and meet with them. They're good people, Ken. They're citizens. They pay taxes. You've got to give them an electricity break, or we're going to lose all these jobs to Tuscaloosa."
Mr. Lipper says he told Esposito merely that Coastal would be given a fair hearing, and when the waitress brought the $38 check, well over the $5 limit on gratuities that officials were allowed to accept, Esposito tried to sign it.
Mr. Lipper picks up the story: "I say, 'You can't pay for that,' and he says, 'O.K., you made your point. Now be courteous. I invited you.' I say, 'That's all well and good, but you can't pay for it.' So he looks up at the waitress, gives the check back, and says: 'Put a cutlet in the bag for the wife. The jerk's paying.' "
As a rebuke, it was wry but firm: learn the rules, kid. But Mr. Lipper recalls it as a characteristic moment: "I don't want to give the impression that I'm above anything, but there is no limit to how careful you can be."
That is precisely the lesson of Mr. Lipper's screenplay.
In the film, which opens on Friday and stars Al Pacino as the Mayor of New York, a casual political favor involving a fixed probation report for a mob-related drug dealer is exposed when the dealer is killed in a shootout that also claims the lives of a police officer and a child. Well-intentioned people and substantial lives in public service are destroyed because of back-room deals that seemed harmless when they were made.
(Although Mr. Lipper's original ideas for the story dominate the film, his actual words do not. Several screenwriters followed him on "City Hall," and Mr. Lipper took the issue of who should get credit to the Writers Guild of America for arbitration. In the end, he prevailed. The credit reads, "Written by Ken Lipper and Paul Schrader & Nicholas Pileggi and Bo Goldman.")
In addition to Mr. Pacino, the $45 million film, directed by Harold Becker (whose credits include "Sea of Love"), stars John Cusack as the idealistic Lipper-like Deputy Mayor, Bridget Fonda as a lawyer for the slain police officer's family, Martin Landau as an unfortunate, beleaguered judge, and Danny Aiello as the Brooklyn party boss, based in part on Esposito and in part on Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President who committed suicide after his involvement in a 1988 corruption scandal was revealed.
Mayor Koch has a small role as a television commentator, and Mr. Lipper makes a cameo as the City Council president. The casting is ironic in that Mr. Lipper left the Mayor's office in 1985 after only two years to run for the council presidency (a job now called public advocate) and, after a vitriolic campaign on both sides, was soundly beaten by Andrew Stein.
"This time I got the job by acclaim," says Mr. Lipper, and it's hard not to note that he has himself corrected history in a rare instance over the last 30 years when his confidence -- even hubris -- has not been rewarded with success.
Ken Lipper, the second son of a Bronx shoe salesman, won a full scholarship to Columbia, graduated from Harvard Law School, changed careers after six months as a lawyer, earning a partnership at the Lehman Brothers investment bank at age 31, and, in 1976, moved to Salomon Brothers, quadrupling his salary.
Living in the upper echelons of power, Mr. Lipper is now a Rockefeller Brothers Fund trustee, and his own investment concern, Lipper & Company, begun in 1986 to handle his family's money, manages $3 billion in assets.
He is a consultant to the Clinton Administration on the Federal budget, and his friends (according to a list he provides) include former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, Senators Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina (who has a role in "City Hall"), and the actor Michael Douglas and the director Oliver Stone, with whom he worked as a consultant on the 1987 film "Wall Street." Since then he has entered a film production business in partnership with Edward R. Pressman, the veteran producer of "Wall Street"; together, they produced "City Hall."
And that isn't all. Overwhelmingly successful financially, Mr. Lipper married money before he made it. He met his wife, Evelyn Gruss, on a blind date while he was at Harvard Law School and she was a freshman at Simmons College. (She is now the head of the child development division at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center; they have been married nearly 30 years and have four daughters.) The philanthropic donations of her father, Joseph Gruss, an oil and gas magnate who had escaped the Nazis in Poland, totaled more than $300 million at his death in 1993.
 Mr. Lipper entered politics in 1982 when, at the behest of the consultant David Garth, he joined Mr. Koch's unsuccessful campaign for Governor as an economics adviser. He was named to the administration during the second of the Mayor's three terms. It was a time when the city had just emerged from economic crisis, and Mr. Lipper was charged, in the words of Paul Dickstein, then the city's deputy budget director, "with jump-starting an economic development program."
To a significant extent, he succeeded. It was the height of the real estate boom in Manhattan; commercial space was at a premium, rents were soaring and businesses were being driven off to the foreign ports of New Jersey and Connecticut. Mr. Lipper's strategy was to develop commercial office space in the boroughs outside Manhattan, using tax breaks and other subsidies to interest builders and lure companies to the new buildings.
Among other things, he was a strong advocate of Teleport, a Staten Island industrial park built around a telecommunications center. Planned since 1979, it was to open in 1983, but in a move that Mr. Koch cites as typical of his deputy mayor's aggressive supervision of the city coffers, Mr. Lipper single-handedly held up the project for a year in order to renegotiate a nearly done deal with the city's co-developers, p'rticularly the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The Port Authority was then headed by Peter Goldmark, now president of the Rockefeller Foundation.
"Peter Goldmark was going to walk all over us, and Ken wouldn't let him," Mr. Koch says.
Perhaps not surprising, it was a success that came with a reputation for arrogance. Among his chief critics is Mr. Goldmark, who to this day is blistering in his private assessment, although he will not speak about Mr. Lipper on the record at all except to say that the version of the Teleport story that casts Mr. Lipper as the hero "is not at all accurate."
"City Hall" is after a high degree of verisimilitude. For the first time, the actual City Hall building was rented as a film set, the result of a policy-reversing decision last year by its chief inhabitants, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the Speaker of the City Council, Peter Vallone. (The $50,000 fee is being applied to renovations at City Hall.) And it was Mr. Lipper, still a senior adviser to the City Council, who made sure the actors had access to the local denizens, including the Mayor.
Mr. Cusack, who took time to observe the behavior of some New York political specimens while preparing for his role, was struck by their passion for secrecy. "Whenever they go to meetings, or to a breakfast or anywhere, they shake hands, hold on and whisper," he said. "There's always some exchange. It's like a virus all these people have -- always a handshake and then a close, ear-to-ear whisper -- people telling secrets all the time, right in front of everyone."
There are limits, however. Mr. Cusack says he isn't really playing Mr. Lipper; indeed, his character, Kevin Calhoun, an Irishman from Louisiana, is hardly a Bronx Jew. One of the film's running jokes is that Kevin has a hard time with the Yiddishisms he hears around him, particularly menschkeit, literally "a man's code of behavior," used to refer to the unspoken rules by which politicans conduct their bargaining.
"It was a word Stanley Friedman always used to use," Mr. Lipper says, referring to the former Bronx Democratic leader who went to jail in 1988 for his illegal involvement in the sale of computer software to the city's Parking Violations Bureau, the same scandal that brought down Mr. Manes.
And even though Mr. Pacino borrowed from Mr. Koch the mannerism of riding in the Mayoral limousine with his head tilted back in exhaustion, his character, John Pappas, is not modeled on Mr. Koch. The paradigm, Mr. Lipper says, is not a mayor at all but Creon, the tragic monarch from Sophocles' "Antigone," whose impossible choice is to yield his authority as king or put to death his beloved niece for willfully defying a cruel edict.
Characteristically grandiose, Mr. Lipper says he conceived the theme of "City Hall" after seeing a performance of "Antigone" Off Off Broadway in 1988. "It suddenly struck me: that's the core of government experience," he says. "He orders her to death, against all of his feelings, all of his will, but he does it to prevent anarchy. He has great moments of ambivalence. It was that sense of frustration versus duty that intrigued me about the government."
Kevin Calhoun may not be Ken Lipper, but there is a scene in "City Hall" in which the script credits the character with the same tenacity and righteousness. In it, Frank Anselmo, the Brooklyn party boss, calls Kevin "a reed."
"Blow on him, and he bends," Anselmo says. To which the mobster replies: "Not this kid. This one's different."
Kevin, of course, is the story's hero. Which brings us back to Meade Esposito. At some point after their notable lunch, Mr. Lipper took up the case of Coastal Dry Dock, in the end denying the pleas of both Esposito and another advocate in the case, Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx, for the city to grant the company an energy subsidy.
Eventually, Coastal went out of business, leaving a $300 million Pentagon contract unfulfilled, and Esposito was convicted of bribing Mr. Biaggi. But not until Esposito's trial in 1988 did the world learn that at about the same time he'd had lunch with Mr. Lipper, Esposito had paid for a Florida vacation for Mr. Biaggi; the jury ruled the vacation was an illegal gratuity for Mr. Biaggi's attempted influence on behalf of Coastal Dry Dock. That's why Esposito and Mr. Biaggi went to jail.
During Esposito's trial, Mr. Lipper was called to the stand. Among other things, he was asked: who paid for the lunch?

HEADLINE: BOOKEND;
My Life: A Proposal

BYLINE: By Polly Frost; Polly Frost reviews movies for Elle magazine and is currently working on a play.

 BODY:
TODAY marks the beginning of the 10th year I've spent on my novel "Dripping." Still convinced it will encompass everything I've learned from Chekhov, those exquisite small epiphanies in which nothing happens and all is revealed. To think there are those who don't realize how hard it is to achieve this mixture of mysterious everyday realism and emotional reticence! Especially in a passage like this:
He was setting down the money for his drink and putting on his coat. She had no reason to be happy, for he had just told her he didn't love her, and yet she heard the music from the jukebox and saw the lights from the taxis on the avenue and she felt overjoyed. Thank God she had remembered to take her Paxil. 
 Then I hit my readers with scenes of senseless East Village crimes and unprotected sex.
Ready to discuss novel with Michael, agent extraordinaire -- at least the three chapters so far finished. Phone machine tells me to contact him on AOL. When did publishing get so up-to-date? Send E-mail reminding him who I am; he messages back a time we can meet in a private chat room.
Downloaded transcript follows:
Michael: The market moves on. Even five years ago you could still get away with the downtown Manhattan female sex thing. But the only literary form I can sell now is the memoir.
Me: Memoir! I thought that was something you did at the end of an august literary life.
Michael: Today it's the best way to start a career. Think "The Liars' Club," by Mary Karr. Think Susanna Kaysen's "Girl, Interrupted." Readers are interested in:
l real lives
l real traumas
l real dysfunctionalities.
So work with me here. Have you ever been
(1) raped?
(2) abused by a family member?
(3) institutionalized?
Me: No, no and no. But I am beginning to feel extremely depressed.
Michael: I can't take on any books about depression. It's been overdone. Get back to me when you have something we can work with.
Take to my bed. 2 A.M.: Wake up with the chilling thought that I may be in this studio apartment in Murray Hill forever. Begin reviewing my existence in Michael's terms. Start by trying to remember the names of my childhood playmates. . . . Realize that I became a writer to escape reality.
Time for an amorous break from my literary anxieties! Should I meet with RufNReady on AOL or CarverFan on Echo? CarverFan great on lit chat, but his idea of foreplay is to ask if I can get my agent to look at his book proposal. Opt for Ruf: says he's a grizzled 45-year-old Wyoming woodsman, my very own Legend of the Fall. We've had sex in every possible cyberposition. Only downside is Ruf's postcoital habit of rhapsodizing about Dean Koontz. No, I admit, I didn't know that the villain of "Whispers" became a psychopath because he'd been locked up in a cellar with thousands of roaches. Ruf lets slip that he also admires R. L. Stine. Could my wild guy be a few years younger than he's claiming?
Ruf messages that he must sign off, while I remain hungry for more. Log on to Echo and search for CarverFan. He coaxes me into a heated discussion about how big an advance Mary Karr will get next time. Thank God for literate people!
Set to work. Buy copies of Karr and Kaysen. What to do about guilt feelings? Normally support local independent store but can't resist 30 percent off at Barnes & Noble.
What I need to include:
l no-holds-barred truthfulness
l opening shocker
l mean relatives (make sure they're dead -- so can't sue)
l description of depressing childhood home
l major trauma.
Review own background.
Drawbacks:
l Mom never hit me
l Dad never jailed, never drank too much, never abused me
l never a teen-age bulimic, anorexic or alcoholic
l never slashed wrists
l never had a vicious dog that was taken away to die.
Usable:
l Mom made me wear lots of pale orange clothes -- a color that makes me look sallow
l Mrs. Felson, baby sitter who forced me to watch reruns of "Lawrence Welk"
l was chronic cookie-dough eater
l dog refused to participate in musical I wrote for her to star in, called "Snoozy in Paris."
How confusing it is to be a professional writer.
Examining my nonlife, realize I must be repressing horrible secret that would fascinate millions of readers, and visit trauma recovery specialist. Miraculously, she elicits painful, hidden memory:
I am a child who has been left in a strange place. There are other children here. We are all wearing rags and eating porridge. I am so hungry that when I finish mine I get up and ask an adult for more. And then there is singing all around me. . . .
Have breakthrough sex-and-lit chat with CarverFan. Says I have every reason to hate my family. According to CF, there is no greater cruelty than banality. How dare my parents not give me anything to write about!
5 A.M. Wake up at desk. Eeeeeek: never logged off. There goes budget -- will have to take review copies to Strand. E-mail proposal to Michael. Download follows:
My memoir will knock every other autobiographical account off the shelves and onto the remainder table. I am going to expose the kind of trauma that can force a child to withdraw completely from the world and into her imagination. This is the book that will tell all about what I confidently predict will be the hottest of all dysfunctionalities: fiction addiction.
Here's a sample passage:
"Don't leave me with Mrs. Felson, Mom, please!" But it was no use. Mother was determined to go to the PTA meeting.
I grabbed "Nancy Drew" and ran to my room.
Highlights will include:
My Lasting Scars.
A Metaphor for America -- I can't think of a better one than my mom's Sting Ray convertible.
A Major Revelation -- My parents recently confessed that they hired Mrs. Felson because she charged less than other sitters. They claim they put the money they saved in a college fund, but I have evidence that they used it to get away for a weekend in Hawaii.
"I can't possibly sell this," Michael responds.
Despair. Must retreat from city and repair artistic soul. But last time was in Adirondacks ran into no one but neo-Luddites with anti-technology book proposals. So log on to AOL and beg Ruf to let me share his mountain existence with him for a while. Make love again and again, until my carpal tunnel syndrome returns. Ruf logs off, telling me there's a bear in his cabin. I suspect it's really his mom.
Return from cyberwilderness experience refreshed and determined. New plan: platform my personality across multiple media. Adaptability is everything in the new literary economy!
E-mail proposal to Michael:
This is the TV lit talk show that will combine the best of Charlie Rose and Sally Jessy Raphael.
POSSIBLE FIRST SHOW LINEUP:
l Judith Regan
l Michael Korda
l Sonny Mehta.
THE ANGLE: I won't interview them; they'll interview me. Every show will be full of Chekhovian epiphanies about my life.
Log off, confident that Michael won't be able to resist. Feel usual post-triumph lustiness. CarverFan or RufNReady? Decide to go with Ruf. So what if he's 12? He knows how to handle a real woman.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 28; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1252 words

HEADLINE: Radically Chic

BYLINE: By Dorothy Gallagher; Louise Bryant: beautiful, smart, ambitious and inclined to scandalous behavior.

 BODY:

QUEEN OF BOHEMIA
The Life of Louise Bryant.
By Mary V. Dearborn.
Illustrated. 365 pp. Boston:
Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.
"I do wish sometimes I were as shallow as a Louise Bryant; everything would be so simple." This is a line of Emma Goldman's, written in 1922. Her reference is to her own overwhelming sense of tragedy at the course of the Bolshevik Revolution, and to Bryant's blithe response to the same events. 
 This is real disdain, not even personal but generic. And since Goldman was not alone among Bryant's contemporaries in her opinion, Mary V. Dearborn, the author of "Queen of Bohemia: The Life of Louise Bryant" and no disinterested scholar, sees the existence of a conspiracy of envy, meanspiritedness and "gender politics" to keep Bryant from her rightful place in history. Ms. Dearborn contends that "a great irony is at work here: in spite of, or even because of, her great contemporary impact, her presence has barely been recorded" by history. "Recovering her story," Ms. Dearborn promises, "discovers a true 20th-century heroine . . . who has, ironically, been overlooked by traditional history and nearly lost to legend."
Not so. Louise Bryant's life is well documented. But I also confess here to a weakness for Emma Goldman (accused of many things, but never before of meanspiritedness to my knowledge), and also to an aversion to the promiscuous use of irony.
Louise Bryant was born in San Francisco in 1885 and raised in Nevada. Her social and economic circumstances were fairly marginal. Bryant (she used her stepfather's name) grew up to be a bold young woman, beautiful, smart, ambitious and inclined to scandalous behavior. Ms. Dearborn sees her as a natural freethinker struggling against the bonds of bourgeois morality.
In 1909, after college, Bryant went to Portland, Ore., where she landed a job on the weekly Spectator, covering the doings of the city's elite. That same year she married Paul Trullinger, a dentist from a rich, prominent family. Ms. Dearborn admits that his money and status were not unimportant to Bryant: "For if Louise was a freethinker, she could also be a bit of a social climber." This is not, Ms. Dearborn quickly adds, "as contradictory as it seems at first consideration." Because "as much as she wanted to be free of social convention, she recognized that it was easier to do so if you were thought to come from a 'good' background. On one level, she could simply get away with a lot more. On another, she had determined at an early age to improve her lot, and if vaulting ahead in class would enable her to do that more easily, she had no problem with it." Am I missing something here? Are there two kinds of social climber?
As a young matron, Bryant maintained a separate studio in downtown Portland, kept her job and gave martini-drinking and ether-sniffing parties in her husband's office. But she was restless. She had made some connection to the world of radical bohemians through the woman suffrage movement, and also through Portland's resident libertarian, Charles Erskine Scott Wood. When John Reed, who had been a protg of Wood's, came to Portland at the end of 1915, Bryant made a play for him. He was already a celebrated radical journalist, dashing and romantic. Bryant was 31, told him she was 27, and gave him the strong impression that she was a woman who had achieved prodigious artistic and professional success. They began a love affair and she soon left Dr. Trullinger in her dust.
Bryant joined Jack Reed in Greenwich Village in the first days of 1916. Far from being lost to history, her life among the Village radicals and bohemians shows up in many biographies of the period and has even made its way into the movie "Reds": her tumultuous four-year marriage to Reed, her involvement with the Provincetown Players, her affairs with Eugene O'Neill and others. (She overcame O'Neill's reluctance to betray his good friend by telling him that Reed was impotent; when Jack confessed to a brief infidelity of his own, she became totally distraught and brought the marriage to a crisis, all the while continuing with her own affairs.)
In August 1917, a reconciled Louise and Jack sailed for Russia. From this trip came Reed's classic "Ten Days That Shook the World" and Bryant's "Six Red Months in Russia" (she was actually there only four months). Her book has gullible schoolgirl charm and inherent interest as a document, though it is not a serious work of reference.
Ms. Dearborn, however, strains to take it very seriously. Referring to one of Louise's typically hyperbolic assertions, she writes that it "may seem like an overstatement; it may even have seemed so to Louise as she made it." But, she adds, Bryant "may have found that to her delight and amazement it might well have been true." To which one can only say, "Huh?"
Bryant came back from Russia by herself, ahead of Reed, and at once began an unsuccessful attempt to renew her affair with O'Neill. Again Ms. Dearborn offers one of her bemused analyses: "Although her actions usually had an internal, idiosyncratic logic, at various points in her life they appear bizarre or inexplicable."
Bryant was now a celebrated authority on Soviet Russia. Her book had been published, she was writing for the Hearst papers and, in a political atmosphere increasingly hostile to Bolshevism and home-grown radicals, she made speaking tours on behalf of the Revolution and of woman suffrage.
Jack Reed died of typhus in Moscow in 1920. Bryant was with him at the end, soon to be comforted by none other than Emma Goldman. After Reed's death she continued as a journalist for a time. (Ms. Dearborn tells us that Bryant's observations in Russia were more trustworthy than Goldman's, since "they were backed up by interviews with Soviet officials themselves"!) But her life had been shunted onto another track. At the end of 1923, when she was pregnant with their daughter, she married the very rich and social William Bullitt.
Ms. Dearborn is uneasy about this marriage. Has her heroine reverted to social climbing? "But was it really weakness to want to live well?" Ms. Dearborn wonders. "Though it seems at odds with her feminism, Louise cannot be faulted for participating in a reigning ideology that assessed a woman's worth according to her husband's."
Married to Bullitt (who thought she was 29; she was 38 by then), Bryant lived the life of a rich man's wife: houses, servants, parties, clothes. She drank too much. In Paris, she began an affair with Gwen Le Gallienne, a sculptor, and her marriage ended in a horrendous divorce. She developed the rare and disfiguring Dercum's disease. She lost custody of her daughter. She lost control of Jack Reed's papers. In the end she was a pathetic Paris character, telling stories of past and imagined glory. In 1936, at the age of 50, she died in a $2-a-night hotel.
No special pleading is needed to write Louise Bryant's biography. Hers was a theatrical life, filled with drama and tragedy, fascinating people and great events; it has an interestingly flawed protagonist. In fact, it has been written before, by Virginia Gardner, whose research seems to form the basis of Ms. Dearborn's book. What is original with Ms. Dearborn, the author of a life of Henry Miller, is some sort of feminist-radical agenda, but her arguments are so contorted (mirth-provoking, even) that they are a disservice to any political cause she might have in mind. Let's not even mention history or literature.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 6; Column 3; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1957 words

HEADLINE: She Made Them Dance

BYLINE: By Joan Acocella; Joan Acocella, the author of "Mark Morris," is now editing the English translation of Vaslav Nijinsky's diary.

 BODY:
One seldom has cause, these days, to complain that a new biography of a woman makes insufficient use of the gender card, but Carol Easton's life of Agnes de Mille is one of those rare occasions. In the 1940's, de Mille was, by her own account, "the best-known choreographer in America -- not the best, but the best known." Dance is a woman's field, but as de Mille pointed out, it was ceded to women only because men didn't consider it important enough to reserve it for themselves. Furthermore, the area in which she made her deepest mark was not concert dance, the women's preserve, but musical comedy a genre more dominated by men -- men who, furthermore, regarded dancing as employment for the backer's girlfriends. De Mille's struggle to be taken seriously in that world is a classic women's tale.
 She was born, in 1905, into an eminent family. Her grandfather was the famous economist Henry George; her father, a successful playwright and screenwriter; her uncle, Cecil B. De Mille. As she grew, she developed an excellent mind, a big nose and a rather trying personality -- combative, demanding, complaining. (In later years, several people, without consulting one another, nicknamed her Agony de Mille.) She spent her teen-age years sitting out the cotillion and writing poems and stories that her father critiqued. He wanted her to be a playwright. He also, she believed, wished she had been a boy, and she undoubtedly wished the same.
 
 At the age of 12, at an Anna Pavlova recital, she received the call to dance, but her father opposed this -- he too regarded dance as a bimbo occupation -- and she didn't start ballet class until she was almost 14. Her body was wrong for ballet ("big-busted, well-hipped," as she put it), and she had almost no gift for classical dance. Furthermore, she discovered that she was a natural comic, the antitheses of what at that time was the dying-swan image of the ballerina. But none of this deterred her from wanting to be a dancer and choreographer. Indeed, it spurred her on. Thus was born the theme of her life: embattlement.
 After a slow start -- typical for a woman -- she had her first big hit at 37: her cowboy ballet "Rodeo" (1942). Five months later came the premiere of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "Oklahoma!," which she had choreographed, and she was famous. By 1944, she had three hit musicals running on Broadway. In all, she choreographed some 15 musicals and 21 ballets. (In between, she wrote 12 books.) In ballet, she was one of the makers -- together with Antony Tudor and Jerome Robbins -- of midcentury realism, the fusion of ballet technique with vernacular movement and modern psychology. On Broadway, she was a leader of a related revolution, the push to integrate dancing with song and story. If Mr. Robbins's 1957 "West Side Story" is what most of us think of as the archetypal musical-from-which-dancing-cannot be-separated, it was preceded by de Mile's "Carousel" (1945), which ended with a 40-minute ballet. And all of this was achieved in bitter conflict. In the 1940's the Broadway bosses still regarded dancing as the least important element in the show. De Mille was routinely asked to hire couch-cast non-dancers, to fit her work to sets that blocked the exits, to yield to every consideration other than that of dance. She fought back with fury. She screamed, she raged; she had nose-bleeds so severe that she had to be taken to the emergency room. Such behavior shortened her career on Broadway. (After their experience with her on "Paint Your Wagon,' Lerner and Loewe hired a different choreographer for their next show, "My Fair Lady.") Without the tantrums, however, she would not have achieved what she did.
 The warfare was not just external. The discovery that de Mille made in her ballet class, that she was a fat little comic in a world of swans, never lost its power to wound her. When she staged her first solo programs, she was dumbfounded, she says (I doubt it), to hear the audience laughing: "I had thought what I was doing was tragic...I wanted to do something that had beauty." This division spawned other, parallel conflicts. Her gift was for acting, for realism, yet what she wanted to create was dancing -- an alternative, symbolic language, like that her friend Martha Graham was inventing: "Martha moved; I grimaced." She was also torn between commercial theater and "art." In her glory years, she ran back and forth between ballet and Broadway, trying to convert ballet to Broadway's realism and Broadway to ballet's idealism.
 Added to these troubles was a further conflict: careerwoman versus "real" woman. In the 50's, it was widely assumed that if a married woman chose to have a career, there was something wrong with her and with her husband. Ozzie worked; Harriet stayed home. Many of de Mille's friends considered her unfit for marriage. "She had such drive," one of her dancers said, "you couldn't imagine her being sufficiently pliable to fit in with anyone else's life." (Imagine this being said of a man.) Nevertheless, in 1943 de Mille married Walter Prude, a debonair Texan who had been Martha Graham's manager and was later one of the top associates in Sol Hurok's office. From the begining, Walter made clear his resentment of Agnes's career, and as her fame grew -- in 1950 she made over $125,000 ($825,000 in today's dollars) -- so did his resentment. He liked to tease her, often in front of others, saying things like "I only married you because I thought I'd be killed in the war." He also took up with other women, or so she believed.
 Not surprisingly, she became hung up on sex. Her dances are heavily populated with hungry females searching for men. Dance itself, she wrote, was a sublimation of that hunger: "Dancing represents sex in its least costly form, free from imprisonment and free to a great extent from emotional responsibility, and, above all...independent of someone else's pleasure. In other words, it means freedom from sex."
 Creative women were bound to lose sexually, she felt. In a letter to her friend Rebecca West, who was grieving over her husband's infidelities, de Mille wrote that West's husband of course had to have a mistress, because he needed to have a woman inferior to him: "That's how it is, darling. Gifted women pay." Betrayal was not the only cost. De Mille repeatedly claimed that female dancers were "frigid," and she presumably had the same worry about herself. Remember that these were the days of Freudians telling women which kind of orgasm was the real kind.
 Carol Easton does not ignore the woman question, but in discussing de Mille's troubles she is more likely to use psychoanalytic reasoning, much of it is pretty lame. When de Mille dreams of marriage, this is "a fantasy with roots that reached back into her childhood, when her whole family had colluded in a fiction of who they were." Presumably, if something is wrong with your family, you shouldn't contemplate marriage.
 But in Ms. Easton's view, the enduring bugbear of de Mille's psychic life was her father, who refused to give her unconditional love. (He wanted A's, not B's.) Thereafter, with every faithless boyfriend, every high-handed boss, de Mille is seen to be re-enacting this primal frustration. When she takes Walter to "Oklahoma!" -- this was the first time he had ever seen her work -- and he refuses to say a single kind word about her dances, Ms. Easton concludes, "It did not take a Freudian to see that in her marriage Agnes had replicated her relationship with her father." In fact, it does take a Freudian. A reader unequipped with that perspective might conclude that the fault lay with Walter, or with history.
 De Mille was a choreographer of the second rank, maybe the third. No shame in that. Her specialty was sentimental comedy, then as now the public's favorite genre, and she fashioned it with wonderful intelligence. She was loved, furthermore, for her wholesome subject matter: monstalgia, patriotism, cute girls, nice fellers. When those themes went out of fashion, so did her work -- whereupon she embarked on a new profession. She became one of the most popular lecturers in the United State, thundering to audiences across the nation on dance, women's rights and the necessity for government support of the arts.
 In her old age, she joined that rather tiresome species, the Grand Old Gal -- a common apotheosis for briliant women (cf. Katharine Hepburn, Lillian Hellman) once time releases them from sexual troubles. She was grand, though. After a stroke that left her, at 69, paralyzed on the right side of her body, she went on working at a barely diminished pace for almost 20 years until her death in 1993. She was large-spirited too. Aware that her talent was inferior to Tudor's and Graham's, she never stinted in her praise of them. (The most valuable book on Graham is by de Mille -- "Martha," 1991.) If she was also a very trying person, maybe that's what good causes need.
 De Mille's best work was not her ballets but her writing, above all her first book, "Dance to the Piper" (1952), one of the finest dance autobiographies ever written. In her prose, as in her ballets, she was the master of the comic character sketch. Here is her portrait (from "Dance to the Piper") of her Aunt Constance, Uncle Cecil's wife and a woman of fable poise:
"I remember one April afternoon began for her with a children's hospital committee meeting that was interrupted by a hysterical summons from across Los Feliz Boulevard because of the drowning of a child in a nearby reservoir. She went to the victim's house, cleaned the house, prepared supper for the brothers and sisters, comforted the mother, returned, bathed and dressed, put in a brisk half-hour hunting flies and ants for her small son's neglected alligator, presided at the dinner table of her own children, sat with them while they studied, and at midnight was found trailing alone around the cellar in a red velvet negligee in search of the special Liebfraumilch which Cecil liked with his late supper."
 It's like a Buster Keaton routine. Incidentally, Walter, on reading the proofs for "Dance to the Piper," advised Agnes not to publish it. As Ms. Easton relates, he said "that the writing was not good...He also pointed out that she already had a career and didn't need another one." Shaken, she tried to get out of the contract. The publisher protested, and Walter finally came around. "Dance to the Piper" was an immediate best seller.
 D.W. Winnicott used to write about what he called the "good-enough mother," the mother who, while not ideal, nevertheless doesn't wreck your life. Carol Easton is a good-enough biographer. At times she seems naive. She does not discuss broad trends, such as Method acting and "midcult," that influenced de Mille's choreography. More important, she does not know enough about dance -- ballet versus modern, narrative versus "abstract," highbrow versus middlebrow -- to place de Mille's work in proper context, and she makes some amazing mistakes about ballet. (Her previous writing have been on music and movies.) Nevertheless, she takes de Mille seriously as an artist. For those who still wonder, as I do, how dance is made, she describes in detail de Mille's choreographic method: how she imagined a dance, what came into her mind first, how many notes and what kind she made before going into the studio. And throughout, Ms. Easton tracks de Mille's struggles with the limits of her gift. De Mille fans will want to read the book. Newcomers should get hold of "Dance to the Piper" instead. It's in print. The 50's being what they were, you won't find out about the bad love affairs or the Jewish grandmother, but you'll have more fun.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Agnes de Mille directing a rehearsal in the 1950's.

TITLE: NO INTERMISSION: THE LIFE OF AGNES DE MILLE (BOOK)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 12; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1517 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Equitable Life's Switch;
A Short Move, but to a Wholly Different Mindset

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
LATER this year, employees of the Equitable Life Assurance Company will start moving into 1290 Avenue of the Americas, Olympia & York's huge building on 52d Street. Physically, some will just trek across the street, while others will come from a few neighborhoods away. Metaphorically, they will travel much farther.
This move brings Equitable full circle in a long, eventful real-estate odyssey. The 137-year-old insurer has owned and occupied some of the city's biggest, most modern buildings. Now, other companies will occupy Equitable Center, the lavish monument Equitable built itself a decade ago. It will be a tenant, albeit the major one, in a more utilitarian building that someone else owns. 
 "The goal was to reduce costs and create efficiencies," said Jonathan D. Miller, a senior vice president of Equitable Real Estate. "The notion that Equitable needed to be in an owned property was dismissed."
Real-estate experts say that similar scenarios are being played out everywhere as shareholders and customers change the yardsticks by which companies are judged.
"C.E.O.'s indulged their egos with fancy headquarters because they got high marks for the appearance of success," said Arthur J. Mirante 2d, chief executive at Cushman & Wakefield, a real-estate firm. "Today, they get high marks for a healthy bottom line and the appearance of austerity."
For some companies, going downmarket is a sign of fiscal desperation. But many others simply emerged from the recession weaned of the need for frills. They will pay top dollar for efficient space; they will let others pay a premium for glitz.
"Equitable, I.B.M., AT&T, all finally viewed their trophy buildings as wasted assets that should enhance the bottom line," said Carol Nelson, executive vice president of the Edward S. Gordon real-estate firm.
Profiting from real estate is not a new idea to Equitable. Like most insurance companies, it invests in real estate and supplies mortgages for many types of properties, and has always made its headquarters do double duty as moneymakers.
Still, even among insurance companies, Equitable has been a trend setter. Its first "home" building, opened on Broadway and Cedar Street in 1870, was the first office building to have elevators -- and thus, one of the first to get good rents for space above the second floor. The 36-story tower it built itself at the same location 45 years later was one of the largest office buildings of its time.
Over the years, Equitable developed properties for its own use in St. Louis, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Pittsburgh. Inevitably, when it ran out of space in New York, it turned to itself for the solution. In 1960, Equitable built the 1.8-million-square-foot edifice at 1285 Avenue of the Americas, at 52d Street, the largest building ever designed for occupancy by a single owner.
It was hardly a prestigious address back then -- "Sixth Avenue was more like Speakeasy Row than Corporate Corridor," recalled Timothy J. Welch, senior executive vice president of Equitable Real Estate. Still, the Time-Life Building had gone up just a block south three years earlier (partly with Equitable financing), and Equitable trusted that others would follow.
Its building was no cut-rate home site. Equitable eschewed outsourcing, employing its own staff to run every aspect of the building, from security to food service to maintenance. Equitable charged its departments high on-paper rents, but the departmental managers did not mind. They knew they were judged on how they grew their businesses, not on their occupancy costs.
But then, in the early 80's, Equitable's executives, like so many others, decided that lumping all of its New York employees together in one building, overseen by a few powerful executives who alone had incentives to ratchet profit up and costs down, was more stifling than efficient.
"A 6,800-person home office seemed much too bureaucratic," recalled William T. McCaffrey, Equitable's chief administrative officer. So the huge Equitable broke itself up into four profit centers and let each one decide where it wanted to live.
T HE real-estate group moved to Atlanta, which it felt was more central for its national business. The pension-operations group moved to Harmon Meadows in Secaucus, N.J., where rents were much lower. Some parts of the life insurance company moved to 135 West 50th Street, others to a modest building on Wall Street. Only Equitable Capital, the main investment arm, stayed on two floors at 1285.
The decentralization was not driven by real-estate concerns, but it could easily have been derailed by them.
"We might not have done it if our own experts had not told us that we could quickly rent the building," Mr. McCaffrey recalled.
The timing was excellent. The building had been well-maintained and modernized, rents were taking off across the city, and the Avenue of the Americas had become a prime address. Paine Webber became the anchor tenant, whose name went on the door, and others soon followed.
Equitable the insurer might have stopped there, but as the hefty rents started pouring in, Equitable the developer wanted more. Over the years, Equitable had been assembling the land west of 1285 to Seventh Avenue. So in 1985, fresh from leasing its first midtown skyscraper, Equitable proceeded to build its second.
But this time, Equitable's focus was on finding tenants, not housing itself. That meant worrying much more about negative perceptions of Seventh Avenue than it had 25 years before about those of Sixth.
"We figured the Equitable name and the building itself would overcome the address," Mr. Welch recalled.
Equitable physically linked 1285 and the new 787 Seventh Avenue, calling the resulting 3.3-million-square-foot combo Equitable Center. It moved some senior executives into the new tower and declared it Equitable world headquarters. It put in a health club, a branch of the Whitney Museum and a lobby dotted with Equitable-owned art, including a 68-foot-high Roy Lichtenstein mural and Thomas Hart Benton's 10-panel mural "America Today." It added fiberoptics, an auditorium and a broadcast studio that even nontenants rent. (Two examples: The mergers of I.B.M. and Lotus, and of Kimberly Clark and Scott Paper, were announced at Equitable Center.)
"When you view a building as an investment, you say, 'I'll get $42 a foot if I put down granite, but I can get $50 if I put down marble,' " Mr. McCaffrey said. "That's a different mindset than, 'What do my people need to be efficient.' "
Again, Equitable's timing was perfect. By the time the stock market crashed in October 1987, Equitable Center, despite charging premium rents, was fully leased. "We got in just under the gun," Mr. Welch said.
But Equitable's good timing as a developer could not immunize the big insurance company against the recession. Equitable, which "demutualized" and went public in 1992, downsized mightily in the 90's. By the end of 1992, it was down to 2,200 New York employees, rattling around in too much space in several buildings.
It had also grown disenchanted with decentralization. "We discovered how unproductive relying on cabs and trains could be," Mr. Welch said.
So, Equitable decided to consolidate. The question, though, was where?
"We canvassed Westchester, downtown Manhattan, we even looked in Albany," Mr. McCaffrey said. "But we simply wouldn't take the chance of losing more people by moving too far away." When a mass defection by the menswear industry opened more than 500,000 square feet of space at 1290, Equitable jumped at it.
Equitable will move into its space in stages, as its leases elsewhere expire. By 1999, Equitable's only presence in Equitable Center will be the 49th-floor meeting center and the 50th-floor board room, both of which, along with the broadcast studio and auditorium, it will use for itself and as a revenue producer. (The company took in $3.5 million from catering alone last year.)
The Willkie Farr & Gallagher law firm has rented most of the space Equitable occupied. Equitable is asking an annual rent of more than $50 a square foot for the almost four floors left. That is a hard target to hit even on Madison or Park, but Mr. Welch seems unconcerned. "I am convinced this space will rent," he said.
Equitable itself will be paying no such hefty rent. Indeed, starting next January, it expects to save some $30 million annually in occupancy costs over the next 16 years.
Of course, the savings have a price. Equitable's new home has all of the technological bells and whistles Equitable may want but little of the luxury. The employees who were at 787 Seventh had 480 square feet of space per person; in the new building, the average will be closer to 280 square feet.
But maybe, in the cost-conscious 90's, frugality is exactly the image that Equitable wants its new headquarters, which will bear its name, to project.
"Sure, image still matters," said Ms. Nelson of Edward S. Gordon. "But it is the image of efficiency and functionality, not flashiness, that counts today."

HEADLINE: Building Homes, and Skilled Developers, in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
AS a latecomer to redevelopment, the Saratoga Square urban renewal area in the Bedford-Stuyvesant and Brownsville sections of Brooklyn still bears the signs of new housing construction waiting to happen. There are scattered vacant tracts in city ownership, many of them once occupied by abandoned housing.
But rehabilitation work has moved forward, and new construction is following. So far it has taken the form of 61 two-family houses (122 dwelling units) known as the Thomas S. Boyland Homes. They are in various stages of completion off Sumpter Street, Saratoga Avenue and Marion Street. 
 These are to be followed by 96 more two-families going into construction this year, and probably over a hundred a year or two after that. Within a few weeks, the first occupants will appear on Sumpter Street.
The obvious principal beneficiaries of this production are the buyers themselves, moderate-income people who are getting an unusually spacious two-family house for $128,000. That price, with a 5 percent down payment, is bringing in first-time home buyers to resettle a neighborhood with the thinned-out look of urban decline.
To Charles Samuels, a 53-year-old construction worker coming from a rental on Decatur Avenue, the neighborhood is "beautiful -- and very convenient." And to Patrician Huffstead, a Nynex employee living as a renter in Park Slope, "The neighborhood is fine. I have a friend living four blocks away and she has no complaints."
But the less obvious beneficiary of the development project is the developer himself, Carlton A. Brown. Its value to his business future underscores a subtle side effect of the citywide home-building program that the New York Housing Partnership has promoted with private and public assistance. It is bringing into being a new class of locally based, usually minority, builder-developers.
Mr. Brown is a 44-year-old resident of Bedford-Stuyvesant, who has lived on Hancock Street, 10 blocks from the development site, for the last 15 years. His late grandmother lived on Halsey Street nearby for 40 years. He himself grew up in Mississippi, the son of school teachers, and went to Princeton on a scholarship. He came to New York to work in the real estate development arm of A.T.&T.
He is a partner in a small company called Full Spectrum Building and Development, based in Harlem, with Walter Edwards, a longtime Harlem property owner, and Richard Durant, an engineer. Though Full Spectrum has contracting experience, it does not meet the conventional criteria for qualifying for bank financing for the $13.3 million Thomas Boyland homes.
Under the Partnership's Neighborhood Builder Program (originally the Minority Builder Program), established builders stand behind the newer builders, acting as mentors. The State of New York Mortgage Insurance Fund guarantees the construction financing provided by banks. Successful completion and sales, and the establishment of business relationships along the way, put the local entrepreneurs in position to borrow for future projects.
"It's a question of establishing a track record," said Mr. Brown, whose mentor in Bedford-Stuyvesant was Leslie Lerner, president of the Beechwood Corporation of Williston Park, L.I. Now Mr. Brown is already bidding for other work, including work outside the city -- a 200-unit affordable housing project in Boston and 110-unit development in Plainfield, N.J.
OTHER home builders before him have been launched by Housing Partnership projects. Among them are Gerson Nieves, president of the Nidus Corporation in the Bronx, which has evolved into a development company from a brokerage and property-management firm on Westchester Avenue. Mr. Nieves worked with DeLuxe Homes of Berwick, Pa., on Melrose Village, a development of 26 two-family houses in the Melrose section of the Bronx, and has since started two other projects for which he was able to get financing on his own. He will build 45 two- and three-family homes in Hunts Point and Crotona Park East.
Then there is Desmond Emanuel, an architect and engineer who is president of Santa Fe Construction in Manhattan. In 1990 he developed the Longwood Historic Homes in the Bronx, 50 newly constructed houses in the Longwood Historic District, with a long-time Staten Island developer, Randy Lee, as the mentor builder.
Since then, on his own, he has taken on development of 200 homes on a former sugar plantation in Antigua called Herbert's Estate. The firm expects to be in construction in May, with financial assistance from the Antiguan Government. Mr. Emanuel described it as a $30 million project that will be built in phases over three years.
"The program has given New York City its first cadre of minority owner-developers," said Kathryn Wylde, president of the Housing Partnership. Eighteen small developers have completed projects, Ms. Wylde said, and six more have projects in planning and construction. The program was given its initial financial backing by Fred Wilpon, chairman of Sterling Equities, a large developer-owner. He is also chairman of the Housing Partnership, and co-owner of the New York Mets.
THE Thomas Boyland Homes are named for a late State Assemblyman from Bedford-Stuyvesant, who was the brother of the current Assemblyman, William F. Boyland. The house are attached, with red-brick face and brownstone-like design. Inside, there is 950 square feet of space per floor. In the owner's three-bedroom duplex, on the first and second levels, there is a walk-in closet in the bedroom and a whirpool tub in the bathroom. The third-floor rental apartment is expected to rent for $650 to $800 a month.
One unusual aspect of the construction is that it uses a product called engineered lumber for major structural members. Manufactured from a combination of laminated and compressed wood products by Georgia Pacific Corporation, it provides a stronger, nonsqueaking flooring system, Mr. Brown said. In recent years it has come closer in cost to conventional lumber, but there are large labor savings in installation.
"We used the money we saved to give larger houses and the whirlpool baths," Mr. Brown said.
Buyers have been getting mortgages through Fleet Mortgage of Westbury, L.I. Planning & Development Ventures, Inc., of Brooklyn, is overseeing the marketing, and the nonprofit Northeast Brooklyn Housing Development Corporation is doing the community outreach for buyers. The public subsidy -- $90,000 per two-family house -- has been supplement by discretionary funds from the budget of Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden.
New York State's contribution has been $15,000 per dwelling unit ($30,000 a house). But with the state looking to pare subsidies, future phases of development may accept buyers with incomes as high as 165 of median for the area -- or about $70,000, Ms. Wylde said. Reduced subsidies raise prices, and also make production riskier for developers, who might find it more difficult to get buyers.
Many of these buyers are coming from public housing, where their departure after years of residence is freeing apartments for occupancy by younger people with lower incomes. Among these buyers is Helen Frampton, a 38-year-old Nynex supervisor who has lived in the Housing Authority's Cypress Hill Houses in East New York for 15 years.
"I was afraid of the idea, but my friend owns two houses and she talked me into it," Ms. Frampton said. "She said it would be a good investment. My older sister and her kids will live in the bigger unit and I'll be in the rental unit. It will probably cost me less that I'm paying now in rent."
She is paying $128,000 for one of the Sumpter Street houses, she said. Her mother, who lives with her in Cypress Hill Houses, isn't reconciled to the idea of moving, however. "At the moment, she says she's staying," Ms. Frampton said.
