HEADLINE: 'Balkan Odyssey'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a former Sarajevo bureau chief for United Press International, I must take issue with the review of Lord Owen's book. 
 There is no reason to excuse Lord Owen's failure to bring peace to Bosnia. His tenure as the European Union's special negotiator for the former Yugoslavia, and the plan he and Cyrus Vance drew up, were both fatally flawed. Time and again, Lord Owen carried the water of the Serbian and Bosnian Serb leaderships. He faithfully repeated and often endorsed their promises not to attack unarmed civilian populations, their promises to respect cease-fires and peace plans. Time and again, these promises were broken, and the slaughter went on. Time and again, Lord Owen assured the Western powers that next time it would be different.
Lord Owen's apparent interest in merely containing the war in Bosnia, not reaching a just or even a lasting peace, won him back his old London sobriquet, Dr. Death, in the streets of Sarajevo and among the Bosnia press corps.
Misha Glenny is certainly correct to say that the lack of resolve and the lack of interest on the part of both the United States and its European allies let the war continue. When the Clinton Administration finally did focus its attention on Bosnia and Croatia, the fighting was swiftly brought to a close.
But it is deceitful to suggest that the Vance-Owen plan could have stopped the war. The Vance-Owen plan was unworkable. It called for dividing Bosnia into 10 ethnic enclaves, many of which could not possibly have been defended or adequately policed by either the United Nations or a multinational force. And few of the enclaves would have been economically viable.
The hope was, and remains, that time and economic growth can heal the wounds of this war and that eventually -- in 10, 20 or 50 years -- Serbs, Croats and Muslims will find that trade brings them together again. This logic brought the French and Germans together in the European Coal and Steel Community after World War II. Today, French and German people whose fathers tried to kill one another in 1940 have buried the wartime enmity and even marry one another.
It was patently obvious to me and to many others on the ground during the war that such a peace could come to Bosnia only if all its people were helped to rebuild their homes in peace. Bosnia, it was clear, had to be provisionally divided into economically viable parts that could be effectively policed for several years by a well-armed international peacekeeping force.
Tens of thousands of corpses later, we at least have a plan that can effectively separate the two sides and allow Bosnia's people a chance to rebuild their lives. That's more than the Vance-Owen plan could ever have provided.
Lord Owen is by no means the greatest villain in the former Yugoslavia. But his major contribution to the war in Bosnia was to prolong the suffering of all peoples -- Serbs, Croats and Muslims -- by giving credence to the hollow promises of the warlords and murderers who found no profit in peace.
 
Peter S. Green
Prague

HEADLINE: Not Just Another Country

BYLINE: By James P. Pinkerton; James P. Pinkerton is a lecturer at the Graduate School of Political Management at George Washington University and the author of "What Comes Next: The End of Big Government -- and the New Paradigm."

 BODY:
To assert that America is exceptional, as analysts have been doing since Tocqueville, is to dwell on paradox. In "American Exceptionalism: A Double-Edged Sword," Seymour Martin Lipset motes that while the United States is the most litigious society in the world -- spending four to eight times as much on lawsuits as Germany, England, Italy, France, the Netherlands or Japan -- it is simultaneously one of the most lawless, vexed by crime rates triple those of other industialized nations. Hence America's double-edged sword: on one side of the blade, "a high sense of personal responsibility, independent initiative and voluntarism"; on the other side, "self-serving behavior, atomism and a disregard for communal good."
 Central to Mr. Lipset's American exceptionalism is the idea of a definable American Creed, "a set of dogmas about the nature of a good society," deriving mostly from the Revolution. These include liberty, egalitarianism (defined as equality of opportunity, not result), individualism, populism and laissez-faire. To buttress his argument, he uses copious survey data to demonstrate how different America is from other advanced countries. For example, in 1992 just 38 percent of Americans agreed that government should reduce the difference in income between rich and poor, compared with 65 percent of Britons, 66 percent of West Germans and 80 percent of Italians. 
 Pausing form cross-cultural explication, Mr. Lipset refreshes the reader with historical explanation. Whereas conservatism in the Old World, he writes, derived from "the historic alliance of church and government," in America it has adhered to the anti-stasist Whiggish tradition instead. Inheritors of Europe's feudal legacy, Tories like Disraeli and Bismarck established group-oriented programs for the poor, it spends more on education.
 This emphasis on individual opportunity makes racial preference programs automatically suspect to most Americans. Reaching back to 1871, Mr. Lipset cites the abolitionist Frederick Douglass as a fierce opponent of quotas; his narrative then leaps forward to the Nixon Administration, which implemented quotas over the opposition of civil rights leaders like Clarence Mitchell, a prominent official with the N.A.A.C.P., and Representative Augustus Hawkins. Of course, Republicans soon abandoned their policy offspring, which then took on a life of its own inside thejudiciary and bureaucracy and in the Democratic Party). "By a supreme irony," Mr. Lipset concludes, Richard Nixon, "the man most hated by the father of the affirmative action programs that have brought them so much ballot-box grief.
 If Mr. Lipset's strengthin this book is his ability to sift vast evidence and pluck out apt conclusions, his weakness is his seeming desire to get some matters off his chest (or off the hard drive of his computer) even if they don't fit hsi thesis. Three chapters, on African-Americans, Jews and intellectuals, seem to have wandered in from some other book; the author procrusteanizes them in this one with the declaration that they are the exceptions. Each of these groups has gone its own, sometimes surprising way. Blacks, Mr. Lipset argues, are faring better than most Americans realize: "The 'invisible man' of the 1990's is the successful black working- and middle-class suburbanite." Jews, combining affluence and liberalism, remain "unique in the American ethnic kaleidoscope"; in contrast to the national trend, Jewish support for Democratic candidates actually rose from 1992 to 1994. Intellectuals are also, Mr. Lipset asserts, "exceptions on the margin," although his quick chronicle, from Communism to McCarthyism to neoconservatism to political correctness, adds little insight into the ways of America's intellegentsia. Meanwhile, Mr. Lipset's own internal cliche-check has failed to catch such clunkers as "leaner and meaner" or "American as apple pie."
 The chapter on Japan also seems out of place, although it allows him toponder how two nations with "highly disparate value systems" can both be economically successful. He pithily summarizes Japan's economic awakening in the late 19th century as a "revolution from above," noting that new business and commercial values were inculcated into old warlords and warriors; yet even after a century of modernization, he adds, Japan's uniqueness -- Nihonron -- survives. Of course, this finding gives rise to the thesis-undercutting thought that perhaps all countries are exceptional in their own way.
 In his 22d book in a distinguished half-century career as a social scientist, with positions at Harvard, Stanford and now George Mason University, Mr. Lipset has chosen to concentrate before him: on the handful of nations with advanced social-science databases that can be analyzed in minute detail. Yet if the subject is America in a shrinking world on the eve of the 21st century, surely it's important also to compare America to the 175 or so developing nations, even if their survey-research infrastructure is sparse. That might be a good topic for Mr. Lipset's 23d book.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Deductible Charges In a Co-op

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
CO-OP shareholders across the country have received, or will shortly receive, notifications of how much of their total maintenance payments can be deducted from their Federal income tax returns. Some will find they can deduct as much as 70 percent. Others, however, will discover they can deduct as little as 20 percent.
Could it be that a building with a high percentage of deductible maintenance is better than one with a low percentage? 
 "It's not a question of one building's being better than another building," said Arthur Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer who is vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives. "It's a reflection of the different services received by different shareholders in different buildings."
Still, many shareholders think of their maintenance fees the same way residential homeowners think of their mortgage payments -- as a tax-deductible, equity-building alternative to rent. Accordingly, the more deductible the mortgage payment, or maintenance payment, the better. Right?
"When you hear somebody say, 'My maintenance is 60 percent deductible,' " Mr. Weinstein said, "that sounds good because it reduces the net cost of paying maintenance." But, he said, as anyone who has borrowed money will readily understand, if given a choice between being able to deduct interest payments on loans or not having to take out the loans in the first place, most people would happily choose the latter. In other words, it costs money to borrow money; tax deductions only soften the blow.
People do borrow money, though. And since 1986, when Congress eliminated deductions for virtually all consumer debt except for residential financing, it has made increasing sense for homeowners who need to borrow money to borrow as much as possible with mortgages and home-equity loans and as little as possible with personal loans and credit cards.
In fact, for many homeowners it has become almost fashionable -- especially in these days of low interest rates -- to refinance their homes or take out home-equity loans to make as much of their debt as possible tax deductible.
But co-op shareholders do not have the same level of control over their tax-deductible debt as other property owners.
Walter D. Goldsmith, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in co-ops and condominiums, explained that co-op shareholders, like other property owners, are allowed tax deductions for real estate taxes and mortgage interest paid on their homes.
But since the co-op building itself is owned by the co-op corporation, the corporation pays real estate taxes and interest on the underlying mortgage on the building. The tax code, however, allows shareholders (who are essentially tenants) to deduct a portion of their maintenance charges (which is essentially rent paid to the co-op) from their taxable income.
And since each shareholder owns a specific percentage interest in the co-op as a whole, each shareholder's deduction is usually determined by the number of shares owned.
For example, in a 10-unit co-op with 10 shareholders who own 10 shares each, each shareholder would be allowed to deduct 10 percent of the real estate taxes and interest paid on the building's underlying mortgage. If real estate taxes and mortgage interest were the only expenses of the building, then the shareholders' maintenance charges would essentially be one hundred percent deductible.
In reality, however, there are always other expenses involved. And as those expenses increase the total cost of running the building, they decrease the proportion of the maintenance charges that are deductible.
For example, if the total additional expenses of running the building just happens to be the same amount as it costs to pay real estate taxes and interest payments, then the total expenses of the building are doubled. This doubles the maintenance payments, which cuts the deductible proportion of maintenance to 50 percent.
In the example above, although the maintenance charges doubled, the dollar amount of each shareholder's deduction remained the same. All things being equal, the situation is similar to a single-family homeowner's being able to deduct property taxes and mortgage interest, but not being able to deduct the cost of heat, electricity, custodial services, water and insurance.
"A building that has a full-service doorman, concierge and porters will probably have a lower percentage of deductibility than one without those services," said Mr. Weinstein. "That's because a greater percentage of the building's expenses goes to nondeductible expenses."
For all practical purposes, then, co-op shareholders get essentially the same treatment by the tax code as single-family homeowners. There are, however, some differences that result from the co-op form of ownership that can have tax consequences on shareholders.
For many single-family homeowners the tax deductions attributable to interest on mortgages are significantly greater than the deductions attributable to real property taxes. Moreover, single-family homeowners often have a significant measure of control over the amount of tax-deductible debt they incur.
But the situation is somewhat different for shareholders in co-ops.
"The biggest variable in a co-op is interest on the underlying mortgage," said Greg Young, director of sales and leasing for City Living, a Manhattan real estate brokerage. "And individual shareholders have no control over it. "
Indeed, opinion is divided on the question of whether it is more prudent to carry as much tax-deductible debt as possible or none at all.
"It's a raging argument in a lot of buildings," said Mr. Weinstein. "Some people argue that since interest is deductible and principal isn't, a building should not put itself in a position of repaying any of the principal on the underlying mortgage."
Others, he said, prefer to be as debt-free as possible, tax deductions notwithstanding.
The real point is that while the issue may be debated in a co-op, a single-family homeowner who wants to carry as much tax-deductible debt as possible could be filling out an application to refinance his or her mortgage.
Co-op shareholders are not entirely deprived of control over the total tax-deductible indebtedness they can incur.
For example, shareholders may legally deduct the interest on their share loans, the debt they incurred to purchase shares in the co-op. Moreover, like other property owners, shareholders can also take out equity loans on their shares as well.
And, if a co-op board is so inclined, or can be persuaded by shareholders, the co-op itself can take out additional tax-deductible debt for maintenance or repairs or even, perhaps, to beef up a reserve fund.
In the end, though, the value of a tax deduction depends largely on the taxpayer's income -- the more income, the more valuable the deduction.
But, said Mark Shernicoff, a Manhattan accountant, "tax deductions should not drive business decisions."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Retail Industry Gloom Fails to Deter Major Projects

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
DESPITE slumping sales, rising bankruptcy filings and consolidations by large store chains that are threatening to create substantial retail vacancies by the end of the year, developers are moving forward with major retail projects on Long Island.
These developers say rentals are brisk because national retailers continue to view Long Island as one of the nation's most lucrative markets. 
 "You have 2.3 million people with extremely strong demographics," said Steven B. Greenberg, president of the Greenberg Group, retail consultants in Hewlett. "There has been very little new development in the last three years, so although the retail business is difficult and we are seeing a host of bankruptcies, things are really not so bad."
The retail downturn has not affected all areas. With consumers always hungering for something new, home furnishings and electronics stores at Roosevelt Center are doing exceptionally well, said Edward J. Minskoff, a principal of MCS Realty Partners of Manhattan. MCS is developing the 2.6-million-square-foot mixed-use complex on the former Roosevelt Raceway site in Westbury.
The 600,000 square feet of retail space in the center, where construction started less than a year ago, is almost completed and is fully rented, said Mr. Minskoff. Retailers include such newcomers to Long Island as Incredible Universe, an electronics store, and the Home Depot Expo Design Center. A Babies 'R' Us store, another newcomer to Long Island, will open in March.
Nearby on Old Country Road in Westbury, two-thirds of the 522,000 square feet of new rentable space on a 38-acre site now occupied by Fortunoff has been preleased -- even though it is not yet under construction, said Alan Fortunoff, Fortunoff's president. He is developing the site as a 930,000-square-foot mall called the Source in a joint venture with the Simon Property Group of Indianapolis.
"This is a terrific time for the kind of mall we are building because we are bringing a lot of retailers to Long Island that are not here now," Mr. Fortunoff said.
The anchor stores at the Source will include a 45,000-square-foot Nordstrom Rack and a 35,000-square-foot Off 5th, Saks Fifth Avenue Outlet, which are outlet stores for the two retailers. Others are Virgin Megastore, a record and video store that will occupy 25,000 square feet, and Just For Feet, a shoe store that has taken 19,000 square feet. Old Navy Clothing Company, a division of Gap; the Cheesecake Factory, a restaurant, and Innovation Luggage are among other retailers who will be in the development.
Ground was broken for the $145 million complex on Feb. 1. The mall will include the 32-year-old existing 212,000-square-foot Fortunoff store when it is completed in August 1997.
At the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center in Garden City almost 400,000 square feet of space is being added to the mall's existing 2 million square feet.
N ORDSTROM, a department store chain based in Seattle, is building a 225,000-square-foot store on the east side of the mall on land it has leased from Corporate Property Investors of Manhattan, the mall owners. The new store, Nordstrom's first on Long Island, will open in the fall of 1997.
Corporate Property Investors itself is completing a 168,000-square-foot second-story addition to the the mall. The new space, to be ready for occupancy this fall, will be divided into 50 stores. About 80 percent of that space has already been leased, said Michael J. Maloney, the company's senior vice president.
"Retail sales were difficult last year and Roosevelt Field has to reflect what's happening in retailing in general," Mr. Maloney said. "However, with such a huge depository of stores, people may not be spending as much as they did in years past. But they are still spending a tremendous amount."
Corporate Property Investors also is moving ahead with plans to renovate and expand its 950,000-square-foot Walt Whitman Mall on Route 110 in Melville and add 330,000 square feet of space. New tenants will include a two-story Saks Fifth Avenue, which will move into 120,000 square feet of new space, and Bloomingdale's, which will occupy 220,000 square feet of the existing mall.
An additional 210,000 square feet of new construction on a second level will be divided into 100 smaller stores. About $250 million is being spent on the mall project, including work being done by the individual department stores.
"Malls are expanding because they look at the long term," said Rick Kreindler, chairman of Island Realty, commercial brokers in Melville.
"What's coming down the road should be positive and whoever presents space in the most attractive way is going to get the business."
New locations are also under development. Wilbur J. Breslin, a Garden City developer, said he expected to start construction of the 790,000-square-foot first phase of a 1.6 million square-foot mall in Yaphank this spring.
He is also at work on a 385,000-square-foot mall in Hempstead, which will replace an Abraham & Straus store on the site that closed in 1992.
In Yaphank, Mr. Breslin said, 500,000 square feet has been leased to three department store tenants, none of which he would name, and 50 smaller stores. The Hempstead space has been fully leased, he said, with the exception of 105,000 square feet that was to have been occupied by Bradlees, a department store chain that has filed for bankruptcy.
Bradlees and Caldor, another department store that filed for bankruptcy last year, are victims of "expanding too quickly, paying very high rents, and facing lots of very severe competition," said Stanley H. Schuckman, president of Schuckman Realty, commercial brokers in Woodbury. The two stores have a total of 17 locations on Long Island, and had been looking for additional locations.
But brokers say that potential vacancies being created by bankruptcies can also be seen in a positive light.
"You see retailers failing and you wonder who's going to replace them, and here comes another wave eager to get into the market because of the excellent demographics," said John Thomas, managing director of Select Investment Realty Advisors in Ronkonkoma.
S TILL, there is a lot more caution in the air, said Arthur D. Sanders, president of Spiegel Associates of Hicksville, owners and developers of retail space. Mr. Sanders said he was working with several large tenants who want to sign short-term leases "while they test the water."
Yet, one newcomer has been so aggressive about entering the Long Island market that it purchased an existing company.
The Stop & Shop Supermarket Company of Quincy, Mass., which has one store under construction in East Setauket and others pending in Roslyn and East Islip, acquired the MelMarkets chain of 17 Foodtown supermarkets on Long Island in December in a transaction valued at $85 million. Stop & Shop focuses on providing a very large selection of foods along with general merchandise such as books, prescription drugs and flowers.
Overall, brokers say, retailers that have something new and exciting to offer will continue to prosper even in this economy.
"The ones that can come up with a niche and provide better service and good selection and good quality will do well," said Lawrence Holzman of Lawrence Holzman Inc., a retail leasing consultant in Manhattan.
Mr. Holzman represents a rapidly growing supermarket chain called Advantage Stores, which is based in Farmingdale.
Advantage, which describes itself as a hybrid between a traditional supermarket and a warehouse club, opened two stores last year, has a third scheduled to open next Saturday in Bethpage, and expects to have as many as 10 stores open by the end of the year.
The concept, a new one, is to offer a smaller selection of merchandise in a smaller environment, with no membership fee, but at similar discounts offered by warehouse clubs.
"We are going from zero in revenues in 1994, to $6 million in 1995 and expect to go to $22 million this year," said Brian Robinson, the company's founder and chief executive officer.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Fair Lawn and Clifton Upgrading Lagging Corridors

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
TIME has not been a friend to neighborhood commercial corridors. Once places where residents flocked to do business, they have been drained of some of their luster and prosperity as malls and strip centers siphoned away patrons. A roller-coaster economy over the last decade has also taken a toll.
But rather than continue at the mercy of such forces, a few communities are pursuing revitalization programs for their lagging corridors, just as has been and is being done for downtowns. Such corridors generally comprise a jumble of businesses -- from individual shops and retail strips to professional offices and even industry -- stretching for blocks and lining a main thoroughfare in the community. 
 Campaigns are under way on River Road in Fair Lawn in Bergen County and on Main Avenue in Clifton in Passaic County to give the old streets a new image more in tune with the 1990's and promote more commerce.
At least from a retail perspective, that may not be easy. "Though traffic at malls is decreasing, these corridors, like downtowns, have an uphill battle to attract customers," said Kurt Barnard, a retail analyst based in Scotch Plains. "They have to offer something other than just stores." Even that will only slow -- not halt -- the decline, he said.
Still, officials in Clifton and Fair Lawn say the efforts will help maintain the tax base in their communities and make them more attractive places in which to live, work and shop. Each, however, is taking a different approach.
In Fair Lawn, business leaders with the borough and county as partners last April began an $8 million, three-year campaign for River Road, the oldest of five commercial corridors in the community. The project also includes two blocks of Fair Lawn Avenue. Financing is coming from public and private sources, including $300,000 from a group of businesses to cover operating costs for the nonprofit River Road Improvement Corporation, which oversees the program. .
"The key is the private sector's involvement," said Donald R. Smartt, president of Downtown Managers, a consulting firm in Verona, who is working on the River Road program. "There's never enough public funds for such efforts, and it insures the program can survive changes in local leadership." He said that forming a Special Improvement District would be considered after three years. A 1984 state law lets communities set up such districts, in which property owners tax themselves to finance improvements as well as services, including marketing to spur business.
River Road runs for a mile and a half through Fair Lawn's western section past houses, offices, shops, service businesses, a retail strip and some manufacturing plants and labs. The 150 businesses that fill its midsection, many in former homes, comprise a weary hodgepodge, worsened by poor lighting and road conditions, according to a report by the River Road Improvement Corporation.
Mayor Joseph Tedeschi is betting that, with a new look involving "better access, and more services, specialty retailers and restaurants," River Road can become more viable. Robert W. Landzettel, chairman of the improvement corporation, agreed. "The results will not pop up overnight, but this program provides the framework to move into the future," said Mr. Landzettel, whose family has run Lazon Paints on River Road for 34 years.
Among the $1.75 million in physical upgrades planned are the creation of two more parking lots and the improvement of three intersections along River Road, with work on the first intersection at Fair Lawn Avenue to start this spring.
Business owners are also being encouraged to spruce up their properties with the help of low-interest loans offered through four neighborhood banks. Each has committed to lend $500,000 annually for the next three years in seven-year loans of $5,000 to $50,000 at one point below the prime rate. The loans can be used to improve store facades and interiors.
The approval process has also been expedited and the borough is revising its zoning ordinance. Some revisions will raise building heights along the street to three stories from two and permit office and residential use above stores. And following the improvement corporation's "streetscape master plan," property owners are encouraged to put in new signage and more landscaping.
O NE example is the $10 million expansion planned for the 25,000-square-foot Shop Rite that anchors an 85,000-square-foot shopping center on the corridor. The old supermarket will be razed and replaced by a 55,000 square foot store.
"We worked with the corporation on the streetscape plan and will implement it at our site," said Todd Koenig of Saphire Associates in Princeton, the Shop Rite project's architect. Among other things, 35 trees will go up in front of the new store, to be clad in beige concrete block, and shepherd-crook street lights will line the entrance. Mr. Koenig said construction would start by June and finish by year-end.
"We have set a higher standard for the street," said Mr. Smartt, the consultant, "and now we are giving property owners the incentives to follow it."
Mayor Tedeschi said that if the program worked well on River Road, it might be tried on the borough's Broadway corridor.
As part of a Clifton's improvement program, the city has so far committed more than $500,000 in Federal grants to renovating 6 of the 25 blocks that comprise its Main Avenue business corridor, one of several in the community.
The initial focus is on physical improvements, including new brick-paved sidewalks, planters and street lights, said Stephen Lopez, who runs a planning and landscape architecture firm in Pleasantville in Westchester County and is a consultant to the city on the improvement program. The work is to be completed by this fall and will then continue along Main Avenue.
At the same time, proposals are before the City Council to add more parking, form a special improvement district and create an "overlay zone" that will set design standards for among other things building facades and signs. The latter is intended "to bring continuity to the avenue's appearance," added Mr. Lopez, who is also Commissioner of Planning for the Town of Greenburgh where a similar strategy improved that community's portion of Central Park Avenue, a main commercial thoroughfare in Westchester County
The property on the six blocks of Clifton's Main Avenue, made up of 40 mostly retail businesses, is a mishmash, Mr. Lopez said. With low-interest loans from the city in cooperation with local banks, property owners will be encouraged to improve the appearance of their buildings using the new standards as well as add more landscaping.
"The area needs an extra shot in the arm, and this program gives me some optimism for the future," said Paul Epstein, whose family has operated Epstein's at Clifton, a women's clothing store on the avenue since 1945.
One encouraging sign is the transformation of a dormant auto dealership into a tire-supply store. Although the tire store, while on Main Avenue, is outside the six-block target area, its transformation at a cost of more than $1 million "is a plus to the avenue and an incentive" for property owners to follow suit, said Donna M. Sidoti, the city's program monitor for community development. "If we do nothing," she added, "the avenue could decline beyond repair."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Part of Fair Lawn Avenue at River Road intersection, top, is to be renovated. Donald R. Smartt, a consultant, far right, met with Arthur M. Levine, a property owner. (Photographs by Lenore Davis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: VIEWPOINT: ELI M. NOAM;
The Airwaves as a Toll Road

BYLINE: By ELI M. NOAM; Eli M. Noam is a professor of finance and economics at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business and director of its Institute for Tele-Information. He was a member of the New York State Public Service Commission from 1987 to 1990.

 BODY:
WHEN President Clinton signed the telecommunications act into law on Thursday, one of the major unresolved issues was whether television broadcasters should pay for their licenses for next-generation digital TV. Senator Bob Dole insists that they should. And the most-discussed way would be through an auction in which they would bid, just like mobile phone operators, for the spectrum they plan to use. 
 Broadcasters are appalled, divining political motives. They successfully fought similar suggestions for decades, but their problem now is that it seems almost everyone loves a spectrum auction: liberals, because it makes companies pay their way; conservatives, because it substitutes market mechanisms for government controls; economists, because it allocates the spectrum quickly and efficiently, and budget balancers, because it raises much money.
Those who oppose auctions are either existing broadcasters arguing on behalf of traditional "free" and new digital TV, or public-interest advocates who regard the spectrum as a public sphere subject to public-service obligations.
It seems fair and efficient to charge for a scarce resource. That makes auctions a useful tool for now, especially if they are linked to flexible usage that encourages competition, such as letting a cellular phone company also use its access for broadcasting. But there is a better free-market option, one that can preserve flexibility for the future: an open-entry spectrum system.
The current auction system compares the spectrum to land. But that is based on today's relatively primitive state of technology in which information is basically coded onto a single frequency to prevent interference with other users. For similar reasons, most bands are dedicated to a single purpose, like mobile phones or radio. It is as if a highway were divided into wide lanes for each type of usage -- trucking, busing, touring -- and then into narrow lanes, one for each transportation company. One can then debate how to distribute the lanes, whether, for instance, by economics, politics, luck, priority or ethnic diversity.
But why not instead mingle the traffic of users, and if the highway begins to fill up, charge a toll to every user? And make that toll depend on traffic conditions, so it is higher at rush hour than at midnight? In such a system, a user does not buy part of the highway, but instead pays for access to the road. On certain frequency bands that would be dedicated to this system, nobody would control any particular frequency and anybody could enter at any time, without need for a license.
All spectrum users in this system would be subject to an access fee, or toll, that would be continuously and automatically determined by the supply-and-demand conditions at the time. They would transmit not on one frequency, but anywhere on a wide band; in New York, for instance, CBS would not come in on the frequency now commonly known as Channel 2, but would enter anywhere along the TV or other bands, with one or multiple programs. With new "smart" technology, TV sets would then select the broadcaster or program that the viewer had chosen from a menu on the screen. Or the viewer might choose to hear music or visit the Internet, and the smart TV would pick those off the band.
THIS is not farfetched. Evolving technology can squeeze much more information into a spectrum band by having the bits of information seek temporarily unoccupied frequencies and time slots rather than stick to one dedicated frequency. And economics, through variations in the access price, can allocate the scarce spectrum most efficiently.
How would the price be set? Users of spectrum bands would run clearinghouses that would function like commodity exchanges, but for spectrum rights instead of orange juice or pork bellies. In practical terms, a clearinghouse would be a computer that sends out price signals; users who accept the price would respond with a return signal. When capacity is underutilized, prices drop and an updated signal is sent.
This system need not be applied to every band. For example, some frequencies could be dedicated to educational or governmental users, which could also resell parts of their capacity to raise operating revenue. Similarly, election candidates could get a "bit endowment" to gain access to the spectrum.
Some auction enthusiasts believe that establishing firm property rights in the spectrum would mean the end of government regulation. But that is naive. Such rights, by themselves, would not end government intrusion any more than private ownership of land stops government from regulating it in detail. Indeed, an auction could lead to regulation if the highest bids are made by companies seeking oligopolistic pricing. To maintain competitive markets, it is thus important to create the possibility of continuous entry by other companies because high prices would then not be sustainable.
Who gets the proceeds from the access charges? As in auctions, it would be the United States Treasury, but with the revenue flow smoothed, rather than dependent on one-time sales. Proceeds now disappear into the black hole of the budget, taking money out of the telecommunications infrastructure when there is a need to upgrade it. This suggests the need for some funds to be designated for reinvestment in communications.
The concept of pay-as-you-go spectrum access, rather than exclusive licenses, is unfamiliar. But it is no different from the situation of an independent gas station that cannot be certain of the price of wholesale gasoline, but buys it at market prices. Where certainty of price is essential, markets for capacity futures will no doubt evolve just as they did for crude oil.
Is the concept practical? In the 1950's, when a law student, Leo Herzel, and the future Nobel laureate Ronald H. Coase proposed spectrum auctions, they were met with a host of spurious objections based on their impracticality. Technologically, this next-generation system is not now available, but its components either exist or are in reach.
The point is that spectrum allocation can take new forms. This suggests that Congress, instead of legislating this matter in detail now, should delegate authority to its expert agency, the Federal Communications Commission, to devise appropriate systems of fees. And it suggests that the F.C.C., whose auctions have been a success story, should not sit on its laurels but should approach free-market spectrum allocation in a pragmatic and searching fashion. We should be ready to bring the invisible hand fully to the invisible resource.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;
Luxury Club's Demise Was Sudden but Slow

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
When the Atrium Club opened in 1975 on a swank block of 57th Street near Park Avenue, Gerald R. Ford was President and the idea of a luxurious social club with a top-flight gymnasium and a dining room was the buzz of chic Manhattan. But when it closed abruptly on Feb. 1, perhaps the most surprising thing about the Atrium Club was that its death took so long -- and that it came without notice.
Dozens of club members and employees came in from a cold winter morning to find the elevators to the eighth-floor club barred by security guards. The only explanation was a three-paragraph "Dear Member" letter taped to the marble walls that read, in part, "Unfortunately, the economic realities of the Atrium Cub do not permit the continued operation of the club on a free-standing basis." 
 All the stock of Atrium Club Inc. is owned by the Dallas-based Club Corporation of America, one of the world's largest health, fitness and golf club operators. James Maser, vice president of Atrium Club, described Club Corporation's role as a "consultant."
Mr. Maser blamed the demise of the club, with initiation fees of up to $1,000, plus $110 or more in monthly dues, on changing tax laws and increasing competition from "super gyms" like Reebok and Equinox on the Upper West Side.
"It closed because the economics of the business would not allow it to continue," he said. He pointed especially to changes in Federal tax laws -- reducing the deduction for business meals to 50 percent from 100 percent and eliminating the deduction for club dues -- that, he said, meant a steady decline in the number of members using the club to entertain clients.
But several members and employees blamed the closing on years of poor management. "All the members I knew left when it was clear the club was being managed very poorly," Joseph F. Blumenthal, a member for 12 years, said. "It was always treated as a black sheep in a very large family."
Services in general, he said, did not merit the club's steep membership costs. For example, deteriorating shower stalls were not retiled, and management dragged its heels in buying new equipment like the Gravitron weight machine.
Behind in the monthly rent, which they declined to disclose, the Atrium Club's management has been trying to sell the operation since November. Gerald H. Morganstern, a lawyer for the building's landlord, Laszlo Tauber & Associates, said negotiations are under way with the New York Health and Racquet Club.
But what will happen to the 1,500 members and 55 gym instructors, kitchen staff and maintenance workers is uncertain. A spokesman for the New York Health and Racquet Club declined to comment. ANTHONY RAMIREZ

HEADLINE: Lower Taxes, Higher Revenues

BYLINE: By Jack Kemp; Jack Kemp, co-director of Empower America, was Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Bush Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It is a paradoxical truth that tax rates are too high today and tax revenues are too low, and the soundest way to raise the revenues in the long run is to cut taxes now." These Reaganesque words came straight from the lips of President John F. Kennedy in 1962, and they ring as true today as they did then.
Why, then, do so many politicans from both parties offer only spending reductions as means to balance the budget? No doubt a balanced budget is an important goal, and we'll have to cut wasteful Federal spending to get there. But surely none of the Republican candidates really believes that we can erase the deficit and reduce the Federal debt solely by tightening our collective budget belt. We need tax reform too. 
 Part of the problem is that for years the liberal establishment has been insisting that the Reagan Revolution increased the deficit dramatically. It seems that many in Congress and several Republican candidates are beginning to believe it. The result is a barrage of attacks on pro-growth tax proposals, based on the mistaken charge that cutting taxes would cause the deficit to explode. A history lesson is in order.
Three times in this century the United States has significantly reduced the top marginal income tax rates. In the 1920's the top rate was lowered from 73 percent to 25 percent. Between 1921 to 1928, tax revenues rose from $719 million to $1.16 billion, an increase of over 60 percent. President Kennedy's tax cuts between 1963 and 1965 lowered the top rate from 91 percent to 70 percent. Over that period, revenues increased more than 16 percent.
In the 1980's, taxes were lowered from a top marginal rate of 70 percent to 28 percent. By the end of the decade, America's real gross domestic product surged by 32 percent and revenues grew by nearly 40 percent. True, nominal budget deficits were higher at the end of the Reagan era. But as a percentage of the gross domestic product, the deficit actually diminished during the 1980's.
That is why today all efforts to expand the economy by lowering the tax burden on work, savings, investment and entrepreneurship -- including flat-tax plans of Steve Forbes and Representative Dick Armey -- deserve to be discussed and debated, without anyone invoking class warfare.
The National Commission on Economic Growth and Tax Reform, which I chaired for House Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole, found that a radical overhaul of the tax code would be vital to our goal of doubling the rate of economic growth. We recommended a simple plan that would tax income only once at a flat rate no higher than 19 percent and would allow working men and women to deduct their payroll taxes. (I would go further and exempt charitable donations and home mortgage interest.)
While we debate such radical reforms, we should quickly reduce the capital gains tax and index it to eliminate the effects of inflation -- a key to ending the budget stalemate.
Critics of a capital gains tax cut claim that doing so would be a payoff to the rich and would cause revenues to fall, thereby increasing the deficit. This is not true. Cutting and indexing capital gains tax rates would help low-income and high-risk entrepreneurial ventures get investors, fostering a more vibrant national economy and thereby expanding the tax base. The capital gains tax is less of a tax on the rich than it is a barrier to the success of lower-income people willing to take a risk.
Cutting taxes is the key to doubling the rate of economic growth, and would do more for America than just help balance the Federal budget. None of the myriad challenges confronting our nation -- poverty, crime, racial tension and welfare dependence -- can be solved without economic expansion.

HEADLINE: After a Dismal '95, Small Markets Surge

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
SOME of the world's smallest markets have come roaring back this year. Leading the charge have been Latin American stocks, though their brethren in Southeast Asia have also contributed to the impressive gains racked up by emerging-markets funds.
Talk about a turnaround. After a dismal performance last year, funds investing south of the border rose nearly 14 percent in January, far surpassing the gains of United States stock funds. 
 The surge in Latin American markets poses a question for investors: Have you already missed the boat this year? Managers of mutual funds invested in the region are quick to reassure, saying Latin America has plenty of room left to run.
With the exception of Chile, though, "Latin America is not a high-growth story," said Robert L. Meyer, who manages more than $1 billion in Latin American equities for Morgan Stanley, including the Morgan Stanley Latin American Fund, which rose 18.1 percent last month. "It's more like a reformed alcoholic. The region has kicked the habit of the fiscal and economic excesses of the 80's."
As a result, there will be setbacks as well as advances, and both will tend to be sharp like the one in January, Mr. Meyer said.
Behind the recent stock surge is a region on the rebound. Latin American markets fell 20.5 percent in 1995 after plunging 15 percent in 1994.
Contributing to last year's decline was selling by Americans who wanted to use their Latin American losses to offset domestic gains. Short-selling by skeptics didn't help either.
By the end of last year, investors acutely aware of the high stock prices in the United States were scouring the world for a region with greater potential in the new year. After a miserable showing in 1995, emerging markets captured much attention, with a particular emphasis on Latin America.
Money started flooding into the region early this year, chasing a limited number of shares. Prices rose as demand began to exceed supply. "It doesn't take much in less liquid markets to be pushed very hard," Mark J. Edwards, co-manager of the T. Rowe Price Latin America fund, said in a telephone interview from London.
The turnabout by investors was based in large part on the strengthening of the Mexican economy. The currency devaluation in December 1994 was handled badly by the Mexicans, Mr. Meyer and others conceded, but other policies have had more success. (For one, the country has a balanced budget.) While the banking sector remains dicey, fears of a general economic collapse have been averted. The country seems to be back on track after stabilizing its currency.
All the region's larger markets -- Argentina, Brazil and Mexico -- are making the transition from recession to growth, said Maria-Elena Carrion, co-manager of the BT Investment Latin American Equity fund. As a result, "earnings comparisons will be much better in the second half of 1996, whereas earnings growth rates will be slowing down in the U.S. and Europe," she said.
Mexico looks pretty good over the next 12 to 36 months, said Peter M. Donovan, who runs the Wright Equifund Mexico, the only fund to invest solely in that country. "Certainly there's more room for the authorities to cut interest rates," he said, "and that should help stock prices."
Mr. Meyer of Morgan Stanley kept his fund fully invested during the region's dark days and is pouring new money into existing holdings. In Mexico, which accounts for about a third of his portfolio, he focuses on blue-chip companies, including two banks, Banacci and Bancomer, each with about 20 percent market share; Cemex, a cement company, and Femsa, one of two companies that control the beer industry.
In Brazil, Mr. Meyer owns shares in the state-owned telecommunications, utilities and oil companies, which he expects to be privatized after spurts in profitability. Telebras's earnings should double by year-end, and it was just listed on the New York Stock Exchange. He also owns shares in Electrobras and Petrobras, electric and oil companies.
Electrobras is also a favorite of Mr. Edwards of T. Rowe Price. His fund tends to focus on blue-chip companies with steady growth.In Mexico, these include Cifra, a retailer, and Televisa, the media giant.
The BT and Hercules Latin America Value funds, co-managed by Ms. Carrion, focus on two major themes in the markets of Mexico, Brazil and Argentina. First are sectors that are sensitive to falling interest rates, like banking, real estate and construction. Next are cyclical stocks like consumer durables and auto parts.
Ed Games, who manages more than $600 million in the Scudder Latin America fund, favors the soft-drink industry, and owns Pan American Beverages, the biggest Coca-Cola bottler in Latin America.
What's the best way to play Latin America? Most of the 14 funds investing in the region came along in 1994, the year after the Latin America group gained 57.1 percent, on average. Many others are very small.
Scudder Latin America, which started in late 1992, is the granddaddy of the group. It is also the favorite of Kim Rebecca, a Morningstar analyst. She says the fund has the "most consistent level of performance and risk management."
The funds can vary widely in their investment practices. While Morgan Stanley stays fully invested, no matter the market conditions, the Scudder fund has pushed its cash holdings as high as 17 percent of assets when prices seemed high.
"When we see a great deal of euphoria," Mr. Games said, "we increase cash so we have money on hand to meet redemptions or buy stocks," after the bubble bursts.
So just how nervous is he after that sizzling January? Enough to have stashed 9 percent of the fund in cash.

HEADLINE: The Sun Shines Again In Brazil and Argentina

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
THE stock markets of Argentina and Brazil staged startling comebacks in the first month of 1996, and they have now recovered all the losses suffered after stocks were dragged down by Mexico's financial crisis.
In Buenos Aires, where the Merval index has risen 5.7 percent since Jan. 1, the rally is being fueled by local investors, mainly large retirement funds that have acquired new capital, and renewed faith at home and abroad that Argentina will not devalue its currency as Mexico did so fatefully in December 1994. 
 In Sao Paulo, Brazil, where the Bovespa index is up 22.1 percent since New Year's, the boom is being driven by foreign bargain hunters and growing optimism over Brazil's prospects for growth and lower interest rates this year.
After erratic trading, heavy losses, capital flight and overall uncertainty in 1995, the sharp rise in Argentine and Brazilian stocks demonstrates new confidence in these two emerging markets. Stockbrokers and market analysts said they expected the rallies to continue, especially after the recent drop in United States interest rates.
"The January rally was not a fluke, and I expect it to continue this year because investors are convinced of Argentina's stability and potential for growth," said Christopher Eccelstone, an analyst for Interacciones Research, based in Buenos Aires. "I only see the market going up from here, perhaps with a few minor glitches along the way."
A big contributor to the bull market seen by Mr. Eccelstone would be Argentina's retirement funds, which are looking to increase yields by investing in equities.
Mr. Eccelstone predicted that Argentine retirement funds, which now have about 6 percent of their $2.49 billion in assets invested in the stock market, could raise their equity position to 25 percent over the next two years.
But Argentina, still struggling to overcome a deep recession brought on by the Mexico currency crisis, desperately needs foreign investment to finance growth in its stock market and economy and to meet its debt payments. The recession wiped away Argentina's growth last year and led to record levels of unemployment.
Many economists and analysts said foreign investors were again interested in Argentina, especially because the country had made good on its promise not to devalue its currency and to maintain its convertibility plan, which pegs the Argentine peso one-to-one with the dollar.
Foreign investors have also been encouraged by a recent agreement between President Carlos Saul Menem and Finance Minister Domingo Cavallo to stop the public bickering that has raised uncertainty over the continuation of policy changes that have brought growth and stability to the economy.
"The key is foreign investors in Argentina," said Luis Corsiglia, a well-known broker here. "We need an inflow of capital from abroad, and we are starting to see a return of many foreigners who were scared away last year."
Mr. Corsiglia, like many other brokers and economists, is predicting 3 to 5 percent economic growth for Argentina this year. He also expects the Merval index to reach 700 this year, for a one-year gain of nearly 35 percent.
STOCKBROKERS are recommending Argentine stocks in the banking and utility sectors, including Banco Frances, Banco de Galicia, Telefonica, Telecom Argentina and the oil company YPF. But brokers said the performance of Argentina's stock market would depend heavily on the ability of the Government to control costs and to institute the next round of economic policy changes in the banking, health care, labor and judicial systems and in the provincial governments.
In Brazil, meanwhile, foreign investors hungry for bargains poured into its stock market during January and the appetite is expected to continue. These investors are showing keen interest in Brazilian private-sector stocks in areas like steel, banking, paper and pulp, and consumer durables. Those areas will probably benefit most from expected growth in the economy and a reduction in interest rates.
"Foreign investors are coming into Brazil because there's a general feeling that some parts of the market are cheap and attractively priced, especially the private sector," said Jay Pelosky Jr., director of research and strategy for Morgan Stanley Latin America. "There is also a sense that the economy is likely to pick up in 1996 and that interest rates will come down dramatically."
Morgan Stanley is advising its clients to maintain a 60-40 split between private- and public-sector stocks in Brazil. State enterprises like the oil company Petrobras, the electricity utility Electrobras and the phone company Telebras were the best performers last year.
"Capital is coming back into the markets and although there may be some bad political news that leads to selling pressure, it will be minimal," Mr. Pelosky said. "Some people still have a bear-market psychology, but we recommend that people get in and stay in."
Wayne Perkins, director of research for Banco Norchem F.A., Chemical Bank's investment banking affiliate in Brazil, said his strategy was to look for stocks that might not have stunning results in the short term but whose prices were so low as to discount potential problems.
"For those who have a strong stomach for volatility and an appetite for strong returns, Brazil is a good place to invest," Mr. Perkins said. "I believe this is the best macroeconomic political situation for Brazil in the last 30 to 40 years."

HEADLINE: Saudi Arabia Economy Is Looking Better

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"An Inconvenient Saudi Dissident" (editorial, Feb. 5) says that the Saudi Arabian Government's fiscal situation has deteriorated in recent years. 
 The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait necessitated the payment by Saudi Arabia of more than $55 billion in cash for direct war-related expenses, which represented one-half of the country's gross domestic product at that time and slowed achievement of the kingdom's economic goals.
Saudi Arabia has largely recovered.
Budgets were cut by 20 percent in 1994 and 6 percent in 1995, subsidies have been reduced, and the fiscal picture is improving, not deteriorating.
This success derives from cultivation of a strong private sector; an open economy that attracts the participation of foreign companies, and investment of nearly $1 trillion in infrastructure in less than three decades.
Gross domestic product growth at an estimated 4.3 percent for 1995 and repayment of the Government's international debt during that year provide evidence of the improved outlook.
 
MEDLEJ AL-MEDLEJ
Executive Director
U.S.-Saudi Arabian Business Council
Washington, Feb. 6, 1996

HEADLINE: At the Apollo, Past Meets Future

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
GRACE BLAKE has a dream mission. Or is it a nearly impossibl' task?
Ms. Blake, the new executive director of the Apollo Theater Foundation, envisions turning the landmark Apollo Theater in the heart of Harlem into a world-class cultural magnet: a place to expose young African-Americans to the arts and to honor legendary entertainers like Billie Holiday and Count Basie who graced the stage on 125th Street. 
 "I came here and realized we have a gold mine," said Ms. Blake, who brings to her seven-month-old job 25 years of experience in the film industry. "For whatever reason, it's not been tapped."
To begin that process, the theater has signed Patti LaBelle for an appearance later this month and B. B. King, Bobby Blue Bland and Ruth Brown for a joint appearance next month that Ms. Blake hopes will attract a wide cross section of people.
"It really and truly is a dream mission," Ms. Blake said, when asked about the daunting prospect of raising money for a theater in a struggling neighborhood in a time of economic retrenchment. "I visualize what can happen with this place. I don't see the odds against it. It's a big challenge, but the challenge is the excitement."
The Apollo is one of the icons of Harlem and of New York City, with a rich history that reflects the permutations of American race relations. But it has lost millions of dollars since the late 1970's and still struggles to survive. The Apollo's decline in fortunes has been linked to that of Harlem, and community leaders see the theater's rebirth as integral to the community's growth.
"Grace has an arduous task," said Warren S. Whitlock, the deputy executive director of the Harlem Community Development Corporation. "They need to create more artistic venues there. It's critical to get more stars -- but big stars want to go to Madison Square Garden, the Meadowlands.
"It's very critical this community understand we have a famous landmark institute we need to support, and I'm sure the community will." '
The four-story building, which was erected in 1913, closed in 1978 because its owners -- the family of Frank Schiffman, a former schoolteacher -- said they felt they were losing too much money. The Apollo did not reopen until 1983. But it began to lose so much money again that by 1991, Percy E. Sutton, the entrepreneur and former Manhattan Borough President, who had bought it with a group of investors at a bankruptcy sale, was ready to give it up. By then, Mr. Sutton had presided over a $20 million renovation that his group hoped would make the Apollo the center of a revitalized West 125th Street, Harlem's main commercial strip. The money went into creating an entertainment complex with a recording studio and television production center; but they were seldom used. In 1992, the investors transferred ownership to the Apollo Theater Foundation.
The nonprofit foundation was created with a mandate that included establishing a permanent public museum within the theater and a hall of fame, and to offer benefit performances and fund-raisers that would go into the construction and maintenance of the hall.
The first inductees will include Nat (King) Cole, Moms Mabley, Duke Ellington and Bill (Bojangles) Robinson. Construction of the hall is expected to cost $500,000.
The theater has not been able to draw, on a regular basis, the big-name stars that made it famous. Yet, more than 17,000 tourists and patrons come to the theater each month, and the legendary Wednesday amateur night competition continues to be popular. The 12-member staff coordinates about 12 events a month.
The glory days began in 1934, when the Apollo opened a "colored revue." In the following years, Sarah Vaughn, James Brown and the Jackson Five were among the many who won the amateur night competitions. When the Beatles made their first trip to New York in 1964, they said the Apollo was the place they most wanted to visit. When there were riots in Harlem in 1966, the Apollo was untouched.
But now, Ms. Blake said, "the sound stage and the recording studio are hardly ever used -- they're sitting there like a huge white elephant." She continued, "We have a facility to screen movies here, and there are no movie theaters in this area except for the Victoria," which is a few doors away.
"I started free movies for kids in this area," Ms. Blake added. "In the last four months, 8,000 kids have come through. I want to make this more of an educational and cultural resource for the community."
One way she wants to do this is by using the Apollo's technical equipment to train young blacks in a variety of film jobs. The theater has a wish list that ranges from filing cabinets to video equipment.
Ms. Blake's tasks include raising money, revitalizing the 10-member board and expanding the theater's artistic venues. She has instituted a "buy a seat" campaign to raise $12.5 million. Patrons can buy seats in tribute to any of the legion of stars who have graced the stage -- Aretha Franklin, the Jackson Five, Sammy Davis Jr., Josephine Baker, Count Basie, Dinah Washington, Pearl Bailey, Ray Charles, Bill Cosby and many others.
Ms. Blake's plans for next month include a gospel tribute to Rosa Parks, the woman whose refusal to give up a bus seat in Alabama was instrumental in sparking the civil-rights demonstrations in the 1960's, and a black-tie benefit and tribute concert with Lionel Hampton.
In honor of Black History Month, "Good Day New York," on Channel 5, the Fox Network affiliate in New York, will broadcast its Feb. 27 show live from the theater, including a version of amateur night involving the "Good Day" staff. The doors open to the public at 5:30 A.M.
Ms. Blake, 59 and the mother of three, is a tall woman with a head of fluffy gray hair and an elegant but easygoing manner. She came to the United States from Trinidad during the desegregation upheavals of the 1960's and made the leap from a secretarial jobs to her film career after visiting the set of the Sidney Poitier film "For Love of Ivy." She was beguiled by the buzz of excitement and creativity. She worked as a production coordinator for films like "Prizzi's Honor" (1985), "All That Jazz" (1979) and "Eyewitness" (1981); a production assistant on "Shaft" (1971), and the executive producer of Spike Lee's "School Daze" (1988).
She is hoping that her film industry connections will work to her advantage in her new realm.
She has already brought members of the Directors Guild of America to Harlem. And in December, the theater was the setting of the Reebok International Human Rights Awards, which attracted Richard Gere and Ziggy Marley, among others.
But Ms. Blake's mission could not have come at a more difficult time, in the wake of the Dec. 8 arson fire that killed eight people in Freddy's clothing store, which is across the street from the Apollo. The fire, which the police have called racially motivated, was set by a black gunman in a white-owned store, and it followed protests by black demonstrators, who were angry that the store owner was evicting a black-owned record store.
A board member for the Apollo Theater Foundation, Evelyn Cunningham, says she believes the board needs fresh ideas to turn things around for the Apollo and that it needs young people with backgrounds in entertainment and law. But, she added, Ms. Blake has already raised morale by talking directly about the difficult tasks ahead and reaching out to people.
"It's no secret that the Apollo is in trouble," said Ms. Cunningham, a retired journalist who is active in civic affairs, "but Grace Blake has made a terrific difference already."
