HEADLINE: THE WORLD: The China-and-Taiwan Problem;
How Politics Torpedoed Asian Calm

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
TEN months ago, China and Taiwan were on the verge of opening their seaports to each other's shipping and inaugurating direct air service across the Taiwan Strait for the first time in nearly 50 years of barely suspended civil war. Now suddenly, pistols are drawn and the threat of military confrontation hangs in the air like grenade smoke.
How such a reversal could so suddenly threaten the stability of Asia is a drama in which there are four players, each with its distinctive contribution to the crisis. The first is the Republican Congress, which has spawned the most energetic coalition ever assembled to openly confront China while the second player, the Clinton Administration, has sought "engagement." Congress has promoted independence for Taiwan and Tibet, and it proposes sanctions every time China is found wanting on human rights, nuclear proliferation and the theft of a Mickey Mouse trademark.
 
 
 
Doing Business
 Often lost in the American debate on China is the fact that for two decades, the Chinese on the mainland and on Taiwan have been getting richer, doing more business together, negotiating greater cultural exchanges and conducting a broader political dialogue than ever before. Millions of Taiwanese tourists have visited their ancestral homes on the mainland, renewed old acquaintances and forged new ones. An estimated $20 billion in Taiwan investment has migrated to the mainland's cheap labor markets and unofficial conversations between Beijing and Taipei became the rule, not the exception.
But instead of nurturing this environment, many in Congress have allied themselves with the political machine of Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, the third player in the piece.
To straddle the divided politics of Taiwan, Mr. Lee has been forced to court Taiwan's pro-independence voters, now thought to be nearly a third of the island's electorate. At the same time, he adheres to the Nationalist Party creed that reunification of China is the ultimate goal. In this schizophrenic environment, Mr. Lee's popularity goes up every time he strikes a blow for Taiwan's international image; playing the American card has been the key to his strategy. In Washington, his political operatives tap American revulsion for Beijing's repression to enhance Taiwan's leverage in the running dialogue with the mainland.
Armed with Congressional backing, Taiwan has been emboldened by its own success into ever more energetic efforts to increase its leverage, including the now famous trip to Cornell University. To the average American, Mr. Lee's trip to upstate New York seemed innocent, even admirable. Wasn't the issue freedom of travel? In fact the trip was part of President Lee's strategy to change the political status of Taiwan. If there needed to be any other reminder, the trip occurred in the same year that Mr. Lee offered the United Nations a $1 billion gift in an unavailing effort to win a seat there.
 
 
 
Wearing Fig Leaves
 President Clinton's abrupt decision in May 1995 to let Mr. Lee visit -- a first-of-a-kind trip for a Taiwan leader -- nearly ripped away the last shred of the fig leaf put in place when President Richard M. Nixon normalized relations with China. The fig leaf was enshrined in the Shanghai communique of 1972:
"The United States acknowledges that all Chinese on either side of the Taiwan Strait maintain there is but one China and that Taiwan is a part of China. The United States Government does not challenge that position. It reaffirms its interest in a peaceful settlement of the Taiwan question by the Chinese themselves." This simple statement, and China's consent to it, shelved the Taiwan problem, and allowed the United States to safely begin removing its military forces from the island. Thus the Taiwan question moved from belligerency to political deferral. Taiwan could take charge of its own destiny. It could walk, talk and act like a country and America would switch its diplomatic recognition to Beijing.
Even though it was a cold war instrument that put Beijing and Washington in common cause against Soviet expansion, the Shanghai communique ushered in the longest period of Asian peace and stability in this century and made it possible for Asia's vibrant new economies to emerge.
The latter-day strategies of Lee Teng-hui to enlarge Taiwan's political identity have attracted sympathy because of the actions of the fourth player in the drama, the Communist Party leadership in Beijing. Nothing has energized Taiwan's determination to stay separated from the mainland as much as the mainland's totalitarian ways. Since the Tiananmen massacres of 1989, Taiwanese have asked themselves why anyone would want to reunify with a government that disparages the very sort of democracy they have cultivated.
As Taiwan has sought protection against the unwanted advances of an increasingly brittle Chinese leadership, those advances have become all the more insistent. A new generation of Chinese leaders, none of whom possesses the vision or self-confidence that Deng Xiaoping showed in his prime, has seized on reunification with Taiwan as a kind of manifest destiny and as a means to tap the latent nationalism of the military, the party and of many ordinary Chinese.
 
 
 
A Temptation
 Many Americans are now tempted to enter this fray on the side of Taiwan, to pursue confrontation or containment of the mainland. After all, why continue to sacrifice American ideals on human rights, democracy, trade and proliferation of nuclear poison to a set of outdated cold war agreements? Hasn't the Shanghai communique been overtaken by the reality of Taiwan's flowering as a powerhouse economy and a robust culture that every day disproves the silly notion that respect for law and human rights cannot coexist with the Asian tradition?
But this also is a trap for America, which spent much of the 1950's and 1960's in full battle dress, with American troops and nuclear weapons stationed on Taiwan and, still, Beijing never changed. The Shanghai communique allowed everyone to put away the guns. The strategic weight of China as a foil against the Soviet Union may be gone, but it has been displaced by China's strategic weight as an Asian power whose political evolution is somewhere on the horizon. So all of Asia has a stake in a stable outcome.
The China-Taiwan dispute is a suspended civil war, easily as complicated as Bosnia and much grander in scale. If President Clinton speaks bluntly to Beijing and underscores his bluntness with a display of American military resolve, that runs the risk of inciting Taiwan's independence movement even further.
And then it would be easy for Taiwan to openly declare greater autonomy or outright independence.China specialists who travel to both sides of the Strait fear that such a spiral could lead to war.
On the other hand, the United States could speak about the benefits to both Beijing and Taipei of stepping back, giving up any notion that either side can end a 46-year estrangement through unilateral actions, whether those actions are military (in Beijing's case) or political (in Taiwan's case).
If war comes, China's antiquated military would certainly come out the loser, but this is hardly the point. As irrational as it seems, the prospect of losing is not likely to deter the People's Liberation Army. Its logic rests on the belief that China is willing to make a greater sacrifice, suffer more destruction than America or Taiwan, in order to prevail on a fundamental issue of sovereignty. There would be no winners in a clash of such magnitude.
And it is worth remembering that while China is now ruled by faceless and unimaginative Communist bureaucrats, it is populated by 1.2 billion Chinese, most of whom look up to America and hope that America will help them, not confront or contain them, in their quest to join the developed world.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Taiwan frigates in a military exercise as relations with China have deteriorated. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Blockade of Oil Wells in Mexico Could Imperil Election Reforms

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 10

 BODY:
A blockade of dozens of oil wells in southern Mexico by local Indians and members of an opposition political party has cost Mexico more than $8.5 million in lost revenues over the last 12 days, officials say, and is creating a political standoff that threatens national electoral reforms.
Dozens of demonstrators protesting environmental damage caused by drilling operations of the state oil monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, have been injured or arrested in recent days as the Government has taken increasingly harsh steps to clear the way to 59 oil wells in the coastal state of Tabasco. 
 In some instances, army units have been called in to back up the police, setting off melees that have resulted in injuries to many, including Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, a senior member of the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party. Mr. Lopez Obrador was the defeated candidate in a hotly contested 1994 gubernatorial election in Tabasco.
Prosecutors have asked the local judge to issue an arrest warrant for Mr. Lopez Obrador on charges of obstructing a federal installation.
Whether the prosecutors will actually try to detain Mr. Lopez Obrador, who is a candidate for the presidency of his party, is not at all clear. His arrest would be certain to heighten political tensions both in Tabasco and in Mexico City.
The blockades have already taken on more of a political tone than an environmental one, and have upset a fragile agreement that just last fall brought all four major political parties back to the table to work out electoral reforms in time for the 1997 congressional elections.
By all accounts, the environmental record of Pemex is a nightmare. The oil wells in Tabasco are among Mexico's richest, but the rush to extract the oil without proper safeguards has turned great sections of the state into a toxic swamp where oil seeps up through the ground and rivers are so polluted they catch on fire.
The president of Pemex, Adrian Lajous Vargas, conceded at a news conference on Friday that the company harmed the environment in the 1970's and 1980's, but said that the company is more careful now and that local people have been adequately compensated for any damages. He estimated that the blockades have cost Pemex and the Mexican Government $8.5 million in lost revenues, but added that these losses would not affect guarantees by the Government last year to use oil sales to back up the $12.5 billion in American loans to ease the country's economic crisis.
Mr. Lajous expressed concern that unless Pemex crews can get in to maintain the oil wells and pumps there could be a serious accident.
But the environmental issue has at times seemed only a pretense for a mounting civil resistance campaign that threatens the shaky government of Gov. Roberto Madrazo Pintado, a member of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. Governor Madrazo is being investigated by the federal Attorney General on charges of having violated election laws by spending $70 million in his 1994 campaign. Fewer than 500,000 people voted in the Tabasco election.
Soon after that election, Mr. Lopez Obrador headed similar blockades and protests in Tabasco. The pressure was so great that the administration of President Ernesto Zedillo at one point was ready to make a deal to remove Mr. Madrazo from office. But local P.R.I. leaders, with Mr. Madrazo himself in the lead, broke ranks with the central Government and refused to give up the statehouse, scuttling the deal and setting off a constitutional struggle over states' rights that is still unresolved.

HEADLINE: In the Super Bowl of Sports Stuff, the Winning Score is $2 Billion

BYLINE: By Robert Lipsyte 

 BODY:
With all the mystical assurance of an ancient seer reading entrails, Steve Mann planted his feet on an upper rim of Atlanta's Georgia Dome last week, hefted a little metal toy truck and declared: "Baseball is dead."
Mann, a lanky 31-year-old redhead with an all-American smile, is the sales manager for Ertl Collectibles of Dyersville, Iowa, where the movie "Field of Dreams" was shot. But Mann is a realist. The truck in his hand, modeled after a 1938 Chevy panel, bore the colors and logo of the Texas Rangers. It was not selling well at $14.99, said Mann, because collectors were turned off by "baseball strikes and $8 million players." 
 On the other hand, the 1956 Ford pickup with Notre Dame colors and a piggy bank slot was doing well. People felt better about football and colleges.
"This is a goofy, vicious, live-for-now, get-it-while-you-can business," said Mann. "Sports collectibles may be a niche business, but it's just like sports."
Just like sports. From niche to Nike, the Super Show, advertised as the world's largest sporting goods trade fair, offered 10,000 booths of hard-charging sales jocks with this season's live-for-now products, from Grant Hill notebooks to Air Much Uptempo shoes. There were athletes to be sure -- Frank Thomas for Reebok, Nadia Comaneci for Danskin, Marcus Allen for Logo Athletic among dozens -- but they were peripheral to products.
Without the distractions of games, the marketing of athletic shoes, apparel, equipment and bric-a-brac becomes a vivid reflection of the flamboyant, winner-take-all world of sports. Or is sports a reflection of the life-or-death business world? The numbers on the Super Bowl scoreboard represent touchdowns and field goals, mere symbols for the numbers on the Super Show scoreboard representing dollars and market share.
Early in the four-day show, the president of Nike, Tom Clarke, talked about how "the power of sport" enabled the nation-state of swoosh to "crack $2 billion" in apparel growth in 1995. He said that the "inspiration of sports allows us to rebirth ourselves constantly." If there was any doubt that he was talking new product, not New Age, another Nike executive, Steve Gomez, clarified the issue when he said that the juggernaut had entered the college football market with a "quest to own Saturdays."
Bad-mouthing Nike's muscling ways was a sideshow at the Super Show that rang hollow, especially from other powerhouses with prime locations at the Georgia World Congress Center, huge multimedia booths, dancing girls and access restricted to those with appointments. But over in the satellite location, the Georgia Dome, where the mom-and-pops and the licensang trickle-downs strutted their stuff, there was mostly admiration for Nike and hopes of something swooshing their way.
"We may get a shot silk-screening a little for Nike," said the president of APSCO, Phil Livoti, one of two guys named Phil who own the Brooklyn apparel and embroidery firm. A third Phil, the Nike founder Phil Knight, could jump them into the big time. They have a line of Mickey Mantle shirts, licensed by the Manhattan restaurant. They still bask in the 1994 Stanley Cup playoffs when Dennis Ingberg, the marketing v.p., kept his finger on the factory's red button through the sixth and seventh games so they could start rolling those Ranger shirts for Sears and J. C. Penney.
Sporting goods people seem to feel ennobled enough by the trademarked triumphs and tragedies of prime-time sports not to worry too much about the seamier doings on their own sidelines. The "sneakers-to-die-for" controversy of several years ago has faded; after all, went the spin, poor youngsters killed for certain brand-name sunglasses and winter jackets before they started killing for athletic shoes.
And the recurring charge of slave labor by third world children making sneakers and active wear has been countered by those who claim that only by keeping an economic presence in a country, no matter how vile the conditions, can there be hope of reform. The sexier issues of bad behavior by the major league models who keep the mills grinding seem to obscure the real violence.
And then there was Howard Schwartz, president of the Sherwood Group of Rockville, Md., makers of flags and pennants, who was displaying an Orbs EcoSpun sweatshirt manufactured from six plastic liter bottles and an equal weight of mill end fabrics. It was a "responsible garment with a story," but Schwartz had yet to find a responsible coach to outfit his varsity with such shirts and hats; it should be a winning coach with the kind of appeal that would allow him to choose saving the planet over Planet Reebok.
Which brought us to another moment when niche met Nike. "Imagine if Nike took this product on," said Schwartz. "How many plastic bottles they'd need."
Just recycle it.

HEADLINE: MAIN STREET, JAPAN: For Better or for Worse;
Who Needs Love! In Japan, Many Couples Don't

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: OMIYA, Japan

 BODY:
Yuri Uemura sat on the straw tatami mat of her living room and chatted cheerfully about her 40-year marriage to a man whom, she mused, she never particularly liked.
"There was never any love between me and my husband," she said blithely, recalling how he used to beat her. "But, well, we survived." 
 A 72-year-old midwife, her face as weathered as an old baseball and etched with a thousand seams, Mrs. Uemura said that her husband had never told her that he liked her, never complimented her on a meal, never told her "thank you," never held her hand, never given her a present, never shown her affection in any way. He never calls her by her name, but summons her with the equivalent of a grunt or a "Hey, you."
"Even with animals, the males cooperate to bring the females some food," Mrs. Uemura said sadly, noting the contrast to her own marriage. "When I see that, it brings tears to my eyes."
In short, the Uemuras have a marriage that is as durable as it is unhappy, one couple's tribute to the Japanese sanctity of family.
The divorce rate in Japan is at a record high but still less than half that of the United States, and Japan arguably has one of the strongest family structures in the industrialized world. As the United States and Europe fret about the disintegration of the traditional family, most Japanese families remain as solid as the small red table on which Mrs. Uemura rested her tea.
A study published last year by the Population Council, an international nonprofit group based in New York, suggested that the traditional two-parent household is on the wane not only in America but throughout most of the world. There was one prominent exception: Japan.
In Japan, for example, only 1.1 percent of births are to unwed mothers -- virtually unchanged from 25 years ago. In the United States, the figure is 30.1 percent and rising rapidly.
Yet if one comes to a little Japanese town like Omiya to learn the secrets of the Japanese family, the people are not as happy as the statistics.
"I haven't lived for myself," Mrs. Uemura said, with a touch of melancholy, "but for my kids, and for my family, and for society."
Mrs. Uemura's marriage does not seem exceptional in Japan, whether in the big cities or here in Omiya. The people of Omiya, a community of 5,700 nestled in the rain-drenched hills of the Kii Peninsula in Mie Prefecture, nearly 200 miles southwest of Tokyo, have spoken periodically to a reporter about various aspects of their daily lives. On this visit they talked about their families.
 
Survival Secrets
Often, the Couples Expect Little
Osamu Torida furrowed his brow and looked perplexed when he was asked if he loved his wife of 33 years.
"Yeah, so-so, I guess," said Mr. Torida, a cattle farmer. "She's like air or water. You couldn't live without it, but most of the time, you're not conscious of its existence."
The secret to the survival of the marriage, Mr. Torida acknowledged, was not mutual passion.
"Sure, we had fights about our work," he explained as he stood beside his barn. "But we were preoccupied by work and our debts, so we had no time to fool around."
That is a common theme in Omiya. It does not seem that Japanese families survive because husbands and wives love each other more than American couples, but rather because they perhaps love each other less.
"I think love marriages are more fragile than arranged marriages," said Tomika Kusukawa, 49, who married her high-school sweetheart and now runs a car repair shop with him. "In love marriages, when something happens or if the couple falls out of love, they split up."
If there is a secret to the strength of the Japanese family it consists of three ingredients: low expectations, patience, and shame.
The advantage of marriages based on low expectations is that they have built-in shock absorbers. If the couple discover that they have nothing in common, that they do not even like each other, then that is not so much a reason for divorce as it is par for the course.
Even the discovery that one's spouse is having an affair is often not as traumatic in a Japanese marriage as it is in the West. A little sexual infidelity on the part of a man (though not on the part of his wife) was traditionally tolerated, so long as he did not become so besotted as to pay his mistress more than he could afford.
Tsuzuya Fukuyama, who runs a convenience store and will mark her 50th wedding anniversary this year, toasted her hands on an electric heater in the front of the store and declared that a woman would be wrong to get angry if her husband had an affair.
"It's never just one side that's at fault," Mrs. Fukuyama said sternly. "Maybe the husband had an affair because his wife wasn't so hot herself. So she should look at her own faults."
Mrs. Fukuyama's daughter came to her a few years ago, suspecting that her husband was having an affair and asking what to do.
"I told her, 'Once you left this house, you can only come back if you divorce; if you're not prepared to get a divorce, then you'd better be patient,' " Mrs. Fukuyama recalled. "And so she was patient. And then she got pregnant and had a kid, and now they're close again."
The word that Mrs. Fukuyama used for patience is "gaman," a term that comes up whenever marriage is discussed in Japan. It means toughing it out, enduring hardship, and many Japanese regard gaman with pride as a national trait.
Many people complain that younger folks divorce because they do not have enough gaman, and the frequency with which the term is used suggests a rather bleak understanding of marriage.
"I didn't know my husband very well when we married, and afterward we used to get into bitter fights," said Yoshiko Hirowaki, 56, a store owner. "But then we had children, and I got very busy with the kids and with this shop. Time passed."
Now Mrs. Hirowaki has been married 34 years, and she complains about young people who do not stick to their vows.
"In the old days, wives had more gaman," she said. "Now kids just don't have enough gaman."
The durability of the Japanese family is particularly wondrous because couples are, by international standards, exceptionally incompatible.
One survey asked married men and their wives in 37 countries how they felt about politics, sex, religion, ethics and social issues. Japanese couples ranked dead last in compatibility of views, by a huge margin. Indeed, another survey found that if they were doing it over again, only about one-third of Japanese would marry the same person.
Incompatibility might not matter so much, however, because Japanese husbands and wives spend very little time talking to each other.
"I kind of feel there's nothing new to say to her," said Masayuki Ogita, an egg farmer, explaining his reticence.
In a small town like Omiya, couples usually have dinner together, but in Japanese cities there are many "7-11 husbands," so called because they leave at 7 A.M. and return after 11 P.M.
Masahiko Kondo now lives in Omiya, working in the chamber of commerce, but he used to be a salesman in several big cities. He would leave for work each morning at 7, and about four nights a week would go out for after-work drinking or mah-jongg sessions with buddies.
"I only saw my baby on Saturdays or Sundays," said Mr. Kondo, a lanky good-natured man of 37. "But in fact, I really enjoyed that life. It didn't bother me that I never spent time with my kid on weekdays."
Mr. Kondo's wife, Keiko, had her own life, spent with her child and the wives of other workaholic husbands.
"We had birthday parties, but they were with the kids and the mothers," she remembers. "No fathers ever came."
A national survey found that 30 percent of fathers spend less than 15 minutes a day on weekdays talking with or playing with their children. Among eighth graders, 51 percent reported that they never spoke with their fathers on weekdays.
As a result, the figures in Japan for single-parent households can be deceptive. The father is often more a theoretical presence than a homework-helping reality.
Still, younger people sometimes want to see the spouses in daylight, and a result is a gradual change in focus of lives from work to family. Two decades ago, nearly half of young people said in surveys that they wanted their fathers to put priority on work rather than family. Now only one-quarter say that.
 
Social Pressures
Shame Is Keeping Bonds in Place
For those who find themselves desperately unhappy, one source of pressure to keep plugging is shame.
"If you divorce, you lose face in society," said Tatsumi Kinoshita, a tea farmer. "People say, 'His wife escaped.' So folks remain married because they hate to be gossiped about."
Shame is a powerful social sanction in Japan, and it is not just a matter of gossip. Traditionally, many companies were reluctant to promote employees who had divorced or who had major problems at home.
"If you divorce, it weakens your position at work," said Akihiko Kanda, 27, who works in a local government office. "Your bosses won't give you such good ratings, and it'll always be a negative factor."
The idea, Mr. Kanda noted, is that if an employee cannot manage his own life properly, he should not be entrusted with important corporate matters.
Financial sanctions are also a major disincentive for divorce. The mother gets the children in three-quarters of divorces, but most mothers in Japan do not have careers and have few financial resources. Fathers pay child support in only 15 percent of all divorces with children, partly because women often hesitate to go to court to demand payments and partly because men often fail to pay even when the court orders it.
"The main reason for lack of divorce is that women can't support themselves," said Mizuko Kanda, a 51-year-old housewife. "My friends complain about their husbands and say that they'd divorce if they could, but they can't afford to."
The result of these social and economic pressures is clear.
Even in Japan, there are about 24 divorces for every 100 marriages, but that compares with 32 in France, 42 in England, and 55 in the United States.
 
The Outlook
Change Creeps In, Imperiling Family
But society is changing in Japan, and it is an open question whether these changes will undermine the traditional family as they have elsewhere around the globe.
The nuclear family has already largely replaced the extended family in Japan, and shame is eroding as a sanction. Haruko Okumura, for example, runs a kindergarten and speaks openly about her divorce.
"My Mom was uneasy about it, but I never had an inferiority complex about being divorced," said Mrs. Okumura, as dozens of children played in the next room. "And people accepted me easily."
Mrs. Okumura sees evidence of the changes in family patterns every day: fathers are playing more of a role in the kindergarten. At Christmas parties and sports contests, fathers have started to show up along with mothers. And Mrs. Okumura believes that divorce is on the upswing.
"If there's a weakening of the economic and social pressures to stay married," she said, "surely divorce rates will soar."
Already divorce rates are rising, approximately doubling over the last 25 years. But couples are very reluctant to divorce when they have children, and so single-parent households account for exactly the same proportion today as in 1965.
Shinsuke Kawaguchi, a young tea farmer, is one of the men for whom life is changing. Americans are not likely to be impressed by Mr. Kawaguchi's open-mindedness, but he is.
"I take good care of my wife," he said. "I may not say 'I love you,' but I do hold her hand. And I might say, after she makes dinner, 'This tastes good.' "
"Of course," Mr. Kawaguchi quickly added, "I wouldn't say that unless I'd just done something really bad."
Even Mrs. Uemura, the elderly women whose husband used to beat her, said that her husband was treating her better.
"The other day, he tried to pour me a cup of tea," Mrs. Uemura recalled excitedly. "It was a big change. I told all my friends."
 
Main Street, Japan
The first article in this look at life in Omiya, a small town in Japan, appeared on July 18 and reported on the schools. The second, on Oct. 15, reported on religion. The third, on Jan. 2, was about farmers. Further articles will examine other aspects of life there.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Spring Camps Open Without Anderson

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The Cincinnati Reds played the Philadelphia Phillies in the first game of their 1970 spring training exhibition schedule, and it was a day Sparky Anderson will not forget.
"It was my first one," Anderson recalled the other day. "I was walking around before the game -- I always walked around in those days; I was always walkative -- and I wound up in left field. Johnny Bench was out there and he said, 'Are you nervous?' I said yeah. That was the first game I actually was going to manage. He said: 'Don't be nervous. Just relax and do what you would normally do.' You remember that." 
 Twenty-six years and 4,028 games, 2,194 victories, 5 pennants and 3 World Series championships later, Sparky Anderson has no role this spring. When the first teams hold their first pitcher-and-catcher workouts Thursday, the venerable former manager will be in California, at home in Thousand Oaks or in the northern part of the state seeing his 14th grandchild for the first time.
"It's the first time in 43 years," he said of his absence from spring training. "I know it's not going to be easy. With the guys up here, I shrug it off and say it's no problem, but I have to be honest. It's going to be hard."
Anderson's annual spring trips began in 1953, his first year as a minor league player. When he was between managing jobs in the spring of 1979, he was in Florida in a nonuniform capacity working on a special for a Los Angeles television station. And last year he stayed away from replacement spring training but was there when the real players showed up after their strike.
But now he has left baseball, resigning from his job with the Detroit Tigers after 17 years and, at the age of nearly 62, attracting no invitations to manage anyone else. His unemployed status has left him with little desire to head to Florida or Arizona and just hang around.
"As of now, I have no urge to go," he said. "But come when it opens, I might. I really don't know. That's going to be a good test for me. That will be one test that will be a hard one and then when opening day comes and the season starts for real. That will be extremely hard. I'm not kidding myself. I'm going to try to stay real busy around those times so I won't get real antsy, but I will anyway. You can't do something for so long and then all of a sudden not do it."
Spring training produces memories for anyone in baseball, and the longer one is around it, the more memories he has. In Anderson's case, spring was the time he would spot the players he would subsequently tout as the next Hall of Famer.
Not all spring memories are pleasant, though. Anderson recalled the day in 1975 he took a team of unknown players to Daytona Beach, Fla., for a game with Montreal, leaving Bench, Pete Rose, Joe Morgan, Dave Concepcion, Tony Perez, George Foster and Ken Griffey in Tampa.
"I had a habit early in my career not to take good ballplayers on the road," Anderson said. "I always wanted to leave my good players at home because they would get more work. That's not right, but I admit I did it. We went over there to play the Expos, and the biggest name I had with me was Darrel Chaney. The rest nobody knew from Adam."
Before Anderson got home, John McHale, the Expos' president, called Bob Howsam, his Reds counterpart.
"John was unhappy and he had every reason to be," Anderson said. "Bob was unhappy and that bothered me because when he's unhappy he lets you know. That ended that. As the years went on, I think I took better clubs on the road than anybody."
The road trips are over for Anderson but not his passion for bas'ball.
"I follow it every day and I'm going to follow it through spring training and during the season," he said. "I'll watch the Dodgers and the Angels and catch cable games. But no one has called about any jobs. I hope they know I won't do any scouting. If I'm going to run around the country, it's going to be managing, not sitting in a hotel room somewhere waiting to scout."
Anderson wi'l be at home, where his wife, Carol, is not accustomed to having him.
"Right now everything's fine," he said. "This is just like a normal winter. But come 10 days from now, we'll start changing. That will be the true test. She's used to doing her things. I try to stay out of her way. She's always been the one to baby me when things are rough. She doesn't need that anymore. I'll have to do this myself. I'll get through it. It's not like the world's coming to an end. But I'll be honest. I'll miss it."
 
 
 
Roller-Coaster Roster Ride
 On Jan. 18, the Florida Marlins put Aaron Small on waivers. On Jan. 23, the Seattle Mariners claimed him. On Jan. 24, the Mariners put Small on waivers. On Jan. 29, the Oakland Athletics claimed him. On Jan. 30, Small rested.
"I was on a roller coaster the whole week," Small, a 24-year-old pitcher, said. "I didn't know what was going on. The funny thing is, I was with Toronto for six and a half years, then four teams in nine months."
Except for a week with the Blue Jays in 1994 and a month with the Marlins last season, Small has spent his seven-year professional career in the minor leagues. He pitched once for the Blue Jays, working two innings in a relief against the Yankees, and relieved seven times for the Marlins last September, gaining a victory and compiling a 1.42 earned run average in six and one-third innings.
"We needed a roster spot," Dave Dombrowski, the Marlins' general manager, said in explaining the decision to seek waivers on the right-hander. "As much as we like Aaron, the chances of his making the team in the spring weren't good. We figured we'd be asking waivers at some point so we might as well do it now."
The Mariners claimed Small because they liked him, but they had a roster problem, too.
"We would like to have had him in our system," General Manager Woody Woodward said. "If a spot had cleared, we would have put him right on the 40-man roster. If it didn't clear, we would ask waivers and if no one claimed him, we would outright him and send him to Triple-A. Sometimes you get him through that way."
Because the Athletics finished lower than the Mariners, they could have had Small by claiming him the first time around. Given a second chance, they plucked him off the waiver wire.
"Some things had transpired between the first and second waiver requests," Sandy Alderson, the Oakland general manager, said. "We had a change in our circumstances, and we took a second look."
Dave Stewart, an assistant to Alderson, contributed to that second look, having played with Small in the Toronto organization.
"I like him as a person, first of all," Stewart, the recently retired pitcher, said. "And I think he has a chance to be an outstanding pitcher. He can be a starter or a reliever. He has a real good chance to pitch for us this year."
When Small checked his telephone messages Jan. 29, he found one from Larry Beinfest of the Mariners and another from Billy Beane of the Athletics.
"I called Larry and he said good luck," Small related. "I called Billy Beane and he told me they had claimed me. I told Larry, I was with you guys for six days and I didn't meet anyone. It was a weird week for me. But I'm excited about it now, now that I can concentrate on what team I'm going to be with."
 
 
 
Winfield's Union Ties
 When he announced his retirement from a 23-year, six-team career last week, Dave Winfield was asked which team's cap he would wear when he was elected to the Hall of Fame. He didn't answer, but the banner that hung on the wall behind him provided an idea.
It was the banner of the Major League Baseball Players Association, the players' union, which Winfield wanted to salute on his way out. That's because Winfield always was a strong supporter of the union and someone who understood why he was able to sign, in December 1980, a contract that would pay him $18,316,602 in the next 10 years, a princely sum for the time.
Union officials always have been fond of Winfield. Marvin Miller, the union's first director, saluted him for his unswerving support of the strike in 1981 even though he had the security of a 10-year contract and the rights the players were fighting for would not affect him.
And there was the recent eight-month strike that threatened to end Winfield's career prematurely. Yet he was out front during that one, too.
Perhaps, then, it would be fitting for the cap on Winfield's Cooperstown plaque not to have "NY" or a Blue Jay on it but to say "MLBPA."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;
In Political Quest, Forbes Runs in Shadow of Father

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
There are moments during the indignities of his Presidential campaign when Steve Forbes wonders what "Pop" would have thought of it all.
Last week alone, father and son would have found plenty to talk about: Senator Phil Gramm ridiculed Mr. Forbes for raising "polo ponies" on his farm; three governors attacked him in Washington, and what his headquarters called a Christian right "smear campaign" accused him of having a Robert Mapplethorpe print on his yacht. (A seascape, not homoerotic art, the candidate shot back.) 
 Speaking of his father, Malcolm, as his 22-year-old campaign bus bounced across the frozen tundra of Iowa from Fort Dodge to Des Moines, Steve Forbes said, "I think he'd be bemused by the intensity of the reaction."
Mr. Forbes says he is running for President because Jack Kemp would not, and to sell America on his flat tax.
But this explanation does not entirely satisfy even his friends, who remain mystified about why a 48-year-old magazine scion with no elective experience would get up one morning to announce that he will spend whatever it takes, about $16.5 million so far, of his inherited fortune to live in the White House.
Mr. Forbes says he has not reached some sort of personal watershed -- "I don't believe in midlife crises," he asserts -- so speculation on at least part of his motives inevitably turns to the specter of his late father, the eccentric and flamboyant publisher whom by all accounts the shy, awkward Steve adored.
Some friends see Mr. Forbes's campaign as an attempt to emerge finally from the shadow of his father, something the candidate rejects.
"Believe me, there are other ways of making a mark for oneself without the risks, the aggravation, the investment, the wear and tear on family life and the meat-grinding process of a Presidential campaign," he said.
In fact, what is far more striking are the parallels in the lives of the two men. Like his eldest son and chosen heir, Malcolm Forbes did not come into his own as a powerful figure at Forbes magazine until he was in his 40's, when he took over after his brother died. Like his son, Malcolm Forbes wanted to be President, and in pursuit of that goal ran twice unsuccessfully -- with young Steve often at his side -- for Governor of New Jersey.
"I came to the conclusion there was no way I could consciously imitate this particular individual," Steve Forbes said. "And it would be futile to do so. He was unique. It's like in athletics. You know, great athletes -- they retire the number. With my father, I figure they retired the shoes. Don't try to fill them. Get your own shoes."
 
Father's Political Path Was an Early Influence
Born Malcolm Stevenson Forbes Jr., Steve was raised in the old-monied hillsides of Somerset County, N.J., moderate Republican fox-hunting land, where the neighbors ran for Congress and served in the Cabinet. Christine Todd, Mr. Forbes's childhood friend from the Far Hills Country Day school, would grow up to become Governor Whitman. Steve Forbes joined the club at 6, when he ran doorbells and bumped along in the converted milk truck that served as the campaign bus in his father's gubernatorial race.
Malcolm Forbes was then a state senator, and he lost in a close 1953 Republican primary to a candidate backed by the powerful New Jersey Republican organization -- an "outsider" position like the one his son is assuming now.
When Malcolm Forbes was trounced by the Governor, a Democrat, in the general election of 1957, he gave up politics for the family business. His son went off to the Brooks School in North Andover, Mass., then on to Princeton, Malcolm Forbes's alma mater. Six months after graduation, in 1971, he joined Forbes as a researcher and began working his way up as the preselected heir.
By this time, Malcolm Forbes was busy promoting his magazine as the product of a happy multimillionaire who ballooned, yachted, motorcycled and collected Faberge eggs. Aside from his popular "Fact and Comment" column, he only occasionally meddled in the editorial content.
Fortune magazine asserted in its Feb. 5 issue that under the younger Mr. Forbes, who now has the title of editor in chief, writers have seen tough articles about companies that advertise in Forbes changed from negative to positive assessments. Mr. Forbes denied that.
In contrast with his father, Steve Forbes always loved policy, and he became enamored of a small group of supply-side economists in his early days at Forbes. Jude Wanniski, a supply-sider who helped push Mr. Forbes into the Presidential race, remembers first seeing him at a 1977 supply-side gathering at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington, D.C. "Steve was there on the periphery, taking notes," Mr. Wanniski said.
After Malcolm Forbes died suddenly in 1990, Mr. Forbes took over the magazine as well as the media company of Forbes Inc., a transfer of power that gave him 51 percent of the voting stock. His younger siblings, three brothers and a sister, had accepted the decision years before. Despite of -- or because of -- his anointment, the new king among princes characterized this period as one of great strain. "That's when everyone was looking, 'Can he do it?' " Mr. Forbes said.
Mr. Forbes had to contend at the same time with the first published reports in the gay press of his father's homosexuality. His parents were divorced in 1985, and friends say Mr. Forbes did not discuss his father's life with them. But certainly in the last five years of his life, Malcolm Forbes became increasingly indiscreet, and he was seen regularly roaring up on his motorcycle in tight black leather to Manhattan nightclubs and, according to current and former workers at Forbes, pursuing some of his young male employees.
"I've always dealt with fact and not rumor," Steve Forbes said. "And if anyone had brought facts that would have warranted a confrontation with my father, I'd have confronted him. Since no one did, I never did."
Asked how the behavior of his most important male role model affected Mr. Forbes's thinking about his father and his own life, Mr. Forbes responded with a remark that seemed to have been prepared a long time ago.
"I think you have to realize that compassion is not approval," Mr. Forbes said carefully, echoing the phrase he had used at an earlier campaign stop to explain his opposition to same-sex marriage.
Did he ever talk to his father about his behavior in the last years of his life? "No," said Mr. Forbes, in a barely audible voice.
 
Opponents' Tactics Take Toll on Forbes
Bill Dal Col, Mr. Forbes's campaign manager, warned his candidate months ago that his opponents would use his father against him. It seems to be working. Although polls show Mr. Forbes leading in New Hampshire, he is in a close race for second in Iowa and is rapidly losing ground among religious conservatives, according to his own and independent polls.
On Friday, Mr. Forbes said an anonymous telephone campaign was being waged against him in Iowa, with callers telling voters that Mr. Forbes supports taxpayer-financed abortions and special rights for homosexuals. Both are untrue, Mr. Forbes said. He supports privately financed abortions, but not in the late stages of pregnancy, and the "don't ask, don't tell" policy for homosexuals in the military.
None of this was part of New Jersey politics in the relatively genteel 1950's. "It's part of the hazing of the American political system," he said.
Mr. Forbes neglected to say that he is engaging in what some political veterans are calling the most negative advertising campaign in primary history, attacking Senator Bob Dole, as well as Mr. Gramm and former Gov. Lamar Alexander, who are behind him in the polls.
Indeed, when Mr. Forbes was asked whether he really had a burning desire to be President, he used the opportunity to take another punch at his rivals.
"Well, it's not the situation where, say, a Phil Gramm. ..." he said, pausing momentarily. "Can this go off the record?" Getting no agreement, Mr. Forbes paused again, then made a decision to continue.
"I think others have spent their whole lives planning to be President," said the candidate from horse country, where one does not display excessive ambition, even if one has spent about $16.5 million.
"And therefore I think they have perhaps an unhealthy desire for it. Yes, you have to desire it. You obviously work hard at it. But you have to put it in perspective, that if it doesn't work out, so be it. I don't think those others are of a mind to say, so be it. No, in terms of ambition, for them it's an obsession."
Mr. Forbes continued: "I have the ambition. And I think I'm going to do a better job as President, because I know what I want to do when I get there. It's not to be, it's to do. With too many others, public life is to be."
Mr. Forbes, who is married with five daughters, is an Episcopalian, and he said he was religious enough to think that his father knows he is running for President.
"I'm sure he does," he said. "And I'm sure I'll get an earful some day when I go up and join him."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Steve Forbes's quest for the Presidency mirrors the dream of his father, Malcolm S. Forbes, shown with his wife, Roberta, and 9-year-old Steve, upon winning the Republican nomination for New Jersey Governor. (Associated Press, 1957)

HEADLINE: Russia Wants No Return of Cold War, Official Says

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Yevgeny M. Primakov, the new Russian Foreign Minister, said today that Russia continued to desire a close working relationship with the United States and had no intention of trying to resurrect the Soviet Union.
Mr. Primakov, who spoke after two days of meetings here with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, also said Russia would not put into effect any new oil deal with Iraq until the United Nations lifted sanctions against it. 
 Mr. Primakov, 66, took over in January as Foreign Minister after Andrei V. Kozyrev, a liberal Westernizer, was fired. It was Mr. Primakov's first trip to the West since his appointment, after extensive visits to the former Soviet republics of Tajikistan, Belarus and Ukraine.
"I'd say we're off to a good start," Mr. Christopher said. Senior American officials said these early, wide-ranging discussions between two men who barely knew one another had been conducted in a conciliatory and friendly atmosphere, despite serious differences on issues like the planned eastward expansion of NATO and the Russian sale of nuclear reactors to Iran.
American officials expressed relief at Mr. Primakov's pragmatism, skill and evident preparation. They said President Boris N. Yeltsin had no desire for instability in the American relationship before Russian presidential elections in June. But the tone was a far cry from the warm talk of alliances, friendship and partnership that used to surround meetings with Mr. Kozyrev.
Mr. Christopher had dinner with Mr. Primakov on Friday night as well as six and a half hours of talks with him. Mr. Christopher said he was "pleasantly surprised" by "the attitudes of openness he brought, and the willingness to recognize differences and manage them." Mr. Primakov "stressed that the cold war is over" and that neither he nor any of his colleagues wanted it back, Mr. Christopher said.
For his part, Mr. Primakov said: "It was very fruitful. As you Americans like to say, it was a very businesslike meeting. The relationship between our two countries is of the first priority." He said there was "no basis to consider that Russian-American relations are in a crisis."
Mr. Primakov is an English- and Arabic-speaking Middle East expert who served in the Soviet Politburo and most recently ran Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service, the international side of the old K.G.B.
He is regarded as a better representative of the tough, more nationalistic tone in Russian foreign policy that Mr. Yeltsin began to articulate after the strong showing of Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky in the December 1993 parliamentary elections.
Two years later, Mr. Yeltsin is further weakened by the quagmire in separatist Chechnya and his own unhealthy heart muscle. With the presidential election drawing near, Mr. Yeltsin is trying to co-opt a new Parliament dominated by Communists and nationalists.
Mr. Yeltsin has fired the most prominent liberals in his Cabinet. American officials insist that the essence of Russian-American relations has not changed, and that as Mr. Christopher said today, there are more areas of agreement than disagreement.
But Mr. Primakov insisted today on "equality" in the relationship, an old cold war complaint about American arrogance, saying, "We want to eliminate from our international life the uncomfortable consequences of the cold war, which we can still feel from time to time."
The two men agreed, at Mr. Christopher's suggestion, on a rough set of principles to govern their relations, Mr. Primakov said. They agreed to try not to surprise each other and to consult early and often, one of Mr. Primakov's big concerns, officials said.
As an example, American officials said, the American Middle East negotiator, Dennis Ross, will go to Moscow to brief Russian officials on the Syrian-Israeli peace talks. Russia is, after all, co-chairman of the Madrid peace conference under which the talks are being held. Similar talks on other regional problems will take place more regularly than before.
The two sides also agreed to work to carry out agreements already reached, including a new Russian effort to ratify the Start II strategic arms reduction treaty, signed three years ago but just approved by the American Senate. It will be a hard sell in the new Russian legislature, officials said Mr. Primakov had told Mr. Christopher, but the Russian Defense Ministry supports the treaty.
And they agreed to try to manage differences they could not resolve, so that they could continue to work together in areas like peacekeeping in Bosnia or fighting international terrorism and drug trafficking.
The prime difference between the two countries is NATO expansion, which Mr. Christopher said would proceed in a "long-term process," emphasizing that NATO would not expand this year. American officials said Mr. Primakov echoed Mr. Yeltsin's longstanding opposition to that expansion, but did not threaten any steps like putting short-range nuclear missiles into Belarus, as some Russian Defense Ministry officials have suggested.
Mr. Christopher tried to encourage Russia to continue military cooperation with NATO, as in Bosnia, where Russian peacekeeping troops take part in a NATO-commanded operation, and in NATO's so-called Partnership for Peace program.
On the eve of the meetings with Mr. Primakov, Mr. Christopher met here with the Ukrainian President, Leonid Kuchma, and announced a summit meeting between President Clinton and Mr. Kuchma in Washington on Feb. 21. As Russia has moved toward more nationalism, American officials have emphasized the importance of a free and independent Ukraine.
While Mr. Primakov has emphasized strengthening Russia's relations with its former Soviet brothers, he said today: "No one is for the re-establishment of the Soviet Union -- it cannot be and will not be. And there is no turning away from the sovereignty the various republics have established."
But Mr. Primakov also discussed with Mr. Christopher some problem areas of the Commonwealth of Independent States, including Georgia, the separatist Azerbaijan region of Nagorno-Karabakh and especially Tajikistan, where the Russian-backed Government is under pressure from a renewed, Afghan-backed Islamic rebellion.
Asked whether Mr. Primakov had discussed with the Americans whether more Russian troops would soon be arriving in Tajikistan, a senior official said, "He wasn't that explicit." But an official said that the discussion of Tajikistan had been longer than the one on Chechnya, in which Mr. Christopher repeated the American position that a political solution is vital and a military one impossible.
On Iraq, Mr. Primakov assured Mr. Christopher that a reported $10 billion agreement to help the Iraqi oil industry would not go into effect until international sanctions against Baghdad were completely lifted, American officials said. Mr. Primakov said openly that Russia was largely interested in getting back some of the $7 billion owed to it by Iraq.
And on Iran, Mr. Primakov repeated the Russian position that its sale of nuclear reactors to Teheran would not help that Government produce nuclear weapons. The United States opposes the sale.
Officials said Mr. Primakov was impressive in his preparation and level of detail on various issues and did not glance over some topics as Mr. Kozyrev had been prone to do. "Christopher and Primakov are of the same generation," one American official said. "They were pragmatic and comfortable together."
Mr. Christopher and Mr. Primakov will meet again in Moscow around March 18, and then again around April 18, when President Clinton goes to Moscow for a meeting on nuclear safety and a summit session with Mr. Yeltsin.

HEADLINE: The G.O.P.'s Grand New Struggle

 BODY:
Heavy, heavy, heavy is the mantle of inevitability. Just ask poor Bob Dole, the latest victim of the voters' quadrennial struggle to escape an arranged marriage. Inevitability panic is often associated with the Democrats, but Republicans are not immune. Witness the serial levitations from the Republican pack. First Steve Forbes, a trust-fund poster boy, surfs along as the lets-lower-my-taxes-even-if-we-have-to-raise-yours candidate. Then the Louisiana caucuses coughed up Pat Buchanan as the latest and most unlikely in a long line of Huey Long reincarnations. Now Lamar Alexander, who brags that he is less tired than Mr. Dole and less naive than Mr. Forbes, is moving up in Iowa.
Some media critics want journalists and voters to ignore the horse race, a mindless instruction in light of the fact that this particular race is intertwined with an important development in Republican politics. A Los Angeles Times headline, "G.O.P. Class Warfare Erupts as Candidates Assail Forbes," was on the money, so to speak. 
 The battle was triggered by a slowly dawning awareness of what the flat tax really means beyond being a handy way for the Republicans to hand the fall election to President Clinton. It would save millions of dollars for Mr. Forbes and other holders of inherited wealth in capital gains and estate taxes for decades to come.
That aspect of this "truly nutty idea," to use Mr. Alexander's words, has opened up the Republicans' most divisive intramural issue -- the question of whether the party is going to serve the economic interests of the old guard that shaped its traditional policies or the middle-class voters who gave it the White House in the 80's and control of Congress in 1994. Huey (the Kingfish) Buchanan placed his bet in Louisiana by promoting his new "conservatism with a heart." He is championing the Republican middle managers who are getting laid off against another Republican faction, the downsizers who are fattening quarterly earnings at the expense of career employees.
Just as the Democrats have been riven at times by racial and union issues, the Republicans could face powerful internal strains over income. They like to argue that the Democrats are the party of class warfare, but it is Phil Gramm who has been calling Mr. Forbes "Richie Rich." Both Mr. Gramm and Newt Gingrich have criticized Mr. Forbes for wanting to take a free ride on investment income while taxing wages and salaries through payroll deductions. Mr. Dole has said that he cannot favor a plan that takes away the home mortgage exemption and loads a $200 billion deficit increase on the backs of wage earners.
Mr. Forbes's policy guru, Jude Wanniski, has recognized the threat in this line of attack and is circulating a memo arguing that Mr. Forbes is the true populist because he wants everyone to get rich. He makes a strained argument that "Forbes is not Old Wealth" since his grandfather started the fortune. It is Bob Dole, according to Mr. Wanniski, who serves the class at the top of the pyramid and is "biased toward preserving and protecting its wealth."
If the Forbes camp is going to play the politics of resentment against Mr. Dole, it had better be careful. Mr. Dole is the Mozart of resentment. Nobody does it better, and for all the rocks in his road lately, Mr. Dole has caught an unexpected break. Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Alexander are both positioned to grab shares of the anti-Dole vote that seemed to be flowing in a bloc to Mr. Forbes.
In any event, recent history shows that fractious primary voters may eventually learn to tolerate an old-shoe candidate. Think of all the Democrats who sighed and accepted the fact that Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis were as good as it was going to get.
The whole business will play out fairly quickly now. So in the coming weeks, disregard all those urgings to ignore the horse race. This one has meaning enough for the direction of the country, the shape of the Republican Party and Bill Clinton's hopes of facing a battered candidate and a squabbling party. Anyway, it is a dandy show.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 12, 1996, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the candidate Steve Forbes in some copies misattributed a reference to him as "Richie Rich." The comment was made by Senator Phil Gramm, not Pat Buchanan.

HEADLINE: O'Rourke's Raise Draws Much Ire

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
LATE last year, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke convinced county legislators and many constituents that dramatic measures must be taken to downsize government. That meant privatizing some county services, eliminating 800 jobs, consolidating departments and reducing travel, meal and car expenses. Mr. O'Rourke's goal: a saving of $2.6 million.
But 12 days ago, the County Executive proposed a 19.5 percent pay raise for himself and County Clerk Leonard N. Spano, including in his proposal retroactive paychecks of totaling nearly $50,000 for the two officials. 
 Now the complaints from outraged taxpayers are being heard loud and clear on the eighth floor of the County Office Building here, especially in the 17 offices of the county legislators.
The callers "feel the timing is bad," said George Oros, a Republican from Cortlandt and Chairman of the Board of Legislators. "That kind of a pay hike is a very difficult sell right now."
One worker who lost her $47,000-a-year job at Woodfield Cottage, the youth detention center in Valhalla, which was privatized, called Mr. O'Rourke's proposal "a slap in the face."
"How could he do this after all we went through?" said Mary C. Bryant, a member of the Westchester County Civil Service Employees Association, which represents 12,000 county workers. "Those of us who were laid off are making do on unemployment, and he's asking for all that money."
The proposal would raise Mr. O'Rourke's salary by $23,250 to $142,335, which is more than Gov. George E. Pataki earns. It would also surpass the salary of other county executives in the New York City area, some of whose jurisdictions have larger populations.
Although the County Executive has offered no public explanation for his unpopular proposal, he did send Deputy County Executive Neil J. DeLuca to the Board's Budget and Appropriations Committee early last week with a revised plan.
Mr. DeLuca recommended a 7.5 percent raise over two years for the two top elected officials -- the same percentage that was approved for the teamsters union and the Civil Service Employees Association for 1994 and 1995. Neither the unions nor Mr. O'Rourke or Mr. Spano would receive raises this year.
Marc Moran, a spokesman for Mr. O'Rourke, said that when an organization downsizes, pay raises are often subject to criticism.
"But downsizing in this case has to do with how the business of government is changing at the end of the 20th century, when in many cases we're working with a model that dates back to the 19th century," Mr. Moran said. "And that's a separate issue from what is reasonable compensation for the work force. Westchester has to remain competitive in order to attract the right people to jobs."
Mr. O'Rourke, who has not received a raise since 1990, had asked the Board of Legislators late last month to make his raise, and those of 2 other elected officials and 240 commissioners and managers, retroactive to 1994.
Mr. O'Rourke's back pay, under the proposal, would have come to $26,136. The County Clerk would have earned $118,345 under the plan, up $19,330 from his current salary. His retroactive check would have come to $21,792.
Other managers and commissioners would receive raises of 7.5 percent. The original pay plan and the amended version are both under attack by Democrats and Mr. O'Rourke's fellow Republicans on the Board and from members of taxpayer groups that had supported the County Executive's moves to downsize. Critics say pay hikes should not benefit elected officials during their current terms of office.
Mr. Spano, who said he learned of the pay-raise proposal from a newspaper story when he returned from vacation, said he was against the plan.
A County Legislator for 22 years and the chairman of the Budget Committee for more than half of that time, he suggested that raises for the two top elected officials in the county be built in on a regular basis to avoid "playing catch-up" every few years.
Katherine S. Carsky, a Republican from Greenburgh, said she shared the sentiments of Republican and Democratic colleagues alike. "Let's just say we agree that Mr. O'Rourke's timing is not good."
But some political observers like Michael Edelman, a lawyer and Republican consultant, said that on the basis of numbers alone and years without a raise, Mr. O'Rourke was not wrong to ask for an increase in his salary.
"But it's a different question as to whether it was a politically bright thing to do," said Mr. Edelman, who practices law in White Plains. "You can't be austere when it comes to county employees and not be austere when applying it to yourself."
Many observers have questioned why Mr. O'Rourke -- County Executive for 13 years and widely considered an astute politician -- would have made such a politically unpopular move.
The County Executive recently put to rest widespread speculation that he would be stepping down from his current post to accept a judgeship by announcing that he would not only complete his current term but possibly seek a seventh.
That announcement followed an abrupt and unexpected shift in the political lineup of the newly elected Board of Legislators when six Democrats, one Conservative and three dissident Republicans took power and elected Mr. Oros Chairman over Mrs. Carsky, who was the county Republican Party's choice.
Following that change in the Legislature, Republican leaders were said to be worried that if Mr. O'Rourke resigned before the end of his term, the coalition might name a successor not to their liking.
No one in Mr. O'Rourke's office would offer an explanation for the County Executive's decision to ask for a pay increase now. Whatever the reason, Mr. Edelman said, Mr. O'Rourke's salary proposal "did not play well to the public."
Meanwhile, Paul J. Noto, a Republican Legislator from Mamaroneck who called the proposal "a little generous," said that the County Executive's salary has historically been tied to management raises and union contracts and that some commissioners are earning more than Mr. O'Rourke.
Dr. Mark Rapoport, Westchester's Health Commissioner, and Millard J. Hyland, the Medical Examiner and Commissioner of Laboratories and Research, each earn $123,005. Edward Stolzenberg, the Hospitals Commissioner, earns $200,000. Joseph Hankin, president of Westchester Community College, earns $124,130 plus a $15,000-a-year housing allowance.
And the position of Deputy Hospitals Commissioner, which is unfilled, commands a salary of $135,000.
Although the County Charter says that the County Executive and County Clerk's salaries should be tied to the pay scale of managers, commissioners and other high-level officials, Mr. DeLuca recommended to the Board last week that that process be changed and a flat rate agreed upon for the future.
The co-chairman of the Budget Committee, Richard G. Wishnie, a Democrat from Briarcliff Manor, agreed with the principle of a flat rate but opposed a pay raise now.
"This is not the time to increase the County Executive's salary," Mr. Wishnie said. "No matter how good a job he is doing, you run for office knowing what the pay scale is. Next term may be a different story."
Mr. Wishnie suggested that a study of comparative salaries be conducted to determine the future pay for Westchester's chief executive.
Mr. O'Rourke currently earns $119,085 a year in a county with a population of 890,000 people.
Robert J. Gaffney earns $107,602 as County Executive in Suffolk County, whose population is 1.35 million. Mr. Gaffney's salary increases are tied by law to the cost of living, and this year he received a raise of 1.77 percent.
In Nassau County, where 1.3 million people live, County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta earns $109,394. His salary was recently raised by 4.75 percent, the same amount received by unionized employees. Like Mr. O'Rourke, the Suffolk County Executive had not had an increase since 1990.
In Rockland County, with a population of 275,000, C. Scott Vanderhoef earns $97,830. His last raise, $2,500, was in 1995. Mr. Vanderhoef, who also earns less than some of his commissioners and some local police chiefs, said such disparities in salaries needed to be looked at.
"But any time an elected official tries to raise his salary for any reason, he will be subject to criticism," he said.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani earns $165,000. And Gov. George E. Pataki earns $130,000.

HEADLINE: Aboard An Extended Shoreline East

BYLINE: By PENNY PARSEKIAN 

 BODY:
SHORELINE commuters from the New London area now have an option to battling traffic on Interstate 95. The Department of Transportation has extended the Shoreline East commuter rail service, which makes stops between New Haven and Old Saybrook, to New London.
This is the first new rail service in the state since Shoreline East was inaugurated in May 1990 and represents a reversal for the current administration. In a budget trimming effort last February, Gov. John G. Rowland recommended terminating the Shoreline service entirely. 
 Harry P. Harris, Deputy Commissioner of Transportation, explained that the new service is a two-year pilot project "to do what we can to reduce the number of cars on I-95, which is heavily congested," particularly across the Quinnipiac bridge. A $250,000 advertising and marketing campaign is being aimed at new riders, Mr. Harris said. Few people rode the first train out of New London on Feb. 1, and only about 20 were on later trains, according to Robert Levy, marketing director of Rideworks, a nonprofit organization that handles customer service for Shoreline East. "But there's a lot of interest," he said, citing the nearly 400 requests for free passes received as of last week. The free passes for February are in addition to free parking arranged by the Department of Transportation and the City of New London.
Representative Robert R. Simmons, a Republican from Stonington who has introduced legislation to bolster the commuter service, believes this is a first step in the right direction.
"I've always been concerned that Shoreline East should not terminate in a lightly populated area west of the Connecticut River," Mr. Simmons said, referring to Old Saybrook. But scheduling remains a concern. The morning trains depart from Union Station at 5:28 and 6:28 and arrive in New Haven at 6:38 and 7:38. Departures from New Haven are at 5:05 and 6:10 P.M., arriving in New London at 6:15 and 7:20 P.M. Mr. Simmons described the morning schedule as "adverse"; in short, it's too early.
Bruce Fellman, who lives in North Stonington and works in New Haven, fits the profile Mr. Simmons is aiming at. Mr. Fellman said he tried driving the 135-mile round trip and has used car pools. Now he boards the train in Westbrook. "It sometimes adds a half hour to my commute," he said, "but it's useful time. I come home and I'm not a zombie, and I get to work and I'm not jittery."
Even though New London is closer to home than Westbrook he says he is not inclined to use the new service. "It's way earlier than I need to be in," he said. "It doesn't seem designed to attract many riders. If they got the timing right, I'd be willing." The D.O.T.'s decision to run the early trains is based on ridership patterns and expenditures, said Lawrence Forbes, rail administrator of the department's Bureau of Public Transportation. "The 7:30 A.M. arrival time in New Haven is the heaviest ridership," Mr. Forbes said. "Thirty percent continue west of New Haven" on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.
"Those were the only times we could do without using additional equipment," he added. "It is a cost-effective way to provide a limited extension of the service."
Mr. Forbes said the project would add between $124,000 and $150,000 to operating costs under the current agreement with Amtrak, which runs Shoreline East. The agreement is now under negotiation.
Mr. Forbes said that running more trains would be possible, because the state has new cars on order, but operating costs, maintenance and track usage fees would add about $1.5 million. "Hopefully the renegotiations will bring costs down so we could do it," he said.
More trains might attract riders like Mr. Fellman, who said his cost calculations for taking the new service came out favorably. He said he added the increase in fare and parking costs and still came up with a savings by taking the train from New London. A one-way fare between New London and New Haven is $7.25, a 10-trip ticket costs $65 and the monthly fare is $151. A monthly ticket for connecting bus service in New Haven costs $5.
Unlike Mr. Fellman, the City of New London is not hedging about the service. At a November meeting of a state task force to gather information on rail service, Peter Gillespie, a city planner, listed new tourist attractions in the region including the Thames River Heritage Park, expected to draw 250,000 visitors; an enlarged Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo and Casino resort complex, the planned Mohegan Sun Resort, as well as the Mystic Seaport Museum and Mystic Marine Life Aquarium. He said that a million visitors now pass through New London annually and existing roads cannot accommodate the anticipated growth.
Philip J. Slack 3d, executive director of Oceanquest, a marine sciences camp and oceanography museum slated to open this year, testified that his organization projected 375,000 visitors (including 5,000 students the first year). He said he thought expanded rail service was needed to keep road traffic moving.
Among the critics of the new service are boaters, who see each new train run limiting their passage to upstream docks. At a Jan. 3 meeting of the Essex-based Connecticut Marine Trades Association, members questioned the legality of extending the service until the economic impact report, being conducted in conjunction with Amtrak's electrification of the northeast corridor, is completed. Between Old Saybrook and New London there are three movable railroad bridges, at the Connecticut River, at the Niantic River and at Shaw's Cove in New London.
But Mr. Forbes sees a minimal impact resulting from these particular four trains a day. "I don't see that we're going to inhibit boaters" during the early morning runs Monday through Friday, he said, adding that the bridges are open only five to seven minutes at a time. "There are things we could do if it hampers anyone," he said. "If we were increasing trains on weekends or holidays, that would be another story."
There are also critics who contend any addition to the service is simply increasing a large subsidy to serve a small constituency of commuters. Shoreline East costs about $5.5 million a year to operate and carries about 300,000 riders. But transportation officials say costs should not be examined in a vacuum. "The cost of adding a lane to I-95 is in the $8 billion range," Deputy Commissioner Harris said. "We have exceeded the original design capacity of I-95. At peak hours, the road is a hair short of gridlock. In 2010, peak hours will be 12 hours a day. You can improve road capacity on a limited basis, but the bottom line is alternatives have got to be the way to go: rail, bus, car or van pooling. So we are committed to getting people onto rail systems. We have to put the system in place and then offer incentives."
Cost and usage constraints have led to unusual arrangements in some areas of the country, said Davis Dure, a consultant with LS Transit Systems Inc. in Bloomfield, N.J. "To expand the flexibility, some commuter agencies have cut a deal with Amtrak to honor commutation tickets," Mr. Dure said. "A midday getaway train, for example, adds to the marketability of the service." Currently there are 18 Amtrak trains a day connecting New London and New Haven.
"Connecticut could reimburse Amtrak," Mr. Dure said. "Virginia Rail Express, a new commuter operation that runs between Washington, Manassas and Fredericksburg, has this arrangement. They do it on the West Coast, too, where Amtrak runs Los Angeles Metro Link trains."
Deputy Commissioner Harris says the expansion of Shoreline East is one of several rail options the state is considering.
"There is a study under way in the Legislature to look at extending service from New Haven to Hartford," he said. A study a few years ago found such a line would most likely generate considerable traffic, but also a sizable operating deficit, he said. "Even if we could absorb the capital cost, we have no room to absorb the operating deficit," Mr. Harris said. "The cost of starting a new system is considerably more than extending an existing one."
Representative Simmons sees rail as playing a larger role in the state's future.
"A major initiative is coming out of southeastern Connecticut, and roads can't handle it," he said. Commuter rail service is "going to be a potential economic boon to New London, because it's going to draw commuters into downtown. Over time, they may discover they can pick up tourism by running trains over the weekend."
"Connecticut is a small state," he said. "If you look at the total acreage of land devoted to roads, we don't have the acreage to meet these growing needs. We have to better utilize the rail infrastructure that we already have."
