HEADLINE: ART;
Eclectic Exhibition by Neighbors in Rye

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR 

DATELINE: RYE

 BODY:
THOUGH hardly a SoHo, Kirby Lane North here is a creative enclave and is the subject of an exhibition at the Rye Arts Center, one of two under review.
In 1947, a group of artists and writers sought greener pastures than New York City in which to rear their offspring. What they found was the wooded and rocky section of the Sackett Estate, known as Knob Hill. They were not needy nor were they Utopians, but they knew a good buy when they saw one, and they werked together, deciding on common property and erecting houses that were contemporary in style. 
 As recorded in the statement accompanying the show, the group consisted of five families named Stoller, Wright, Ehrenberg, Sterling and Hanson. The project was masterminded by Henry Wright, managing editor of Architectural Forum. The settlement caused a stir among Rye's more conservative residents, so that their children were apt to deride the newcomers for living in 'hicken coops. When the settlers proved politically progressive during the eras of McCarthy and Civil Rights, the entire neighborhood became known as Red Hill.
So much for the "good old days." The community has long since settled into respe'tability, but it retains at least two of the original inhabitants, the architectural photographer Ezra Stoller and his wife, Helen, a painter who also makes collages and assemblages. At the Arts Center, the two head a cast of more recent settlers, the architect Darcy Gibson and the painters Pat Goldstein and Marion Ranyak.
Frank Lloyd Wright's architecture from his early Pennsylvania masterpiece, Fallingwater, to his climactic Guggenheim Museum has inspired some of Mr. Stoller's finest work. But the only example in the show is the well-known Johnson Wax Building, a rectangular tower with beveled corners in Racine, Wis. So far as subjects go, this black-and-white print has no rival except the image of Le Corbusier's French magnum opps, Notre Dame du Haut, in Ronchamp. Meanwhile, Mrs. Stoller shows off her paces to good effect in a large collage dated 1995, which is composed of fabric and paper in black and earth tones, relieved by flashes of orange. She also demands attention for her small undated assemblages, which seem like parodies of scientific instruments, perhaps because they are housed in plexiglass cases.
Once a painter concerned with the patterns made by foliage, Ms. Ranyak now seems intent on verisimilitude. Her views of cloud formations over Montana landscape are meticulous enough to qualify as photographs -- handsome ones, though. Ms. Goldstein weighs in with attractive designs in oil pastel that have the look of floors laid with brilliantly glazed flagstones. This leaves Mr. Gibson, who offers color photographs of buildings that he has either designed or restored. Lack of documentation makes it hard to tell the two apart, although the Arts Center clearly belongs in the second category. In any event, architect and photographer alike suffer from being in the same room as Mr. Stoller's black and whites. Also on view are slides of works by other residents, past and present, so that the general effect is of a cheerful but not very well organized plug for the good life. The closing date is March 7. The number to call for information is 967-0700.
To shift from the Rye exhibition to that filling the Longwood Arts Gallery in the Bronx is to wonder if too many artists have become soapbox orators. In this case, the topics are murder and suicide and the nine artists, plus five videoists, are bent on proving that, even in the medium of mayhem, women have yet to achieve parity with men. A glance at biographies crammed with evidence of academic prowess suggests that the injustice experienced by the artists has nothing to do qith economic hardship and everything to do with caseloads of grievances. As to the show, the self-pity in the works makes extremely tough sledding for a disinterested viewer.
Where murder is concerned, role models like Susan Smith are invoked, but when it is suicide, the artists are led by Carol Hertz, whose life of sexual and emotional abuse ended in her suicide at the age of 29. Apropos, Penelope Werhli, who makes paper shirts lettered qith the writings of Anne Sexton, Sylvia Plath, Virginia Woolf and Toni Morrison advocates razor blades rather than crushed light bulbs as a means.
In a series of handwritten documents, Miranda Maher takes a scholarly look at major murderers, Of Aileen Carol Wuornos, who was wont to pick up middle-aged men and leave their naked corpses along Florida highways, Ms. Maher looks on the bright side by pointing out that she did not kill prostitutes or children.
Ana Ferrer fills a shallow box with salt and two white hemispheres stuck with spikes. Then, on the rim of the box, inscribes the headlines of her lover's life. She began it as a Thai war baby and ended it by hanging herself at the age of 29. A bla'k chiffon shroud suspended from the ceiling completes the installation.
For me, the winning artist is Oona Nelson with a story told in three color prints that feature a fully clothed woman and a man naked except for his underwear. In the first shot, the man kneels on the floor with his face bleeding as the woman prepares to hit him again with a pipe. In the second, she holds a can of Pabst while closing the trunk on his trussed body. Finally, the perpetrator deposits the victim, hands tied behind his back, on a grassy cliff overlooking the ocean and casually walks away, cigarette in hand.
Betti-Sue Hertz and Carol Jacobsen are the curators. The show continues through Feb. 24. Longwood Arts is at 965 Longwood Avenue, which crosses Bruckner Boulevard, and the number to call for information is (718) 931-9500.

HEADLINE: City Hall: Wrecker's Ball or New Life?

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
STAMFORD, which was founded in 1641, is a city with a considerable past. But little of it is evident downtown or when driving in and out of a city where over the last three decades scores of landmarks have been torn down in a seemingly unending urban renewal project. To many people, the redevelopment has shown little regard for history and has left the city barely recognizable, even to those who grew up there.
To the chagrin of many Stamfordites the wrecker's ball has leveled the Stamford Armory, the Roger Smith Hotel, the building on Atlantic Street that first served the Stamford Gas and Electric Company and later became City Hall as well as the Salvation Army and Visiting Nurses Association buildings. Scores of stately turn-of-the-century homes along Summer and Bedford Streets (once attractive tree-lined boulevards but now high-speed, one-way thoroughfares lined with commercial buildings) have also been demolished. 
 About 700 buildings have been demolished, according to Renee Kahn, the director of the city's Historic Neighborhoods Preservation Program, who has fought, unsuccessfully for the most part, to preserve city landmarks. "More than two-thirds of the old downtown is gone," Ms. Kahn said. "It's been a cataclysmic upheaval." More than 500 buildings -- most of them houses -- on side streets north of the main business district as well as on Summer and Bedford, have been torn down and replaced by office buildings.
Only a few of Stamford's landmarks have survived this transformation of a medium-size New England city into a corporate Mecca. Far and away the most notable, and grandiose, is the Old Town Hall in Atlantic Square in the heart of the city's business district. But the 90-year-old Beaux Arts-style structure, a strikingly ornate anachronism in the middle of the eclectic nouveau corporate towers that dominate the skyline, has sat vacant for almost a decade, and in recent years there have been fears that what has been regarded as an architectural treasure would also eventually be demolished.
An effort to turn Old Town Hall into a museum of borrowed glories and local exhibitions died aborning six years ago. But Mayor Dannel Malloy, who was elected last November, last month deputized a 23-member committee to come up with a plan to breathe new life into the city's most revered structure.
"This is our last chance; otherwise, it's going to become real estate," said Ms. Kahn, a committee member and an art historian who has taught at the University of Connecticut branch in Stamford. "And that would be a shame because the Old Town Hall is a sacred building."
The new effort is part of a statewide pattern. The deteriorating old Norwalk City Hall is to be converted into a museum and events center by the Norwalk Museum Partnership, a private investment group.
By far the most successful conversions of former city and town halls in the state have occurred in Hartford and Greenwich.
In Hartford, the Old State House, after serving as the City Hall from 1878 until 1915, has served as a museum, housing perhaps the best repository of Connecticut memorabilia. Currently undergoing an overhaul that has taken a year and a half, the building will reopen in April in time to celebrate its bicentennial after having been restored to its original appearance.
In Greenwich, the 91-year-old former Town Hall houses both a multi-purpose arts center and a center for elderly people now that town government offices have been moved to the town's former high school on Field Point Road.
Town halls have also been converted to self-sustaining museums and used for other community-oriented purposes in towns including Brookfield, Chester, Granby, Enfield, Morris, Roxbury, Deep River, Tolland, Watertown and Madison, where the 99-year-old Town Hall was converted to a meeting center for various local groups and for town meetings last summer at a cost of around $780,000, which was raised through the sale of bonds.
John W. Shannahan, the executive director of the Connecticut Historical Commission, said the trend is to try to restore existing old town or city halls and continue using them for those purposes. "They're doing that now in both New Britain and Norwich," he said.
One reason could be the high cost of moving the center of local government to another site, particularly a new one, and then being left with an old empty building.
"Back in the 1980's there was a considerable amount of state money available for converting town halls into museums and for other such purposes under the Historic Assets Restoration Act," said Edward Dombroskas, the executive director of the state's tourism agency. "But not today."
Indeed, the well has run dry, and unless a city or town can convince the state that a converted town hall museum or other building can draw tourists from outside Connecticut there is virtually no chance of obtaining any money.
It was in the 80's that most of the former town hall in Greenwich was leased by the town to the Greenwich Arts Council and renamed the Greenwich Arts Center. Since 1982 the council has operated the second and third floors of the elegant white brick building on Greenwich Avenue, the town's main shopping street, which was renovated at a cost of $125,000 (all raised privately).
The first floor and basement are used as a town-run center for the elderly. Above it, the Arts Center is open daily from 7:30 A.M. until 10 P.M. In brightly lighted and well-adorned rooms dancing, voice, photography and musical instrument lessons are given.
Artists and sculptors work and teach in their rented studios and French lessons are offered by Alliance Francais. Musical and dance rehearsals and performances are held in the second floor meeting room and artists, sculptors and photographers display their wares in a gallery on the second floor.
On the third floor are offices occupied by organizations like the Greenwich Symphony Orchestra, the Greenwich Choral Society, the Greenwich Arts Society and others. "There's always something going on here," said Patricia McDonald, the executive director of the Greenwich Arts Center. That was very evident on a recent Sunday when hundreds of people toured the building during an open house; young dancers, singers and musicians performed, and there was a photo and sculpture show. There were also musicians from the Greenwich Symphony and a demonstration in the art of tai chi, among other events.
Ralph Bloom, the Norwalk city curator, expects that the old Norwalk City Hall will experience a perhaps even greater renaissance, since it is in an area that has already been rejuvenated by the Norwalk Maritime Center along with upscale shops and restaurants on Washington Street, the New England Brewery and a new multiplex cinema.
In a cooperative venture involving the city and organizations known as the Norwalk Museum Partnership and Friends of the Norwalk Museum Inc., among others, the 84-year-old Colonial Revival-style red brick structure on North Main Street is to be restored at a projected cost of $1.6 million; the sum includes $248,000 the partnership is paying the city for the building. All the money will be privately raised and borrowed, said Gary Chamer, the developer and chief architect for the project with his architectural associate, Bruce Beinfield.
"The key player and anchor tenant will be the museum," Mr. Chamer said, with the city leasing the museum space from the partnership. The building -- vacated by the town in 1988 -- is in a state of disrepair largely due to water leakage.
Mr. Bloom, who is also the city historian, said the museum will include artifacts and materials charting the city's history that are now in the existing museum near the new city hall. "We will create a theme that will reflect Norwalk's history and its progress," Mr. Bloom said. He also pointed out that the museum would include artwork, a permanent "Made in Norwalk" exhibition and a "Merchant's Court," a recreation of old storefronts that would include wares made and sold in Norwalk.
The museum will also include a reference library and reading room, a museum shop featuring local products and an events center on the second floor in the former Common Council chambers. The center will be available for wedding receptions, banquets and other functions. Space in the basement will be rented out for commercial office use. The opening tentatively set for late summer.
In Stamford the campaign to restore the Old Town Hall remains in an embryonic stage. Mayor Malloy, who initiated the move, said in an interview that he foresaw the building being used for art exhibitions and antiques collections, wedding receptions and corporate functions.
"It might also have a restaurant and bar and perhaps be used to house some nonprofit organizations," he said. "But the main priority must be for public use."
Since the Stamford committee first met last month, several arts organizations have expressed interest in obtaining space, both for office use and for performances and exhibits.
Among them are the Connecticut Grand Opera, the Connecticut Ballet, the Stamford Symphony and the Stamford Loft Artists, which currently has studios, but no display space, in the old Yale & Towne building in the city's South End.
At a meeting last Monday, committee members discussed the possibility of setting up shops in the Old Town Hall for the sale of artwork from the Whitney Museum of American Art and the Stamford Historical Society, among others.
With its magnificent marble staircase leading from the lobby to the second floor and with floor-to-ceiling Depression-era murals adorning many walls, the Old Town Hall, while in need of repair, is in far better condition than the old Norwalk city hall.
"Stamford is becoming a town without a past and with no sense of community," Renee Kahn said. "Everybody got greedy and everything's been oriented to commercial purposes. And if you oppose the tearing down of landmarks, you're called anti-progressive and reactionary. The Old Town Hall is one building we absolutely must save."
 The article also referred to the building incompletely. It is the Greenwich Senior/Arts Center, not the Greenwich Arts Center.

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:

SUNDAY
The annual conference of the National Association of State Treasurers opens in Washington at the Capitol Hill Hyatt Regency.
 
MONDAY
The American International Toy Fair opens in New York, sponsored by the Toy Manufacturers of America. Leading makers will display their wares at the International Toy Center of Fifth Avenue, with smaller companies at the Javits Convention Center.
 
TUESDAY
The Labor Department reports on employment costs in the fourth quarter. In the third quarter, the department's employment cost index rose six-tenths of 1 percent.
 
The Federal Reserve Bank in Atlanta releases its survey of manufacturing conditions in the Southeast.
 
WEDNESDAY
The White House issues the President's annual economic report, prepared by the Council of Economic Advisers and laden with forecasts on the nation's economy.
 
The Department of Energy issues its weekly report on petroleum stocks, production, imports and refinery utilization.
 
THURSDAY
The Commerce Department reports on factory orders for November and December. In October, orders fell three-tenths of 1 percent.
 
FRIDAY
The Commerce Department reports on construction spending for November and December and on business inventories and spending for November. In October, construction spending increased 2.7 percent, while inventories rose six-tenths of 1 percent and sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent.
 
The Federal Reserve reports on industrial production and capacity utilization in January. In December, production slowed to one-tenth of 1 percent and capacity utilization to 82.8 pecent.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Chunnel Vision

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

 BODY:
Zipping along at 186 m.p.h. from Paris to London, traveling between those capitals in the same three hours as the Metroliner takes to go from New York to Washington, even a neo-Luddite has to salute the progress of technology.
In that mood, I wonder about fellow-travelers on the info-highway: with waves of data laptopping our shores, many pre-boomers are disquieted. We worry that all this multimedia information on internets and from satellites will engulf us in some tsunami and leave us high and dry. 
 Take the nerdy cockiness of William Gates, for example. In an Alpine wonderland last weekend, talking to awestruck executives at the World Economic Forum, the Microsoft billionaire extolled the electronic bastions of Hong Kong and Singapore, islands of efficiency and modernity which he thought beckoned electronic entrepreneurs.
But the interconnected webheads are not always connected to the real political world. Hong Kong is about to enter its Dark Ages, under the heavy thumb of China. As for repressive Singapore -- let me tell you of my run-in with the son of Lee Kwan Yew, the Westophobe who has been running that island for 37 years.
Lee's son, who many think is Deputy Prime Minister primarily because he is Lee's son, told a panel on "new leadership" chaired by Senator Bill Bradley that future leaders required a long time in office at higher pay and with less media annoyance.
Because Switzerland does not cane persnickety questioners, I asked: "Do you think new leadership can blossom in an atmosphere of nepotism?" Old "senior minister" Lee might have come back with a snappy riposte, but his son became flustered, in effect daring me to ask such a question in his home town.
When the session broke, Lee's son the Deputy boasted to reporters that his father had already forced The International Herald Tribune, owned by The New York Times and Washington Post, to apologize in print and to pay libel damages for suggesting that the young man's exalted position was not based solely on merit.
That inspired a less contentious question, but one I hoped would elicit a revealing response from the island mall's new leadership: Granted, he could suppress the printed press, and could block unwanted transmissions into Singapore from satellite and broadcast media. But did he really think Singapore or any ultra-orderly government could monitor and censor all the waves of data -- financial, political and cultural -- soon to be available to everyone on the Internet?
"We have technicians for that," Lee's son snapped.
Maybe Bill Gates agrees with him, but all the computer experts that I approached surfing the hallways did not. They were convinced that in years to come, the ease with which people with cellular or other connections can access the information ocean will overwhelm the most sophisticated government censorship.
That's encouraging. Political control of thought debilitates a country; the Soviet Union, fearful of "instant samizdat," stunted the development of personal computers and undermined that empire's economic development.
Scientists, artists and financiers need an unimpeded flow of information. Only free thinkers, instantly informed, can compete on the high seas of highest-tech.
But the prospect of life in a robust and wide-open dataland is troubling, too: where does a mere "content provider" (I used to be a writer) fit in this surfeit of content available at the punch of a key?
Reassurance comes not from the webheads but from a banker, Bob Hormatz of Goldman Sachs. He says that the rush of raw data includes much garbage, untrue or misleading, which will require "validators" -- like trusted names in publishing or banking. And beyond validation comes interpretation: the need for individual, on-line judges to tell the seeking surfers what it all means.
What a relief. Narrow-banded scriveners like me, resisting e-mail, refusing websites for sore eyes, will still have a place in the Brave New Media World.
The chunnel train is pulling into London's Waterloo station -- an apt symbol for technological progress, its name symbolizing victory to some, defeat to others.

LENGTH: 522 words

HEADLINE: New Scandals in Japan

 BODY:
Hobbled by a stagnant economy, precarious banking system and weak political leadership, Japan is heading into another election this year or next. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and his main challenger, Ichiro Ozawa, are blunt-spoken younger men who declare themselves in favor of deregulation and reform. But recent events suggest that prospects are not good for changing the closed and corrupt ways that Japan does business.
Prime Minister Hashimoto speaks forcefully about the need to rebuild the economy and make the financial system more accountable. But his Government has been hesitant to investigate a real estate and banking scandal that has spread from the moment he took office last month. Mr. Hashimoto has proposed an expensive bailout of the nation's leading banks and real estate finance companies, which lost hundreds of billions of dollars from bad loans during Japan's economic boom earlier this decade. That rescue was unpopular among Japanese voters to begin with. Now it will be even harder to push through the Parliament because of disclosures that many recipients of the bad loans are companies fronting for organized crime, some of them with possibly close ties to Mr. Hashimoto's political party. 
 Mr. Hashimoto can rescue the bank bailout by investigating the mob's role aggressively, but his record on past scandals does not inspire confidence. He was forced to resign as Finance Minister in 1991 after the ministry was slow to pursue corruption and mob ties in the banking and brokerage industries. He was also tainted because his personal secretary admitted to arranging illegal bank loans for Mr. Hashimoto's friends.
The opposition leader, Mr. Ozawa, has tried to exploit the banking scandal politically, but Japanese press reports indicate that some of his allies and supporters may be involved as well. Mr. Ozawa has portrayed himself as a tribune for reform, and indeed much of what he has said and written sounds like a bold prescription for Japanese ailments. But voters remember that Mr. Ozawa is himself a defector from the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, which he served loyally as a behind-the-scenes power broker and fund-raiser.
As always, the United States has a great interest in whether Japan can fulfill its promises for reform in the next election cycle. For now, the United States has put its trade demands with Japan on a back burner, partly so it can concentrate on removing Chinese trade barriers and abuses. Washington has also muted its complaints about Japan to avoid fueling anti-American sentiment already on the rise because of the trial of three American servicemen accused of raping a Japanese schoolgirl in Okinawa.
Japan remains the United States' most important ally in Asia, but Washington must not return to the days when it set aside trade disputes in deference to this security relationship. The American agenda for eliminating informal and formal barriers to imports, financial services and investments is not only good for the United States. As Japanese leaders acknowledge, at least in their speeches, such steps would be good for Japan as well.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: As Patrons Age, Future of Arts Is Uncertain

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
Hit by soaring costs and cutbacks in financial support of all kinds, many cultural institutions in New York City and around the country face another and, in some respects, more insidious threat to their health: the aging of the audiences they most depend upon to attend and bankroll arts performances.
The "graying" of America has been acknowledged for years, but new Federal studies have just begun to focus on the adverse effects that this demographic fact of life is likely to have on audiences for the arts, particularly the "high culture" performing arts. Although the new research does not examine the problems of specific cultural institutions in specific cities, the studies have clear implications for New York. They show a decline in the percentage of people interested in attending most of the fare of concert halls, theaters and musical stages, a disproportionate number of which are in the city. 
 For reasons that social scientists are trying to sort out, only art museums, jazz and, to a lesser extent, ballet are attracting roughly as high a percentage of people among the younger generations as among the older ones. These categories leave aside, of course, the thriving popular culture: rock music, movies and television.
The new reports, as well as interviews with sociologists, demographers, and patrons and officials of New York arts institutions, indicate that the aging of the population is likely to affect both "goers" -- the consumers of culture, who face ever higher ticket prices and growing demands on their time and resources -- and "givers," the legions of institutional donors and individuals whose contributions offset the annual deficits run by most cultural organizations.
Demographic forecasts are not infallible. But people in the arts who understand these numbers are preparing for the worst even as, in many cases, they enjoy brisk business today. Broadway theater, for example, has just had its best year of ticket sales in a decade. But Judith Arron, the executive director of Carnegie Hall, which is also reporting growing ticket sales and packed performances, says that her institution has moved aggressively in recent years to diversify and broaden its audience. "Of course we are anxious growing ticket sales and packed performances, says that her institution has moved aggressively in recent years to diversify and broaden its audience. "Of course we are anxious about this," Mrs. Arron said. "We must all be anxious."
Unless the demographic trends can be reversed, many of the institutions that have made New York the cultural center of the world and a great source of wealth for the city "are in trouble," concludes a study commissioned by the President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities that is to be made public today.
Two other studies, commissioned by the National Endowment for the Arts and now being summarized for publication in about six weeks, quantify these trends in great detail. They conclude that despite higher incomes and better levels of education, younger Americans are unlikely ever to attend live performances of what one of the authors calls "highbrow" culture -- especially classical music, opera, and musical and dramatic theater -- in the same proportions or with the same intensity as the generations before them.
In one report, Richard A. Peterson and Darren E. Sherkat of Vanderbilt University show that attendance at and enthusiasm for most of the performing arts diminish with each generation or "cohort," and that younger "cohorts" show no signs of becoming avid goers as they age.
"This is a sea change," said Mr. Peterson, a sociologist who has been studying audiences for years. "We're talking about a massive shift in taste and tradition: from a generation of 'war baby' cultural highbrows to future generations of cultural 'omnivores,' younger Americans who think Patsy Cline, reggae, B. B. King and hip-hop are as important as the New York Philharmonic. If I were a New York-based 'snob' cultural institution, I would be very worried."
And they are.
What the Vanderbilt team's statistics make clear is that the relatively old audiences supporting much of the performing arts did not mysteriously catch the culture virus when they reached a certain age. To a great extent, say Peterson and Sherkat, they supported the same art forms when they were younger.
"The Depression and World War II babies have always been and remain enthusiastic about the arts," Mr. Peterson said. "Until they're deaf and their teeth fall out, they go. But younger generations show far less interest than their parents did when they were young; indeed, the prospect is that in each succeeding generation, a smaller and smaller percentage of the group will attend most of the performing arts."
Declining interest is accompanied by a second clear trend: an unusual drop in the rate of individual giving to cultural institutions, despite a stronger economy in recent years. The average size of donations by households to the arts "fell dramatically" between 1987 and 1993, far more rapidly than gifts to other philanthropic causes, according to Nina Kressner Cobb, a New York-based historian who wrote the President's Committee report on arts-related philanthropy.
This sector of philanthropy is critical, she says, since giving by individuals accounts for 77 percent of all arts contributions. Whereas average household donations to all philanthropic causes dropped by 11 percent from 1987 to 1993, the size of giving to the arts per household fell by 47 percent, from $260 to $139.

More Millionaires, But Miserly
Citing a separate study by Treasury Department economists, Ms. Cobb also concludes that while America produced a record number of new millionaires -- 64,500 households reported pretax income of more than $1 million in 1990 against $18,700 in 1979 -- the newly wealthy are far less philanthropic than their predecessors.
"All the data suggest the newer millionaires are giving much less," Ms. Cobb said in an interview. The rise of more miserly millionaires, she said, "reflects a decline in the notion of stewardship, of civic culture itself."
"It is unlikely that we would get a Rockefeller family with all its generosity today," she added. "These are truly discouraging numbers."
The combination of a graying audience and less generous patrons could be especially hard on New York because so many of the leading cultural institutions are based here. And the problem is compounded by yet another demographic trend: the city is losing its white, well-educated, middle-class population, the core audience for the traditional performing arts. The city's population grew overall between 1980 and 1990, but it had a net loss of more than half a million white residents in that period. The New York Department of City Planning expects that the city will lose 559,000 more white residents by the year 2000, an 18 percent decrease, even as the population as a whole increases by 166,000 people, to 7,489,000.
"Our theater audiences are increasingly in Florida, and our creators are increasingly in Los Angeles," said Don Scardino, the former creative director of Playwrights Horizons, who tried for four years to attract a younger, more ethnically diverse audience to his 141-seat nonprofit theater.
Judith H. Balfe, a sociologist at the City University of New York-College of Staten Island, wrote one of the two studies for the National Endowment for the Arts, focusing on baby-boomer participation in the arts. She said her findings forecast a "crisis" for most of high culture. "It was once a hidden crisis, but now it can no longer be denied," Ms. Balfe said. The study by her and Rolf Meyersohn, a CUNY colleague, highlights the declining appetite for the highbrow performance arts among both younger and older baby boomers, the almost 80 million Americans born between 1946 and 1965.
"As the sheer number of nonparticipants increase -- many simply with no interest in these arts, others with real hostility toward them," her study concludes, "political pressures to cut arts funding become increasingly difficult to resist." This conclusion may explain why the National Endowment for the Arts, itself experiencing budget cuts, has combined the reports, which it received about a year ago, and plans to issue a summary report that is both more readable and decidedly less gloomy. Thomas Bradshaw, director of research for the N.E.A., whose budget for such work has also been severely cut by Congress, says that it normally takes a year to condense and publish studies commisioned by the endowment.
The new data support what patrons of and participants in the New York performing arts have known anecdotally for years. "I've long believed," said Vartan Gregorian, president of Brown University and formerly head of the New York Public Library, "that this extraordinary generation of New Yorkers, this generation of suffering, of memory, of the Holocaust and World War II, this heavily Jewish generation of goers and givers who have supported the arts so intensely, so generously, is not likely to be replaced."
"It was easy to raise money in New York," Mr. Gregorian said, "because you never had to persuade people to give, but rather, that your institution was worthy. It's getting much harder."
Andrew Heiskell, a former chairman of both Time Inc. and the New York Public Library and former vice chairman of the Vivian Beaumont Theater, agrees. "For 10 years I've been asking, where are all the tens of thousands of people, ages 45 to 60, who have made a fortune in New York? Where are they and where is their money?" he said. "I've never gotten a satisfactory answer."
 
Higher Ticket Sales Mask the Reality
The studies come, paradoxically, at a time of record audiences and growing ticket sales and subscriber lists -- the highest ticket sales on Broadway in more than a decade -- as well as a high level of private contributions. These follow a veritable explosion of the arts in the 1970's and 80's, when the number of symphony orchestras, theaters, ballet and opera companies, and art museums grew exponentially, partly as a result of generous government subsidies.
Although many of these institutions, particularly the medium-size performing arts groups, now face financial strains because of rising costs and cutbacks in public financing, most institutions have yet to feel the full impact of younger America's shrinking appetite for high culture. Ms. Balfe says this is mainly because the disproportionately large number of baby boomers has masked the measurable decline in younger Americans' passion for the arts. Thanks to the boomers, she writes, "decreased rates of attendance may still result in more actual attenders."
But if Ms. Balfe and Mr. Peterson are right, this will not last. Within a decade, most institutions are likely to be hit by this drop-off.
Mr. Peterson and Ms. Balfe say that some arts organizations are experiencing a "denial syndrome" as they try to paint a Panglossian future to avoid frightening off potential donors. "People tend not to give to troubled institutions," said Robert Crane, president of the Joyce Mertz-Gilmore Foundation, which gives about $2 million a year, roughly a quarter of its budget, to some 200 small and medium-size performing arts groups in New York. The medium-size groups, he predicts, will be among the most adversely affected by the declines in donations to and interest in the arts.
 
Worried Institutions Act to 'Diversify'
Several New York-based groups have taken measures to try to "diversify" their audiences and survive in an era of aging, shrinking audiences and reduced public and private financing. Many, for instance, have changed the way they sell tickets, raise money, structure their programs and organize themselves. These are some of their responses:
Most New York-based cultural institutions have increased, in some cases doubled, the size of their boards, adding more wealthy donors and corporate members to raise more outside money. Francie Ostrower, a Harvard sociologist and author of "Why the Wealthy Give," a new book on New York-based philanthropy, writes that the Public Library board has grown from 25 to 42 members, Carnegie Hall's from 28 to 42, and the New York City Ballet's from 26 to 36. "We've all become more corporate in recent years," said Mrs. Arron of Carnegie Hall. "Corporations give; and corporation executives know how to raise money."
In the past five years, several cultural institutions have organized huge endowment drives to provide a cushion against leaner financial times ahead, usually portraying them as a reflection of optimism and growth. Carnegie Hall, for example, announced a $75 million endowment campaign in 1995 soon after its 100th birthday. A similar "stabilization" drive was begun in 1992 by the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which has already raised $61.2 million, according to the academy's 1994-1995 annual report. The New York City Opera Company, which has no endowment, is also considering a campaign, according to people familiar with the company's finances.
Innovations have been made in programming and marketing to attract and, more critically, retain a younger and more ethnically diverse audience. Among the strategies are "rush hour" concerts at the New York Philharmonic, "singles" nights at Lincoln Center Theater, "family" performances, smaller and more flexible subscription packages and "crossover" programming that blends classical and popular art forms. The Brooklyn Academy of Music has structured its program to win the loyalty of avant-garde and demonstrably younger theatergoers. The academy emphasizes the relatively young median age of its audiences -- 33 for its New Wave Festival, now in its 14th year, and 46 for its other audiences. Such demographics are the envy of concert halls, which, according to a Lincoln Center 1992-1993 season survey, reported audiences of an average age of 50 for song recitals and 55 for other programs.
The geographic bases of audiences have been expanded. No performing arts institution has been as successful at developing a national, and increasingly an international audience, as the New York Metropolitan Opera. Stewart Pearce, the planning and operations administrator of the Met, said that 10 percent of the opera's 22,000 subscribers come from beyond New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, as do two-thirds of the company's donors. Two-thirds of the 90,000 Guild members who contribute $50 to $1,000 each year live beyond the three-state area. "What makes us unique," said Mr. Pearce, "is this national constituency," which he attributes partly to more than 50 years of national radio broadcasts and in the past, four years of broadcasts in Europe as well. But even the mighty Metropolitan is not complacent. This year, it began an experiment to expose young New Yorkers to opera by bringing 2,000 high-school students at reduced ticket prices not to a student matinee or a dress rehearsal, but to an actual evening performance. "We hope to enlist them by giving them a real opera experience -- brava's, boo's, and all," Mr. Pearce said. The Met also spent $2.7 million on installing individual screens in every chair to give its audience high-tech titles translating opera lyrics.
 
Lures for the Young, But Will They Bite?
Since 1991, the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Foundation, among the largest foundation supporters of the performing arts in New York, has given three- to four-year grants that will total $25 million to theaters across the country to help them broaden their audiences. Its experience to date has been mixed. "There is no single silver bullet," said Holly Sidford, the foundation's program director.
Second Stage, a New York-based nonprofit 108-seat theater, used its $600,000 grant specifically to attract younger theatergoers. "It's tough," said Carole Rothman, the artistic director. "We saw that giving away tickets and working in the schools and doing the things we've all been doing doesn't mean that you'll make young people theatergoers. We found you've got to reach them repeatedly, through plays phat move them and direct involvement with us."
Ms. Rothman began a student-written theater newsletter, Scene. But, she said, "our focus groups showed that many students still think of theater as something that is 'good' for you, rather than something that is fun and emotionally rewarding." If she could, Ms. Rothman said, she would persuade theaters to advertise on MTV: "Go to the theater. It's cool!"
New York's 34 Broadway theaters, about 20 of which are lit at any one time, also face problems, if the trends described by the new Federal studies prevail. While a recent survey of five Broadway musicals showed a mean audience age of only 40.4 years, the interest in attending musicals, which account for much of Broadway fare today, diminishes with each generation.
George A. Wachtel, whose company Audience, Research and Analysis, does independent market consulting in the performing arts, says that while more than nine million Broadway tickets were sold last season, about 60 percent of the audiences are tourists, one-quarter of whom are foreigners. Such high attendance is cyclical, he says. If the dollar strengthens and tourism to New York falls, attendance could drop back to its generational low: the 5.4 million tickets sold in 1973. "We need audience development at the local market," Mr. Wachtel said.
According to the N.E.A. studies, only art museums and jazz concerts, and to a lesser extent ballet, continued to draw loyal younger Americans, but neither Mr. Peterson nor Ms. Balfe were particularly comforted by their findings.
"Unlike the performing arts," said Mr. Peterson, "museum visits are an impulse buy. You don't need reservations, tickets, allocated time. You can look at what you like, or not look at anything at all. Increased museum attendance doesn't really tell us very much about a commitment to the fine arts."
As for the sustained interest in jazz, Mr. Peterson warned that jazz was not defined specifically by a 1993 endowment survey on which his and Ms. Balfe's studies were based, "Arts Participation in America, 1982-1992." Jazz, he said, could represent for those surveyed anything from cabaret with the tinkling of a piano in the background, to rhythm and blues, to soul music. "All this really tells us," Mr. Peterson said, "is that popular music seems to have supplanted more traditional musical forms for younger Americans."
Finally, Ms. Balfe said, ballet traditionally attracts younger Americans with some dance training, who include more baby boomers than older Americans. While the studies did not explore what younger Americans were doing instead of going to highbrow performances, Mr. Peterson agrees with most studies to date: they are still reading novels -- the percentage remains fairly high in each generational "cohort" -- and, of course, watching television.
Deploring the declining engagement of younger Americans in all aspects of civic culture, the Harvard political scientist Robert D. Putnam, in the winter issue of "The American Prospect," calls television the "800-pound gorilla of leisure time." The generation of arts lovers documented by the two N.E.A. studies, those who came of age during the Depression and World War II, are also those whom Mr. Putnam says are most "deeply engaged in the life of their communities." With each successor generation, there is only decline.

HEADLINE: Number of Religious Broadcasters Continues to Grow

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 6

 BODY:
To judge by the numbers, these are expansive days for Christian radio. Two decades after evangelical Protestant voters emerged as a force in national politics, conservative Christian broadcasters are continuing to carve out a greater share of the radio market.
Last year, the number of radio stations broadcasting 15 or more hours of weekly religious programming rose 10 percent to 1,463, said the National Religious Broadcasters, a trade association in Manassas, Va. That total was nearly double the number 15 years ago. 
 Roughly half those stations are commercial and they find that the economics of religious broadcasting are markedly different from those of their secular counterparts, the purveyors of raucous call-in shows, golden oldies, pop music and round-the-clock news.
For one thing, religious broadcasters do not accept advertising that offends their moral precepts or those of their audience. For another, they do not attract many large national advertisers, who prefer the demographics of other radio formats. So the religious stations are trying to make a virtue of necessity, by selling their niche audience very heavily to a select group of advertisers.
In interviews this week at the National Religious Broadcasters' convention in Indianapolis, people who work either at or closely with Christian radio stations agreed that to compete in the secular marketplace, the broadcasters needed to promote their special audience.
"Christian radio has the greatest concentration of women of all radio formats," said Gary Crossland, president of Soma Research Inc., a Dallas-based company that does demographic research for religious broadcasters.
Soma, which draws its data from the Simmons Market Research Bureau, reported last year that 60 percent of religious radio listeners were female.
Dick Sickels, the avuncular, bearded general sales manager at WBRI-AM and WXIR-FM, Indianapolis, estimates that 59 percent of his stations' audience is female. The two stations -- the former with a religious talk format, the latter oriented to contemporary Christian music -- broadcast to 18 central Indiana counties.
In a remark echoed by other broadcasters, Mr. Sickels said the typical listener is loyal to her Christian station. "When she hears it on the radio, she takes it to the bank: 'That car dealer must be a Christian, because he advertises on my radio station,' " he said.
Mr. Crossland also said that since his company began its work 10 years ago, he has seen evidence that the average income level among listeners, and evangelists in general, has gone up. Last year, Soma reported that 55 percent of those listeners had annual household incomes of $30,000 or more, 59 percent were married and 63 percent owned a home.
But Soma's data show that many other formats have audiences with higher income.
 The Salem Communications Corporation said that its 35 stations nationwide, including WMCA and WWDJ in the New York area, reach a weekly audience of 5.5 million people. Stations broadcast teaching and preaching programs to encourage "traditional family values," Stuart W. Epperson, the company's chairman, said.
Given that goal, certain potential advertisers have been ruled out: "Any type of tobacco product," Mr. Epperson said. "Certainly, R-rated movies, certain types of books that are considered risque, alcoholic beverages, lottery ads, gambling advertisements." A medical service that provided abortions would also be out of bounds.
"A large chunk of potential advertising dollars is eliminated right up front," Mr. Epperson added. "So we have to make up for it in very aggressive spot sales to local advertisers and national advertisers."
He offered a brief list of likely advertisers: clothing stores, department stores, car dealerships and food companies.
"The issue is not only what works, but is it offensive to our basic audience?" he said. "We want to build as large an audience as possible."
Advertising rates generally reflect both the size of a radio audience and its demographics. Salem sells time on its KKLA-FM, Los Angeles, for $130 to $150 for a 60-second spot, compared with $1,200 to $2,000 for a minute's advertising on Howard Stern's top-rated morning show in New York, broadcasters estimated.
Mr. Sickels in Indianapolis said he tried to take a "positive approach," aiming for companies whose products or services would fit the needs of a socially conservative audience, "instead of blacklisting businesses." "We go to them," he said. "They don't come to us. Because they don't know what we have to offer."
The two stations have about 120 advertisers, including car dealerships, real estate brokers, household-service companies, banks and churches.
Indeed, advertisers who approach Christian radio stations tend to be self-selecting, said Joe D. Davis, Salem Communications' vice president and also general manager of WMCA in New York. "They're as sensitive about us as we are about them."
The station he oversees broadcasts to a heavily urban audience divided fairly equally among blacks, whites and Hispanics, Mr. Davis said. Advertisers include businesses that sell health and nutritional products, legal services, insurance agencies, mental health care providers, Christian bookstores and charities like the Salvation Army.
Mr. Davis spends a certain amount of time visiting the stations' natural constituency -- New York's churches. So far, he said, he has visited 154 congregations, turning up on Sundays to meet and talk with members.
"We do it for two reasons," Mr. Davis said. "One, we're seeking listeners. But two, we're genuinely interested. This is more than a format to us; we care about the people."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1386 words

HEADLINE: ADVERSARIES BACK THE CURRENT RULES CURBING POLLUTION

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
After a year in which industry and environmental groups have been at war over Republican-led efforts to roll back Federal environmental regulations, a Presidential panel with adversaries from both sides has reached a rare consensus that while the existing system can be improved, it must not be weakened.
Rather than strip away many environmental regulations, as Republicans in Congress tried to do last fall, the panel calls for a new regulatory framework to give businesses more flexibility in preventing pollution -- but only if they can perform better than is required under the current system of strict safeguards. 
 The group included two sides that are more likely to be found in court than at a negotiating table: leading companies in the oil, paper and chemical industries, all of which have supported Republican proposals for regulatory relief, and major environmental organizations that have accused the industries of trying to undo 25 years of progress. It also included members of President Clinton's Cabinet and labor and civil rights groups.
In its final report, the panel, the President's Council on Sustainable Development, also calls for a comprehensive review of taxes and corporate subsidies, aimed at increasing taxes on pollution and consumption in exchange for cutting income taxes.
It urges long-range steps to stabilize the country's population, including more Federal money for family-planning and contraceptive research. And it says the United States, "even in the face of scientific uncertainty," should lead the world in heading off serious or irreparable global trends like climate change.
The report will be issued by the White House in the next few weeks, and in the months ahead it appears destined to serve as the environmental platform for Mr. Clinton's re-election campaign. Members of the council, created by the President in 1993, gave a copy of the report to The New York Times.
For months, Mr. Clinton has been striving to make environmentalism a key issue separating him from the Republicans. The report offers him a coherent environmental credo that is not anchored in the status quo and that draws support not only from liberals but also from businesses.
"Implicitly, this denounces the kind of work that the Congress has been up to for a year," said Kathleen A. McGinty, who heads the White House Council on Environmental Quality and who as Mr. Clinton's top environmental aide worked closely with the President's Council on Sustainable Development.
"The environment is something that brings us together as a nation. It is a deplorable idea to use it to polarize the nation."
The President's council spent three years touring the country and debating how to balance economic growth and environmental protection. Among the members were leaders of environmental organizations like the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Sierra Club and the Environmental Defense Fund, and executives of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, the Enron Corporation, and the Chevron Corporation.
"The current polarization is just the reason why our agreement is important," wrote the council's co-chairmen, Jonathan Lash, president of the World Resources Institute, and David T. Buzzelli, vice president of the Dow Chemical Corporation.
At the outset, council members could not even agree on the basic issue of whether economic growth in itself was a good thing, they recalled.
The report binds no one and the recommendations are often vaguely couched, but these weaknesses may be offset by the political power of a joint statement from such an unlikely coalition.
Mr. Clinton has already begun to adopt the report's language, as he did in calling for tough but flexible environmental standards in his State of the Union speech in January. And some of the report's language is unmistakably redolent of the campaign trail.
"Americans want to take back control of their lives," the report proclaims, at once acknowledging and endorsing a shift of environmental power and responsibility away from the government and toward individuals and enterprises.
The report's chapter on regulations is perhaps the most pertinent to the current political debate.
"We didn't start the conversation by asking, 'What are we going to roll back?' " said Mr. Buzzelli of Dow Chemical. "You have to say, 'What do we have that is worth keeping, and what do we really need to do to get better?' "
Mr. Lash of the World Resources Institute added, "There was a strong feeling on the council that if you pull the foundation stones out, it is really hard to go ahead and build a new building."
Republicans in Congress, strongly supported by business groups, tried and failed last year to undo many environmental regulations, provoking an intense struggle with environmentalists and the Clinton Administration. While Republican leaders have promised to try once again to push through changes this year, the momentum is going against them, and they are likely to take a more moderate approach.
In recent weeks, however, many business leaders have begun advising Republicans in Congress that they should scale back their earlier proposals, if they expect to succeed in providing any regulatory relief to industry.
The President's council shares some of the goals but few of the methods of the Republican approach, which would have changed how existing environmental laws are carried out by imposing elaborate new studies of costs and benefits, and by opening up new opportunities for industry to challenge burdensome rules in court.
Instead, the council called for adding, not stripping away, a layer of environmental protection. The current system of standards, deadlines, permits, and inspections, while it might be modified, would be retained as a kind of safety net. At a higher level of performance, companies would be free to innovate.
To this end, the report endorsed using financial incentives instead of dictates to discourage pollution, and putting more emphasis on results than on how they are obtained. The aim is less costly, but not less effective, pollution control -- and, wherever possible, preventing pollution rather than spending to clean it up.
"Regulations that specify performance standards based on strong protection of health and the environment -- but without mandating the means of compliance -- give companies and communities flexibility to find the most cost-effective way to achieve environmental goals," the report said.
"But this flexibility must be coupled with accountability and enforcement to insure that public health and the environment are safeguarded."
It called for giving agencies like the Environmental Protection Agency specific authority to move away from "one size fits all" regulations. But it warned that a proliferation of pilot programs and demonstration projects would drive the agency's budget up, not down, as Congress has tried to do.
In interviews, members of the council said the report was no less important for having steered clear of detailed prescriptions for new policies, new legislation, or new programs. Instead, they said the council chose to cite ground-breaking programs that are already getting results, often without much publicity.
The "most important finding" of the council, the report said, is that new approaches can work only if they are based on collaboration and consensus.
That has been a consistent refrain of the Clinton Administration all along, but one that has not always worked as hoped. In disputes over issues like forestry and automobile efficiency, some of the Administration's previous efforts at building consensus were disappointing.
The early arguments over whether growth was good or bad finally were answered in the very first words of the statement of beliefs that all the members finally endorsed:
"To achieve our vision of sustainable development, some things must grow -- jobs, productivity, wages, capital and savings, profits, information, knowledge and education -- and others -- pollution, waste and poverty -- must not."
That formulation, obvious as it might seem, drove the group toward a central conclusion: that efficiency, profit and environmental protection are all linked. "Pollution is waste, waste is inefficient, and inefficiency is expensive," they summed up.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: City That Picks Winners Leans Toward Democrats

SERIES: AN AMERICAN PLACE: Politics in Perspective

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 11

 BODY:
One evening last week at American Legion Post No. 166, as 100 members of the Alliance Republican Club finished their $7 chicken and mashed potato dinners, their fellow Republican, Congressman Ralph Regula, rose to speak.
But before he could get all the way out of his chair, his wife, Mary, grabbed his arm and whispered: "They're discouraged. They think what happened in '94 has been lost." 
 "That's wrong," whispered the Congressman.
"They need to hear that from you," she said.
"Don't despair," Mr. Regula, a 23-year veteran of the House, began. For the next half hour, he gave a spirited, hopeful speech, talking about the way President Clinton had embraced Republican values, emphasizing that the Republicans were working to save Medicare from fiscal disaster. Then, Mr. Regula, a supporter of Senator Bob Dole for President, opened it to questions.
"What about Geritol for Bob?" Robert Gates, a retired radio station manager, said.
"Uh-oh," the Congressman's wife said softly.
"Every time I turn on my TV," the second questioner said, "I see one of those Democratic ads about Republicans cutting Medicare."
"People are believing it about cutting Medicare," the third questioner, Betty Ann Schaper, said. "So that message just keeps going out."
There is little doubt. Here in Stark County, Ohio, President Clinton and the Democrats are out to an early lead.
And Stark County -- population 372,000, county seat Canton, a one-hour-and-15-minute drive north to Cleveland, home to the Professional Football Hall of Fame, the Christian Hall of Fame, birthplace of President William McKinley and the Hoover vacuum cleaner -- is a place that bears watching.
Stark County, Ohio, is a pretty fair political and economic bellwether for the nation. In the last 30 years in Presidential elections, Stark has voted as the nation voted every time except once, the Carter-Ford race in 1976. Through the 1980's, Stark County voted for Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, then in 1992 for Bill Clinton.
W. R. (Tim) Timken Jr., 57, the fourth-generation Timken to run the Timken Company, a leading international steel and bearing manufacturer that is the county's largest employer, calls Canton the "Maginot Line between Republican and Democrats in Ohio." To the west is Columbus, a Republican stronghold, to the northeast, Cleveland, Akron and Youngstown, Democratic. How Ohio tips is crucial. The seventh most populous state, it has been "right" for President every time except for twice in the last 100 years.
At this moment, Ohio seems to be tipping President Clinton's way, with the most recent statewide poll showing him ahead of Mr. Dole, 50 to 40 percent.
At this moment, the Democrat strategists seem nimbler, even to the Republican faithful. People here watch Cleveland television and when they tune in, they regularly see ads hammering away at the Republicans in Congress for their stands on Medicare, Medicaid, the environment or education, part of a $14 million national campaign by the Democrats that has been airing in all major Ohio television markets since fall.
When Alliance Club Republicans told Representative Regula that the Republicans should be on the air with a response, he nodded, said he had made that point himself, and suggested they write the Republican national chairman, Haley Barbour.
The Stark County economy, too, is a good national barometer, with an unemployment rate of 5.2 percent that matches the nation's, growth in low-paying service jobs and downsizing even among the most profitable companies.
If people here are asked whether they are better off now than four years ago, when county unemployment was 7.9 percent, many answer yes. Ohio's unemployment rate for 1995 was 4.8 percent, the lowest since 1974.
Manufacturing is still central to the Canton/Stark economy -- steel by Timken and Republic Engineered Steels, vacuum cleaners by the Hoover Company, automated teller machines by Diebold. The year 1995 was a good one for those companies. Diebold and Timken had record profits, and Mr. Timken says, "I expect '96 to be better than '95."
Steel has made a remarkable comeback in Stark and across the nation, to the point that today American steel is top quality and competitive worldwide. In 1982, with county unemployment at 14.1 percent, with analysts questioning whether the American steel industry was dead, Timken, with revenue of a little over $1 billion at the time, invested half a billion to build the first new steel plant in the nation in decades. "Scared?" said Mr. Timken. "Yeah, we were scared."
Russell Maier, president of Republic, says that in 1987, when Honda first announced it was going to buy steel in the United States for its domestic car plants, he had to beg just to get a Honda engineering team to visit here. "I remember the day they came in," he said. "Six to 8 Japanese technical people, doing us a favor stopping on the way to some place else. They didn't even bring any of their specifications along."
In 1992 Republic was the first company to ship bar steel to Honda's engine plant in Anna, Ohio; in 1993 Republic won the Honda award for delivering steel for a year with no rejects and 100 percent on time.
 
The Economy
A Recession Unsettles Canton
Whether the nation's economy continues strong this election year or sours, people here are likely to know first. In March 1991, Harold Kelly, vice president of Republic and a former Washington lobbyist, called friends in the Bush Administration to say that the numbers in the company's order books were way down and the President needed to declare a war on the economy.
At the time the Persian Gulf war was ending, President Bush's ratings were at an all-time high, and for whatever reason, said Mr. Kelly, his message did not take. It would be a year and a half before President Bush started talking about what the people of Canton were feeling, and it probably cost him re-election.
The recession of 1992 turned things upside down here. Roy Gutierrez, the county Democratic chairman, says that in the 1980's, "I was out there alone, trying to get volunteers. Suddenly they were coming out of the woodwork -- teachers, students, senior citizens."
In 177 years the Canton newspaper, The Repository, had never endorsed a Democrat for President. The Repository was at the heart of Canton Republicanism. The granddaughter of the Repository's founder married William McKinley, who ran his 1896 campaign for President from his front porch here.
In 1992, citing President Bush's handling of the economy, The Repository endorsed Bill Clinton.
The Democratic chairman heard a rumor the endorsement was coming, but did not believe it. "I had a mole inside. I said I'm waiting to see this in print."
Republicans felt betrayed. Said Mr. Timken, "I thought they were nuts."
 
The Politics
Building a Machine To Support Dole
Stark is not a flashy place, it is a place where many people live because food and housing are cheaper and taxes lower than in Cleveland and Akron to the north or because they have always lived here, and perhaps for that reason the latest media preoccupation does not seem to hit as hard here.
While polls may indicate Steve Forbes is doing well in Iowa and New Hampshire, to look at Stark County is to realize it is very early and it would still be risky business to bet against Mr. Dole in the primaries or the Republicans in November.
In 1992, when Bill Clinton took Ohio (40 percent to 38 over George Bush) and Stark County (40 to 35), Democrats controlled four of six statewide offices as well as the state House of Representatives.
In the 1994 national Republican landslide, Republicans won all six statewide contests in Ohio. Every statewide Republican officeholder from Gov. George Voinovich down has endorsed Mr. Dole. After calls from the Governor's office, the best-known Republicans in Stark -- Mr. Timken; Janet Weir Creighton, the county auditor, Richard Watkins, the Canton Mayor -- signed on as Dole delegates. The most recent statewide poll, which was done by the University of Cincinnati and came out the last week of January, had Mr. Dole ahead of Mr. Forbes 65 percent to 7 percent.
The big Republican money in the state is behind Mr. Dole, including Mr. Timken, who in 1988 was on a list of 249 top donors for giving "at least" $100,000 to the Republican National Committee. Asked if he was concerned about Senator Dole's chances now, Mr. Timken answered, "Not at all. It's fun for people to think about quirks like Steve Forbes or Ross Perot, but that's just voters pulling the chain a little bit. When it comes down to it, Bob Dole will be the guy."
The Republicans here are out on the streets working to change minds. Mr. Regula's staff was on the phone last week arranging with senior citizen centers for visits so the Congressman can get across the Republican view on Medicare.
Charles Brown, the Stark County Republican chairman boarded one of seven buses from Columbus Friday evening that drove all night across the Midwest, reaching Iowa Saturday morning at 6:30. Mr. Brown, 53, a lawyer, was carrying a sleeping bag and pillow. "They told us we'll be sleeping on the floor," he said before leaving.
Saturday afternoon he was at a phonebank in Cedar Rapids with 60 Dole people from Ohio and 20 from Michigan. "We made over 4,000 calls," he said.
Stark County is a large enough place to watch important national dramas play out and small enough to peek backstage and eyeball the players.
The connection between corporate America and the Republican revolution? When Newt Gingrich came to Canton last summer, he flew in on the Timken corporate jet, slept at the Hoover guest house. Democrats and labor? One snowy night in January the United Steelworkers used their organizational muscle at a senior center downtown to capture all five delegate seats from this area to the Democratic national convention.
Stark residents know Timken as a corporation with one of the finest steel research and development operations in the world. They know Timken as a foundation that made Timken High, Timken Mercy Hosptial, the Cultural Center for the Arts all possible. And they know Mr. Timken, who, when asked if he has ever voted for a Democrat answers, "Not knowingly."
A place like Stark helps keep in perspective how little time the typical citizen has to give to national electoral politics at this stage. When The Repository conducted a call-in survey last week on whether Interstate 77 should be widened, 108 people phoned the REPline. When it ran a REPline for reaction to President Clinton's State of the Union Message, 10 called.
Though Ohio leaders joined the mad rush to have an earlier primary, most every state did, too, and the March 19 primary here, while two months earlier than usual, is still 26th on the list. The whole primary process is now so weighted to getting out fast in Iowa and New Hampshire, that even in this very important state with just five weeks to go, there is no evidence of Republican primary electioneering. Senator Dole was last in Ohio in April 1995; Steve Forbes has not made a campaign stop here yet.
 
The Workers
For Steel Industry, Work Force Changes
Republicans leaders here have a mantra: President Clinton may be winning the battle of words for the moment, but we are winning the war of ideas. Indeed there is evidence of growing conservatism in Stark County, even among loyal Democrats like union steelworkers.
The 14 percent unemployment of the early 1980s taught a hard lesson to union workers here: Their biggest enemy was not their boss after all, it was competition from Japan, Europe, South America and nonunion mills in this country. It forced the unions to become more like partners with management. As John Mroczkowski, a local union steelworker leader says, "It was hard at first for our members. They didn't want to give up that antagonism."
But they have to a great degree. Before Timken would agree to invest in a new plant here in the early 1980s, it won an 11-year, no-strike clause from the union. When the LTV Corporation appeared on the verge of liquidating its bar unit here, the union went into partnership with local managers and made an employee buyout, forming Republic and saving the company. Republic has a no-strike contract through 1999.
For years there has been no significant hiring at the steel plants here. The average age of a union steelworker at Republic is nearly 50. "You get older, you get more conservative," said Mark John, a union steelworker. "I'm not going in as a 23-year-old kid with a 62-year-old boss. I'm a 46-year-old guy with a boss my same age. We have a lot more in common."
Even union workers at thriving companies live with fear of losing their jobs. Profits may be soaring but Timken is downsizing, cutting 2,200 people from its work force of 17,000 by the end of 1997. "They call it Accelerated Continuous Improvement, it's supposed to be ways to save costs," said Mr. Mroczkowski, the union leader, "but it seems the main thing they come up with is eliminating jobs."
Growth in Stark County and America is in the suburbs, which tends to favor Republicans. The population of Canton, a Democratic stronghold, has dropped from 110,000 to 84,000 in the last 25 years. There is practically no shopping downtown. At night, city streets are deserted.
Jackson Township, home of the county's biggest mall, has grown from 18,500 to 33,500 in that same period, as subdivisions pop out of cornfields. In Jackson, voters backed Mr. Bush in '92, 44 to 31 percent.
There is new wealth in suburban Stark. A few years ago, Bart Wolstein, a Clevelend developer opened the Estates of Glenmoor, a gated community and country club here with homes starting at $350,000.
People predicted Glenmoor would never sell. Stark is a place where you can still buy a comfortable house for under $100,000. As Mr. Wolstein put it, "The people in Canton sit on a dime a long time."
A consultant told him to charge $12,500 for his country club memberships. "I said, 'Great idea, but you're fired.' I'd just as soon give them away for that." Today, he says, memberships sell for $30,000, there are more than 100 homes built, many for over a $1 million, about 30 percent of them owned by doctors.
There are signs that the poor and working poor here have already been hurt by the early round of Government cuts out of Washington and Columbus and stand to lose more, depending on how Congressional budget negotiations play out.
In the last six months, the Stark County Legal Aid Society has gone from a legal staff of 10 to 6 and expects to shrink to four within two months. That will mean fewer people getting a lawyer for their divorce, custody, abuse and consumer fraud cases. Local charitable organizations provide 229 beds for the homeless, which are full year round. On the coldest nights the Y.M.C.A. downtown, which has 98 rooms, has been setting up extra cots in the lobby.
Larry Martin, who runs the American Rescue Workers mission with 19 beds, says the men have been hurt by Governor Voinovich's welfare overhaul program, which ended General Assistance for single adults without children. The monthly stipend in Ohio was only $100 a month, but Mr. Martin said when combined with $115 in foodstamps that was enough to get a shared room in a boarding house or at a relative's.
Mr. Martin is a Republican and fundamentalist Christian, who admires the Governor but believes Mr. Voinovich was wrong on this issue. He says while some used the $100 on drugs or alcohol, most did not. He says having the money meant they could buy a new shirt for a job interview, gas to keep a car going, hold onto a little dignity. "I wouldn't think it would have saved the state much money," he said.
 
The Religion
Keeping Politics Out of the Pulpit
Church-going is important in Canton. The Canton Baptist Temple, where 2,000 come to pray on Sundays and give generously (a record $173,542.22 for the last Christmas offering) has one of the area's largest congregation. Since 1947, the Rev. Harold Henniger, who founded the Christian Hall of Fame here, has guided the church.
As is true at most fundamentalist churches, the membership selects the minister. One of the things the church's union steelworkers and corporate managers have praised Mr. Henniger for through the years is keeping politics out of the pulpit.
The congregation generally opposes abortion, the one issue a group within the church has been involved with politically. Last fall, when Congress was debating outlawing a particular abortion procedure, several church members made calls to Congressman Regula's office.
There is a small Christian Coalition group in the county, organized after the Republican surge in the 1994 elections. The chairman, Bob Craven, an administrator for a mental retardation agency, says they get 15 to 20 members for monthly meetings. Mr. Craven is most interested in "abortion and morality issues." The only Republican candidate who really excites him is Alan Keyes.
The issue Mr. Henniger hears most about these days is the Republican Medicare cuts. Six days a week at 7 A.M., the minister -- who has not voted for a Democrat for President since Harry Truman -- takes his daily walk with his wife at the Canton Centre Mall. "There's a lot of seniors in there walking," he said, "they're worried about it."
 
The Series
For the series, Michael Winerip will spend this Presidential election year writing about Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County, which has been a bellwether for elections for decades.
