HEADLINE: The Meteoric Rise of Web Site Designers;
Corporations With Cyberfever Demand a Cutting-Edge Presence on Line

SERIES: @WORK: Web site designers

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
Until a year ago, Matt Pacetti, a 25-year-old graphic designer, had never been on the World Wide Web, but now he is the design director of Avalanche Systems, a 30-person agency in Manhattan that has created Web sites for NBC, Elektra records and Super Bowl XXX.
Despite such personal success, unusual for a graphic artist just a few years out of Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, Mr. Pacetti's allegiance to his career is shaky. "The future is very much up in the air," he said. "I think I'll always be in design, but I don't know how committed to Web design I am." 
 Mr. Pacetti's ambivalence is as typical as his nearly overnight rise in the field of Web site development, which has grown by leaps and bounds in the last year as the race to stake a claim to the Internet has riveted the computer industry.
Estimates of the number of sites on the rapidly expanding Web -- the highly popular graphics portion of the Internet -- range from 90,000 to 265,000. Overnight, every business from General Motors to the Schlitterbahn water park in New Braunfels, Tex., seems to have decided it needs a Web site. There might be a total of 16 million individual pages (about one screenful of information each). Someone has to design most of them.
Many are simply the work of hobbyists who have learned to use the Web's basic writing tool, HTML, or hypertext markup language, in a day or two by reading a book. They freelance, selling their services to friends and small businesses.
But increasingly, the demands of corporate clients for on-line versions of magazines or glitzy marketing sites that run hundreds of pages deep require the efforts of a Web team. The group might include graphic designers, writers and HTML authors to assemble pages and "back end" programmers to give sites advanced capabilities, such as updating stock quotes or allowing visitors to download music. Project managers or producers oversee the efforts.
Pioneers in a profession that is regarded variously as a passing fad and a cutting-edge career with a limitless future, Web designers tend to focus on the immediate -- finishing a job, solving a technical problem, creating a dynamic effect by making part of the picture rotate or transform itself into something else. Their resumes tend to be short and varied, their plans vague.
Nathan Shedroff, the creative director of Vivid Studios, a San Francisco company that created the Web site for the debut of Windows 95, said: "We're in the old guard because we've been doing this for more than a year and a half. Right before doing Web design we were doing interface design for on-line services and CD-ROM's. Back further, we did books."
The field has sprung into being so rapidly that no one has managed to count the new jobs created, or the amount of business generated. But Rick Spence, an on-line analyst at Dataquest, a research firm, estimated that at the very least, "tens of millions" of dollars are spent on Web site development annually. Tens of thousands of people are involved. A study by Forester Research found that the cost of creating and running a site for one year ranged from $304,000 for a corporate promotional site, to $1.3 million for an on-line publication, to nearly $3.4 million for a site offering catalogue shopping.
The arrival of big-spending clients has led advertising agencies to set up Web design divisions, and spurred the growth of independent studios.
"The number of new agencies and people with a clue is increasing so fast it's scary," said Kyle Shannon, a founder of Agency.com, a Web design company, and of the World Wide Web Artists Consortium, a 14-month-old professional group with 500 members. It is precisely the speed at which technology and fashions in multimedia change that gives many Web designers a sense of vertigo about their careers.
Everyone remembers when CD-ROM's were the wave of the future -- just two years ago. Venture capital chased small start-up companies. Hollywood discovered Silicon Valley. Then consumers showed a marked indifference to many of the titles, and even multimedia giants like Time Warner Inc. scaled back.
Now the excitement has shifted to the World Wide Web, and every billboard and glossy magazine advertisement trails the obligatory "http" Web address. Some developers worry about a backlash if corporations that have sunk serious money into sites fail to see much in return.
"The big companies will do it as R.& D., to stay current," said Stu Rohrer, a Web producer who began working for commercial on-line services like Compuserve, a unit of H & R Block, in 1982.
"But I predict in the first half of this year a lot of people who did their Web site last year will say, 'That was nice, but let's not do it again.' "
He added, "There's a lot of danger of things drying up for people doing this kind of work."
Peter Seidler, the creative director and co-founder of Avalanche Systems, said that even if the Web's popularity cools, the skills acquired for its design could be upgraded for the next development.
"The ability to conceptualize information and render it interesting in digital form is going to change shape over the next 10 years, but the skills will continue to evolve," he said. "It's a great career move at this point."
Salaries range from no pay, for volunteers trying to learn skills, to $30,000 for a competent HTML author, to $100,000 for a programmer familiar with CGI and Perl, the main computer languages used to connect the Web to data bases.
Josh Bernoff, an analyst at Forester Research, predicted that in each of the next two years, salaries for Web artists and HTML authors would rise 10 percent, and for back-end programmers, 20 percent.
"Talent is so much more in demand than there is supply," he said. "A lot of people think this stuff will fall flat on its face." But he disagrees. "I see vast increases in the amount of useful information on the Web and the amount of people it takes to create and develop that information," he said.
At Avalanche, a 15-month-old studio that is one of the hottest in New York, junior designers and programmers sit at identical black desks with Power Macintoshes, their work surfaces cluttered with empty iced-tea bottles and Sony Discmans. They tend to be in their early 20's, and their life span and that of the personal computer parallel each other.
Mr. Pacetti, the design director, is working on a new look for Pathfinder, the sprawling Time Inc. site. "Right now the site is so visually cluttered people don't know where they're supposed to go," he said. "It's about organizing information, a standard design problem. How to create a flow for someone's eye."
A few seats away, Robin Schuldenfrei, an HTML author, was updating a site for the Summer Olympic Games, hundreds of pages of biographies and press releases that are on line as part of NBC's Web site.
"A lot of what I do is content organization," she said. "The Olympic site is 32 sports. If you want to get the latest you shouldn't have to go six pages into it."
Ms. Schuldenfrei, 23, who graduated from Brown University in June with a degree in art history, worked for a summer during school in the Art Deco and Art Nouveau department at Sotheby's. But she found HTML was her most marketable skill. "I was in the right place at the right time," she said. "The technology was just taking off. If I was at Sotheby's, I'd be faxing and photocopying all day."
It is HTML authors like Ms. Schuldenfrei, however, whose long-term prospects may be most limited. Some new programs bypass HTML and allow anyone to create Web pages. Last month the Microsoft Corporation bought Vermeer Technologies, the maker of the leading automated program, Front Page.
But this month at least, the Web is still a place where Bryant Wilms, 22, of Avalanche can use the computer-design skills he acquired in college to insert a morphed -- combined -- image of Kate Moss and Johnny Depp into a Web site for "Late Night With Conan O'Brien."
Mr. Wilms lives in Brooklyn but would prefer Manhattan if it weren't so expensive. On the other hand, "I practically live here now," he said. "We have some cots in the back."
The computer industry is expected to be a chief engine of job creation in America and abroad over the next decade. Unlike other growth fields -- health care and residential care -- computers are spawning a class of jobs, some new and some transformed. Some, like Web site design, might continue to expand or be part of a bubble that eventually bursts. This is the second article profiling the new workers and their world.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
New York Planning Tourism Campaign

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
The New York City Economic Development Corporation has begun a search for agencies to handle advertising and public relations for its initial national and international campaign to promote tourism as well as recruit businesses to the city. Billings were estimated at $10 million. 
 Agencies that specialize in advertising or public relations (or both) will be asked to complete questionnaires, Charles Millard, president of the development unit, said Friday, adding that a maximum of 10 agencies would then be asked to make capability presentations based on responses to the questionnaires. A decision is expected by the middle of spring, he said, and the campaign is scheduled to begin in the fall.

HEADLINE: U.S. Shows China a Worrying Lack of Fortitude

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I look without surprise at the transfer of nuclear weapons technology to Pakistan by the Chinese Government (front page, Feb. 8) and the possibility that the Clinton Administration will waive sanctions. 
 The violation of international and bilateral agreements is to be expected of Beijing. What should not be expected is the willingness of the Clinton Administration, with political cover from pro-China Republicans and Democrats in Congress, to turn a blind eye to the violations.
Beijing has showed time and again that it will risk being discovered breaking various agreements for a chance at more profit. In my work as a human rights advocate, I have uncovered repeated violations of the 1992 memorandum of understanding on prison labor, as products made in the Laogai, or labor camp system, continue to be exported to the United States.
American officials will privately admit they know the Chinese Government is not adhering to the memorandum, but Chinese "compliance" with the agreement gets public lip service from the Administration.
I will repeat what I said when I was released from detention by the Chinese Government last summer: The Communists are liars. They will not follow foreign agreements if they interfere with internal considerations.
The Administration and the "trade-at-all-costs" members of Congress say that increased commercial ties will give us increased leverage with China. It is the Chinese who are exerting leverage over United States policy, as seen by the heavy lobbying against sanctions by companies like Boeing and Westinghouse, which fear having lucrative contracts canceled in retaliation. In the face of a consumer market of 1.2 billion people, many in the business community see only dollar signs as the ultimate gain of China policy.
I hope this Administration and Congress will show some resolve. Only that can re-establish a strong negotiating position with the Chinese. The next time the United States finds itself across the table from the Communist leadership, more than just dollars may be at stake.
 
HARRY WU
Executive Director
Laogai Research Foundation
Milpitas, Calif., Feb. 9, 1996

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Prices Continue to Retreat On Indications of Ample Supply

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Gold prices dropped yesterday for the fifth time in six days as falling borrowing rates pointed to adequate supply.
On other commodities markets, crude oil prices rose and cotton fell. The Commodity Research Bureau index fell 0.52 point, to 247.50. 
 The one-month rate to borrow gold has fallen every day this month, reaching 1.222 percent yesterday, compared with 3.625 percent four weeks ago. The current rate is the lowest since July.
The drop shows that owners of gold, like central banks, are more willing to lend gold. The lower rates also make it cheaper for mining companies to sell borrowed gold at current prices and replace it with future output from their mines.
"Gold prices are falling because there's ample supply," said Dinsa Mehta, chief bullion trader with Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. "Investors who have gold holdings are lending it out to the market, and that's showing in the lower lease rates."
Gold for April delivery fell $4.50 an ounce, to $404.50 an ounce, on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange -- a 3.5 percent drop from Feb. 2, when the price of $417.70 was the highest for gold in almost six years.
Crude oil prices jumped in the last minutes of trading amid speculation that Iraq and the United Nations might not reach an agreement on an offer that would allow Iraq to export some oil to buy food and medicine.
James Rubin, a spokesman for Madeleine Albright, the United States representative to the United Nations, said there were no "significant developments" in the talks, which were in their fourth day yesterday.
His comments raised speculation among oil traders that Iraq might not agree to the United Nations offer for some time, if at all. The proposal would let Iraq sell $2 billion of crude every six months.
"No one's saying anything," said Tony Lerner, energy trader at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. "That means there's no breakthroughs yet, and that's bullish."
The March crude oil contract rose 19 cents, to $17.97 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Cotton prices fell after the National Cotton Council predicted that this summer's United States cotton crop would rise from last year's, rivaling the record large crop of 1994.
March cotton fell 1.05 cents, to 84.33 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Post Gains; Trading Light

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in light activity yesterday, as concern seemed to ease about accommodating the huge supply of new debt securities from last week's Government quarterly refunding and as the lack of fresh economic data left traders without strong direction.
The market continues to nibble away at the record $44.5 billion in bills, bonds and notes auctioned by the Treasury last week. But supply is no longer the burden it was then, when bond prices dropped as the market contended with distributing the securities.
The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond increased 29/32, to a price of 99 20/32 yesterday; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, was at 6.03 percent, down from 6.09 percent on Friday.
In recent weeks, the rising price of gold has weighed on the market, but gold prices fell back sharply yesterday -- more than $4 an ounce -- as ample supplies were seen.
Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said that rather than being a consequence of any real concerns about inflation, the recent run-up in gold prices was a result of jittery investors looking for alternative investments after the strong gains by both debt and equity securities. Regardless of the causes, the bond market had been distracted by gold's rise.
Jack McIntyre, a market strategist at MCM TradeWatch in Boston, a market research and analysis firm, said that while the bulk of supply of new Treasury issues was out of the way, some dealers were still struggling to sell inventory amassed at last week's refunding. Given the record low interest rates for the securities being auctioned, demand was more than adequate, he said, as foreign investors showed an interest.
Now the market can refocus on economic data and keep an eye on the budget discussions in Washington, which, to Mr. McIntyre, seem to be carrying a more conciliatory tone.
"We are leaning bullish on bonds and taking our cue from the intermediate to shorter maturities," he said. He thinks the market will continue to see a widening of the yield spread between the short and long ends of the market, with the trend lasting through the year.
Technically, he said, the bond market is sound, and he expects prices to move higher in the near term, with the yield on the 30-year bond dropping back to less than 6 percent. If gold should slide below $400 an ounce, Mr. McIntyre said, the bond market could get a substantial psychological lift.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said that while market participation was limited yesterday, it was firm and had its fundamentals intact. The shorter maturities are doing well, he said, on the belief that the Federal Reserve will continue to lower short-term interest rates.
"We see the yield on the long bond at 5.75 percent by March," Mr. Alexy said. "If we're wrong, it will not be because interest rates did not move lower but because of a steepening of the yield curve."
He said that investors still had a great deal of cash to invest and that the dollar was firm. Also, the outlook for economic growth remains weak,Mr. Alexy said.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of bills yesterday, rates declined for the third consecutive week. The auction drew decent demand, with the average rate for a three-month maturity at 4.80 percent, down from 4.88 percent last week, and a six-month rate at 4.71 percent, down from 4.79 percent.
Traders said that while the number of bids was impressive, it might have been helped by the reduced size of this week's auction, which was $27.4 billion, compared with $32.4 billion the week before.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexico Renews Its Intention To Sell Parts of Oil Monopoly

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Despite growing popular opposition across Mexico to the move, Government officials reiterated their commitment today to selling key pieces of the huge state-owned oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, while hinting broadly that they might limit foreign investment to insure that domestic companies get a chance to participate in the privatized businesses.
At a ceremony this morning at a sprawling oil refinery at Tula, in central Mexico, President Ernesto Zedillo also sharply criticized opposition-party politicians and their followers, who have blocked dozens of oil wells in the gulf state of Tabasco, causing a standoff that the Government says has cost Pemex more than $8.5 million in revenue in the last two weeks. 
 "Nobody has the right to use the nation's energy resources, their exploitation or their utilization for personal reasons, nor as instruments of pressure or for political battles," Mr. Zedillo said at a ceremony to make public a five-year energy-development plan. "The energy resources belong to the nation and ought to be utilized in accordance with the law for the progress of Mexico and the well-being of all Mexicans."
The development blueprint contained no real surprises. But it could send a mixed message to foreign investors, many from the United States, who have expressed interest in bidding on the two parts of Pemex that are being privatized: its secondary petrochemicals and the natural-gas distribution operations.
Changes in Mexican law last year made it possible for those operations to be sold. The rest of Pemex remains "strategically important," and thus reserved for the state.
Investors interested in the 60 petrochemical plants to be privatized over the next few years are likely to be heartened by the strong support Mr. Zedillo gave today to moving ahead with the proposed sales. That support came in spite of huge-scale demonstrations by the oil workers' union and others who do not think that any part of Pemex -- which has taken on mythic proportions here since the oil industry was nationalized in 1938 -- should be sold.
The new energy minister, Jesus Reyes Heroles, said today that private investment was essential to rebuilding the energy industries and said that three bids had already been received for the petrochemical complex at Cosoleacaque, the first facilities on the list to be privatized, though he did not say who the bidders were.
But the newspaper El Financiero reported the Government's concern that foreign investment would have to be limited if it threatened to concentrate ownership in the hands of a few non-Mexican companies.
A former Pemex official, who spoke on condition that his name not be used, said the company had discretion to determine which petrochemical plants could be sold only to Mexicans. "The Government would like to give as much advantage as it can to Mexicans," the ex-official said, "but they can't let Mexicans buy the plants for peanuts, so they need some competition,"
A spokesman for the energy ministry would not confirm or deny the newspaper report, but in his speech today, Mr. Reyes Heroles said Pemex should be used as an engine for Mexican economic development. He cited the area of goods and services in the oil industry, which he said should be used "to boost national providers that are willing to participate competitively."
Mr. Reyes Heroles also said that between now and 2000, Mexico's energy industries would need nearly $34 billion in capital, of which $6 billion will have to come from private business and investors.
President Zedillo said that a substantial part of the money from the privatizations would be used to fortify Pemex. Last year, though, Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz told officials of the United States Treasury and the International Monetary Fund that the proceeds of the Pemex privatization, as well as the sale of railroads, airports and deep-sea ports, would be used to balance Mexico's budget and reduce its debt.
The blockades of the oil wells in Tabasco state by supporters of the opposition Democratic Revolutionary Party continued today. On Sunday, however, the party agreed to allow Pemex crews to enter the grounds of some blocked wells to do maintenance work. The leftist party continues to negotiate with the Government to reach a peaceful solution to the growing conflict.

HEADLINE: In Settlement, Toy Maker to Give Refunds

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The $20 billion United States toy industry showed its happiest face to the world yesterday, announcing record retail sales figures for 1995 at the start of its biggest annual trade show. But the Federal Trade Commission dampened the festivities with the news that it had won its first consumer-refund settlement for deceptive advertising in the toy industry.
The settlement was with the Remco Toys division of Azrak-Hamway International Inc. The F.T.C. had charged that Remco's television advertising campaign for its Steel Tec toy vehicle kits was misleading. The company misrepresented the number of types of toys that could be constructed from the kits and the kinds of things the toys could do, the F.T.C. said. 
 Because of the settlement with Remco, thousands of consumers who bought the toys are eligible for full refunds, the F.T.C. said.
"This is the first F.T.C. toy case where consumers have qualified for a full refund owing to deceptive advertising," said Jodie Z. Bernstein, director of the Bureau of Consumer Protection at the F.T.C.
As for the industry, which gave a noisy and colorful sendoff to its 93d annual American International Toy Fair in Manhattan, the sales record was a surprise, considering the difficult climate for retail stores. The sales grew nearly 7 percent, to $20 billion, in 1995 from $18.7 billion in 1994, according to the Toy Manufacturers of America Inc., a trade group of 235 manufacturers and importers that sponsors the trade show.
In terms of wholesale shipments, however, the increase was only 3 percent, and "that, allowing for inflation, made it a flat year," said George B. Volanakis, the chief executive of the Ertl Company and the president of the trade group. "We're likely to have the same sort of year in 1996."
The association announced that the strongest-growing segment of the industry was the girls' doll category, which was up 12 percent, to $1.89 billion, at the wholesale level, which amounts to about $2.4 billion at retail. This reflected the popularity of Mattel Inc.'s Barbie doll, which had its biggest retail sales year, at about $1.4 billion.
The big losers among the industry's traditional categories were male action toys, which declined 14 percent, to $795 million, in wholesale sales. Mr. Volanakis said this reflected the decline in popularity of the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers, which were the sensation of 1993 and 1994.
Another category -- nontraditional but nevertheless huge -- turned in an even poorer year: The video-game segment declined 19 percent, to $2.53 billion, at the wholesale level in 1995. Consumers began waiting "until the next generation of technology became available," Mr. Volanakis said.
The statistics were announced in the Toy Center at 200 Fifth Avenue, marking the opening of the fair, which, for seven days, is bringing together toy makers, retailers, salespeople and Wall Street analysts. The organizers of the fair expect 20,000 buyers from 99 countries, and they signed up 1,619 exhibitors, 30 more than last year. The fair expands to the Jacob K. Javits Center on Friday, where it will run through the weekend.
As in the past, the attendees were met at the portals of the Toy Center with formidable hoopla and hype: The greeters-in-suits included Mr. and Mrs. Potato Head, glad-handing giant Smurfs, a grunting green Incredible Hulk and an affable Pink Panther. A teddy-bear maker even brought in a live bear cub to pose for pictures in the frigid weather.
Those attending the fair were also assailed by a self-styled "Toycott": Leaflets were distributed, demanding a boycott of toys made in China. The demonstrators, who represented the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the U.S.-Tibet Committee and other groups, said they were protesting human-rights abuses in China, and they contended that some toys and toy parts were made in that country by political prisoners.
As for Remco, it agreed to settle the F.T.C.'s charges of deceptive advertising, as did Starwood Advertising Inc. of Aspen, Colo., Remco's agency. Consumers may phone Remco at 1-800-243-2961 to receive an application for a refund.
The Remco toys, which cost $9 to $40, were manipulated off-screen in the advertisements by hidden wires or tubes, and "in actual use, the vehicles could not perform as they had in the ads," the F.T.C. complaint said.
Aaron Locker, a spokesman for the advertising agency and for Azrak-Hamway, a privately held company based in Manhattan, said Azrak-Hamway "still thinks that it did not violate the law, but the company did not have the resources to engage in lengthy litigation with the F.T.C." He declined to disclose the company's annual revenues, the number of Steel Tec toys sold or the company's estimate of the eventual cost of the refunds.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mrs. and Mr. Potato Head walk along 23d Street in Manhattan yesterday, headed for the American International Toy Fair. More than 1,600 exhibitors are attending the show, the industry's biggest. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Police Apology Is Offered In Queens Man's Shooting

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC 

 BODY:
The first thing Lebert Folkes says he wants to know is why Police Officer Christopher Strom, a nine-year veteran, shot him after ordering him out of his car in front of his Queens home on Sunday night. Then, he says, he wants to know where to find a good lawyer.
Police officials apologized yesterday for stopping Mr. Folkes's car and apprehending him in the first place, saying a computer error had mistakenly identified the car as stolen. They also acknowledged that Mr. Folkes was shot accidentally after what they said was a struggle to remove him from his car. 
 "Obviously, an error was made by the New York City Police Department," said Deputy Chief Lawrence F. Loesch, the commander of Queens detectives, referring to the department's failure to remove the car's registration number from the log of vehicles reported stolen after it was recovered. "Clearly, we made a mistake."
The chief said the behavior of police officers during the shooting incident would be investigated.
Speaking from his bed at Jamaica Hospital, where he was in stable condition after being shot in the face, Mr. Folkes said he was driving his sister's black 1989 Nissan home from a friend's house at about 8:20 P.M. when a light-colored Buick pulled up behind him on Beach Channel Drive in Far Rockaway.
"I knew that white car," the 29-year-old unemployed Jamaican immigrant said. "I knew it was the police."
Witnesses said the two undercover police officers blocked the front of the Nissan with their Buick before exiting their car, drawing their guns and ordering Mr. Folkes to get out.
Mr. Folkes and at least two witnesses, one standing about 15 feet away, said the policemen did not identify themselves in any way as police officers.
"They didn't flash their badges," Mr. Folkes said. "They didn't say they were the police."
Mr. Folkes said he tried to cooperate and get out of the car, but when he reached to unbuckle his seat belt, Officer Strom pulled him by his jacket out of the car and onto the ground.
"As soon as he pulled me out of the car and I was on my belly with my face down, he shot me straight," Mr. Folkes said.
The police gave a different version of the incident, saying the bullet that wounded Mr. Folkes on the right side of his face was probably fired accidentally from Officer Strom's 9-millimeter semiautomatic service weapon.
"As it stands now, it is an accidental discharge," Chief Loesch said at a news conference yesterday at the 101st Precinct headquarters.
He said Mr. Folkes had refused to get out of his car and physically struggled with the police officers.
"They take him out of the vehicle physically, and a struggle ensues," the Chief said, adding that the lone gunshot rang out as the officer was trying to handcuff Mr. Folkes.
Chief Loesch said that the police officers were wearing their badges on chains around their neck but that he did not know whether they had flashed them or vocally identified themselves when they ordered Mr. Folkes to exit the Nissan.
Before blocking Mr. Folkes's car, Officer Strom and the second undercover officer who was riding with him had noticed that the Nissan had a lock that had been tampered with and called for a routine computer check on the car's registration, the chief said. The officers were informed over the radio that the car, which belongs to Mr. Folkes's sister, Iona Folkes, had been stolen, the chief said.
In fact, the car had been stolen on Jan. 15, he said, adding that Ms. Folkes had informed the police at least three times that it had been recovered the next day. But the police never removed the car from a computer list of stolen automobiles, the chief said.
About two weeks ago, Mr. Folkes had been pulled over by the Nassau County police, who were also mistakenly informed that the Nissan was a stolen automobile, Ms. Folkes said.
"The 101st Precinct apologized," she said.
"Why would he want to shoot me?" Mr. Folkes said. "Why would I resist arrest while they had two guns at my head?
"If he would have just said give me your license and registration, he would have seen everything was perfect.
"I'm going to find myself a good lawyer," he said.

HEADLINE: A Wal-Mart Experiment On Internet

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
In a move certain to accelerate the acceptance of computer-based shopping, Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retailer, said yesterday that it would begin trials next month of a system for selling its merchandise over the Internet. The Microsoft Corporation will supply the software for the experiment.
"We believe it's a concept whose time has arrived," said David Glass, the president and chief executive of Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark.. Electronic retailing, he said, will "create a tremendous opportunity to serve customers that we don't presently serve or who are limited in time." 
 And if the trials are successful, he said, the company intends to move aggressively to expand the system.
Microsoft has been working with Wal-Mart to develop the software needed to conduct retailing operations on the Internet's World Wide Web. Both companies said yesterday that the alliance was not an exclusive partnership and that Microsoft would not have a financial interest in Wal-Mart's electronic retailing.
Microsoft is developing a product called Merchant Server that requires Microsoft's Windows NT operating system. Merchants would use the server software to create data bases of goods, publish electronic catalogues, handle secure transactions and keep customer records.
A number of other companies, notably the Netscape Communications Corporation and Open Market Inc., make competing software.
Mary A. Modahl, director of new media research at Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., said Wal-Mart's entry into electronic retailing would invigorate a market that has been moribund lately because of slow sales and concerns about privacy and the security of financial transactions.
"I think electronic retailing is heating up right now," she said. "Mastercard and Visa recently came together with a standard for doing secure credit-card transactions, and that has created a sense of optimism. Plus, there is strong growth in the on-line market as consumers continue to sign up."
Neither Mr. Glass nor William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, would estimate the size of the electronic retailing market, either in terms of customers or dollar volume.
"It's easy to over-promise and under-deliver, but we have an opportunity to build a completely different industry," Mr. Glass said.

HEADLINE: Sudan Pays High Price for Ties to Islamic Militants

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Americans no longer occupy the American Embassy here. Every last diplomat left by airplane last week in a protest at what Washington says is the sanctuary that Sudan provides to some of the world's most violent terrorist groups.
The United Nations has set a late-March deadline, with the potential threat of economic sanctions, for the Sudan to surrender suspects wanted in connection with an attempt to assassinate Egypt's President last June. The economy is already in a shambles, Sudan's relations with its neighbors are in crisis, and the country remains hobbled by a long and costly civil war. 
 Here in Khartoum, the dust-choked capital of Africa's largest country, the question now is whether these hardships will be enough to persuade the Islamic military Government that took power seven years ago to reconsider its ways.
"There's a growing sense that something's got to give sooner rather than later," one Western diplomat said, repeating sentiments expressed more guardedly by ordinary Sudanese in a country in which the Government is highly unpopular. "And what Washington and the United Nations have done has added to the sense that things may be coming to a head."
With a per capita income of just $200 and a capital where goats forage for scarce grass even along some central streets, the Sudan would seem an unlikely target for such international attention.
But since it seized power seven years ago, the Government of Lieut. Gen. Omar Ahmed al-Bashir and Dr. Hassan al-Turabi, who heads the powerful National Islamic Front, has become a source of mounting concern to the West as it has transformed this multi-religious country into a strict Islamic state and established close ties with Muslim militants around the world.
And now that the United Nations Security Council has effectively endorsed an accusation that the Sudan has sheltered some of the militants who attempted to assassinate President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in the Ethiopian capital last June 26, the Khartoum Government is under pressure as never before.
The Sudan has regularly denied harboring terrorists, and it has said it has no evidence that the three suspects wanted in the assassination attempt in Addis Ababa are anywhere within its borders.
In a nationally televised address, the Foreign Minister of the Sudan, Ali Osman Mohamed Taha, denounced the recent pressure by the United States and the United Nations as "part of a psychological campaign against Sudan to isolate it in Islamic, regional and international forums."
Sudanese officials reiterated that complaint in interviews here, with some suggesting that it is the country's close ties with Iran that have made it a prime Western target. "Essentially, the direction of this Government is not one that pleases the United States and its friends in this region," said Dr. Abubaker al-Shirgieti, director of the country's External Information Council.
With the Sudanese Army showing no sign of disloyalty, there are few here who suggest that the Government is likely to be challenged soon, despite the mounting pressures in the West.
But with economic problems growing, some diplomats say that the army might be pushed toward a closer partnership with Sadiq al-Mahdi, the Prime Minister whom General Bashir ousted in 1989 in a bloodless coup.
Some diplomats also assert that the Government might even loosen its ties with Islamic militants in an effort to stave off United Nations sanctions and to regain American economic aid, which was blocked in 1993 when the State Department added the Sudan to its list of states that sponsor terrorism.
The current Government has twice before taken limited steps against terrorist groups in response to Western pressure.
In 1994, it expelled to France the notorious terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal. And last fall, faced with charges of involvement in the attempt against the Egyptian President, the Government said it would end a policy that had allowed all Arab passport holders to enter the country without visas, and it dismissed its external intelligence chief, Nafi al-Nafi.
Some Western diplomats here cast doubt on whether those moves were truly significant, describing Mr. Nafi as mostly a scapegoat. But in a country that finds itself increasingly isolated, the diplomats say they have little doubt that the messages from the United Nations and the United States are being weighed.
"There is no question that the United States has a hearing in Sudan," the American Ambassador, Timothy Carney, said in a telephone interview from Washington, where he and many of his staff members arrived late last week after leaving the Sudan. "People listen to us."
The ambassador, who left the Sudan after the State Department warned Americans here of potential terrorist threats against them, is now expected to make regular return visits to the Sudan as a nonresident emissary based in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi.
The State Department also advised the other 2,100 American citizens who live in the Sudan to consider leaving, but none have accepted a United States offer of free passage, an apparent sign that most regard the warning as overwrought.
For its part, the Sudanese Government has in recent days put on a highly cooperative public face, going as far as to publish newspaper notices appealing to citizens to assist in handing over the suspects wanted in the attempt to kill Mr. Mubarak.
The new cooperation comes as the Sudan is plainly vulnerable, its economy crippled by near-triple-digit inflation and a staggering foreign debt of some $16 billion.
Moreover, its relations with the International Monetary Fund are so strained that it faces the very real prospect of becoming the first country ever to be expelled from the agency, a step that would cut it off from remaining lines of badly needed credit.
At the same time, the Sudan now counts among its enemies at least four of its nine neighbors. Egypt and Ethiopia, furious in their view that Sudan was behind the attempt on Mr. Mubarak, only barely maintain official ties.
Uganda and Eritrea have severed relations and accused the Sudan of trying to undermine their Governments. Late last year, Eritrea even announced that it had turned over the Sudanese Embassy in its capital to the National Democratic Alliance, an umbrella organization of Sudanese opposition groups that have vowed to overthrow the Sudanese Government.
Those tensions have only worsened as the black African rebels in southern Sudan have intensified their 12-year civil war against the Government. The Sudan has accused Ethiopia, Eritrea and Uganda of providing arms and other support to the mostly Christian and animist guerrillas, who are battling to shake off the longstanding dominance of the Arab Muslim north.
A central question, then, that the Government will likely weigh in the weeks ahead is whether to bow to Western pressure and risk losing the backing of the militant Muslim groups and others who still support it, including the Government of Iran.
To Mounir Sayeed, who as the representative here of the militant Palestinian group Hamas maintains an office under the name Al Aksa Information Center, the answer is evident. "We don't have anything to be afraid of," he said.

HEADLINE: Supply-and-Demand Balance Weakens for Semiconductors

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12

 BODY:
The semiconductor industry's leading indicator fell sharply in January, a trade organization reported today, providing a disturbing sign that the demand for computer chips is growing more slowly than the supply.
That news is likely to put pressure on technology stocks and could lead to a big selloff on Tuesday. 
 The Semiconductor Industry Association reported that the book-to-bill ratio for the three months that ended in January fell to 0.93, the first time the ratio has dropped below 1.00, or break-even, in five years.
The association issued its report after regular stock trading closed. But in after-hours trading, Intel, the largest chip maker, fell more than $2.50 from its close of $58.2344, while Applied Materials, which makes machinery to manufacture chips, fell $3 from its close of $40.
Semiconductor industry analysts had been predicting a drop from December's level of 1.12 in the book-to-bill ratio, but they had expected the ratio to remain positive, in the range of 1.05 to 1.07.
Indeed, some analysts had said that the industry had left behind the cyclical swings it suffered from in the past. In the mid-1980's, when American chip makers were losing ground to Japanese competitors, book-to-bill ratios below break-even were common.
Instead, the latest numbers indicate that the chip industry may still be just as cyclical as the computer industry, which it supplies.
"The book-to-bill is just catching up with the reality in the end markets," said Rick Whittington, an analyst with the Soundview Financial Group who has predicted a decline in the chip business for some time.
"Pricing has fallen out of bed" for memory chips, the largest portion of the market, he said. "There is too much supply."
The book-to-bill ratio compares the rate of orders to shipments. Thus, a ratio of 0.93 indicates that for every $100 worth of computer chips shipped, only $93 worth was ordered. The last time the indicator fell below 1 was in January 1991, when it hit 0.99.
"I think it's an inventory problem," Thomas W. Armstrong, the president of the Semiconductor Industry Association, said in a telephone interview. "We had a similar problem in 1991, and it was a one-month blip. As best as I can tell at this time, we are looking at the same kind of thing now."
Mr. Armstrong said the association still expected that the chip industry's sales would grow by 29 percent this year. "This looks like an aberration to us," he said. "Even though we are surprised by the 0.93 ratio, we remain confident about the long-term outlook for the global semiconductor industry. Semiconductors are more pervasive than ever, and the microelectronics content of the average electronics product continues to grow."
Semiconductor orders dropped 16.8 percent, to $4.16 billion, in January, from $5.01 billion in December, which was a record. But orders in January were 16.3 percent higher than the $3.58 billion recorded for January 1995.
Semiconductor shipments rose slightly in January, to a record of $4.47 billion, four-tenths of 1 percent higher than the $4.46 billion recorded in December. Shipments in January were 39.5 percent higher than the $3.20 billion in January 1995.

HEADLINE: Study Examines Race and Justice in California

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
Almost 40 percent of black men in their 20's in California are imprisoned or on probation or parole on any given day, a study released yesterday says.
The new study is the latest and the most dramatic in a series of reports in the last few years showing that young black men are being incarcerated at a rate far out of proportion to their number in the overall population. A study last fall, for example, found that nationally one-third of the black men in their 20's were under the control of the criminal justice system. That was an increase from five years ago, when one-fourth of the black men nationwide ages 20 to 29 were incarcerated or on probation or parole. 
 By contrast, yesterday's report said that only 5 percent of the white men in California in their 20's and 11 percent of the Hispanic men of that age group were in the criminal system last year.
Vincent Schiraldi, the author of the study, attributed the high numbers for black men to tougher punishment for the use of crack cocaine than for other drugs; harsh new sentencing laws; the prison construction boom, and poverty, lack of good jobs and poor education in inner cities.
"Conscious or not, it is difficult to imagine the war on crime being waged with this vehemence if middle-class white males were similarly affected," said Mr. Schiraldi, who is executive director of the Center on Juvenile and Criminal Justice in San Francisco, a research and advocacy group.
Mr. Schiraldi predicted that with California's new "three strikes" sentencing law, the number of young black men in prison will only become more disproportionate. He said that one recent survey of 1,000 cases in Los Angeles found that blacks were charged at 17 times the rate of whites under the new law, which provides for automatic life sentences for criminals convicted of three felonies and double the usual sentences for those convicted of a second serious offense.
Willie L. Brown Jr., the recently elected Mayor of San Francisco, said at a news conference yesterday where the report was released, "It doesn't take a genius to realize something is wrong when you look at the numbers."
Blacks make up only 7 percent of the population of California, Mr. Brown said, but they account for 18 percent of those arrested in the state and 32 percent of its prison population. Mr. Brown, who is black, was Speaker of the California State Assembly for 14 years.
Speaking of the new study, Mr. Brown said, "Hopefully this will raise the consciousness of our politicians and the public at large to realize that simply incarcerating everyone will not solve the problems we have."
Criminologists, however, are divided on what the report means.
James Q. Wilson, professor of management at the University of California at Los Angeles, said that although the figures were very troubling, "if you set aside the arrests for crack cocaine, they are not the result of bias in the criminal justice system."
Most crimes nationwide are committed by young people and by males, Professor Wilson said, and no one argues that the system is biased when it imprisons a disproportionate number of young men.
Instead, the fact that almost 40 percent of young black men are under the control of the criminal justice system "reflects an unhappy fact," Professor Wilson said. "The system is more or less putting people in prison at the rate at which they commit crimes."
He said there was no easy solution except to "try to profoundly change the circumstances of people in their early years of life."
But Alfred Blumstein, a criminologist at Carnegie Mellon University, said that increasingly the disproportionate figures result from the war on drugs, in which the police have focused on the inner city rather than the suburbs because the drug trade there is more out in the open and involves blacks.
"The issue we really have to face is the degree to which we are damning a whole generation of people who are pursuing the only economic opportunity they see, however wrong it is," Professor Blumstein said.
In New York State, about 1 of every 3 black men in their 20's is in prison or on probation or parole, said Robert Gangi, the executive director of the Correctional Association of New York. The rate is higher in California than in New York in part simply because California has just completed a major prison construction program, Mr. Gangi said.

HEADLINE: With Detentions Up, Border Is Still Porous

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Feb. 9

 BODY:
It is a few minutes before midnight, and Fernando Quiroga is crouched in the carrizo cane along the banks of the Rio Grande. The air smells sweet, and the light of a half-moon casts a faint glow on the river.
Mr. Quiroga, a senior agent with the United States Border Patrol, circles like a cat down to the river, suddenly positioning himself between Mexico and a group of 15 Mexican men who have just waded across. 
 "Detenganse!" he shouts, the rough Spanish equivalent of "Freeze!" The Mexicans, most dressed in caps with sports logos like the Toronto Blue Jays, the New England Patriots and Duke University, quickly surrender. They quietly throw their belongings, most wrapped inside plastic grocery bags, into a pile in front of Mr. Quiroga and three other agents.
Detention of illegal immigrants like this have risen in the past year in all the nine Border Patrol sectors along the United States-Mexico border. And the Immigration and Naturalization Service, one of the few Federal agencies to have a large budget increase approved by the Republican-controlled Congress, is hiring 1,000 new agents to patrol the border, a 20 percent increase in the size of the force.
The increase also allows the agency to expand its technical resources, like motion sensors, night-vision devices and a computerized fingerprint file for every detainee.
But a day and a night with Border Patrol agents here in Brownsville, even while offering a glimpse of the new technology at work, offers an even starker illustration of just how porous the border remains. Even Mr. Quiroga estimated that while he and fellow agents were detaining their group of men, another three or four groups of similar size were probably making it across the river uncaught.
The chief of the Border Patrol section in Brownsville, David Aguilar, said increased detentions were deterring only some people from trying to enter the country. With 138 agents, or roughly 46 in each eight-hour shift, to patrol 68 miles of winding riverfront and thousands of square miles between the border and inland checkpoints, the odds favor the immigrant.
"If someone is determined to come across, they're going to make it," Mr. Aguilar said. "What's driving these people is human needs."
A shift with Agent Quiroga was marked by hours of quiet waiting, hours of paperwork to process the detainees, and a few moments of excitement and tension when he confronted a man wading across the mouth of the Rio Grande with $135,000 worth of cocaine and marijuana. The man escaped back to Mexico, but the drugs, which he threw into some bushes, were confiscated.
The night even had flashes of humor. As a spectacular sunset came to Boca Chica beach, near where the Rio Grande empties into the Gulf of Mexico, Agent Quiroga confronted a woman parked in a Lincoln Continental along the shore. He suspected her of waiting to pick up an illegal immigrant. Asked what she was doing, the woman languidly scooped a Chlorox bottle into the salty Gulf water. "Oh, I'm just collecting some water to put on my lawn," she said, before driving off.
"Gulf water for the lawn," Agent Quiroga said, breaking into laughter. "Now, that's a new one."
Most people coming across do not bear drugs and say they are simply looking for work. Interviews with detainees here, virtually all of whom were bused back to the Mexico border town of Nuevo Progreso and some of whom said they would simply try to cross again the next day, also demonstrate how the relatively immense economic opportunities in the United States continue to act as a magnet for those trying to cross illegally.
"I won't lie to you," 34-year-old Jose Aguirre Garcia, from the city of Linares in Nuevo Leon province, told Mr. Quiroga as he was being processed at the Border Patrol center in Brownsville. "I will try to come again tomorrow."
Trying to support a wife and three daughters back home, he said he had earned $2,000 in a few months picking citrus fruit in Florida last year, with no substantial work available in Mexico.
"You're doing your job," he told Agent Quiroga with a friendly laugh. "And I'm doing mine."
And while he had heard that the United States was more hostile to illegal immigrants these days, Mr. Aguirre remained a bit skeptical. "They certainly seemed to welcome my work in Florida," he said.
Baltazar Trinidad Guadalupe, a 21-year-old man from a small town a hundred miles north of Mexico City, said he wanted to get to Houston where his relative say there are plenty of jobs available laying sheet rock. He said: "Yes, I will try it again. I have set a goal. Houston is my goal."
Mr. Trinidad said he believed he could make at least $12,000 in a year's work in Houston, compared with the $1,500 he made this past year doing odd jobs in Mexico.
Dressed in black jeans that were wet to the thighs from his crossing, a faded green shirt and cowboy boots, Mr. Trinidad offered a history that illustrates what immigration officials call the "squeezing the balloon" phenomenon: a successful crackdown in one part of the border often leads to increased efforts at crossing elsewhere.
Mr. Trinidad said he had tried a few times without success to cross at Ciudad Juarez, across the river from El Paso, late last year and had been caught each time. El Paso has had a much-publicized increase in agents and technology in the last year and a half to deter immigration. "I heard it might be easier to get across at Matamoros," Mr. Trinidad said, speaking of the Mexican border city across from Brownsville. "So I came here."
While detentions are up an average of 66 percent all along the border, to 169,463 this past January, from 102,156 in January 1995, they have skyrocketed in a few traditionally less-traveled places in particular: 116 percent in the Tucson, Ariz., sector, 144 percent in Yuma, and 278 percent in El Centro, Calif. Detentions are up 39 percent here in the Brownsville area, and attempted crossings appear to be up as well, Mr. Aguilar said.
Immigration officials say that in time, they hope to "squeeze the balloon" everywhere and make crossing as difficult all along the border as it is in places like El Paso.
And for every person like Mr. Trinidad who is able to travel elsewhere along the border, they say, there may be many other would-be illegal immigrants who give up because the trip to an easier crossing point is too expensive or daunting.
At 4 A.M., Mr. Aguirre and the other men were bused back to Mexico. They had spent four hours in detention, had had their fingerprints loaded into a computerized file and had been advised not to enter the country illegally again.
While the United States says it will eventually try to put repeat offenders behind bars, in most cases it has neither the prosecutors nor the jail space to do so now.
The front line of defense remains people like the green-eyed, mustachioed Agent Quiroga, a 30-year-old native of Laredo, Tex., where he once played middle linebacker for the local high school.
The job has its dangers -- a Border Patrol agent was killed just last month in Eagle Pass, Tex., in a shootout with drug smugglers, and agents on the Arizona border have had shots fired at them at least 10 times in the past six months. Conversely, some Border Patrol agents have been accused of brutalizing immigrants.
But Mr. Quiroga said that for most agents the job is more typically marked by days of relatively uneventful work, often involving detentions of people who say with a shrug that they will come back. He said he no longer even lectures them about not trying again.
"That's a negative," he said. "No lectures. You could turn blue in the face trying to do that. A lot of people say, 'Why are you taking me back? I'm just trying to make a better living for my family. All I want to do is work. Is that such a crime?' "
And Mr. Quiroga is not at all unique among agents when he says that even in doing his job as best he can he is not immune to sympathy for people on the other end of the cat-and-mouse operation.
"In some ways, it's kind of impossible to hold back what's going on," he said. "You talk to these people, you put yourself in their shoes, and you can see exactly what the hell is going on out here. You can understand where they're coming from."

HEADLINE: Facing Foes, Rohatyn Ready To Withdraw As Fed Choice

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker who has lobbied for the No. 2 seat on the Federal Reserve Board, drafted a letter to President Clinton today, withdrawing from consideration after concluding that his nomination would face insurmountable opposition from Senate Republicans, senior Administration officials said tonight.
Mr. Rohatyn faxed a copy of the letter to the White House late today. But President Clinton's chief of staff, Leon Panetta, asked him to put off a formal withdrawal while the Administration tried to strike a last-minute deal on Capitol Hill linking his nomination to the renomination of Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Fed. 
 "Felix Rohatyn unfortunately and for no good reason except politics seems to have prospects on the Hill that are not more than bleak," the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said tonight. He said President Clinton was expected to take the issue up "in a review of the issues at the Fed" on Tuesday.
Reached in New York tonight, Mr. Rohatyn confirmed that he had faxed the White House, asking the President to withdraw his name. "Mr. Panetta asked me to hold off for a day because they were still making efforts," Mr. Rohatyn said, "but I frankly think this is a closed chapter."
The President had been expected to announce the reappointment of Mr. Greenspan, a Republican whom the Clinton Administration concluded was the only candidate who could be confirmed before the Presidential election, this week. It would be Mr. Greenspan's third four-year term.
Mr. Rohatyn, 67, senior partner of Lazard Freres, is known for his role in helping New York City survive its fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's. In recent weeks, he has sought to win the vice chairmanship of the Federal Reserve, vacated by Alan S. Blinder. Mr. Blinder resigned to return to Princeton University.
Mr. Rohatyn's first problems were within the Administration itself: Several of Mr. Clinton's top economic advisers, including Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin, were reported to have reservations about his appointment.
Others, though, argued that his views in favor of interest-rate policy promoting economic growth and job creation would be a good counterpoint to Mr. Greenspan's caution and instinct to fight inflation at all costs, even if it meant slower growth.
But the major obstacle came from Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, a member of the Banking Committee and chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee. He assailed the views of Mr. Rohatyn, who he said favored a wide range of activist public solutions to economic problems. Mr. Mack, citing President Clinton's recent declaration that the age of big government was over, said of Mr. Rohatyn several days ago: "It would be difficult to find a nominee more at odds with Bill Clinton's rhetoric."
White House officials have been searching for more than a week for members of the Banking Committee willing to support Mr. Rohatyn. But in an election year, few Republicans would go against their leadership.
Mr. McCurry, in a statement earlier today, said he was concerned that the appointment to an independent board like the Fed "is becoming enmeshed in politics." White House officials said they expected the appointment of Mr. Greenspan to go forward, though they did not know if it would be announced only after another candidate for vice chairman had been found.
While names have not been formally presented to Mr. Clinton, the President has been involved in "a number of conversations," a senior official said recently. The recommendations are being made by a group that includes Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the National Economic Council; Mr. Rubin, and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Joseph E. Stiglitz.
Though the relationship between Mr. Greenspan and the White House began as a rocky one, his management of the economy -- keeping inflation low and the recovery continuing, if slowly -- has been widely praised. He supported the bailout of Mexico and the White House strategy to raise the debt limit this year, and he helped silence some Republican critics of the Administration.
Mr. Greenspan's relationship with Mr. Rubin is said to be particularly good, though it was unclear whether Mr. Greenspan had agreed to Mr. Rohatyn's appointment, or sought someone more compatible with his own views. This has become a real problem, an Administration official said tonight, adding, "This is one of those things that's not easy in a normal year, and impossible in an election year."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Computer Chip Orders Post an Unexpected Drop
The semiconductor industry's leading indicator -- a comparison of orders and shipments of computer chips -- fell to an unexpected low in January, a sign that demand for chips is growing more slowly than the supply. The report is likely to pressure technology stocks and possibly lead to a selloff.
The Semiconductor Industry Association reported a book-to-bill ratio for the three months that ended in January of 0.93, the first time the ratio has been below 1.00, or the break-even mark, in five years. Analysts had forecast a drop from December's ratio of 1.12, but not one so steep. [Page D2.]
 
$1.67 Billion Bid for Teledyne
WHX, which owns Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel, offered $30 a share in cash and stock, or $1.67 billion, for Teledyne, a maker of aviation electronics and specialty metal parts. [D2.]
 
Mexico Oil Privatization Reaffirmed
Despite growing opposition across Mexico to the move, President Ernesto Zedillo, left, and other Government officials reiterated the commitment to selling key pieces of Petroleos Mexicanos, the huge state-owned oil monopoly, while hinting that they might limit foreign investment to insure domestic companies a chance to participate in the privatized businesses. [D7.]
 
For Cigna, a Green Light
Cigna cleared the final regulatory hurdle to its plan to split its domestic property and casualty businesses. The insurer still faces legal challenges from rivals and clients. [D4.]
 
Apple Suspends Dividend
Apple Computer disclosed in an S.E.C. filing that it had for the first time suspended payment of its quarterly dividend. [D4.]
 
Long-Distance Rivals Talk
Investors drove up the shares of AT&T and MCI Communications, after MCI confirmed that the companies were in talks about teaming to build local phone networks. [D10.]
 
Wal-Mart to Try Sales on Internet
In a move certain to accelerate the acceptance of computer-based shopping, Wal-Mart Stores will begin trials of a system for selling merchandise over the Internet. [D6.]
 
A New Kind of On-Line Newspaper
Netscape, Pointcast and media groups including Reuters, ESPN and The Los Angeles Times are planning an Internet news network that can be displayed in the screen-saver software of a personal computer. [D8.]
 
Grace Discloses Federal Inquiry
W. R. Grace said a Federal grand jury had raised the possibility that the company violated criminal laws while seeking to persuade the Food and Drug Administration to allow it to resume imports in 1991 from its dialysis-products factory in Ireland. [D8.]
 
How Much Trouble In Toyland?
The toy industry opened the American International Toy Fair in New York by announcing record retail sales for last year. But after inflation, sales were roughly flat. And the Federal Trade Commission dampened festivities by saying it had won its first consumer-refund settlement for deceptive toy advertising. [D4.]
 
A Security Move Backfires
Three years ago, Royal Dutch/Shell asked Nigeria's military Government to protect its oilfields from attack. The results were disastrous, the company acknowledges; critics accuse Royal Dutch/Shell of colluding in the oppression of local people. [A1.]
 
The Difference a Hiring Can Make
Hilton Hotels said on Feb. 2 that it was hiring Walt Disney's chief financial officer as chief executive; its stock has since jumped 21.7 percent. But what will Stephen Bollenbach do for the hotel company? Market Place. [D10.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: IN THE PACK;
A Strong Second-Place Gives Heart to Buchanan

BYLINE: By ADAM NEGOURNEY 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Feb. 12

 BODY:
With a focused and conservative appeal, Patrick J. Buchanan gathered the right wing of this state's Republican Party behind him today and did "far better than anyone predicted" -- as he exuberantly put it tonight -- for the third time in this year's Republican Presidential season.
Mr. Buchanan's populist approach, combined with the collapse of the campaign of Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, allowed Mr. Buchanan to proclaim himself as the undisputed leader of both social and economic conservatives in the Republican Party as he headed into New Hampshire. 
 "We did well with Christian conservatives," Mr. Buchanan said, fired up. "I'm a religious conservative, too, and they're great people."
Mr. Buchanan's strong showing here was particularly surprising because his advocacy of high tariffs, widely derided by his Republican opponents as protectionist, seemed risky in Iowa because it is heavily dependent on agricultural and manufacturing exports. His sister and campaign chairwoman, Angela "Bay" Buchanan, said the trade issue "works even better for us in New Hampshire." But, that said, Mr. Buchanan might come to remember these weeks as some of the easiest of his Presidential campaign.
Mr. Buchanan had a lot going for him in Iowa. He was able to take advantage of low expectations, and a committed, organized religious community provided him the kind of strong organization that makes the difference in a low-turnout forum like caucuses. His victory in the Louisiana caucuses, and, before that, the Alaska straw poll, gave him a burst of favorable publicity and undercut his principal rival for conservative support, Mr. Gramm.
"I think he was aided tremendously by the collapse of Gramm," said Roger J. Stone Jr, a Republican consultant. "His goals in the final days here were to consolidate social conservatives. He very clearly has done that tonight."
Mr. Buchanan's campaign has never been flush with money, but he has consistently been able to raise money from small contributors. And he might be able to pick off some of the major economic supporters of Mr. Gramm, now that he assumes the mantle of the leading spokesman for Republican conservatives. But the New Hampshire primary is only one week away, which does not give Mr. Buchanan much time to raise money or spend it.
And while Mr. Buchanan enjoys a committed base of support in New Hampshire -- he won 37 percent of the vote when he challenged President George Bush there in 1992 -- he also has a considerable reservoir of enmity among many Republicans there who remember the political damage he inflicted on a sitting President of their party. A poll published by The Boston Globe this week found Mr. Buchanan with 16 percent of the vote, trailing Senator Bob Dole and Steve Forbes.
If history is any guide, Mr. Buchanan's vibrant showing here should help him do better in New Hampshire. But while he has a committed band of supporters, it is a limited one. In Iowa, a third of the voters who went to caucuses described themselves as members of the religious right, and 4 in 10 of the people in that group voted for Mr. Buchanan, according to an entrance poll conducted by the four networks and The Associated Press.
Most political professionals say that despite the strength Mr. Buchanan showed here tonight, his support does not extend to more than 35 percent of the Republican primary voters.
Mr. Buchanan might find that as a serious contender, he is going to be subject to the kind of scrutiny that he has largely escaped.
"It clearly gives Pat a major boost," said Eddie Mahe, a longtime Republican consultant. "But I think the other side of this is his media colleagues are going to start paying attention to him. He's got a free ride until this point. Pat's going to get his day in the sun."
Mr. Buchanan, who has spent this campaign defying the odds, showed no signs of concern tonight. "So I say to my friends in New Hampshire," he said, fairly shouting as he included his wife, Shelley, in his victory speech, "keep the lamps lit tonight. Shelley and Pat are coming home."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Victory Laced With Caution

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Feb. 12

 BODY:
In the quarter-century since George McGovern gained a bit of visibility by finishing a surprisingly close second in this state's nominating caucuses, then little known, Iowa's political voice has grown immeasurably louder. But the message is difficult to understand and often misunderstood.
For all the commotion that surrounds the caucuses -- the millions of dollars and thousands of hours expended by the candidates, the blizzard of television commercials, the invasion of this civilized and amiable state by enough journalists to cover a fair-sized war -- they remain a preliminary. They are Act I, Scene 1 of the yearlong drama of electing a President, not its climax. 
 As of the moment, with only 43 of 1996's days elapsed, fewer than 150,000 of the nation's many millions of Republicans have expressed their views in an official proceeding: 21,000 in the Louisiana caucuses on Feb. 6 and about 100,000 in Iowa.
Not that the candidates are ever shy about claiming victory. Tonight Senator Bob Dole, Patrick J. Buchanan and Lamar Alexander, the former Education Secretary, all staked claims, and no one could call any of them a liar.
It may be, of course, that Bob Dole's victory here will set him on the high road to nomination in August and election in November.
He prevailed here by doing things that should stand him in good stead as the campaign unfolds. He kept cool when polls and scuttlebutt said he was losing ground to Steve Forbes; he kept his sometimes-damaging caustic wit under control, and he built a far more cohesive organization than the one he fielded eight years ago.
He goes into the New Hampshire primary a week from Tuesday with the state's popular governor, Stephen Merrill, deeply committed to his cause, which is another big change from 1988.
But he can draw only limited comfort from history. Edmund S. Muskie, who won the Democratic contest in 1972; George Bush, who won among Republicans in 1980; Richard A. Gephardt, who won the Democratic contest in 1988, and Mr. Dole himself, the Republican winner that same year, all ran into heavy political weather in New Hampshire and never recovered.
Only Jimmy Carter, who in 1976 developed a stealth strategy in this state, organizing meticulously, precinct by precinct, before his rivals noticed, won contested caucuses in Iowa and won the Presidency the following November. He won again in 1980, and his Vice President, Walter F. Mondale, won four years later, but both lost the general election.
Tonight's results provide plenty of evidence that Mr. Dole could falter again. He finds it very hard to stir voters' emotions. His margin here was not large, and in the crucial primaries ahead, he will not benefit from the next-door-neighbor status that benefited him in Iowa. A poll of participants entering the caucuses, conducted by the television networks and The Associated Press, showed that voters cared less about Washington experience and a candidate's prospects of winning in November than about conservative values.
There were also signs here that Mr. Dole has little appeal for those who, unlike the older generation, put relatively little emphasis on the Senator's World War II heroism and consider his long service on Capitol Hill a liability, not an asset. He won a third of the vote among those 45 and older and only about a fifth among those 44 and younger, according to the poll of participants -- a worrisome pattern in a party that is trying to sell itself as the vehicle of change.
One of the two rank outsiders in this year's field, Mr. Buchanan -- a former White House staff member, a writer and a broadcaster, but never an elected official -- sought here to establish himself as more than a protest candidate. Pulling about a quarter of the vote and finishing second, he not only did that but also established himself, for now, as the conservative alternative to Mr. Dole.
He succeeded in attracting and motivating a broad constituency of have-nots, people who feel wronged by the North American Free Trade Agreement, outraged by abortion and threatened by internationalism. He did well among the state's powerful Christian conservatives, capturing four of every ten voters in that group, and among the economically distressed, outpolling Mr. Dole among voters with family incomes under $30,000 a year.
Second-best in Iowa has sometimes proved a bankable political asset. Mr. McGovern parlayed it into the Democratic nomination in 1972, and Mr. Bush showed enough strength in defeating Ronald Reagan in 1980 that he was chosen as his party's Vice-Presidential nominee. But the evangelist Pat Robertson got nothing out of his surprise runner-up status in the Republican caucuses in Iowa in 1988.
Mr. Buchanan's performance was undeniably impressive, although he did as well in some states four years ago in his primary challenge of George Bush.
But unless he can broaden his appeal to include mainstream Republicans, he will go the way of Mr. Robertson and of Father Charles Coughlin and Huey P. Long in the 1930's. Eventually, more conventional and less divisive politicians always find ways, as did Franklin D. Roosevelt in the New Deal, to address the needs of the dispossessed and steal the constituencies of the ultraconservatives.
Many factors, politicians said, played a part in Mr. Forbes's dismal showing. Organization has always counted in Iowa, and he had little, relying almost entirely on his television commercials and phone banks. Some Iowans resented his spending $4 million in the state, and without grass-roots workers to get them to tonight's meetings, those intrigued by his ideas apparently stayed home.
Mr. Forbes failed in his ambition to turn himself from a millionaire publishing mogul into a bona-fide Presidential candidate. Not since Wendell L. Willkie, a utility executive, won the Republican Presidential nomination in 1940 has a businessman made a major splash inside one of the major parties.
Even as his poll numbers soared, Mr. Forbes stuck to his 4-3-2-1 mantra --- fourth in Iowa, third in New Hampshire, second in Delaware and first in Arizona. But others set the expectations for him much higher, so he suffered.
New Hampshire, however, has a quirky political culture that could play into Mr. Forbes's hands. Since Revolutionary days, and especially since the Manchester Union Leader became its dominant newspaper, it has resented taxes more than any other state. Hated taxes, in fact, and rewarded like-minded politicians. That has helped Mr. Forbes's flat-tax plan catch on in New Hampshire, though Mr. Merrill, in ill-documented television commercials made for the Dole campaign, has managed to convince some people that it is a disguised middle-class tax increase.
Then, too, organization usually counts for much less in New Hampshire and in other primary states.
The most disappointed man in Des Moines tonight must have been Phil Gramm of Texas, who launched his campaign a year ago with an impeccably conservative record, endless energy and plenty of money. But in the event he proved too clever by half, as the British like to say about those who outsmart themselves.
He predicted victory in Louisiana, but he did not campaign much there in the last ten days, choosing to concentrate on Iowa. Then when Mr. Buchanan ambushed him in the bayous, his support here started to dry up. By playing footsie with Delaware, which is staging its primary on Feb. 24, thus violating the unwritten agreement that no other primary takes place for at least a week after New Hampshire's first-in-the-nation primary, he alienated both Governor Merrill and the Union Leader. Otherwise, he might have had the valuable backing of both.
All along, Mr. Gramm said there would be "only three tickets out of Iowa," meaning that only the top three candidates would survive the caucuses. In historical terms, he was right. No fourth-place finisher has gone on to win the nomination. If that rule is broken this year, Mr. Gramm seems unlikely to be the man to break it. His campaign has gained no momentum in New Hampshire; he had counted on momentum from Iowa to carry him forward there.
The hardest to figure is Mr. Alexander, the piano-playing man from Tennessee, who campaigned for months in his red plaid shirts without generating anything resembling a groundswell, then caught on a bit this week. He was a big winner in the expectations game, but how much further he can go is unclear.
"I think that what we're going to have coming out of Iowa," he had said on Sunday, "is a weak Dole, a falling Forbes, a rising Buchanan and a rising Alexander, and of that field I'm the most likely to be nominated."
What he predicted almost happened, and he was clearly delighted by his showing, which was far stronger than the pundits or polls had predicted.
But anyone who watched the underwhelmed audiences drawn by most of the candidates in the last week of the campaign, and the cheering mobs that turned out to hear President Clinton, can only speculate about might-have-beens.
Sure, Mr. Clinton's events were artfully and expensively staged. Sure, the Presidency has a special glamour. But the Republicans will have to overcome those things in the fall if they are to win, and many of them wondered this weekend whether Gen. Colin L. Powell or Jack F. Kemp or William J. Bennett or one of the many others on the long list of noncandidates might have struck a spark in Iowa.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk
