HEADLINE: BLOOD AND OIL: A Special Report.;
After Nigeria Represses, Shell Defends Its Record

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: YORLA, Nigeria

 BODY:
When members of the Ogoni people began attacks three years ago on Royal Dutch/Shell's oilfields in Nigeria, the company appealed to the country's military Government for protection.
The results, senior company officials now acknowledge, were utterly disastrous. 
 To crush the unrest by the Ogoni, who complained of environmental damage to their territories and demanded money for the oil extracted there, Nigeria sent its notoriously brutal "mobile police" and mounted a campaign of repression that included laying waste to whole villages.
Last November the military Government of Gen. Sani Abacha executed the most prominent Ogoni, Ken Saro-Wiwa, after he was found guilty of inciting a riot that led to the killing of four pro-Government chiefs. His trial was widely condemned as a sham in Europe and the United States.
Now, Royal Dutch/Shell is on trial in the court of public opinion. Critics here and abroad accuse the company of colluding in the brutal oppression of local people, of polluting Ogoniland and of failing to speak out against the execution of Mr. Saro-Wiwa.
Several countries, including the United States, are contemplating sanctions against Nigeria. A coalition of human rights and environmental groups is planning a worldwide boycott of Shell's gasoline and other products.
Even London's Royal Geographic Society, not usually the most militant of groups, has dropped the company as a patron and returned a $60,000 donation.
The Saro-Wiwa case has set off a debate reminiscent of the one over economic relations with South Africa before majority rule. Some critics of the Nigerian Government say that by refusing to cooperate with it, companies like Shell could hasten the return of democracy, or at least avoid complicity with corruption and denial of human rights.
An examination of Shell's actions in Nigeria, assembled from interviews with officials of Shell and the Nigerian Government as well as dissidents and human rights groups abroad, from separate tours of Ogoniland with officials and dissidents, and from a review of official and corporate documents, brings out these broad points:
*Although Mr. Saro-Wiwa has been widely portrayed as a gentle, pipe-smoking eco-martyr, he was a far more complex figure, an ambitious -- Ogoni political rivals say ruthless -- leader. His movement focused on ecological protection after calculating that this would have appeal in the West, but its main goals were to win the region autonomous power and a share of its oil revenues.
*Nigeria's leaders saw the Ogoni movement as a step toward separatist war, like the fierce conflict over the Biafra region in the 1960's. The response was ferocious. One internal Nigerian Army memo outlining the Government's strategy called for the "wasting" of "leadership cadres, especially vocal individuals."
*Shell gave Nigeria an important pretext for violence when it specifically asked the Government to send the mobile police -- known locally as the "kill-and-go mob." Shell paid for the transportation and salary bonuses of some troops -- ostensibly oilfield guards -- who committed the abuses.
*There is evidence of significant pollution in the region in which Shell has pumped oil, but it is not as dire as portrayed by Shell's critics. A 1995 World Bank study concluded that while the pollution angers local residents, the impact on human health "is not expected to be substantial." The report added that "given the low environmental and health impacts, the actual future benefits of reducing oil pollution are low."
*Shell, despite the urging of Western diplomats, declined until the last moment to lend its voice to the international campaign for clemency after Mr. Saro-Wiwa was convicted of murder in a secret and clearly rigged trial. But it is far from clear that Shell's influence would have saved the writer and fellow activists hanged with him.
Shell officials fervently deny doing anything more than trying to protect company personnel and equipment and say they had no control over the actions of the Nigerian security services. They said it was not unusual for companies seeking protection to pay transportation costs and salary supplements for troops living outside their barracks. "We were not there," said Egbert Imomoh, Shell's top manager in Port Harcourt. "We don't know what happened."
Shell officials say they have begun a major study to assess environmental damage in the region. But senior company officials said Shell's image had been dealt a serious blow by the events in Nigeria.
"Saro-Wiwa's execution was a disaster for us," said Alan Detheridge, Shell's West African coordinator.
Nonetheless, the company brushes aside suggestions that it should pull out of Nigeria, or at least freeze the $3.8 billion natural gas project it is pursuing there. The World Bank announced soon after the executions of Mr. Saro-Wiwa and eight other Ogoni activists that it would not proceed with negotiations to provide money for some of the project.
"All we can pull out are our 270 expatriate staff," said Mark Moody-Stuart, one of four managing directors of Royal Dutch/Shell, in an interview in his London office. "The Nigerians can run the oil industry on their own and buy help on the market," he said, adding that "the French would replace us in a flash."
 
The Roots
Big Profits, Political Rivalry
For nearly four decades Shell has been pumping oil in Nigeria's delta region, to its own enormous profit, and to the benefit of Western countries that have been ready customers. Shell produces roughly half of Nigeria's oil, a commodity that accounts for some 90 percent of the country's foreign exchange and a steady stream of revenues for Nigeria that have often been siphoned off by corrupt officials.
The operations are strategically important to the company, which lacks enough reserves of high-quality crude to meet the requirements of its refineries and gasoline stations. Shell takes for itself 257,000 barrels of the 900,000 barrels the company pumps daily, giving Nigeria the rest.
Nigeria is also lucrative for Shell. Nick Antill, an analyst with the London securities house Barclays de Zoete Wedd, puts Shell's Nigerian profits at $170 million to $190 million a year. "That's nearly 10 percent of total exploration and production profits, which is significant," he says.
Little, if any, of these profits trickled down to Ogoniland.
The Ogoni campaign against the company began in 1990 when a group of conservative traditional leaders formed the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People to win statehood, more money and better environmental protection for the Ogoni. Garrick B. Leton, a former federal minister, became the first president. Mr. Saro-Wiwa, then 49 and a successful writer and TV producer, was appointed spokesman.
The movement persuaded the Government to create an Oil and Minerals Producing Areas Development Commission to channel money to these regions, with an initial promise it would get 3 percent of Nigeria's $10 billion annual oil income, later raised to 13 percent.
But Mr. Saro-Wiwa favored a more confrontational approach to Shell and the federal Government, Mr. Leton said in an interview at his spacious Port Harcourt house. And the two men fell out in a dispute over tactics tinged with class rivalry and personality differences.
The movement was founded by "rich traditional leaders with big houses in Port Harcourt," said Botom Mitee, a supporter of Mr. Saro-Wiwa whose brother was also tried for murder but acquitted. But Mr. Saro-Wiwa, though he had grown affluent during his years as a local administrator and trader, "identified with poor Ogoni in the villages."
Against its official leaders' wishes, Mr. Saro-Wiwa set up new branches of the group under his control, including a youth wing called the National Youth Council of the Ogoni People. Leadership of this group won Mr. Saro-Wiwa a following among Ogoni impatient with traditional leaders. But Mr. Leton said the group became Mr. Saro-Wiwa's "private vigilante army."
At Mr. Saro-Wiwa's urging, the movement demanded $10 billion in oil royalties and enviromental compensation from Shell and the Government in December 1992.
Shell attributes Mr. Saro-Wiwa's success in gradually taking control of the movement and radicalizing it to the continuing poverty of the Ogoni, as promises of more federal aid never materialized. Most villagers still lack even electricity and piped water. For this, Shell blames the Government.
In 1992 Mr. Saro-Wiwa allied the Ogoni movement with the Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization, a group based in The Hague that strives to give minority groups access to international organizations. He carried his campaign to the United Nations and canvassed support in Europe and the United States. He designed an Ogoni flag, wrote a national anthem and began signing his letters as "president and spokesman of the Ogoni people."
The struggle for control of the Ogoni movement between its traditional leaders and Mr. Saro-Wiwa came to a head in June 1993 over his plan to draw attention to the Ogoni plight by boycotting a Nigerian presidential election that was supposed to mark the country's return to democratic rule.
Mr. Letun and other founding fathers of the movement opposed the boycott, were outvoted and resigned, allowing Mr. Saro-Wiwa to take over the group's presidency.
Mr. Saro-Wiwa's campaign against Shell and the federal Government angered Nigeria's military leaders, who said they feared he was stirring up secessionist feeling in the oil-rich east, 20 years after Biafra's unsuccessful breakaway bid.
 
The Violence
Countercharges And Confusion
In late 1992 Shell asked the Government to send troops to protect its operations from recurring vandalism. But dismayed by continuing vigilante attacks and the ferocious crackdown, Shell withdrew from the region in early 1993, asking the authorities to protect the installations left behind.
The violence continued. Soon after Shell left, an oil pumping station here was set afire and destroyed, and the other four stations in Ogoniland were damaged. Ogoni leaders and the military accuse each other of being responsible. The blazing oil left behind a landscape of charred trees and blackened earth. Even today, nothing grows.
The next year, according to an internal memo obtained by Nigerian dissidents, the company specifically asked the military Government to deploy its mobile police.
What happened in those months of upheaval is a matter of deep dispute.
The Government, in its official account, asserts that vigilantes with ties to Mr. Saro-Wiwa's youth group spearheaded attacks against Shell installations and murdered 40 Ogoni opponents.
Mr. Saro-Wiwa's brother, Owens Saro-Wiwa, and a report by a delegation from the Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization to Ogoniland in Febuary 1995 give very different accounts of these incidents. Owens Saro-Wiwa acknowledges that vigilante lawlessness existed in 1993. But he says most of the vandalism was carried out by soldiers, who stole generators and corrugated iron sheets for profit during their campaign against the Ogoni.
Internal military documents show the Government hoped that by crushing the Ogoni protests it would persuade Shell to resume operations in the region. In May 1994 the commander of an internal security task force, Maj. Paul Okuntimo, wrote to his superior, Lieut. Col. Dauda Komo, the Military Administrator of Rivers State, which includes Ogoniland. The message, later obtained by dissidents, said "Shell operations still impossible unless ruthless military operations are undertaken."
It called for "wasting targets cutting across communities and leadership cadres, especially vocal individuals." It detailed special allowances for the troops and suggested applying "pressure on oil companies" to help pay the costs of the operation.
Owens Saro-Wiwa estimates that the attacks largely destroyed about 30 Ogoni villages, killing some 2,000 people, although there is no independent verification.
By then Shell had already abandoned its operations in the region, declaring that it was unwilling to work in conditions of civil unrest and military oppression. Mr. Detheridge, Shell's West African coordinator, said the company would not return "until we have the local community on our side."
On May 21, 1994, Nigerian security forces detained Ken Saro-Wiwa in the Gokana region of Ogoniland while he was campaigning for election to a constitutional conference and took him to Port Harcourt.
The Government says Mr. Saro-Wiwa told his youth supporters, in a statement that included a reference to the paramount chief's meeting place:
"The vultures who connived with the security forces to stop me from addressing you are now meeting at the Gbenemene's Palace Hall in Giokoo sharing money sent them by the federal Government in an effort to thwart my bid for the constitutional conference. Go to the meeting place and deal with the vultures."
His supporters say Mr. Saro-Wiwa never made that statement, though they concede that he used similar language several months earlier.
According to the Government, a crowd of several hundred Ogoni youths attacked the small meeting hall where chiefs and elders were gathered, massacring four with rakes, iron bars, stones and planks.
Today the slain chiefs' blood is still splattered on the walls and floor, which is littered with stones and chunks of concrete used to crush their skulls. The burnt-out remains of two of their cars are slowly being swallowed up by vegetation outside.
The four murdered men -- Albert T. Badey, a former secretary to the state government, Chief Edward Kobani, Chief Samuel M. Orage and Chief Theophalos B. Orage -- were on a list of 10 "vultures" that Mr. Saro-Wiwa made public the previous October because of what he said was their opposition to his agressive campaigning for Ogoni rights against Shell.
The Government insists that Mr. Saro-Wiwa and eight others incited the murders. Mr. Saro-Wiwa's supporters say the killing was done by Government agents to incriminate the Ogoni leader.
What few outside the Nigerian Government disagree about is that Mr. Saro-Wiwa's trial was a travesty, its outcome preordained and his sentence more a reflection of Nigeria's harsh politics than any judicial process.
Mr. Saro-Wiwa was tried before a mixed military-civilian court with no right of judicial appeal. Two prosecution witnesses later retracted evidence and said the Government bribed them. Mr. Saro-Wiwa was hanged on Nov. 10. Nineteen more Ogoni are awaiting trial for the same killings.
 
The Responsibility
A Lost Cause From the Start?
Critics of Shell contend the company has considerable influence over the Nigerian Government and could have done much more to prevent the hanging. The company disputes both assertions.
Initially, when Mr. Saro-Wiwa was put on trial, Shell refused to intervene with the Nigerian authorities, saying "the company does not get involved in politics."
In a statement issued last Oct. 31, after Mr. Saro-Wiwa was sentenced to death, Shell acknowledged that it was being pressed to use its influence to secure clemency but declined to do so, saying, "It is not for commercial organizations like Shell to interfere in the legal process of a sovereign state such as Nigeria."
The company also implicitly accused Mr. Saro-Wiwa of supporting violence, saying in a statement at the time of sentencing that while the Ogoni movement claimed to be nonviolent, "this is not our experience."
Shell's stance brought protests from Mr. Saro-Wiwa's friends. And on Nov. 2 the company issued a new statement that omitted the accusation of abetting violence. But it expressed no regret at the death sentences and again refused to intervene.
Only after Mr. Saro-Wiwa's appeal for clemency had been denied did Shell's chief executive officer, Cor Herkstroter, fax General Abacha requesting a pardon.
Mr. Detheridge insists that Shell's relationship with Nigeria has to be based on business considerations, not political ones. "We can offer advice and we can point out the consequences of an action," he said. "But we do not lecture or try to give orders because we do not interfere in politics and government."
Owens Saro-Wiwa says he met three times during the trial with Brian Anderson, Shell's top executive in Nigeria. He quoted Mr. Anderson as saying it would be "difficult but not impossible" to get his brother freed, provided the Ogoni movement called off its campaign against the company.
But he said his brother refused this offer, replying that the campaign against Shell would end once he was free and the company agreed to negotiate with the movement. Mr. Anderson then broke off contact with him, Owens Saro-Wiwa says. In a videotaped interview issued by Shell, Mr. Anderson denies ever having made such an offer, but confirms that he met with the condemned man's brother.
Britain and the United States privately urged Shell to help save Mr. Saro-Wiwa. Mr. Moody-Stewart of Shell said, "Of course we pointed out to Nigerians the risk of sanctions."
On Nov. 8, the day General Abacha rejected Mr. Saro-Wiwa's clemency plea, President Clinton's special envoy to Nigeria, Ambassador Donald T. McHenry, urged executives of American companies with interests in Nigeria to apply one form of leverage that he thought might work: to explain to Nigeria's leaders that carrying out the executions could invite international sanctions.
While Mr. McHenry says he does not know whether the companies followed his advice, some of them, including the American oil companies Mobil and Chevron, say they did warn their partners about the international repercussions of proceeding with the hangings.
American and British diplomats in Lagos as well as a senior Nigerian diplomat said the campaign to save Mr. Saro-Wiwa never had much chance. The military, they said, was adamantly unwilling to bow to foreign pressure a second time so soon after General Abacha spared the former head of state Olusegun Obasanjo from execution for conspiracy in May.
"The military are a macho bunch," said the Nigerian diplomat. "They couldn't give way a second time. The two incidents were too close in time. If they had been further apart we might have saved him."
 
The Pollution
Low Standards, A Few Regrets
Sitting in his comfortable top-floor office at Shell Center on the south bank of the River Thames with 17th-century naval paintings on the wall and a view of the Houses of Parliament, Mr. Moody-Stuart said he was not sure whether anything could have been done to avert the hanging. But he does says the whole crisis in Ogoniland could have been avoided.
"What I regret is that we did not launch our Niger River Delta Environmental Survey six or seven years ago," he said. He added that if there had been an agreed analysis and action program when the Ogoni movement was founded, "it would have taken a lot of heat out of Ken Saro-Wiwa's campaign."
Shell is now setting up such a commission, at a cost of $4.5 million, to assess the delta's environmental needs. But the project is off to a shaky start. In November Prof. Claude Ake, a representative of the delta communities, resigned in protest at the executions and because he doubts the commission's impartiality.
Ogoni activists like to describe how, after four decades of oil pumping, their 400-square-mile ancestral land is host to 96 oil wells and five big pumping stations, where vast quantities of natural gas are burned 24 hours a day, dirtying the air and lighting up the countryside.
They complain of leaky oil pipes crisscrossing their land and hindering farming. They complain, too, of frequent oil spills that destroy crops and pollute the creeks where the Ogoni fish.
While calling this an exaggerated picture, Shell concedes that environmental standards at its oilfields in the Niger delta are lower than in Europe or America.
"It's a question of priorities," said Dick van den Broek. "Nigeria is a poor country. How much should it spend on enviromental protection?" As majority partner, the Nigerian Government must pay 55 percent of all environmental spending, Shell points out, and it has been reluctant to sacrifice profits for costly environmental protection.
Mr. Saro-Wiwa indicated a keen awareness of the international political appeal of environmental issues in his last book, "A Month and a Day: A Detention Diary," saying of a visit to America: "What that trip did was to convince me that the environment would have to be a strong plank on which to base the burgeoning Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People."
Neither Shell nor the Nigerian Government has conducted a comprehensive environmental impact study of its operations in Ogoniland or elsewhere in the Niger delta.
A 1995 World Bank study, "Defining an Environmental Strategy for the Niger Delta," concludes that while the oil industry has caused environmental damage, "oil pollution by itself is of moderate priority when compared with the full spectrum of environmental problems in the Niger Delta." Many of these, it says, stem from a fourfold population rise since 1958. The study cited oil leaks into the delta waters, saying they indicate "poor or no treatment of effluents" by Shell and other oil companies.
Many Ogoni leaders say their main complaint is poverty.
"Backwardness is what is wrong with us," says Charles Kpakol, chairman of the Gokana local government council, one of three Ogoni regional authorities. While appointed by the Government and opposed to Mr. Saro-Wiwa's Ogoni movement, he is still critical of the federal Government for spending too little in Ogoniland.

A chart on Tuesday with an article about accusations that Royal Dutch/ Shell had condoned a Nigerian Government crackdown against members of the Ogoni people misstated the volume of Nigeria's oil production. It is 1.8 million barrels a day, not 1.8 billion.
An article on Feb. 13 about the role of Royal Dutch/Shell in Nigeria misstated actions of the Royal Geographical Society in London. While some of its members urged the society in January to sever its links to Shell as a corporate patron, the society has not broken ties or returned any Shell donations.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Goodbye Santo Domingo, Hello Manhattan

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
Underneath its sugar coating, "Nueba Yol," a comic fable about a young Dominican widower who visits New York City and discovers it is not the paradise paved in dollar bills that he had imagined, offers a fairly hardheaded dose of urban reality. At almost every turn, Balbuena (Luisito Marti), a happy-go-lucky Dominican Everyman who mortgages his house in Santo Domingo to buy a visa, finds his boundless good will either ignored or exploited by others.
To its credit, "Nueba Yol" (Dominican slang for New York), is neither a downbeat story about an innocent dreamer consumed by the plagues of poverty and drugs nor a rags-to-riches fantasy. To audiences in the Dominican Republic, where it has been a smash hit, the movie offers a comforting message: there's no place like home. 
 The movie, which was produced, written and directed by Angel Muniz, is a crude but engaging combination of humorous star vehicle, social-realist commentary and lighthearted farce. For more than a decade, Balbuena has been one of the most popular characters on Dominican television. And at times the movie feels like an episode of a sitcom that might be called "Balbuena Goes to Manhattan." Unlike his Pollyannaish counterparts on American television who would be ridiculed as naive chumps, Balbuena is someone whose genuine friendliness and trust in others are huge assets.
Unable to speak English and lacking a green card, Balbuena finds it almost impossible to find work even as a dishwasher. He is repeatedly menaced by suspicious drug dealers who don't recognize him from the neighborhood. Everything from the mechanics of unlocking an apartment door to finding his way around on the subway becomes a potential crisis.
At the same time, Balbuena faces resentment in his cousin's already overcrowded household. He is despised by Pedro's teen-age children, who are embarrassed by their Dominican origins. One family quarrel becomes so overwrought that Pedro collapses from the stress.
For all the dangers and obstacles it throws in his path, "Nueba Yol" shares Balbuena's faith in the kindness of most strangers (except for drug dealers). He finds romance with an attractive woman (Caridad Ravelo) and a tentative economic foothold working in a Mexican restaurant.
"Nueba Yol" is absolutely clear about what it takes to make a better life in New York or anywhere else. Luck, pluck and hard work are the way, and beware of shortcuts.
"Nueba Yol" is unrated.
 
NUEBA YOL
 
Written (in Spanish, with English subtitles) and directed by Angel Muniz; director of photography, Christopher Norr; edited by Robinson Perez; music by Pengbian Sang; produced by Miguel Angel Muniz, Jose Lluberes, Luisito Marti and Rafael Cespedes; released by Kit Parker Films and D'Pelicula. Running time: 104 minutes. This film is not rated.

HEADLINE: At the Nation's Table: Austin, Tex.;
Elegant Variations On the Empanada

BYLINE: By Anne S. Lewis 

 BODY:
For Ash Corea there is no such thing as a simple empanada. The savory half-moon-shape turnovers indigenous to Latin America are typically stuffed with meats, fish or poultry. But at Ms. Corea's Empanada Parlour in Austin, Tex., she experiments with fillings like sweet potato seasoned with cilantro pesto, and turkey, bok choy and peas spiked with curry powder.
For two years, Ms. Corea, 47, a graduate of the Cordon Bleu Cooking School in Paris, has been delighting empanada aficionados with the spicy, savory and sweet empanadas that she serves at her small downtown storefront and sells wholesale to grocery stores. 
 Ms. Corea was raised in London and has worked in the food business on and off for the 16 years that she has lived in the United States. She became interested in empanadas as a caterer in New York City in the 1980's, when she noted the popularity of stuffed savory pastries. And it wasn't that she set out to experiment with the Latin turnovers; she was really trying to improve the bland Cornish pasties of her London youth.
"Those deadly boring pies filled with cubed beef, peas and potatoes," she recalled with a laugh and a toss of her dreadlocks. "They never saw a trace of garlic, pepper or herbs!"
Ms. Corea, her three partners and their staff bake 12 varieties of at least 600 empanadas a day. "These pies are the perfect fast food," she said. "They're low in fat, economical and -- with all the filling possibilities -- interesting to people who take food seriously."
They're $1.50 each. Ms. Corea's customers eat empanadas for snacks, pick them up on their way to work in the morning, like bagels, and take them home at night for meals. The Empanada Parlour, which is in a downtown storefront, has 10 tables and seats about 40 people. The menu includes a few soups, salads, sandwiches and a daily special. Prices range from $3.50 for soup to the daily special at $5.99.
The response here in the Texas capital has been gratifying, even though Ms. Corea acknowledges that when she began, few of her customers had any idea what an empanada was. "At first I got a lot of skeptical, 'Oh, those are just healthy fried pies!' -- even though they were so obviously baked."
The Empanada Parlour is at 500 East Fourth Street, Austin, Tex. 78701; (512) 480-8902. It is open Monday through Saturday, from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. ANNE S. LEWIS

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mixed as the Mark Attracts Most of the Attention

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Political and economic uncertainty in Europe drove traders to the safety of the German mark yesterday, leaving the dollar mixed against major currencies.
The dollar was down against the mark and up a fraction against the Japanese yen after a day of choppy, thin trading. 
 Most European currencies also showed losses against the mark, which strengthened on signs of steady interest rates in Germany and repeated denials that France and Germany would form their own monetary union.
John Rothfield, an international economist at the Chicago office of Nationsbank-CRT, said that the dollar was down because the mark rose and not because traders dumped dollars.
"People are saying that this stall in the dollar rally isn't a change in sentiment against the dollar," he said.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar was trading at 1.4730 marks, down from 1.4764 on Monday. It was quoted at 106.81 yen, compared with 106.80 the day before. The British pound rose to $1.5367 from $1.5290.
The mark strengthened after German central bankers indicated that they might not be ready for another cut in interest rates despite economic data showing a slowdown in their nation's economy, the largest in Europe.
A member of the Bundesbank's policy-setting committee, Ernst Welteke, was quoted by a German financial daily as saying that the central bank would maintain interest rates until further data on the money supply become available in March.
The president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, called again for economic union and a single currency. He also said that creating the union was more important than sticking to the 1999 start-up date.
Lisa Finstrom, a senior currency analyst at Smith Barney Inc., said "we'll just have to wait" until Bundesbank officials moved more decisively. Traders, however, did not wait as they bought more marks.
The French franc fell against the mark as the Prime Minister of France, Alain Juppe, again denied speculation that Germany and France would link their currencies rather than join a broader European union.

HEADLINE: The Economics of Never-Never Land

BYLINE: By Paul R. Krugman; Paul R. Krugman, professor of economics at Stanford, is the author of "Peddling Prosperity" and "The Age of Diminished Expectations."

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
I sometimes wish that I could bring myself to have faith in supply-side economics. True believers like Steve Forbes live in a never-never land in which there are no hard choices or painful tradeoffs, budget deficits will be cured by growth and poverty will vanish as the rising tide lifts all boats. Alas, like the great majority of grown-up economists, I just cannot manage the necessary suspension of my critical faculties.
Supply-side economics can be defined as the belief that cutting taxes produces an explosion of economic growth. Yes, most economists agree that taxes are a drag on the economy. But supply-siders insist that the payoff from lowering rates would be vastly larger than others think plausible. 
 Mr. Forbes promises that he can cut almost everyone's taxes without increasing the budget deficit; a Congressionally appointed panel tells us that switching to a flat tax would double the economy's growth rate.
Why does anyone listen to such extravagant promises? Many people accept supply-side nostrums simply because, like the victims of telemarketing scams, they have not learned that a deal that sounds too good to be true probably is. But for those who demand some evidence, the supply-siders continually return to what they regard as the clincher: the supposed economic miracle of the 1980's, in which Ronald Reagan's tax cuts were followed by simultaneous declines in inflation and unemployment.
But mainstream economists have never found the experience of that decade at all mysterious. The conventional wisdom in 1979 held that bringing inflation down would require a prolonged period of high unemployment. That is exactly what happened: The unemployment rate, which had been 5.8 percent in 1979, averaged 7.5 percent during the eight years of Mr. Reagan's Presidency. (It rose rapidly to almost 11 percent during his first two years in office, then declined gradually thereafter, not returning to 5.8 percent until 1988.) Why should anyone be surprised that inflation was lower when he left office than when he entered it?
Mr. Forbes and many others seem to be confused about the difference between the level of unemployment and its rate of change. Anyone who paid attention in Economics 101 knows that inflation normally declines if the unemployment rate is high, even if that rate is falling. Yet the supply-siders insist that something miraculous must have happened after 1982 because employment rose and inflation fell at the same time.
Imagine an overweight person going on a severe diet, beginning with a starvation ration of 800 calories a day and gradually increasing his intake to a somewhat healthier 1,500 calories. Would it be a refutation of conventional dieting theory if the person continued to lose weight as his meals grew larger? Well, substitute jobs for calories, inflation for weight, and you have the fuzzy logic behind the legend of Reaganomics.
The tragedy is that just last year Congressional Republicans seemed to have come to their senses, returning to old-fashioned, tight-fisted conservatism. Despite Mr. Forbes's fourth-place showing in Iowa, the Republican nominee, whoever he is, will probably run not on the theme of fiscal responsibility but on a Reaganesque program of tax cuts. Such a program would promise growth, but it would deliver new and bigger deficits.
Although Bob Dole has attacked Mr. Forbes's flat tax, he has also famously offered to be "another Ronald Reagan, if that's what you want." But unlike Mr. Reagan in 1980, a newly elected President Dole would find a Government already deeply in debt. Worse yet, the day is approaching when the baby boomers will start to retire and claim the trillions of dollars in Social Security and Medicare benefits they have been promised.
It may be pleasant to imagine that we could fly away from these problems by sprinkling a little supply-side fairy dust and thinking of Christmas. But the Republican Party is an organization of adults -- isn't it?

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
A philanthropist invests in downtown Portland, Me., hoping to help stem the flight to the suburbs.

BYLINE: By Susan Diesenhouse 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Me.

 BODY:
THIS picturesque port city has been benefiting from investments by one of the state's top philanthropists, Elizabeth B. Noyce, who has turned her attention to commercial real estate.
Mrs. Noyce was once married to the late Robert Norman Noyce, co-inventor of the integrated circuit and the co-founder of the Intel Corporation, the largest maker of chips for personal computers. She has been a leading supporter of cultural and medical institutions and education in Maine. Last year she spent about $13 million to buy two blocks and part of a third in the downtown here. 
 With the purchases she got three office towers and an old five-and-dime store and some land, all off Congress Street, a principal commercial thoroughfare, between Brown and Elm Streets. Her goal is to entice back to the city commercial tenants that might otherwise rent space in suburban malls.
Mrs. Noyce said her real estate companies -- the October Corporation and the August Corporation -- spent $1 million in 1995 and would spend $1 million this year to refurbish the office buildings. In the fall, she hopes to build a year-round farmer's market of about 60,000 square feet and a 700-car garage.
"We intend to inspire people to come back downtown, not to develop it enormously but to reverse the trend out to the suburbs," Mrs. Noyce said in an interview. "I've been told by people that this is bringing a breath of fresh air to Portland."
Mrs. Noyce, 65, became a summer resident of Maine in 1968, when she and her husband bought a vacation home. After their divorce in the mid-70's, she became a permanent resident. Mr. Noyce died in 1990.
Mrs. Noyce joined the downtown business community in 1991, when the bank she used, the Bank of New England, failed, and she founded a new bank, the Maine Bank and Trust Company. When that bank needed expansion space, she bought the building that housed it, on Congress Street.
Now, the October Corporation is leasing offices that might otherwise be vacant by offering concessions like extensive improvements, rents that are modestly below market rates and perhaps a period of free or reduced rent.
"That will make it possible to fill up retail space and attract arts groups," according to Barbara Hagar, executive director of the Downtown Portland Association, which manages an improvement district for the neighborhood. "Betty Noyce has the patient money that the city needs."
Mrs. Noyce said that if her property investments were successful her response would be to "buy another portion of downtown."
Portland, a city of about six square miles, with 63,000 residents and 3.8 million square feet of office space, has been losing businesses and residents to its suburbs since the 1970's. By 1992, it was experiencing a debilitating mix of suburban flight, economic recession and a decline in the commercial real estate market. The downtown office vacancy rate climbed to 23 percent.
The turnaround has been rapid, with the vacancy rate last year down to 11.9 percent, said James D. Harnden, a partner of Ram Harnden Commercial Real Estate. The asking rent for prime office space is $14.50 to $18 a square foot and for secondary space, $8 to $13. Retail space on the popular Exchange Street is leasing for $15 to $19 a square foot compared with almost $25 in some malls, Mr. Harnden said.
Mrs. Noyce and some smaller new landlords "have brought in more activity downtown than we've seen in 10 years," he added.
Of the 350,000 square feet in its three office towers, all of which are on Congress Street, the October Corporation has leased about 50,000 square feet since it closed on the properties last summer.
The vacancy rate at 465 Congress Street has gone from 15 percent to 3 percent, and at 477 Congress from 15 percent to 5 percent. But at 511 Congress, the major tenant, Fleet Bank, recently left, causing the vacancy rate to jump from 46 percent to 70 percent, said Morris L. Fisher, a broker with the Boulos Company.
One new tenant at 465 Congress, a stately 10-story turn-of-the-century tower, is Ghislaine Berube, a partner in Hughes Berube, a small computer consulting company.
Last fall, her company moved from nearby Cape Elizabeth to Portland. It hired a new employee and is renting 1,500 square feet at $8 a square foot. The October Corporation built a wall to create a room, installed new carpeting and painted. Such refurbished accommodations could command $10 a square foot, Mr. Fisher said.
Ms. Berube chose the building because she likes the Victorian lobby replete with marble, brass and mahogany details; the central location; the nearby parking garage, and the relatively crime-free neighborhood.
"It's a warm and fuzzy town and a very attractive building," she said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Expectations Of Rate Cuts Lift Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
With the bond market still holding fast to its expectations of further interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, with a weak regional report on business conditions generating only a muted response.
Prices rose early as traders anticipated a flow of cash into short-term Treasuries from investors taking profits on the recent gains in the stock market. This forced traders short-selling the bonds -- that is, betting against the market -- to buy Treasuries instead, to either take profit or limit losses. At the same time rumors of a hedge fund buying three-year notes helped keep prices generally higher. 
 Traders said that bond-fund managers bought all maturities each time prices dipped, and they said they expected this type of choppy trading to continue in the near term.
For the most part, the market ignored the 94-cent surge in prices for oil contracts -- a measure of the bullishness of this bond market, traders said. Unlike gold, crude oil is watched closely by the market and is considered a good gauge of inflation. But yesterday, the traders said, the rise in oil prices appeared to be caused by the recent cold weather, and energy prices remained at relatively low levels over all.
The 30-year Treasury bond rose 2/32, to a price of 99 16/22; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, slipped to 6.02 percent, from 6.03 percent on Monday.
The Atlanta Fed's index of regional business activity for the month of January was a -12.3, compared with a -23.5 in December, with most components in the index up from their levels a month ago, indicating that the Southeast economy was weak, but not more than anticipated.
Another bit of data released yesterday, this by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, was the employment cost index for the fourth quarter of 1995. It indicated that labor costs remained restrained, another good sign of subdued inflation.
The index for private industry workers, the broadest measure of labor costs, rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, a bit more than expected but only because of what appears to have been a year-end jump in benefits, Cheryl R. Katz, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, said.
William J. Michaelcheck, chairman of Mariner Investment Group, a money management firm, described yesterday's session as quiet, with bond prices showing little movement.
"The market, however, is still bullish," he said. "But it has stabilized, with yield levels not changing much. People have factored more Fed interest-rate cuts into current prices."
A two-year Treasury note yielding 4.80 percent, Mr. Michaelcheck said, would be consistent with a Federal funds rate -- a Fed rate controlling what banks can charge each other for overnght loans -- of 4 percent; it is now at 4.25 percent.
Thus, Mr. Michaelcheck said, the market is anticipating further easings over the course of the year. "And because there is not much disagreement in the market over that," he said, "there is little volatility." Yesterday the two-year issue closed higher to yield 4.78 percent.
Mr. Michaelcheck noted that the data that has been released so far this year implied a weak economy in 1996, with slow growth. The market will start to get economics statistics during the next month or so that will either validate or prove wrong what the market has priced in.
"Because the market is being bullish, it is vulnerable to strong economic news and could sell off sharply if it found that the economy is rebounding," he said.
In bond futures trading, which influences trading in the cash market -- especially on days when there's little fundamental data available -- prices moved in a narrow range. Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst for Thomson Research of Boston, said she believed that the futures market was at a crossroad.
"While there are a lot of conflicting technical indicators, what is exerting the most control over the market is the monthly uptrend and its will to push prices higher," she said.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises, but Broad Stock Measures Fall

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Broad measures of stocks fell yesterday, led by a slump in semiconductor companies, but the Dow Jones industrial average managed a small gain, for its seventh consecutive record.
The Dow had been down 40 points late in the day but rebounded in the final minutes of trading to end with a rise of 1.08 points, to 5,601.23. In the last seven days, the 30-stock average has added 227.33 points, or 4.2 percent. 
 But broader indicators fell off their records, reacting to news that an industry gauge of demand for semiconductors fell in January to its lowest level in five years, suggesting profit drops for chip makers.
Also, "people are nervous because the stock market is up 10 percent in the past month or so," said Phil Schettewi, a money manager at Loomis Sayles in Washington.
Declining stocks outnumbered advancers yesterday by 1,226 to 1,090 on the New York Stock Exchange, where 441.5 million shares changed hands, compared with 401.5 million shares on Monday.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slid 0.94 point, to 660.51, after rising as much as 2.78 points. Declines in regional telephone, computer and semiconductor issues outweighed gains in oil, insurance and bank shares.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 8.16 points, to 1,087.22, ending a three-day streak of records. Intel and Applied Materials, both microchip makers, fell the most. Other broad indexes also turned lower.
After the close of trading on Monday, the Semiconductor Industry Association said the book-to-bill ratio declined to 0.93 in January from a revised 1.12 in December. That means chip makers received only $93 in new orders for each $100 of products shipped last month. Concern that slowing demand will hurt profits pushed Intel shares down 1 7/64, to 57 1/8, Applied Materials fell 1 5/8, to 38 3/8.
Micron Technology fell as much as 1 1/4 after it was downgraded by Duff & Phelps Investment Research and Pacific Crest Securities, then rebounded to finish at 37 3/4, up 3/4.
Still, losses in semiconductor shares were limited because investors were braced for bad news. Concern began spreading last year that lower chip prices and expanding production would stunt profits, prompting money managers like Jeffrey Vinik of Fidelity's Magellan Fund to cut their positions.
Gains in chip stocks helped fuel 1995's rally, pushing the Philadelphia semiconductor index up more than 100 percent during the first eight months of last year. Since Sept. 8, the index has fallen 36.5 percent.
Many analysts said the weak orders report signaled that makers of personal computers and chips ordered too many semiconductors late last year, and then had excess inventory at the end of the fourth quarter.
"In the fourth quarter, there were some overly optimistic expectations of demand for memory," said Ron Bohn, chip analyst at Dataquest Inc. "We are seeing some of the ripple effects of over-ordering showing up as cancellations now."
Some money managers expect that orders will pick up and profits will balloon later this year. "In my heart of hearts I think that 1996 will be the beginning of a massive corporate upgrade cycle" in computers "that will spur a huge rally in tech stocks as we go through this year," said Philip J. Orlando, money manager at Value Line Asset Management, which oversees $5.5 billion of investment money.
Computer companies also fell yesterday. Morgan Stanley downgraded Compaq Computer and Dell Computer to "neutral" from "outperform." Dell dropped 2 11/16, to 31 1/4, and Compaq skidded 1 1/4, to 50. I.B.M. lost 1 5/8, to 113 5/8.
Office Depot said fourth-quarter earnings rose 11 percent, less than analysts had expected. The stock fell 1, to 19 1/4.
Banks, which benefit first from lower interest rates, gained. Citicorp rose 1/2, to 76; BankAmerica climbed 3/8, to 70 3/4, and Banc One advanced 5/8, to 39 1/2.
Shares of regional telephone companies slipped after surging on Monday. Merrill Lynch lowered its long-term opinion on BellSouth and U S West to "above average" from "buy." BellSouth slid 1, to 44 1/2, after adding 1 5/8 on Monday; U S West fell 1 1/4, to 35 3/4. Ameritech slumped 1 1/2, to 64 7/8, and Bell Atlantic skidded 7/8, to 73 1/2.
Teledyne rose 1, to 28, after WHX sweetened its takeover offer to $1.67 billion, or $30 a share. The maker of aviation electronics, among other things, has spurned two offers from WHX since November 1994.
United Technologies jumped 2 7/8, to 105 3/4. The maker of Carrier air- conditioners and Otis elevators said it would use its free cash to acquire companies and buy back shares.

HEADLINE: Index of Pay and Benefits Rose 2.9% in '95

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
For the sixth consecutive year, the raises that American workers receive have been smaller, or no higher, than those of the year before, according to 1995 figures released today by the Labor Department.
The 2.9 percent increase in overall compensation last year, the skimpiest since at least 1980, was just enough to keep workers ahead of inflation, which at the consumer level ran at a 2.5 percent pace. 
 "The good news is no inflation," Robert B. Reich, the Secretary of Labor, said in an interview, alluding to the fact that payrolls account for about 70 percent of business costs. "The bad news is no raise."
Reiterating a Clinton Administration theme -- the widening income gap between ordinary workers and the well educated -- Mr. Reich noted that in private industry those in blue-collar occupations had increases in pay and benefits averaging 2.5 percent last year compared with a 3.1 percent gain for white-collar jobs.
"White-collar workers beat inflation," the Secretary said. "Blue-collar workers didn't."
A surge in costs did appear in the figures for the final three months of the year, however, with the Employment Cost Index rising nine-tenths of 1 percent. That is the biggest increase in nearly three years and markedly more than had been expected. The jump was attributed to a surge in the cost of benefits even as wages and salaries maintained the steady pace they have kept for some time.
Analysts acknowledged surprise at the jump in benefits costs, which the department attributed to "a reversal in the trend of declining increases" in the cost of health insurance and bonus payments. But most of the analysts said this did not portend faster inflation.
"Labor-cost increases are still quite small, though there's a suggestion that perhaps the very best of the labor market performance is behind us for this cycle," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities in New York.
He added that he did not think these figures, which are closely followed by the Federal Reserve, would prevent the Fed from making further cuts in short-term interest rates to keep a slackening economic expansion going as it approaches its fifth anniversary. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is to tell Congress next week what strategy the Fed agreed upon at its policy session at the end of January.
"We do not expect to see any intensification of wage pressures this year," Merrill Lynch told its clients today. "We believe that inflation will remain dormant during 1996. And we expect the Fed to continue to ease policy."
Some analysts, however, were at least mildly concerned about the final quarter's surge in benefit costs, even though Mr. Reich dismissed the increase as "almost entirely" bonuses and Joseph E. Stiglitz, the President's top economic adviser, said, "I don't see anything disquieting."
One analyst expressing concern was David C. Munro of High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm in Westchester County, N.Y. He said he regarded the increase as the latest in a series of indicators of budding wage pressures, including higher hourly earnings and anecdotal reports from the Federal Reserve and other sources about spot labor shortages.
Mr. Munro said bonuses should not be disregarded as aberrations or the exclusive province of Wall Street or the executive suite since they "are increasingly wage-like," with many more companies using them for flexibility now that increases in pay have been significantly "deautomated."
The 1.3 percent jump in fourth-quarter benefit costs, sharply higher than the four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the September quarter, lifted the 1995 total to 2.8 percent, the report showed. This was down from 3.4 percent in 1994 and was far from the 1988 peak of 7 percent.
Wages and salaries, which rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, the same as in the second and third quarters, advanced 2.9 percent for 1995, or about the same pace as has prevailed since a sharp deceleration in 1992.
Combining the components, total compensation costs were 2.9 percent higher for the year, slightly below the 3 percent rise in 1994 but the slimmest since records were started on a comparable basis in 1980. Merrill Lynch said this might be the smallest rise in labor compensation since the 1950's.
Higher compensation was more pronounced in service industries than in goods-producing industries, 3 percent versus 2.5 percent -- a reversal of 1994, when workers producing goods fared modestly better. Increases ranged from 2 percent at stores selling general merchandise to 5.4 percent for colleges and universities.
Among blue-collar workers, compensation gains ranged from 2.3 percent for machine operators, assemblers and inspectors to 3.3 percent for handlers, equipment cleaners, helpers and laborers.
Compensation of union members rose 3 percent, a bit higher than the 2.8 percent for nonunion workers; in service industries, union workers had a gain of 3.7 percent, compared with 2.9 percent for nonunion workers, but in goods-producing industries the rise for union workers, at 2.2 percent, trailed the 2.6 percent increase registered for nonunion employees.

HEADLINE: Report Warns That New York Area Could Decline

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The New York metropolitan region -- the nation's pre-eminent urban center, and a worldwide symbol of opportunity -- faces the threat of a long-term economic decline in the 21st century unless residents and politicians summon the will and resources to begin a multibillion-dollar campaign of transportation improvements, education reforms and urban rejuvenation, a major planning group said yesterday.
The report, based on a five-year study by the Regional Plan Association, a private research group based in Manhattan, looks ahead 24 years to the year 2020 and predicts two very different possible futures for the 31-county, three-state metropolitan area stretching from Litchfield, Conn., to central New Jersey. 
 One view features a bleak landscape of crumbling urban cores, increasingly isolated wealthy enclaves, transportation paralysis, deteriorating air and water quality and feeble economic growth. In the alternative vision, residents zip about in high-speed trains on a fully interconnected regional rail system patterned after the Paris Metro, the aging urban centers have been recaptured as places to live, work and play, and lifelong adult education and job banks connect the population to new opportunities in the global economy.
The report said that the first portrait would emerge as the region's future if current trends remained unchanged, and that making the second one a reality would require sacrifice, ingenuity and a rethinking of some of the region's most treasured tenets, from self-government in every small community to the historically arrogant self-identity that holds that the world will always beat a path to New York's door.
"It may be the last opportunity we have," the association's president, H. Claude Shostal, said at a news conference in lower Manhattan. "If we don't do it, we're going to be left behind."
As a small private organization, the Regional Plan Association has no power beyond the persuasiveness of its vision. But it has a history of imprinting that vision on the region, and it has connections. Its board of directors -- a list that ranges from academics like David C. Chang, president of Polytechnic University in Brooklyn, to Robert R. Kiley, former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority -- move in the upper circles of the region's business and politics.
While the authors of the report acknowledge that the governors of the three states have won office with an emphasis on cutting taxes, they say that such views are too much aimed at the next election or next budget and not at the long-term risk.
The association, the oldest urban planning group in the nation, has gazed ahead twice in this century, in 1929 and in 1968. Both of those studies concluded that harnessing uncontrolled growth was the New York region's gravest threat.
The new report starts from a fundamentally different place: the risk now, it states, is outright decline. That thought, even if only subconsciously adopted in the political and business communities, could reframe the debate about where the region is headed and how it will get there. The myth of New York as a tireless colossus, building and rebuilding itself through some untended machine of growth, is over, the plan's authors say.
"The issue is no longer how to manage growth, but how to find growth to manage," said the association's chairman, Gary C. Wendt, who is also the president and chief executive of the G.E. Capital Corporation in Stamford, Conn. "Our success is no longer guaranteed."
Another fundamentally changed assumption in the study concerns the suburbs. For the last 30 years, they were the engines of economic growth and job creation, as corporate office parks grew in the region's outer ring. But the deep recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's, and the weak recovery since then, have rendered those old distinctions moot. Every part of the region suffered just about equally; there was no immunity of place.
"It shattered the myth of suburban economies' being independent and isolated," Mr. Shostal said. "You can't hide now."
The globalization of the world economy, the deep recession from 1989 to 1992, and region's weak recovery since then provide the backdrop and context of the study. The report concludes, for example, that the lavish commitment by governments in competing world business capitals like Singapore and Paris are making the flaws of New York region's infrastructure all the more glaring.
Competition within the United States is becoming just as intense. In the decade from 1982 to 1992, for example, the report said that employment in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut region grew by the smallest percentage of any of the nation's 15 major metropolitan areas.
But the constant theme of the report is also that the region has immense strengths and half-fulfilled promises that if capitalized upon, would create strong competitive advantages. The system of commuter railroads and the New York City subway, for example, were built totally without coordination and planning by private developers in the 1800's and early 1900's. But the report says that only 25 new miles of track, much of it laid in bits and pieces around the region, would interconnect the various systems, allowing single-ticket travel of the sort that many major urban systems around the world have long since adopted.
Money is of course the great hurdle for the plan. The total capital costs, according to the report, would total $75 billion over 25 years. And while all three governors and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said generally supportive things today in videotaped comments played at the association's news conference, none embraced any new system of taxation to raise money.
Polling research by the association also concludes that residents would not trust government with all that new money anyway. Robert D. Yaro, the association's research director and chief planning officer, said that a majority of residents of the region, questioned in a poll last year, said they would be willing to support higher gasoline taxes, as long as the proceeds were dedicated to specific capital improvements. That led to the idea of a tristate infrastructure bank that would distribute the new revenue stream, insulated from political pressures.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CAUCUS;
Dole Ends the Race in Iowa As a Scalded Front-Runner

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Feb. 13

 BODY:
In his third outing in the Iowa caucuses, after more than three decades of tilling the political soil here, Senator Bob Dole of neighboring Kansas took only slightly more than a quarter of the votes Monday night, running powerfully only among older and wealthier voters, those who made up their minds a long time ago and those looking for Washington experience.
It was a dangerously narrow constituency for one who hopes to rally a disparate party in November. 
 An entrance poll conducted by the television networks and The Associated Press showed that among other groups whose backing Mr. Dole had sought, his performance was unimpressive. Moderate voters, for example, gave almost as many votes to Lamar Alexander, the former Governor of Tennessee, as to Mr. Dole.
A third of those who took part in the caucuses said the Senator's age -- at 73, he would be the oldest man ever elected President if he won this fall -- would hurt him in the White House.
Mr. Dole returned to New Hampshire, whose primary takes place a week from today, as a highly vulnerable front-runner. His 26 percent of the total Iowa vote was well below the 37 percent he won here against a smaller field in 1988, and slightly below his own purposely modest target of 28 percent for this year.
The other candidates finished as follows: Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, 23 percent; Mr. Alexander, 18 percent; Steve Forbes, the millionaire publisher, 10 percent; Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, 9 percent; Alan Keyes, an anti-abortion crusader, 7 percent; Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, 4 percent; Morry Taylor, a businessman, 1 percent, and Representative Robert K. Dornan of California, less than 1 percent.
In many ways, the outcome mirrored the one eight years ago, when the television evangelist Pat Robertson finished second to Mr. Dole with 25 percent and George Bush came in third with 19 percent. Mr. Alexander will now hope to do what Mr. Bush did in New Hampshire in 1988, when he vaulted from third place to first, overtaking Mr. Dole, and went on to win the Republican nomination and the Presidency.
Arguing that Mr. Buchanan was too divisive a candidate to be nominated, Mr. Alexander said with renewed vigor this morning that the race would come down to him and Mr. Dole, and that the Senator was "too old to be the first President of the next century." He repeated the mnemonic aid he has used for months: "A B C -- Alexander Beats Clinton."
The entrance poll suggested that Mr. Alexander had taken votes from Mr. Dole in the final stages of the Iowa campaign. About 40 percent of Mr. Alexander's backers said they had once considered supporting the Kansan. And 40 percent of his backers said they decided to vote for him in the final three days.
During that time, Mr. Alexander asserted that he had avoided negative campaigning, even though he ran an ad labeling Mr. Dole a Washington insider and Mr. Forbes a Wall Street insider, and accused his rivals of mudslinging.
Mr. Alexander, 55, who served as Secretary of Education in the Bush Administration, drew support from all segments of the party, although he did least well among those who called themselves strong conservatives. Of his backers, 34 percent said they were moderates, 46 percent described themselves as somewhat conservative and 12 percent said they considered themselves very conservative.
The lion's share of very conservative voters, who have risen to prominence in the Iowa Republican Party in recent years, went to Mr. Buchanan. He got 37 percent of their votes to 21 percent for Mr. Dole. Mr. Buchanan must now hope that he can emulate Ronald Reagan, who dramatically broadened his appeal in 1980 in moving from a second-place finish in Iowa to a victory in New Hampshire, rather than flaming out like Mr. Robertson eight years later, who never matched his Iowa showing.
Mr. Buchanan was full of fire, if hoarse of voice, in television appearances this morning, asserting that he alone could recapture for the Republicans this fall the voters who supported Ross Perot's third-party candidacy four years ago.
Mr. Buchanan argued that economic issues -- the loss of jobs to Mexico and Southeast Asia in particular -- are as important to his campaign as social issues. But the entrance poll showed that 62 percent of his Iowa supporters identified themselves as part of the religious right, and 74 percent of them said they backed a constitutional amendment to outlaw abortion. Over all, caucus participants split on such an amendment, with 46 percent supporting it and 44 percent opposing it.
Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, who backed Mr. Dole, said Mr. Buchanan was "sticking his head in the sand" in advocating American withdrawal from international trade agreements. Doing so would cripple Iowa's agricultural and industrial exporters, he said, "but people didn't focus on his economic message."
Some have suggested that Mr. Buchanan, who once wrote speeches for Richard M. Nixon, will find the going tougher in New Hampshire, where social issues are generally less salient than economic issues, especially taxes. In rebuttal, he pointed to his race against Mr. Bush in New Hampshire: "I almost beat the President of the United States in 1992 in eight weeks, without a nickel in my jeans."
But the state was in the throes of a recession, from which it has since emerged. Even then, Mr. Buchanan was unable to build on his New Hampshire showing in later tests.
Because he has almost unlimited resources and because his flat-tax plan has played well in New Hampshire, few were willing to write off Mr. Forbes just yet, but the survey suggested that his campaign themes failed to take hold in Iowa, despite a relentless, unprecedented $4 million television blitz.
About half the caucus participants, for example, said they preferred a flat tax to the present graduated income tax. But of those who backed a flat tax, Mr. Forbes won only 18 percent, about as many as Mr. Dole, even though Mr. Forbes built his campaign around the idea. Mr. Buchanan, who produced his own version of a flat tax relatively late in the game, got the support of 25 percent of the group.
Another favorite Forbes theme also appeared to have availed him little. He assiduously proclaimed his credentials as an outsider who would root out what he termed "the Washington culture" of bureaucracy and corruption, but when asked what decided their vote, only 7 percent of the caucus-goers said they sought someone who was not a career politician.
What did matter in Iowa, the entrance poll indicated, were conservative values, followed by an ability to beat President Clinton and experience in Washington, which was mentioned by 15 percent. So it could be said that twice as many people here rejected Mr. Forbes's anti-insider crusade as accepted it.
If Mr. Dole's support was concentrated among those more than 45 years of age and those with family incomes exceeding $75,000, it was geographically dispersed. Where he was best organized, he ran most strongly, whether in rural southeastern Iowa, industrial Waterloo in the north or Johnson County, which includes Iowa City and the University of Iowa.
Alone among the candidates, Mr. Dole is well organized in all of the important states that have yet to vote. But organization has proved less important, historically speaking, in primary contests than in the caucuses here.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE NEXT STEP;
DOLE OPENS DRIVE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE WITH NEW THEME

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 13

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole opened the seven-day sprint to the nation's first Republican primary here today by reaching for a new economic message tailored to the populism of Patrick J. Buchanan, who finished a close second to the Senator in the Iowa caucuses.
Appropriating a theme that worked for Mr. Buchanan in Iowa on Monday and in his challenge to President George Bush here four years ago, Mr. Dole attacked corporate greed and appealed for the support of blue-collar workers. It was a departure both for Mr. Dole and for the Republican Party, which historically caters more to well-heeled voters. 
 "Corporate profits are setting records and so are corporate layoffs," said Mr. Dole, looking tired and subdued as he stood before the State Legislature in Concord. "The bond market finished a spectacular year. But the real average hourly wage is 5 percent lower than it was a decade ago. Two years ago, family earnings were hit with the largest tax increase in the history of America."
As the candidates converged on New Hampshire, there was already a first casualty in the wake of the outcome of the Iowa caucuses. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas plans to announce on Wednesday that he will withdraw from the race, aides said.
Mr. Gramm had come on forcefully in last year's run-up to primary season, raising millions of dollars and building organizations in several states. But he was unable to translate those efforts into votes. He placed a dismal fifth in Iowa and was upset by Mr. Buchanan the week before in the Louisiana caucuses. [Article, page B9.]
By contrast, Mr. Buchanan today was savoring his rise to the top of the competition, while pressing forward with his economic themes. In Manchester, he told a crowd of about 250 reporters: "New Hampshire, like every other part of America, feels that sense of economic insecurity, economic stress. They are suffering, too, from wages that seem to go down as the Dow Jones hits 5600."
Until today, Mr. Dole's economic message was largely devoted to the need for a balanced Federal budget. But the unexpected strength of Mr. Buchanan in Iowa, and Mr. Dole's own less-than-decisive performance, seemed to spur the Senator to revise his appeal.
While the economic picture here has improved dramatically in this state in the last four years -- the unemployment rate was 3.2 percent in December, well below the national average of 5.6 percent -- Mr. Dole is clearly banking on the issue of the economy. When he took on Mr. Bush in 1992, Mr. Buchanan did best among voters to whom economic problems were of particular concern.
Mr. Buchanan, fighting a head cold and looking exhausted, accused Mr. Dole of taking his issues, and dismissed criticism from his opponents that he is too extreme to capture the nomination.
"How can my views be too extreme when Bob Dole is echoing me on every issue?" Mr. Buchanan asked at a midday news conference here. "We are now moving the national debate in the direction in which we have been trying to take America; the Republican Party is becoming a Buchanan party."
As the campaign shifted from the flatlands of Iowa to the rockier terrain of this state, the contenders adjusted not only their message on issues but to the altered state of the race.
The one candidate who was all smiles today was former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, who finished third in Iowa. After plodding anonymously along the campaign trail for more than a year, today was a day to bask in a newfound glare.
"Now that we've had this contest in Iowa, we know that the race will come down to Senator Dole and me," Mr. Alexander told a group of schoolchildren who greeted him in a hotel room here at 6:30 A.M., only four hours after he landed in New Hampshire.
At every stop, Mr. Alexander asserted that Iowans had responded to his upbeat message amid the blizzard of negative advertising in the state, particularly from the campaign of Steve Forbes, the publishing magnate who came in fourth. Even so, Mr. Alexander was broadcasting a commercial in New Hampshire that attacked Mr. Dole as "a Washington insider for 35 years" and Mr. Forbes as "a Wall Street insider his entire life."
Mr. Forbes did not travel to New Hampshire today, and instead returned home to New Jersey, where he spent the day in strategy meetings. Aides said he was also filming a new batch of commercials -- this time, positive ones.
The top three finishers in Iowa devoted much of the day jockeying for position. The Dole campaign sought to place itself as being in a one-on-one race with Mr. Buchanan. That is probably because Mr. Dole is battling Mr. Alexander for many of the same voters who are more moderate than Mr. Buchanan's backers. In addition, advisers to Mr. Dole said they believed he had far more appeal than Mr. Buchanan, who, polls show, has particularly high negative ratings.
Barely mentioning his narrow victory in Iowa, Mr. Dole raised the stakes for himself in this state. "Whoever wins next Tuesday in New Hampshire will probably be the Republican nominee," he said in remarks to a small gathering at a fire house in Goffstown.
The messages of the candidates who arrived in New Hampshire today seemed to reflect that voters in this state's Republican primary are generally more moderate than caucus-goers in Iowa, perhaps because independents here can vote in either party's primary. Four years ago, 35 percent of the Republican primary voters described their affiliation as independent, in a survey of voters leaving the polls.
Three-quarters of the voters in the Iowa caucuses described themselves as conservative, while four years ago in New Hampshire, polling showed that only 55 percent of primary voters considered themselves conservatives and 35 percent moderates.
On Monday, 35 percent of the caucus-goers in Iowa said they considered themselves part of the conservative Christian political movement, and Mr. Buchanan drew the largest share of those voters. But polls showed that only 9 percent of the Republican primary voters in New Hampshire in 1988 considered themselves fundamentalists or evangelical Christians.
That might explain why today, Mr. Buchanan repeatedly emphasized his economic message.
Behind their orchestrated events, campaigns were assessing how much money they had to compete here this week, and how much they would need to continue after New Hampshire.
Mr. Alexander spent much of the day on the telephone soliciting contributions, including a conference call with 250 supporters, each of whom pledged to raise $5,000 by the end of the week. His aides said they needed a quick infusion for the campaign to move South.
Mr. Buchanan, who is also scraping for money, said there was a surge in calls to his toll-free campaign number Monday night, from an average of 50-75 a day up to 1,200. "They do wonder whether we can win," he said of the callers. "But more and more are coming to believe that Pat Buchanan can be the next President of the United States."
Beyond the candidates, voters here were gearing for a final weeklong frenzy of campaigning. "Iowa said something like who ain't going to be President," said Eddie Barker, 66, a school bus driver in Concord. "Next week, we're going to tell you who is."
