SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 949 words

HEADLINE: White House Rebukes G.O.P. For Scuttling Nominee to Fed

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The White House, giving up on the nomination of Felix G. Rohatyn to be the Federal Reserve's vice chairman, attacked Congressional Republicans yesterday for blocking the appointment of an "obviously qualified" candidate, and poisoning the atmosphere in Washington.
Michael D. McCurry, President Clinton's press secretary, said the Republicans had engaged in cheap election-year politics, while Laura D'Andrea Tyson, director of the White House National Economic Council, took the criticism a step further, accusing the Republicans of opposing potential appointees simply because they failed to share conservative views. 
 "These are people with high credentials," Ms. Tyson said, referring to Mr. Rohatyn and also to Alicia H. Munnell, a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy, whom the White House decided not to nominate for a Fed seat after Republicans mounted a campaign against her.
"You don't have to agree with everything Ms. Munnell and Mr. Rohatyn said at every point in their lives," Ms. Tyson said, "but there is no question they have the capability and capacity to serve the country on the Federal Reserve."
A similar theme -- an increasingly partisan system that no longer thrives on the give-and-take of forthright debate -- was struck by Mr. Rohatyn, the 67-year-old New York investment banker, in an interview yesterday.
Having asked President Clinton on Monday to no longer consider him as a potential nominee, Mr. Rohatyn offered an angry view of the evolution of national politics.
During the 1960's and 70's, Mr. Rohatyn noted, he had headed commissions in New York that helped nurse the New York Stock Exchange through a crisis and saved the city from bankruptcy. In each case, he said, he had worked with people of strongly divergent political views and ideology, all pulling successfully toward common goals. But such cooperation, he said, was no longer welcomed in Washington.
"What troubles me most is not the fact that I am not going to be vice chairman," he said. "What is important is the inability to reach across ideological differences in order to have a rational dialogue about hugely important economic issues."
Republican lawmakers defended their actions, arguing that Mr. Rohatyn's views were too far outside what they considered the economic mainstream. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, chairman of the Banking Committee, said "the vast majority" of his committee's members simply did not support the Rohatyn nomination.
Mr. Rohatyn, a managing director of Lazard Freres & Company, had sought the Fed nomination. He enlisted people in Washington to help him in his quest, among them Howard H. Baker Jr., the former Republican Senate leader and chief of staff for President Ronald Reagan.
But with Senator Connie Mack of Florida acting as spokesman, Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee -- which must approve nominations to the Fed's seven-member board of governors -- made clear to the Administration their adamant objections to Mr. Rohatyn.
"At this point," Mr. Rohatyn remarked yesterday, "I would say to you that the charm of public office is considerably diminished in my mind, and the charm of the private sector considerably enhanced."
Until the early 1980's, the Fed vice chairmanship often went to men more closely linked to the central bank's chairman than to the Administration. That changed with President Reagan's appointment of Preston Martin as Paul A. Volcker's vice chairman, ushering in an era in which the vice chairman emerged as the Administration's point man at the Fed. Mr. Martin and his successors occasionally clashed with Mr. Volcker and with Mr. Greenspan, his successor.
Alan S. Blinder, a Princeton University economist who left the vice chairmanship when his term expired two weeks ago, was in this tradition, and Mr. Rohatyn had promised to be a similar Administration voice.
Now the White House is in a quandary. Mr. Greenspan's second four-year term expires on March 2, and Mr. Clinton is widely expected to renominate him. But the President had hoped to package the Greenspan nomination with a vice chairmanship of his choice.
With Mr. Rohatyn's candidacy dead, however, Mr. Clinton could be forced to either leave the vice chairmanship vacant for the time being or to nominate someone more acceptable to the Republicans -- and perhaps more in sync with Mr. Greenspan's views.
The President met yesterday afternoon with his top economic advisers and asked them to come up with a new list of names, both for the vice chairmanship and for another Fed governor's post that is vacant, Administration officials said.
The issue that sank Mr. Rohatyn, more than any other, was economic growth. He has described himself as conservative -- "very conservative," he said yesterday -- but nevertheless an advocate for greater economic growth than Mr. Greenspan might favor. Without a more robust economy, he said, "balancing the budget is a fantasy and avoiding serious social strains is a fantasy."
That view drew sharp criticism from Senator Mack, who is also chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. In memos prepared by Joint Economic Committee staff members, Mr. Rohatyn was portrayed as insufficiently concerned about inflation and as likely to bring "unsophisticated" economic views to Fed policy-making.
"There was a feeling among the Republicans, led by Senator Mack, whom I have never met, that my views represent a danger to the Fed and to the integrity of the nation," Mr. Rohatyn said, adding, "I am open to discussion on a lot of issues, and I have great difficulty living in a world of absolutes -- which is where we seem to be heading."

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 750 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: BOWING OUT;
Poor Showings In 2 Contests Lead Gramm To Withdraw

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 13

 BODY:
Reeling from back-to-back defeats in Louisiana and Iowa, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas decided today to quit the race for the Republican Presidential nomination, ending an extravagantly planned and financed campaign and making him the first casualty of the primary season.
Mr. Gramm was on the verge of throwing his support behind Senator Bob Dole, people close to both men said tonight. The Kansas Senator was to speak with Mr. Gramm by phone Wednesday morning. 
 Mr. Gramm's decision, which he is to announce at a news conference on Wednesday, came after he placed fifth in Monday's Iowa caucuses, and second to Patrick J. Buchanan in the Louisiana caucuses, which had led most political experts to believe that his candidacy had failed.
Mr. Gramm canceled a series of campaign events today. He declined to say directly what he had in mind, but left little doubt that he considered his campaign's prospects bleak.
"When you run fifth in Iowa, an important state, you would have to be brain-dead not to take a look at where you are and what you're doing," Mr. Gramm told reporters in Iowa today before leaving for this state. "One of the things that we're going to try to do this afternoon and tonight is take a look at where we are."
A senior Gramm aide said tonight that Mr. Gramm's chances had essentially collapsed in the week after he was upset in the Feb. 6 Louisiana caucuses by Mr. Buchanan. That was a state that Mr. Gramm had boasted he would win right up until the night of the caucusing, thus elevating what otherwise might have been a passing political event into a well-covered embarrassment.
Gramm aides said that until the caucuses in Louisiana, their polling had shown the Senator in "a very strong position for second," in Iowa, a state where he had always wanted to do well. "We felt very confident," an aide said. "Then Louisiana took the wind right out of our sails."
Although there was some sentiment in the Gramm campaign to hang on through next Tuesday's primary here, in the hope that Mr. Dole's campaign might stumble and give Mr. Gramm one last opening, in the end the Texas Senator's advisers concluded that was untenable.
"You can't finish second in Louisiana, fifth in Iowa and even third in New Hampshire and hope to keep raising money," the aide said.
Mr. Gramm's withdrawal came almost a year to the day after he formally announced his candidacy at Texas A & M University, where he was an economics professor for 12 years.
His departure is particularly striking because, on paper at least, he had seemed to have everything in place from the day he announced his candidacy.
He was a Senator, with flush campaign treasury -- he raised $21.1 million last year -- and a crafted conservative economic and social message which seemed perfectly attuned for voters who dominate the Republican primary process.
But there were flaws to the strategy, not the least of which was that Mr. Gramm was a candidate who was not helped by exposure. He had a plodding style that his own aides discovered during their campaign research was more likely to irritate than to ignite voters.
Mr. Gramm seemed to become increasingly concerned about this as his standing in the polls stagnated and other candidates vaulted past him. Mr. Gramm asked reporters whether they found him arrogant.
On a political level, Mr. Gramm's attempt to present himself as the candidate best able to unite social and economic conservatives was put to the test in Iowa, and it failed.
Mr. Buchanan fanned persistent doubts among Christian conservatives about Mr. Gramm's commitment to outlawing abortion. The strong second-place showing by Mr. Buchanan left Mr. Gramm with little hope of claiming the conservative mantle.
Finally, Mr. Gramm seems to have been betrayed by his own political calculus as well. He employed a novel approach to winning the nomination, attempting to win early notice by tending the fields outside of New Hampshire and Iowa. He invested efforts in states that had not before played a prominent role in the selection process, including Louisiana, Arizona and Delaware.
But he lost Louisiana. And he irritated political leaders in both New Hampshire and Iowa, who are protective of their early places in the political selection system.
Mr. Gramm's expected withdrawal would leave the race to four main contenders: Mr. Dole, Mr. Buchanan, Lamar Alexander, the former Governor of Tennessee, who finished third in Iowa, and Steve Forbes, who finished fourth.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Richter Awaits Start Of His Second Season

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

DATELINE: RYE, N.Y., Feb. 13

 BODY:
Mike Richter stopped several hundred pucks in practice today at Playland Ice Casino. Then he walked into the Ranger locker room and stumbled awkwardly over the big leg pads of Glenn Healy, who has started the last 16 games in goal.
A few minutes later, Coach Colin Campbell purposefully walked up to Richter's locker and, with theatrical solemnity, asked Richter if he was ready to play Thursday night against the Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden. 
 "I can play tonight," said Richter.
Much of this was for show. The pratfall over the pads is a running gag between the two goalies, who share a limited amount of space in the same corner of the room. The questioning by the coach was staged for the benefit of reporters who had been peppering Richter with the same sort of questions.
Richter, who has been sidelined for seven weeks with a serious groin injury, is expected to dress Thursday night when the Rangers try to equal the franchise record of 24 consecutive games without defeat at home. It isn't certain, however, if he will be the starter.
"I feel good, I feel really good," Richter said. "I'm getting my timing back and I'm getting strong. I can come back whenever called upon. I thought I would play last weekend, but we held off, and I think that was a good idea.
"With an injury like this, you have to be absolutely certain it's not going to be damaged. A'd, even under those circumstances, it could still happen."
Richter said the groin muscle "actually pulled right off the bone where it connects" when he made a save in a victory at Edmonton.
"It's high up, every movement originates from there, it seems, it's such a central area," Richter said. "It's about as debilitating as you get for a goaltender."
Campbell said he wouldn't make a decision on his starter until Wednesday. "We don't have to push it, so why should we?" he said. "Wait until it's 100 percent. You always have to play through scar tissue and push it that last mile. With any player, you can't really push it until you get into the game. He doesn't have to play unless he goes in as a backup in the first one, two, three, four games."
During today's spirited practice, which Campbell called "a goal-tender's practice," Richter faced drills during which columns of teammates tested him with wrist shots, backhanders and slap shots. When Richter quickly slid across to make a save on Luc Robitaille's rebound, the captain Mark Messier led the cheers by banging his stick on the boards and smiling.
When Richter skated the puck out toward the blue line, seeking to pass it, a few teammates yelled "Go! Go!" and "Shoot! Shoot!" But he declined to take any unnecessary chances.
Before the injury, Richter had a record of 19-8-3 with a goals-against average of 2.62. Following Sunday's 6-2 victory in Tampa Bay, Healy is 14-5-7 and 2.79.
"The biggest key for me is patience," Richter said. "When you see the light at the end of the tunnel, you start kind of sprinting for it a little bit."
During the first two weeks of the rehabilitation, he spent two hours a day in the hyperbaric chamber, which is phought to speed the healing process. He managed to finish a book called "Jihad vs. McWorld," (Times Books, 1995).
"It's about the globalization of world economics," said Richter.
Last summer, Richter studied existentialist authors at Columbia, calling it a "nice change of gears" and "incredibly interesting" after a disappointing season.
Kierkegaard, Camus and Sartre. Sounds like one of the forward lines from the old Quebec Nordiques.

HEADLINE: Association Benefited From Links To Politics

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Since 1929, when it issued its first master plan for the 31 counties in and around New York City, the Regional Plan Association has provided long-range blueprints for the region. Though it had no money to carry out those plans, it did hold the attention of governors, mayors, developers and corporate planners who could carry out its vision.
The association, which now has a staff of 25 and an annual budget of $2.5 million provided by dozens of companies and foundations, was formed in 1923 by 12 prominent New York City business executives to focus on the region's future. Fortuitously, that group included Frederic Delano, the uncle of Franklin Delano Roosevelt. 
 Historians say its first plan, released in 1929, months before the stock market crash, succeeded in providing a map that guided road, bridge, tunnel and airport construction and parkland acquisition for the next four decades. Predicting an era of sweeping economic expansion, the plan called for commuter parkways, interstate expressways and new rail services to connect New York City to its rapidly growing suburbs.
Although the experts now point to flaws in the 1929 plan -- saying it overemphasized road construction and its recommendation for large-scale railroad construction was never adopted -- its successes are attributed to the political allegiences it inspired.
President Franklin D. Roosevelt, for instance, had ties to the plan from its inception through his uncle and as the former Governor of New York. When he formed the the National Planning Board in 1936 under another New Yorker, Interior Secretary Harold L. Ickes, the New York region received a disproportionate amount of Federal aid through the Public Works Administration.
In a 30-year building spree, Robert Moses, the legendary master builder, marshalled city, state and Federal money into construction of the Hutchinson River Parkway in Westchester County, the Northern State and Southern State parkways on Long Island, and the creation of Bear Mountain State Park and Jones Beach State Park.
And Austin Tobin, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, presided over construction of large parts of the George Washington Bridge, the Lincoln Tunnel and Newark Airport. Both men relied heavily on the 1929 Regional Plan to justify their developments and acquistions.
In 1968, when the Regional Plan Association issued its second master plan, it proclaimed a historic turn for the region. No longer was there a need for such sweeping growth; it emphasized the limiting of suburban sprawl and excessive reliance on cars.
Among the reccommendations in 1968 were that development and jobs be concentrated in New York City and several suburban hubs that were already served by rail lines or major highways -- Newark, White Plains, Stamford and others.
Although the second master plan failed to prompt any new government controls on development, it captured the attention of many of the region's corporate planners. Persuaded by the plan, and using it to help local win zoning changes, companies like the G.T.E. Corporation and Champion International moved their headquarters from Manhattan to Stamford in early 1970's, and Johnson & Johnson built its headquarters in downtown New Brunswick, N.J.
These days, the association still has ties to political leaders: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's mother was a member of its board 1977 to 1989.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Ekes Out a Gain But Stocks Generally Fall
Broad stock indexes dropped from their record levels, pulled down by a slump in semiconductor stocks. But the Dow Jones industrial average gained slightly, to its seventh record in a row. The spurt has lifted the average 4.2 percent in the last week. The Dow ended up 1.08 points, at 5,601.23, while the S.& P. 500 index eased 0.94, to 660.51. [Page D8.]
 
Compuserve to Restore Access
Compuserve will restore worldwide access to most of the 200 sex-related computer data bases that it had blocked under pressure from German prosecutors. The company said it wanted to leave Internet censorship up to individuals, and would provide subscribers with software that could selectively block any material a user found offensive. [A1.]
 
High Pay for Apple's Chief
While the financial future of Apple Computer may be in flux, that of Gilbert F. Amelio, the company's new chairman, is secure. A compensation expert said his pay package would range from $10 million to $12 million a year for the next five years, and could go much higher if the stock price improved. [D5.]
 
Jacor Gets More Radio Stations
With the radio industry deregulated, Jacor agreed to buy Citicasters for $770 million. With the 19 stations from Citicasters, Jacor will have 54 stations in 13 cities. [D7.]
 
Top RJR Nabisco Officers to Testify
The top two executives of RJR Nabisco have been ordered to testify in a lawsuit involving Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn, who are pushing for a spinoff of the company's food business from its tobacco operations. [D4.]
 
Kerkorian's Single-Mindedness
Kirk Kerkorian could have had a seat on Chrysler's board, but gave the job to a deputy. The episode shows how the billionaire investor was more eager to see Chrysler's stock climb than to oversee the business. [D4.]
 
Meager Raises for Workers
American workers' overall compensation rose 2.9 percent last year -- the skimpiest increase since at least 1980, the Labor Department reported. The gain barely kept pace with inflation, at 2.5 percent. [D2.]
 
Equitable's Chief Plans to Retire
Richard H. Jenrette, who revived the fortunes of the Equitable Companies, will retire as chairman and chief executive, prompting a series of executive changes at the insurer and at its investment-banking subsidiary, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. [D4.]
 
Threat to New York's Eminence
The New York region faces the threat of a long-term economic decline, a planning study found, unless residents and politicians summon the resources to begin a multibillion-dollar campaign of transportation improvements, education reforms and urban rejuvenation. [A1.]
 
Joan Collins, Author, Wins
A Manhattan jury found that Random House must compensate the actress Joan Collins for a manuscript that its editors declared unreadable and unpublishable. Publishing executives had watched the case closely. [A1.]
 
Not Too Late to Book a Room
Hotel rooms in Atlanta are all but sold out for the summer Olympics, but thousands of rooms are still available in private houses, apartments and condominiums. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D6.]
 
Chanel Pushes for Younger Users
Chanel is spending $10 million to market its new fragrance, Allure. Ads feature smiling faces in their 20's, including the first black woman to appear in Chanel fragrance advertising. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

NEW YORK CITY
 
Jury Sides With Joan Collins
 
A Manhattan jury said that Random House has to compensate the actress-author Joan Collins for a manuscript that its editors have already declared to be unreadable and unpublishable. [Page A1.] 

Review Faults Care at Woodhull
 
A significant number of problems in deliveries at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center can be traced to mistakes or poor care by the hospital, a state review has found. But overall, the study found little difference in the quality of delivery room care between New York City's 11 public hospitals and their private affiliates. [B1.]
 
Repeal Sought on Shelter Rules
 
The Pataki administration is planning to eliminate an array of regulations that have long been used to force New York City to meet fire, safety and health standards in its shelters for single homeless adults, state officials said. [B5.]
 
3 Are Killed in Queens Fire
 
A 3-year-old girl and two adults died when flames dashed through a three-story house in South Jamaica, Queens. [B2.]
 
Growth of the No-Frills Grocery
 
A new kind of grocery store, a no-frills warehouse-style emporium meant to convey a real marketplace atmosphere, is emerging and thriving in Manhattan. Markets like Fairway, Gourmet Garage and the Vinegar Factory have been expanding by opening new branches, enlarging their current locations or both. The Living Section. [C1.]
 
REGION
 
Warning of Regional Decline
 
The New York metropolitan region faces the threat of a long-term economic decline in the 21st century unless residents and politicians summon the will and resources to begin a multibillion-dollar campaign of transportation improvements, education reforms and urban rejuvenation, a planning group said. [A1.]
 
N.J. Transit Ends Split Shift
 
New Jersey Transit said that it was no longer scheduling the type of nighttime split shift worked by an engineer who was killed in last Friday's train crash, and was considering doing away with all similar shifts in the wake of questions about the safety of such schedules. [B1.]
 
For Love of Community Theater
 
Across the suburbs, hundreds of actors and scores of directors and technicians are addicted to the footlights, working free or for a comparative pittance in a circuit of more than 60 community theaters. And while they may be teachers or salespeople during the day, most have worked in professional theater and make community theater a year-round second career. [B1.]

The day after Governor Pataki became just the second New York governor in this century to have a veto overridden, his critics, supporters and advisers alike agreed that he had chosen not to use all of his powers to prevent the Legislature's vote. News Analysis. [B1.]
 
Replacing Bradley in Senate
 
A crucial race for the United States Senate heated up as Richard A. Zimmer, a Republican Congressman, formally announced that he would seek the seat being vacated by Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat who decided not to seek a fourth term. [B4.]
 
Helping Out With 'Be Mine'
 
Bill Schifrin has sold thousands of rings in nearly half a century. He thinks his rings are lucky, since people approach him on the street to show them off years later. Repeat business is not a sign of success in his trade. About New York by David Gonzalez. [B4.]
 
A Weekend to Die For (or From)
 
Two 30-year-old lawyers from Syosset, L.I. -- far too embarrassed to give their last names -- felt compelled to check out the Concord Resort Hotel's 48-Hour Fun Fest Weekend for Singles after finding themselves unattached, again, for Valentine's Day. "My mother made us," one of the lawyers said. Our Towns by Evelyn Nieves. [B4.]

A sprawling school district in Dutchess County in New York voted Monday to hire Education Alternatives Inc., as a budget consultant. In January, Education Alternatives lost the last of three contracts it had with public school districts when the Board of Education in Hartford said it was ending the nation's first experiment in a private company's helping to manage an entire school district. [B12.]

The White House, giving up on the nomination of Felix G. Rohatyn, the 67-year-old New York investment banker, to be the Federal Reserve's vice chairman, attacked Congressional Republicans for blocking the appointment of an "obviously qualified" candidate. Business Day. [D1.]

LENGTH: 591 words

HEADLINE: Dancing to Buchanan's Tune

 BODY:
As the endless caravans of Republican Presidential candidates spread out through New Hampshire this week, it is hard to reconcile this party with the finely tuned election machine that took over Congress a little over a year ago. Bob Dole has made being front-runner look like a dance competition as he tries to pick up the beat from Pat Buchanan. Lamar Alexander rides a new momentum, courtesy of the 17,000 Iowa Republicans who gave him a third-place showing in Monday night's caucuses. Steve Forbes lost, at least temporarily, his status as the leading Anybody But Dole. Having spent more than $400 per voter to come in fourth, Mr. Forbes will not qualify for any awards as investor of the week.
The true message of Iowa may be that the Republicans preferred watching the "Chicago Hope" lobotomy episode to supporting any of the options offered up on their plate. Fewer than 100,000 voters -- down from 120,000 in 1988 -- turned out to decide who would get a lift and who, like Phil Gramm, would vanish into the shadows. A bigger crowd showed up for the "Pocahontas" premiere in Central Park. 
 Every election, however, has its story. Iowa's is that Pat Buchanan now owns the social conservative wing of the Republican Party, while the moderates are casting about desperately, flinging their allegiance from one Dole substitute to another. Among the candidates still standing as the New Hampshire primary approaches, Pat Buchanan is the only red-meat orator. That can be important to the Republicans, who are slowly evolving into the party of preference for male voters. A certain reek of testosterone on the stump is a valuable com modity, especially when coupled with Mr. Buchanan's swaggering presence.
He is still the darling of the religious right, but this season Mr. Buchanan's primary message is a sort of economic nationalism. He rails at immigration, the United Nations and Wall Street big shots who give American jobs to 70-cent-an-hour workers in Singapore. His solutions are high tariffs, protected industry and closing the border. The pitch worked so well in Iowa that yesterday in New Hampshire Mr. Dole discovered that he too was worried about corporate greed, blue-collar layoffs and U.N. threats to American sovereignty. Give the majority leader another few days of bad polls and he will be disowning Nafta and denouncing high quarterly earnings as a threat to the traditional values he learned as a boy in Kansas.
Mr. Buchanan's mix of xenophobic populism and social conservatism seems threatening to the coalition of well-off suburbanites and blue-collar workers that has been the Republicans' key to victory in recent years. Ronald Reagan pioneered the approach, tailoring his economic program to the business community while he won the hearts of the working class with issues like abortion, school prayer and affirmative action.
But poke Mr. Buchanan and you find yet another Republican supply-sider who thinks that what this country needs is a lower inheritance tax. When he is not raising up tariff walls, the Beltway's answer to Huey Long is conjuring up his own flat tax, capital gains break and dividend tax repeal.
The New Hampshire voters, who have a cornucopia of tax-cut plans to choose from next week, may wind up as confused as the voters in Iowa, where only 18 percent of those who favored a flat tax wound up voting for Steve Forbes. That is the most intriguing statistic of the campaign to date. Did the television ads not work, or was it the old Forbes charisma that kept them away in droves?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

LENGTH: 1195 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Deficit Looks Tiny as Issue

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
For nearly two years, the Republican economic rallying cry has been loud, insistent and single-minded: The biggest problem ailing the American economy is the Federal budget deficit, and the country cannot prosper until it is wiped out. But a Presidential campaign season has a way of rewriting political agendas, and Republicans have learned that what once seemed to play well in Washington does not ring many bells elsewhere.
In recent weeks, a visitor could sit through Rotary Club luncheons in Iowa or New Hampshire and barely hear mention of the deficit. And suddenly a struggle is on to redefine the party's economic priorities, to choose between the shrink-the-Government approach that House Republicans have championed since the 1994 midterm elections and the economic growth messages that Republican candidates for President seem to believe are what the voters want to hear in the 1996 race. 
 Indeed, the only idea that Patrick J. Buchanan and Steve Forbes have in common is to treat the deficit as something akin to the dirty remnants of a big snowstorm -- an eyesore that will melt away once the country changes its economic climate. And now even Senator Bob Dole, jolted into new tactics by Mr. Buchanan's strong finish in the Iowa caucuses on Monday, is shifting gears. After talking for weeks about the economic elixir of a balanced budget, Mr. Dole began talking yesterday about stagnant wages and corporate layoffs, the populist issues that have propelled Mr. Buchanan's campaign.
Mr. Buchanan's message about the budget deficit is right out of the supply-side textbooks: "When you get good jobs that put $30 or $40 an hour in people's pockets, you solve the deficit. No one can tell me that the problems of the Federal deficit and the loss of these high-paying jobs are unrelated."
In the week before the Iowa caucuses, even supporters of Mr. Dole and Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, the two candidates who built their entire economic platforms around balanced budgets, acknowledged that they were failing to address the anxieties workers feel about job insecurity and declining real incomes.
Speaking recently in Portsmouth, N.H., just before his last push in Iowa, Mr. Dole never mentioned those issues, even when he had the opportunity. Instead, opening a biotechnology laboratory, he recounted his role in the budget process and compared his insider's knowledge of Washington to a corporate engineer's understanding of "how to put together all those pipes and make something useful come out." That drew tepid applause.
"I'm surprised that he has been unable to talk about real economic issues," Bob Wynn, a Portsmouth businessman who has abandoned Mr. Dole for Mr. Forbes, said after listening to the majority leader speak to the Rotary Club. "They don't seem to be his primary concern."
Until his shift in tactics yesterday, Mr. Dole had consistently declined to change the nature of his message or talk about economic strategy in anything other than vague generalities. He never mentioned corporate downsizings, or trade accords like the North American Free Trade Agreement, which he supported. And whenever he was asked about specific proposals like Mr. Forbes's flat tax, he would briefly discuss the pluses and minuses and then declare that Congress should hold hearings.
"We're trying to talk about our issues, not theirs," said David Carney, a New Hampshire coordinator for Mr. Dole. But Mr. Carney conceded that Mr. Buchanan and his message were "stronger here than most people think."
Mr. Buchanan maintains that the Congressional Republicans have focused on the wrong issues. "Let's face it, people want some romance and drama in their politics," he said recently in between campaign stops in Iowa, where he railed against the exporting of jobs to China and Mexico and what he portrayed as Nafta's evils. "So what has this party spent the past year talking about?"
Then, with a long laugh, and using the abbreviation Washington insiders fling around for the Congressional Budget Office, he answered his own question: "A balanced budget in seven years based on C.B.O. numbers."
"Now, who outside of wonk-land in Washington knows what C.B.O. numbers are?" he continued. "Balanced budgets are not something you go to the barricades for. But if you talk about losing national sovereignty or creating an America that once again makes radios and TV's and becomes the world's manufacturing powerhouse, people come out of their chairs."
It is too early to tell whether Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Forbes will force a broad change in Republican economic strategy. But if Mr. Dole continues to pursue his rivals' themes, then a shift seems inevitable, particularly now that Mr. Gramm has faded from the race.
"There is a kind of quiet rethinking among Republicans about whether balancing the budget is enough of a message," said William Kristol, the editor of The Weekly Standard, a conservative magazine, who is one of the party's more influential strategists. "Whatever one thinks of the Forbes and Buchanan plans, they do address the wage stagnation problems, the job uncertainties. They have very different solutions, but each is addressing the concerns of middle-class America in ways that Bob Dole's balanced-budget talk does not."
But Mr. Kristol added that he had reservations about following either Mr. Forbes's strategy or Mr. Buchanan's too zealously. "The flat tax and protectionism are both political traps for the party," he said. "The question is whether Dole or Alexander can develop some alternative message about economic growth."
One quandary for Mr. Dole is whether a shift to a new agenda resembling those of his rivals could look credible. In the Senate, he has been a traditional free-trader, arguing against exactly the kind of steps Mr. Buchanan advocates: tariffs on imports from Asia, a halt to immigration for the next five years, renunciation of American participation in the World Trade Organization. (Mr. Dole struck the deal with President Clinton in late 1994 that assured passage of the global trade accord that created the W.T.O. as the arbiter of world trading rules.)
And after championing an ever smaller Federal Government -- which is what the balanced-budget issue was all about -- Mr. Dole could have problems advocating an activist agenda of retraining programs to aid distressed workers; his tendency is to advocate market solutions.
"He is really in a squeeze, because he needs Buchanan's supporters and yet he knows that he can't move too much into that turf," one of Mr. Clinton's political advisers said recently, clearly enjoying the moment.
He may have little choice: New Hampshire is Mr. Buchanan's strongest ground. While the state has enjoyed an exporting boom, some of its biggest high-tech employers have shipped jobs abroad. That makes the state fertile ground for Mr. Buchanan's stock speech about "corporate executioners" who "worship at the altar of efficiency" and lay off American workers.
Mr. Dole does not yet have economic applause lines like that. But there is every indication that his speechwriters will be drafting them in the next few days.

HEADLINE: Highlights of the Report by the Regional Plan Association: Work Force;
Advocating Full Participation

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Access to lifelong adult education and retraining in the rapidly changing world of work will be central to prosperity in the next century, the plan contends. But shifting population patterns will also mean that minority residents and immigrants -- the fastest-growing segment of the population -- will need to be helped past the barriers of language and discrimination that now hinder their full participation.
 The plan thus advocates two tracks that on some levels appear to conflict. It says that strenuous efforts must be made to help immigrants and minority group members assimilate into the mainstream economy through education, job training and the learning of English. But at the same time, it urges recognition and encouragement of the informal economy that operates in many ethnic neighborhoods off the tax rolls and often in violation of various laws. 
 The plan also envisions a new kind of job information network that would help poor inner-city residents learn about job opportunities, and a campaign to push for immigration changes that would encourage more skilled immigrants with work-related visas to move to the region. A regional council of business, government and community leaders should be formed to guide the creation of a lifelong learning system, the plan says. THOMAS J. LUECK

HEADLINE: Highlights of the Report by the Regional Plan Association: Centers;
Strengthening The Urban Cores

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The long-term vitality of the region as a whole is inextricably tied to the health of its urban downtowns, from the central business district of midtown Manhattan to the urban cores of Bridgeport, Conn., and Newark, the Regional Plan Association said in its report. These business centers must not only be desirable places to live and work in the 21st century, but must also be better linked with each other through a more interconnected transit system.
Lower Manhattan and the financial services centers in Jersey City and Long Island City, Queens, must all be better connected by rail service, the plan maintains, to assure the region's pre-eminence as a global financial center. Growth must be channeled into the downtown areas throughout the region to preserve open space, reduce transportation needs and create jobs. 
 This so-called centers campaign would cost about $17 billion, according to the plan, with most of that money going to housing initiatives to encourage moderate-income home ownership in these downtown areas. Improving the housing stock for moderate-income buyers would strengthen these centers economically, the plan contends, as big corporations in the region continue to retool into smaller, leaner organizations that depend on the labor that these residential areas can provide.
Historic preservation and encouragement of the arts will further strengthen the centers, but the plan also calls for gradually encouraging companies to locate in the urban downtowns. KIRK JOHNSON

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Is it science or voodoo? Seeking economics' true role.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
GEORGE BUSH had a problem with the vision thing, which helped seal his fate as a one-term President. Economists have a similar problem, contend Robert Heilbroner and William Milberg, colleagues at the New School for Social Research and authors of "The Crisis of Vision in Modern Economic Thought" (Cambridge University Press). And while the voters haven't specifically been asked what they think of economists, they have indirectly expressed their views on the subject by bolstering the fortunes of Pat Buchanan and Steve Forbes, Republican candidates who have made campaign issues of their contempt for mainstream economics.
Many practitioners see their point. The annual meeting of the American Economic Association last month was dominated by existential hand-wringing, only partly induced by the decline in undergraduate economics majors and the collapse in demand for newly minted economists in both business and academia. 
 It is far from clear, though, that many would agree with the Heilbroner-Milberg prescription for redemption: an acknowledgment that economics is less a science than a running dog to capitalist ideology, along with a new focus on making government work as the defender of capitalism from its own excesses.
Macroeconomics, the study of what makes whole economies tick and what the public generally identifies as economics, is plainly in trouble. Fiscal fine-tuning to keep the economy on an even course, built around the ideas of John Maynard Keynes, reigned supreme in the 1960's -- it was Richard M. Nixon, after all, who said "we are all Keynesians now." But the failure of the economics establishment to cope with the oil shocks of the 1970's and the subsequent bouts of stagflation opened Keynesianism to challenges from which it has never recovered.
In what at first appeared to be a drive for a new grand synthesis, economists led by Robert Lucas of the University of Chicago tried to reconcile beliefs about the causes and cures for unemployment and inflation with the likely behavior of individuals and businesses. What they ended up with was a recipe for nihilism.
In some cases "rational expectations" models predicted that the private sector response would fully offset government policy initiatives -- a tax cut today, for example, would lead individuals to save more to cover their share of the higher taxes needed in the future to pay interest on the Federal debt. In other cases, rational expectations models suggest that the private sector response could even be perverse, exacerbating a problem that Government policy was designed to solve.
Consider the implications: if the reactions of private markets to government intervention are inherently fluky, there was little basis for predicting the future and virtually none for fine-tuning the economy. "They destroyed macroeconomics," concludes James Tobin of Yale, who, like Robert Lucas, won a Nobel prize for investigating the Keynesian framework.
To Mr. Heilbroner and Mr. Milberg this is cause for abandoning the pretense that economics is a science and accepting the role of pragmatic guardian of The System -- what they call "a general recognition of the need for expanded public intervention to protect the capitalist order from the difficulties and dangers with which it will have to contend." But to Mr. Tobin, one does not follow from the other.
While he agrees that it is reasonable for economics to serve as the superego of capitalism, there remains a conventional job to be done -- a job that depends on economists using scientific methods to make decisions about what sort of intervention works, when. And while many academics and the journals they write for are deep into navel-gazing, "economists at the Congressional Budget Office, the White House and the Federal Reserve still have to come up with forecasts and recommendations for government policy," Mr. Tobin says, "and they still must use modified Keynesian models to do it."
What's more, he argues, the predictions do a whole lot better than a roll of the dice.
The world's opinion of economists has certainly changed since the heady days of the 1960's. While it was tempting to think of economics as an exact science in the making, macroeconomics is, and always was, a messier matter. Policy economics is a compromise: guesswork educated by theory and statistical evidence.
But there is a curious symbiosis between critics of the right, who see the limitations of Keynesian economics as a rationale for abandoning interventionist policy, and critics of the left like Mr. Heilbroner and Mr. Milberg, who see them as a rationale for abandoning economists' pretense to objectivity and worship of science.
Economics is a tent big enough to accommodate both Robert Lucas and Robert Heilbroner. But the center ring is still occupied by economists who worry about the implications of lower interest rates or bigger budget deficits, and advise accordingly.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Political Void in Italy Drives Up The Mark, Hurting the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The German mark strengthened yesterday on the heels of Italian political problems, dragging down the dollar in the process.
The dollar fell against the mark as the German currency and the Swiss franc benefited from Italy's inability to form a new government. The mark, Europe's strongest economy, and the Swiss franc typically attract investment in times of political and economic uncertainty. 
 The mark's strength drew enough support from the dollar to leave it lower against the Japanese yen, as well. Big buyers declined to support the dollar.
Political uncertainty in Italy increased after the Prime Minister-designate, Antonio Maccanico, abandoned a two-week effort to form a government, leaving the country in yet another leadership crisis. The next move is up to President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, who, for the third time in a year, can either call early elections or name another leader to try to form a government.
The Milan stock exchange's main index dropped 3.62 percent yesterday. The mark continued a surge against the Italian lira that began on Tuesday, rising 1.5 percent yesterday. The dollar also rose against the lira, to 1,583, from 1,575 lire on Tuesday.
But the dollar did not fare as well against other currencies. In New York late yesterday, it traded at 1.4644 marks, down from 1.4730 on Tuesday. It finished at 106.25 yen, compared with 106.81 yen the day before. The British pound rose to $1.5419 from $1.5367
The mark also gained strength yesterday because of continuing doubts that the first stage of European monetary union would be in place by 1999, as planned.
Another factor was the decline yesterday of some stock and bond indexes in the United States -- failing to provide a boost to the currency needed to buy them. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 21.68 points, and the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond also declined, driving up the yield to 6.09 percent.
"The dollar has been acting in a negative fashion all week, said Tom O'Malley, a senior foreign exchange analyst for Technical Data in Boston. "The market is looking for fresh data to come to the rescue."
In other trading, the dollar fell to 1.1955 Swiss francs, from 1.2027 Swiss francs on Tuesday, and to 5.0460 French francs, down from 5.0715 francs.

HEADLINE: Imam's Progress, Secular and Sacred;
Guiding a Harlem Congregation Past Crises of Debt and Faith

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
On his deathbed, Ali Rashid, the imam of the Malcolm Shabazz Mosque in Harlem, scribbled down the name of his successor. It was the same name he had secretly added to mosque documents months before his death: Izak-El M. Pasha.
"I didn't know enough Arabic to lead the prayer and was still a student of the Koran," recalled Mr. Pasha, a plumber who as imam would be leader, teacher and spiritual healer to one of the nation's oldest black Muslim communities. "I knew how to be a servant of God, but to lead a people whose spirit was down? No siree!" 
 He contemplated leaving town with his wife and three children.
Mr. Pasha, 46, remembers crying that night in February 1993 when he submitted to the "will of Allah" to guide the orthodox Sunni Muslim sect, which had been divided for decades by internal squabbles, financial debt and a crisis of faith, a legacy of its break from the Nation of Islam in the 1970's. By the 1990's, the congregation had dwindled to 700.
"I told the community that if I accepted, it would have to be a 'we' leadership, not a 'me' leadership," said Mr. Pasha, who proceeded to quit his job as a supervisor at the Par Plumbing Company in Lynbrook, L.I. "It would take all of us working together to bring about a success, a new spirit and a new dawning."
Today, the mosque, where Malcolm X preached and Louis Farrakhan once delivered his fiery oratory on black supremacy, has again become a civic and economic presence in Harlem, with 8,000 worshipers.
Mr. Pasha is credited with turning around the fortunes of the mosque, a landmark gold-domed house of worship at 116th Street and Lenox Avenue, and he is being called Harlem's new spokesman, not only for religious doctrine but also for secular issues of concern to blacks.
In 1994, Mr. Pasha quietly mediated a potentially volatile dispute between store owners and illegal vendors along 125th Street. Last month, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who called the imam a "messenger who unites people," became the first incumbent Mayor to visit the 52-year-old mosque. These days, the imam is working on an ambitious project for the mosque and its neighborhood.
"I'm putting together a 175-year plan, which I consider a first phase," he said the other day, settling into a worn burgundy leather chair in his modest sixth-floor office. "People ask me, 'Where are you going to be in 175 years,' and I say, 'I'll live in my grands and great-grands.' You have to start thinking like that."
Mr. Pasha's office is crammed with diagrams, renderings and clay models of Harlem, replete with a magnificent new mosque, a 475-room hotel with a 1,600-seat banquet room and 2,800-seat concert hall, a mall and 190-unit low-income apartment complex. The first phase of the plan -- a joint project of the mosque and four nonprofit Harlem development groups -- is to cost $1 billion, financed through donations and state and Federal money. Mr. Pasha would not say how much has been raised so far.
But ground is to be broken next month on the apartment complex, the Malcolm Shabazz Gardens, on 117th Street. The mosque, which would manage the projects, is also working with the Harlem Community Development Corporation to build 85 units of federally subsidized housing for the elderly.
The imam, who has the intimidating bulk of a wrestler offset by an easy smile, has become known for such enterpreneurial spirit but also for grass-roots diplomacy. When two followers came to him with complaints about their wives, Mr. Pasha picked up the phone and called the women.
"Hold on for a minute," he said. "I have someone here that needs to speak to you about a problem he's having."
The Mayor's office itself appealed to Mr. Pasha to help defuse the dispute with 125th Street sidewalk vendors, many of them mosque members who, merchants complained, were siphoning off their customers. The city's attempts to move the vendors failed until Mr. Pasha began preaching compromise during juma, or Friday prayer services. At the city's behest, the mosque agreed to manage a market on a city-owned parking lot across from the mosque.
"The way he handled the vendors situation and the tremendous job the mosque is doing operating the market is evidence of what the imam means to this community," said Warren S. Whitlock, deputy executive director of the Harlem Community Development Corporation. "The imam and his worshipers believe in a self-reliance philosophy. They're working to help the black community here understand the importance of that message."
Mr. Pasha called the tensions between the vendors, most of them recent immigrants from Africa and the Caribbean, and the store merchants a cultural clash best handled through moral persuasion and a mild rebuke.
"We have as much racism practiced among us as black people as any racism that has been practiced upon us by other groups," he said. "The African doesn't like the Jamaican. The Jamaican doesn't like the Trinidadian. The black American doesn't like the non-American black.
"Islam won't accept racism, and won't allow Muslims to practice it."
Mr. Pasha sounded a similarly impatient note about racial discord when people questioned his motives in inviting Mayor Giuliani to speak just a few days before the holy month of Ramadan. Some perceived it as grandstanding on the imam's part. Others suggested that the mosque had been used by the Mayor to placate blacks angry over his bickering with the Rev. Al Sharpton.
"Sometimes, leadership in Harlem treats African-American people like children, fraidy-cats," Mr. Pasha said. "Like if some white man talks to us, we're going to be led back into slavery. We have a constituency and I'm obligated to bring those they elect to them. We respect leadership, that's our way. All that other stuff about 'he said this about him,' leave it outside. I don't want to hear."
Though conservative in manner, the imam, who favors flannel shirts and corduroy trousers, is a product of the radical 1960's, having spent much of his youth rebelling against a society he viewed as oppressive toward blacks. The fourth of nine children in a Bedford-Stuyvesant family, he dropped out of high school and took up with gangs. A life of hopelessness, he said, was given new hope when his oldest brother, Ali, persuaded him in 1972 to join the Nation of Islam, the regimented religious group that subscribed to racial separation.
At the time, the Malcolm Shabazz Mosque was Temple No. 7, a popular, politically active mosque following the teachings of Elijah Muhammad, founder of the Nation of Islam. It was at Temple No. 7 that Malcolm X, the movement's most famous convert, preached the new black man's religion and nationalism.
Mr. Pasha, who received a high school equivalency diploma, worked his way up through the ranks, first by selling fried fish and the group's newspaper, Muhammad Speaks, on street corners, turning 10 percent over to the mosque.
In 1978, after Elijah Muhammad's death, the Nation of Islam splintered into two factions. One was led by Mr. Farrakhan, who replaced Malcolm X as minister of Temple No. 7 before moving to Chicago to assume national leadership. The other was headed by W. Deen Muhammad, a son of Elijah Muhammad, who had softened his position in later years and moved the Nation closer to more traditional Islam.
Mr. Pasha's own beliefs had changed over the years, and he chose the latter path. In the 1980's, Temple 7 was renamed Malcolm Shabazz in honor of the slain leader. Mr. Farrakhan's followers went to the Nation of Islam Mosque at 125th Street and Fifth Avenue.
Mr. Pasha speaks of Minister Farrakhan in the kind of hushed tones reserved for an estranged brother. "Some of us were able to see that in real Islam racism is not accepted," he said. "Others did not."
During the next 10 years, a legal battle over Elijah Muhammad's estate further fractured the spirit of his followers, and the need to pay his back taxes forced many followers to sell properties to prevent foreclosure on mosques, including the Malcolm Shabazz Mosque. Its restaurants and other projects were shut. Mr. Pasha has paid most of $1 million owed in taxes.
To insure that a new generation stay the prescribed course of Islam, the mosque now operates a school for 70 students that teaches Islamic culture, along with English, Arabic, Spanish and French, American history and algebra. A new restaurant and health food store are doing steady business in once-vacant storefronts adjoining the mosque.
As the solemn call to prayer washed over the mosque, Mr. Pasha excused himself to pray. He returned to find a representative from City Hall waiting in his office. The mosque's financial officer and Mr. Pasha's brother Ali were waiting in an adjoining room. And he is reminded by his secretary, his oldest daughter, that he promised to fix a leak in the mosque's basement.

HEADLINE: Tribe Says Developer Threatens Sacred Site

 BODY:
For more than 1,000 years, archaeologists say, the Mohican Indians lived on land in the Catskills community of Leeds, N.Y. The tribe has long since left the area, settling in Wisconsin, but its lawyer returned yesterday to fight plans to build a Wal-Mart superstore on a 30-acre cornfield the tribe considers sacred.
The tribe contends that the Town of Catskill, which includes Leeds, conducted only a cursory archaeological review before granting a zone change requested by Wal-Mart. It filed suit yesterday in Greene County Court to block construction of the store. 
 "We're asking the court to restrain the town from moving forward on this project until the archaeological work is complete," said George Rodenhausen, the lawyer representing the tribe. He added that the Town of Catskill and Wal-Mart had been unresponsive to requests to protect the site, where preliminary excavations have turned up a wealth of artifacts.
"What we're talking about here are whole deposits of artifacts that have been sealed in by the flood plains," said Dr. Christopher Lindner, an archaeologist with Bard College. "If we had to pick a wish list, it couldn't be better than this." The cornfield lies next to a stream and abuts the site of a historic Dutch trading post. Dr. Lindner said the site could merit a full-fledged archaeological dig, which could cost more than $1 million.
The battle here is part of a nationwide fight over Indian archaeology. Backed by recent political gains, the wealth from casinos on Indian reservations and no small dose of moral indignation, American Indians are increasingly trying to reclaim pieces of their heritage, forcing developers and local administrators to balance economic growth against the cost of destroying sites spiritually significant to Indians.
"You find it from Alaska to the Virgin Islands," said Dr. Muriel Crespi, an Indian specialist with the National Park Service. "The confluence of legislation, public awareness and a more politically sophisticated Indian people is changing the scenario."
According to Dr. Robert Kuhn, the program coordinator for the State Historic Preservation Office, which oversees the 10,000 archaeological sites in New York State, the Hudson Valley has become particularly fertile ground for these kinds of conflicts.
Once the home of the Mohican tribe, the area from Lake Champlain to Manhattan has also been one of the most heavily developed regions in the Northeast. Those two competing interests, Dr. Kuhn said, pit expensive excavations against low-cost development.
"In each of these projects, we have to balance that," Dr. Kuhn said. "Our goal is to find a way that the project can go forward and still protect the resource. In many instances, there are ways to do both."
In Leeds, however, the lawsuit came after negotiations with the retailer had stalled. Wal-Mart officials canceled a January meeting at the tribe's Bowler, Wisc., reservation and turned down a Mohican offer to use proceeds from their casino there to buy out the company's option on the land, said Steven Davids, vice-chairman of the tribal council.
"We want to learn from this site," Mr. Davids said. "If an excavation is to occur, we want it to be full and thorough. We don't want it rushed so they can get a Wal-Mart in there."
Wal-Mart officials did not returned phone calls yesterday. But earlier, Betsy Reithemeyer, a spokeswoman for the retailer, said it had consistently worked with Indian groups on preservation issues. She cited efforts to preserve a burial mound at a Wal-Mart in Paso Robles, Calif., as well as an artifact display at a store built on an Indian site in Canton, Ga. She also said the company would await the results of the next round of state-mandated excavations, scheduled for this spring, before making any decisions on the land.
The lawsuit, however, could become an interesting test case for Wal-Mart, which has often been at odds with local communities over development plans. Part of the suit contends that the Catskill Town Board did not fully consider the economic impact of the superstore on Leeds and surrounding communities.
"Historically, Wal-Mart has been a predator," said Michael Smith, a member of "It's Not Easy Being Greene," a preservation group formed to fight the development, which first notified the Mohicans of the site's significance. Mr. Smith, a lawyer in Manhattan who grew up in Leeds and has a weekend home there, complained that Wal-Mart monopolizes local business by driving prices down and forcing out small merchants. In addition to the Mohican tribe, two members of the preservation group are plaintiffs in the lawsuit.
In this historic community, though, some residents say Wal-Mart is needed to bolster a flagging tourism economy. In December, the County Board of Legislators passed a resolution unanimously supporting the retailer's plans.
"It's a very sensitive issue, and the Town of Catskill will take great care to recognize the rights of all the parties involved," said Joseph Izzo, the Catskill Town Supervisor, who said he had not yet seen a copy of the lawsuit. "It is a very important economic issue, too, though."

HEADLINE: The Divorce Debate

 BODY:
Led by conservative Christian groups, a new movement is afoot to toughen state divorce laws. Its main target is the "no-fault" divorce statutes adopted by every state over the last 25 years to make divorces easier, quicker and less freighted with destructive recrimination.
There are powerful reasons to be alarmed about the impact of family breakups on children, and about the high incidence of poverty in single-parent households. But rolling back the clock to make the legal process of divorce more expensive and acrimonious is not a useful answer. 
 Supporters of tougher divorce laws complain that the current rules encourage a casual attitude toward the dissolution of marriage. But few people who have lived through a no-fault divorce, especially those with children, would say they took the step lightly.
Even though divorces have jumped about 30 percent in the last 25 years, blaming the new laws for a long-term upward trend confuses cause and effect. No-fault divorce was a response to changes already taking place in the family system.
Under the no-fault approach, a divorce is granted even if only one spouse wants it. By contrast, a bill just introduced in the Michigan Legislature would deny a divorce when one spouse opposes it unless the plaintiff could show that a spouse had been physically or mentally abusive, had a problem with alcohol or drugs, had committed adultery, had deserted the home or had been sentenced to prison.
The idea is to try to force couples to stay together. But a more likely consequence would be a return to the perjuries, fabrications and other devices required to obtain divorces before no-fault. That would mean yet more pain for children, as parents slug it out in a prolonged legal blame-game, wasting scarce family resources in the process.
Another consequence would be to discourage couples from getting married in the first place -- thereby aggravating the already staggering problem of unwed motherhood, and the resulting social and financial vulnerability of women and children.
The nation should be concentrating on ways to reduce the economic stresses that experts say contribute both to the high divorce rate and to the rising number of children born to unmarried couples. Absent fathers should be required to live up to their child support obligations. But making it more difficult for people to escape a broken marriage seems cruel and counter-productive.

LENGTH: 657 words

HEADLINE: New Hampshire Passion Play

 BODY:
If Iowa's Presidential caucuses tested the candidates' appeal to the religious right, next week's New Hampshire primary shapes up as a test of economic platforms. So the focus will be on the flat-tax fantasies of Steve Forbes and especially the faux populism of Pat Buchanan. Although both men are capable of veering toward the wacky, it is a debate worth having.
The exercise will test the ability of Bob Dole and Lamar Alexander to respond substantively to Mr. Buchanan's simplistic, but highly emotive harangues. Also, the economic debate will test the Republicans' ability to respond to the discontent of their grass-roots participants in the economy after two decades of listening to the party's theorists and its fat cats. 
 Mr. Buchanan's radar is good. He understands the middle-class concern over the growing gap between rich and poor, the stagnation of buying power and the uncertainty of future employment. But his remedies are perverse. His platform is anti-immigration, anti-trade and anti-corporation. Contrary to the workers'-solidarity rhetoric he was using Wednesday in New Hampshire, it is also anti-poor and anti-worker.
Mr. Buchanan can pose as the working man's fiery friend, but his tax plan is a boon to the haves. His own flat-tax reform plan, while more balanced than Mr. Forbes's, would exempt the interest gains and stock dividends of individual investors from taxation. He wants to give investors a tax holiday on capital gains income and eliminate inheritance tax for estates up to $5 million.
His tax plan, in short, would stuff the pocketbooks of the affluent, while his trade policies would squeeze the purse of the average consumer. He calls for imposing punitive tariffs on goods from China, Japan and low-wage countries. He would withdraw from Nafta, the trade accord with Mexico and Canada, as well as the World Trade Organization, which oversees fair trade rules. He would close America's borders to immigrants for five years.
At the core of these positions is the notion that foreigners are the root cause of America's economic slowdown. That is a notion in search of evidence. Mr. Buchanan's tariffs would not create more jobs -- the Federal Reserve Board has more effect on employment -- but it would jack up the price of low-priced clothes and food that America imports, a blow to the budgets of poor families.
He seeks to give the impression that if these low-priced goods were not on the market, there would be more manufacturing jobs for unskilled laborers. That is a neat, but misleading formulation. In certain situations, imports and immigration do threaten low-skilled workers, even if they help other low-wage consumers. But what Mr. Buchanan rejects are the reams of evidence that the plight of America's unskilled workers -- wage declines and small benefit increases for two decades -- is a home-grown problem that bears a scanty relationship to foreign trade, investment or immigration.
The remedy for slow-growing wages is faster growth of productivity in the American workplace. That turnaround will not be achieved by bashing foreigners, but instead must be accomplished in an expensive, persistent campaign to drive up savings and investment as well as worker education and training. If Mr. Buchanan preached that, he would sound remarkably like President Clinton.
Of course, it may not be possible for Mr. Dole and Mr. Alexander to make such reasoned points when Mr. Buchanan is in his blowtorch mode. Mr. Dole and Mr. Alexander seem to hope that they can intone their usual pieties about small government and the respective virtues of having a lot of Washington experience or only a little bit, and then leave it up to the voters to fill in the blanks. But for the moment, Mr. Buchanan is filling in the blanks, usually with passionate nonsense. His is not a new strategy for Presidential primaries nor, in the light of history, necessarily an unsuccessful one.

HEADLINE: The End of Taiwan?

BYLINE: By Chas. Freeman 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
No one wants a war in the Taiwan Strait. Not President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan, whose hopes for re-election on March 23 depend on convincing voters he can still manage relations with Beijing to the island's advantage. Not Jiang Zemin, China's President, who just a year ago emphasized China's patience in pursuing peaceful reunification. Not Bill Clinton, who doesn't want his handling of China to be an issue in this year's Presidential campaign.
But Taiwan's miscalculations, China's emotional reactions and the United States' inattention have created tensions that could escalate into combat soon after Taiwan's election. Such a war would not only threaten Taiwan's democracy but also finish any hopes of America's building a constructive relationship with China. It could even destroy our alliance with Japan. 
 Mr. Lee, who faces tremendous pressure from voters to push for separation from China, will likely be re-elected. Beijing believes that he is committed to separatism, and since last summer has been conducting extensive military exercises in the Taiwan Strait to make clear the price of a call for independence.
China would rather not go to war. The People's Liberation Army is not now capable of conquering Taiwan -- an island fortress with a well-trained army and cutting-edge weaponry. There is no reason to believe that Beijing's generals are stupid enough to try.
But Taiwan is heavily dependent on trade, making it vulnerable to escalating military harassment. The Chinese Army has made plans, including carefully selecting targets for missile attacks, to carry out such a campaign. At the same time, China could begin the long effort to train its troops for conquest and to build the sorts of ships, amphibious landing craft and aircraft it would need to invade. Taiwan can win a battle or two, but not a protracted test of strength.
Few leaders in Beijing -- civilian or military -- can doubt the potential for disaster in a conflict with Taiwan. Beyond the obvious risks of war, China could face economic sanctions and possibly military intervention by the West. War in the Taiwan Strait could also cause Japan to arm against China.
Like many other Asian nations, Japan is dismayed by the absence of effective American leadership. Since World War II, the price of Japan's disarmament has been reliable American management of its strategic defense.
If America failed to come to Taiwan's aid, many Japanese would demand that they take over their own defense, claiming that America could no longer be counted on to fulfill its responsibility.
If, however, the United States did intervene in a war between Taiwan and the People's Republic -- either by supplying Taiwan's forces or actual military action -- it would have to use its bases in Japan, thus forcing Japan to choose between its nonhostile relationship with China and its alliance with the United States. Japan would almost certainly side with us, but no future Japanese government would allow itself to be put in such a position again.
The results in either case would probably be Japanese rearmament, military rivalry between Tokyo and Beijing, a loss of confidence between Tokyo and Washington and alarm throughout Asia.
What can the United States do? Sino-American relations have collapsed since the fall of the Soviet Union. Congress has filled the policy vacuum with gestures against Beijing: forcing President Clinton to issue visas to Taiwanese leaders; passing legislation supporting Tibet's secession from China and calling for a bill to finance a radio station for Chinese dissidents.
It has been years since the executive branch conducted an effective dialogue with Taiwan's leaders, who have fallen into the habit of lobbying Congress and have usually received what they wanted.
The Clinton Administration must forge a coherent China policy and persuade Congress not to undercut it. We should firmly remind Taiwan that it does not have a blank check that it can fill out in American blood, but also firmly remind China that it cannot count on us to stay out if it goes to war with Taiwan.
Then we must begin a constructive dialogue with China. A first step would be to stop blackballing its entry into groups such as the World Trade Organization. Unless we make China a member of the club, we can't hope to hold it to the rules.
Even on the most rancorous issue between the nations -- human rights -- there is room for cooperation. China has recognized the need to create a modern legal system. Congress should finance an effort by American and Asian experts to help China build a rule of law that can eliminate abuses.
Although Bill Clinton may wish to avoid having to devote time to China in an election year, too much is at stake in the Taiwan Strait for him to ignore it.
