HEADLINE: What's Next, Tail Fins?;
Fast Speeds and Big Cars Send Gas Consumption Up

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

DATELINE: MANLIUS, N.Y.

 BODY:
Gas guzzling is back.
Americans are driving bigger cars and trucks longer distances and at higher speeds -- ignoring warnings about increased pollution or another oil shock. 
 And why not? Gas costs less, in inflation-adjusted terms, than at any time since the 1950's, the golden era of gas guzzling, when metallic monsters with fins spewed noxious fumes and got 10 miles to the gallon in city traffic.
Today, gas is so cheap that Mary McIntosh never looks at the price signs when she goes to fill up the 40-gallon tank of her hulking Chevrolet Suburban sport utility vehicle. She just pulls the truck, which seats nine people, into the first Mobil station she sees -- because she has a Mobil credit card.
"I zip it through and that's it," she said in her living room here as her husband, David, who drives his own Suburban, nodded in approval. The convenience is well worth the few dollars the couple might save from their $200 monthly gasoline bill if they shopped around, she added.
With price such a small consideration, the McIntoshes have no reason to drive slowly. In fact, now that nearly every state has lifted the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit on major rural highways, they -- like most Americans -- are going faster.
The McIntoshes say they sometimes exceed 70 m.p.h. on the weekend skiing trips they take with their four children to Stowe, Vt., 200 miles away. And on some roads that would mean driving in the slow lane. The New York State Police says the average ticketed speed rose from 73 m.p.h. in 1994 to 76 m.p.h. last year.
Energy specialists say the McIntoshes' driving habits are typical these days. With memories of the oil shocks of the 1970's fading, the oil cartel apparently broken and prices generally stable over the last decade, they say, motorists have little incentive to conserve energy. Indeed, the gas mileage of their Suburbans, like most of the popular sport utility vehicles, is not much better than the monster gas guzzlers of old.
As a result, gasoline consumption is increasing at an accelerating pace, according to the American Petroleum Institute. After declining slightly from 1989 through 1991, it rose by 1.1 percent in 1992, 1.4 percent in 1993 and 1.7 percent in 1994 before shooting up 2.5 percent last year. Consumption was 327.2 million gallons a day in 1995, up from 319.2 million gallons in 1994.
The industry trade group attributed last year's jump partly to the introduction of reformulated gasoline, which delivers somewhat lower mileage. Actual highway travel rose at a slightly lower pace last year than in 1994 -- 2 percent versus 2.5 percent.
Analysts believe consumption will continue to rise, perhaps at an accelerating rate. Fred Leuffer, an oil analyst for Bear, Stearns, the securities firm, predicts a 2 percent increase this year and stronger growth for the next five years. Making matters worse, he said, "We're going to see much smaller gains in fuel efficiency."
The abandon with which Americans are hitting the gas pedal worries both environmentalists and strategic planners. John M. DeCicco, a senior associate for the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy, a nonprofit research and lobbying group in Washington that urges energy conservation, calculates that a car loses 18 percent of its mileage if it increases its speed to 65 miles per hour from 55 m.p.h. and a whopping 33 percent if it guns along at 75 m.p.h.
In contrast to the 1950's, today's cars are equipped with catalytic converters that greatly reduce pollution. Still, Mr. DeCicco worries that all the gas guzzling will wipe out some of the gains from the recent switch to cleaner gasoline in cities with high ozone levels, like New York and Los Angeles. "It's going to make it harder for some states to be in compliance" with ozone limits set by the Federal Clean Air Act, he said.
Some experts fear Americans are getting dangerously complacent. Granted, they say, oil output is up in the North Sea, the Gulf of Mexico and elsewhere. And granted, recent finds in Colombia are being brought into production, and Iraq stands a good chance of getting sanctions against its exports relaxed.
But some specialists worry that the United States is once again ignoring the risk of becoming increasingly dependent on foreign supplies. Imports, which add about $50 billion to the nation's trade deficit, have been rising steadily in recent years and now account for about half of oil consumption. And if political upheavals should ever disrupt production in the key exporting nation of Saudi Arabia, they say, the threat of another shortage would be real.
"We're better off than a lot of countries, but we're poorly prepared," said Milton Copulos, the president of the National Defense Council Foundation, a conservative group in Washington that has warned of another oil crisis in hearings in Congress. "We have done so many things that place ourselves at risk that getting out of it will be difficult, especially when there is not the public will to do the things that need to be done."
The 1990's nonchalance couldn't be more different from the conservationist fervor that swept the nation after the Arab oil embargo of 1973 created long gas lines and sent pump prices soaring.
Trying to come to grips with that crisis, which Secretary of State Henry Kissinger called the "economic equivalent of the Sputnik challenge," the Senate passed a bill to require higher fuel efficiency in cars, highway speed limits were lowered and service stations were closed on Sundays in some places.
There was talk of rationing gasoline, and President Nixon asked drivers to hold purchases to 10 gallons. The Mobil Oil Company and other oil giants halted gasoline advertising, and with surprising speed, consumers shifted to smaller cars.
Today, the forces of both the marketplace and the work place seem to be conspiring to erase Americans' former energy austerity.
Millions of Americans, like the McIntoshes, find that the cost of gasoline barely dents their budgets. Adjusted for inflation, the current average price of $1.14 for a gallon of unleaded regular gasoline is only half what it was in the early 1980's.
And while most drivers were already exceeding the 55 m.p.h. limit, the increase to 65 m.p.h. in states like New York and even higher in several Western states spurred them to go faster. On a recent trip from Nyack, N.Y. to Syracuse on the New York State Thruway, for example, many cars were spotted speeding along at 75 m.p.h.
"I don't worry about gas mileage, I worry about the troopers," said Ralph Miller as he and some friends ordered coffee at the takeout counter of a Thruway rest stop. He said he drove his white Toyota Land Cruiser, parked outside and bristling with skis, between 70 and 75 m.p.h.
Another restaurant customer, Frank Schiavelli, said he made a point of obeying the law by setting his cruise control for 65 m.p.h., only to find, he said, that "almost everybody was passing me." Mr. Schiavelli, a salesman, said he drives more and flies less these days because on short trips he can get there just as fast.
Gregory C. Sitler, a major in the Division of Traffic Services of the New York State Police, said once drivers got used to higher speeds they had trouble slowing down to comply with the lower 55 m.p.h. limit along heavily traveled stretches. "It's almost like it doesn't exist," he said.
New Jersey and Connecticut are among the handful of states that have not raised their 55 m.p.h. speed limits.
Meantime, the long-term trend away from using mass transit to get to work continues. Between 1980 and 1990, for example, when 18 million jobs were created, 22 million more commuters hit the highways rather than the train or bus -- usually driving alone.
Allen Pisarski, a consultant on traffic patterns in Falls Church, Va., who has long studied driving habits, said that shift was continuing. At the same time, he said, women are driving more, and now cover more miles than men. In part, that reflects their increasing presence in the workplace, but even housewives are making more trips, he said.
For Mrs. McIntosh, a typical day might including dropping off her daughter Sara, 11, and son David, 9, at school in the morning, then heading for the mall with Katherine, 6, and Patrick, 22 months. In the afternoon, she picks up the older children, drops Sara off for a violin lesson and then returns with David to take both of them to soccer practice. For his part, Mr. McIntosh, who has his own insurance business, goes on frequent hunting trips to Oneida Lake, 60 miles away from their home in Manlius, which is nine miles southeast of Syracuse.
The McIntoshes chose their Suburbans, which barely get 12 miles to the gallon in local traffic, two years ago because they were big enough to ferry their children and all their gear, and because the hefty size made Mrs. McIntosh feel safer, especially with a toddler in the car. "I know it's so American," she said. "It's big and has a lot of power."
Another factor whetting the national thirst for gasoline is the continuing suburbanization of America, making long drives essential to keeping in touch with friends. Wellington Sears, a 74-year-old retired engineer, drives 15 miles in his 1987 Lincoln to get free coffee and play bingo along with dozens of other retired people at the Caldor department store in the Fayetteville Mall near Syracuse. His wife drives her Mercury to the same bingo game, and afterward the two go separately to other malls to meet friends.
It burns a lot of gas, Mr. Sears concedes. "I don't care," he said. "I do my thing, she does hers."
Then, of course, there is the sheer fun of driving fast. Jerry Rubitski, a student on his way to Tufts University from Utica, said he loves to barrel along the New York Thruway at 75 m.p.h. in his BMW coupe while listening to loud music. Does he worry about gas mileage? "Not really," he said as he got behind the wheel.
And if big is beautiful for many American motorists, very big is back, too. An increasing number of people want to take their living room, kitchen and bathroom along when they travel, keeping demand strong for gas-hungry recreational vehicles. In the 1990's sales of these vehicles have grown dramatically, hitting a peak in 1994 and falling slightly last year.
Eric Rector, general manager of a dealership in Clifton Park, N.Y., walked through his cavernous showroom filled with gleaming white vehicles, which get as little as eight miles to the gallon on the open road. Stepping inside the $150,000 Sun Voyager, he showed how the 13-foot-long living room can be expanded when the vehicle is parked.
"People work hard," he said, "and they work to have fun."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Lose Steam; Prices Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the first time in three sessions as talk of selling by hedge funds and other distractions drove buyers to the sidelines in the absence of economic reports.
A decline in the value of the dollar, an increase in the issue of corporate bonds and rising commodity prices combined to weigh down the market. 
 "While a lot of things did bother the market, said Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist for CS First Boston, "there was no technical damage done, and there were no signals of a dramatic change to fundamentals or tone taking place now and over the near term."
The price of the 30-year bond dropped 28/32 , to 9822/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.09 percent, from 6.02 percent on Tuesday.
Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch, a New York market research and analysis firm, said an abundant amount of corporate debt was issued yesterday, adding to the market's concerns about supply.
In the corporate market, the largest domestic sale of the day was Salomon Inc.'s $500 million of notes due in 2003. The notes, with an interest rate of 6.75 percent, are priced at 99.798 to yield 6.787 percent, or 137.5 basis points more than a similar Treasury issue. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The noncallable issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's, BBB by Standard & Poor's and A- by Duff & Phelps.
The Salomon issue was one of a total $1.275 billion in domestic offerings yesterday -- not including the Province of Ontario's $1.5 billion global issue of 10-year debt.
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said the Ontario offering created more supply of securities that the market has to absorb, lowering interest rates to attract investors. That in turn brought some hedge funds, or large institutional investors, to sell securities to protect themselves from falling prices. Traders said some of the selling was to raise cash to pay for issues bought at last week's refunding. The weakness in the Treasury market yesterday began at the opening, after selling overseas. Weighing on prices and extending the day's lows were rumors of hedge funds selling short-term notes and a decline in the dollar against major currencies. A weak dollar makes American investments like Treasury securities less attractive to foreign investors.
Rising commodities prices were also a market distraction, although many participants do not see inflationary pressures building. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodity futures traded in New York and Chicago was up a point to 250.68, the higest level since January 1998.
Today, the market turns its attention to a number of economic reports, including orders for durable goods and factory orders for December and the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's survey of regional business activity for February.
"The key report could be the Philadelphia Fed index," Mr. Palash of MCM Moneywatch said, "because it will give us the first indication of whether the manufacturing sector has rebounded from the effects of the East blizzard.
"If it stays negative it tells us that manufacturing remains weak and that leaves the door open for further easing. If stronger than I think it will just be chalked up to a weather-related rebound and have a limited impact on the market."

HEADLINE: In New Vision By Planners, An Open War On Old Ideas

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The Regional Plan Association, an old and respected urban planning organization that usually draws little attention to itself, has declared open war on some treasured ideas about the New York metropolitan region.
The group, after five years of study, issued a report on Tuesday concluding that the 31-county three-state region around New York City is at risk of a long-term decline in its economy and its quality of life unless dramatic steps are taken and billions of dollars are invested now in transportation, education and housing. The report was couched in language of darkest gloom, hinting that a centuries-long pattern of self-sustaining growth had perhaps come to an end. 
 But the very elements that give the study its force -- its sweeping, long-term vision and gloomy threats -- may also be the great stumbling blocks in selling it as a blueprint for where the region goes from here.
Politicians are likely to shy away from such a pessimistic view of the region's prospects, and many business leaders too tend to take a more promotional view of the area in which they have a stake.
While the planning group took the long view -- trying to peer a quarter-century into the future -- the time frame in which political and business leaders operate seems to grow shorter and shorter. It can often be difficult for them to look much beyond the next election or the next quarterly earnings report. And even if they were willing to, many say that the pace of technological and economic change today makes trying to look so far into the future an act of utter audacity.
"I think they've gone way out on a limb," Chris Biddle, a spokesman for the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, the state's largest business organization, said of the planning group. "Yes, it's true that New York and Connecticut and New Jersey share economies, and that we're at the center of corporate downsizing, losing jobs hand over fist, and that there are some serious problems -- but does this mean we're entering a tragic decline? I don't think you can draw that conclusion. I think there may be changes ahead we can't even anticipate."
The plan's authors concede that selling their vision in the late 20th century represents a whole different set of problems from those faced by earlier planners. In 1929 and even in 1968, for example -- the only other times that the association has issued long-term plans -- the New York business community was dominated by individual titans who could move mountains with a few telephone calls. Corporate leaders today, working for globally dispersed companies and answering to stockholders with short-term profit agendas, have less opportunity to focus on a broad civic agenda.
The era of conservative government -- with its goals of doing more with less -- has also left politicians less room to manuever. The capital-spending items urged in the 1996 plan, led by mass-transit improvements and affordable housing initiatives for downtown centers of the region, would total $75 billion over the next 24 years.
But even officials who support many specifics of the plan, like the need to create a more interconnected regional transit system, for instance, distanced themselves from the report's harshly insistent arguments about what will happen if those things are not fixed.
Louis R. Tomson, deputy secretary to Gov. George E. Pataki, said that the Governor heartily supported some of the plan's infrastructure ideas but that the overall tone of the study would certainly not be finding its way into the next series of "I Love New York" promotional brochures. "We don't share their view, and we clearly are not going to use their view to help attract people to the New York region," Mr. Tomson said. "We're basing our actions on optimism."
But if the selling is harder, the tactics promise to be different. Officials of the Regional Plan Association went on television on Wednesday night for an hour of public television in all three states, laying out the group's views in a program called "Region at Risk." An on-line chat in cyberspace was also scheduled with one of the plan's co-authors, Robert D. Yaro, on America Online.
The association is also openly pinning many of its hopes on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, who has been, they say, by far the most vocal and aggressive leader in the region in pushing for a new view of regional planning and cooperation.
"I'm not sure the average person understands what the Regional Plan Association is about, but they understand the message," said a spokesman for Mrs. Whitman, Robert Friant. "I think people are worrying, 'How am I going to get to work, am I going to get stuck in traffic, and am I going to have a job?' Those are important questions and they resonate."

HEADLINE: Drug Makers Raised Prices For Retailers 4.6% in 1995

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Manufacturers' prices of the 500 most widely used prescription drugs rose 4.6 percent last year, the National Association of Chain Drug Stores, a trade group, said yesterday.
The association said the increase compared with 4.1 percent in 1994 and 4 percent in 1993. The chain druggists said pharmacies paid $41.6 billion for the 500 drugs last year, which was 85 percent of the cost of all prescription drugs purchased by the stores. 
 Prescription drug price inflation slowed in 1993 as drug manufacturers moderated price increases after they became an issue in the 1992 Presidential campaign and the ensuing Washington health policy debate.
In another survey, by the Labor Department, manufacturers' prices for drugs rose 4.2 percent in December from a year earlier. That same month, the Producer Price Index of all finished goods rose 3 percent from a year earlier. In contrast, retail drug prices rose only 2 percent over December 1994, while the overall Consumer Price Index was up 2.2 percent.
Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, a University of Minnesota researcher who directed the price survey for the chain drugstores, noted that the Bureau of Labor Statistics numbers included "everybody else the manufacturers give discounts to: hospitals, health maintenance organizations and government agencies."
But Ronald L. Ziegler, president of the drugstore association, said the gap between the Producer and Consumer Price Indexes reflected a squeeze on pharmacies, which were forced to swallow part of the increase.
In several lawsuits in Federal District Court in Chicago, thousands of pharmacies contend that the manufacturers have unfairly refused to offer them discounts that are available to many managed-care buyers.
Last week, 15 drug manufacturers agreed to settle a class action related to the discounts for about $408 million in cash and products. The companies said they had not acted improperly. The drug chains and at least one big group of pharmacies rejected the proposed settlement and are maintaining their lawsuits.
The Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers Association, a drug makers trade group, said yesterday that there had been only "modest inflation at the producer price level" last year. The manufacturers group cited a different measure of prices, which the Bureau of Labor Statistics officials said had been superseded by a pharmaceutical industry index in the 1980's. According to the earlier measure, called the wholesale price index, which the bureau said it still kept for "historical reasons," manufacturers' prices rose 3.7 percent in 1995, up from 3.1 percent in 1994, while prices of all manufactured goods increased by 2.2 percent in 1995.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: Fraud Figure's Actions Dim Recovery by Investors

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Three years ago, Steven Hoffenberg stepped into the spotlight by proposing to rescue a failing New York City tabloid with money from his Towers Financial Corporation, which turned out to be a Ponzi scheme that defrauded investors of $450 million.
This week, awaiting sentencing after pleading guilty to criminal fraud charges in the Towers case, Mr. Hoffenberg was in Little Rock, Ark., preparing to sue a key figure in the Whitewater scandal and telling associates he planned to run for the United States Senate -- after he somehow withdraws his guilty plea, is acquitted at some future trial and pays off his big debts. 
 From the first, everything about Mr. Hoffenberg has been over the top, as those who recall his brief career as acting publisher of The New York Post can attest. But his behavior in recent weeks -- from his Whitewater activities to his staging of a phony Federal Bureau of Investigation raid at a Long Island business -- has seemed so bizarre that Federal prosecutors have tried to get his bail revoked to insure that he will show up for sentencing for his crimes next month.
"Mr. Hoffenberg is in a very erratic state, and -- in the vernacular -- really seems about to boil over," said David Lewis, assistant United States attorney, at a bail hearing on Tuesday afternoon before Judge Robert W. Sweet in Federal District Court in Manhattan.
Judge Sweet then volunteered that Mr. Hoffenberg had "visited our chambers" on Feb. 9, before leaving for Arkansas with the court's permission. "Fortunately, I was not present," Judge Sweet said, "but it was such an interchange that there may be some substance to what you say."
This unraveling of Mr. Hoffenberg's personal life would border on farce if it did not affect the thousands of investors who are still owed hundreds of millions of dollars from the Towers debacle. Their chances of recovering even a fraction of their money were slim, in any case, since Mr. Hoffenberg spent so lavishly while the Ponzi scheme was in full sail. But without Mr. Hoffenberg's rational help in tracking any missing assets, their odds diminish even further.
Amy Millard, an assistant United States attorney, told Judge Sweet on Jan. 31 that Mr. Hoffenberg still owed the Securities and Exchange Commission "many millions of dollars" under a civil settlement the commission obtained in the Towers case in November 1994. "He has made no payments to date, and yet he is expending large sums of money," Ms. Millard said.
Besides promising to pay $60 million to the S.E.C., $37 million of which was to help compensate investors, Mr. Hoffenberg also owes $516 million under a second settlement reached in November 1994 with the creditors of Towers Financial. While no one asserted at the time that he had anything like that much money, he did agree under that settlement to assist the bankruptcy trustee in tracking down any assets that might help satisfy that judgment.
But he has not provided that assistance, the Federal prosecutors have noted in court, and his own finances remain a mystery -- one that, in their view, raises the risk that Mr. Hoffenberg will flee before being sentenced.
At a hearing on Feb. 8, Michael Sommer, an assistant United States attorney, asked that bail be revoked, citing the "extreme amount of money involved in the underlying crime and the potential for flight capital being out there."
Judge Sweet declined and gave the financier until 5 o'clock last night to meet new bail terms. He also issued a bench warrant that would allow the Government to arrest Mr. Hoffenberg if he did not comply by the deadline.
As of 5 o'clock last night, no arrest had been made. Instead, the Government sent a letter to Judge Sweet explaining that Mr. Hoffenberg had offered some securities of uncertain value to meet the property requirements of the bond.
The Government was still evaluating those securities, the letter said, and would advise the court today of whether they were acceptable. In any case, the letter continued, no arrest would be made until after noon today.
Jeffrey Hoffman, Mr. Hoffenberg's lawyer, has repeatedly assured Judge Sweet that his client, while angry and "vociferous," is not a threat to others and has kept every required court date.
Mr. Hoffenberg, in a collect call from Arkansas last night, denied that he had behaved erratically. He said he would comply fully with any order by Judge Sweet, but referred questions about his case to Mr. Hoffman. "I can only talk to you about Whitewater," he said.
His Whitewater activities initially involved setting up a legal defense fund to aid James B. McDougal, the former business partner of President and Mrs. Clinton. In addition, he and Mr. McDougal entered into a deal to share the "economic opportunities" presented by Mr. McDougal's celebrity, such as movie deals or T-shirt sales.
But Mr. Hoffenberg said last night that he was now planning to sue Mr. McDougal over the terms of the deal. Mr. McDougal could not be reached for comment, but Mr. Lewis, the assistant United States attorney, told Judge Sweet on Tuesday that the Whitewater defendant's lawyers had called him "indicating that Mr. McDougal wants Mr. Hoffenberg to leave him alone."
After becoming involved with Mr. McDougal, Mr. Hoffenberg began to tell associates and journalists that he planned to run for the United States Senate seat now held by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, who is leading the Senate's Whitewater investigation.
And even before that, Mr. Hoffenberg quarreled bitterly with Mary Hasho, the woman who bore his child -- and who had pledged her home as part of his bail when he was first arrested two years ago. It was Ms. Hasho's recent demand to be removed from his bail arrangements that first brought Federal prosecutors to court to seek new bail terms.
But at those hearings, Federal prosecutors have outlined other acts by Mr. Hoffenberg that they say have caused them alarm.
Ms. Millard described an incident in which Mr. Hoffenberg was said to have tried to intimidate Ms. Hasho's brother by going to his office "with another individual." Then, she said, Mr. Hoffenberg "told him that the other individual was with the F.B.I., that he had 20 more F.B.I. agents around the corner."
According to Ms. Millard, Mr. Hoffenberg has also tried to drum up new business with brochures that include pages from the fraudulent financial statements created for Towers Financial -- statements that she said were a component of the very fraud for which he was awaiting sentencing. Moreover, she said, he has portrayed himself repeatedly as a "Government witness" who can help disbarred stockbrokers regain their licenses to do business.
Asked how he was supporting himself, Mr. Hoffenberg said in an interview last week that he was "a business broker," who had "bought collection agencies for other people." He has an office in Great Neck under the name of Acquisition Associates.
That is the latest of a series of businesses he has started since Towers collapsed in early 1993. In mid-1993, after losing his bid for The Post because of an asset freeze imposed at the S.E.C.'s request, he started a newspaper called Her New York, aimed at a female urban audience; it collapsed a few months later with complaints that staff members had not been paid.
He also became involved with a new bill collection agency, the Diversified Credit Corporation, in violation of the terms of his original plea bargain with Federal prosecutors. That company also collapsed.

HEADLINE: Columbia Loses Harassment Suit

 BODY:
A Federal jury in Manhattan found on Tuesday that Columbia University failed to properly investigate a former employee's sexual harassment complaint against her supervisor, and so must pay her $450,000.
The trial followed a 1994 decision on the case by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which said that even though the employee, Sharon Karibian, who worked in the university's fund-raising office, had not suffered any economic loss because of the reported harassment, she was entitled to sue. The focus of such a case, it said, should be on the behavior of the accused harasser. 
 The appeals court said that an employer could be held liable for the behavior of employees who use their supervisory roles to demand sexual favors of lower-ranked personnel.
But the jury did not find that Mr. Urban had sexually harassed Ms. Karibian. Fred Knubel, a Columbia spokesman, said that "there is no basis for a verdict awarding damages against Columbia."
Judge Thomas P. Griesa said in court that he was puzzled by the verdict. The university has asked him to set it aside.
 Ms. Karibian said that her supervisor, Mark Urban, had threatened to cut her hours if she did not have a sexual relationship with him. Indeed, Mr. Urban gave Ms. Karibian pay raises and promotions, which she said were conditional upon a continuing sexual relationship.
 Ms. Karibian went to university committees numerous times to complain about Mr. Urban. "The jury found that Colombia has a duty to investigate these complaints, and by its failure to do so, implicitly condoned the behavior," said Elizabeth L. Coob, Ms. Karibian's lawyer.

HEADLINE: Sudan, Denying Terrorism Role, Vows to Resist World Pressure

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Top Sudanese officials, facing increasing international pressure for allowing terrorist groups to operate in the country, are making an attempt to cooperate with Security Council demands on one hand while threatening retaliation on the other.
The Security Council wants the Sudan to surrender three Egyptians suspected of involvement in the attempt to assassinate Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, last June in Ethiopia.
Sudanese officials have said repeatedly that they do not believe the suspects are in the Sudan. Nevertheless, the Interior Ministry has ordered all Egyptians to register with the police, and arrest warrants issued by the country's Prosecutor General are being read repeatedly on state radio and television.
Officials here warn that the country's Islamic military Government might lash back in the event of sanctions, although the United Nations is far from imposing any sanctions.
In this country, where the lead-in to the television evening news often includes images of lightning striking the Statue of Liberty, anti-American sentiments are common among officials.
"If people push us into a corner, we're going to fight back," Dr. Ghazi Atabari, the Secretary General of the National Congress, said in an interview. "Any means that is available to us, we'll use it."
Mahdi Ibrahim, the country's representative-designate to the United States, said in a separate conversation: "If action is taken against Sudan, it is baseless, it is a gross departure from the norms of justice, and it will only affect the people."
The United States has withdrawn its diplomats from Khartoum because, it says, the Government provides sanctuary for the Islamic Group, which claimed responsibility for the attack on Mr. Mubarak, as well as for other violent Muslim militant organizations.
Hassan al-Turabi, the leader of the National Islamic Front and perhaps the country's most influential political force, dismissed as "foolish" the American contention that the Sudan supports violent terrorist groups, and he said those beliefs fuel anti-American propaganda.
"You know human beings," he said. "Evil has to be adapted into somebody or something. "Now in Sudan, America has come to play that role."
Representatives of the Organization for African Unity and the United Nations are now in the Sudan for talks on the issue, and the Security Council has given Secretary General Boutros-Boutros Ghali until March 31 to report on whether the Sudan has cooperated in surrendering the suspects to Ethiopia.
In what it has portrayed as a sign of its earnestness, the Sudan in recent days has asked Ethiopia to provide further information to help in tracking down the suspects. Ethiopia, already at odds with the Sudan, has challenged its sincerity.
"Since Sudan knows full well where the three gunmen are being sheltered and protected by its own security personnel, the notice issued by its prosecutor is the latest confirmation Sudan is not about to comply with the request of the Security Council," Ethiopia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.
Saddiq al-Mahdi, the Prime Minister who was overthrown in a 1989 coup here by Lieut. Gen. Omar Hassan Bashir, said the steps taken by the United States and the United Nations indicate the deterioration in relations between the Sudan and the rest of the world.
"The regime has come to the end of its tether," Mr. Mahdi said in an hourlong conversation in his home. "How long it can remain there, I don't know."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Belichick Isn't Moving to Baltimore

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH 

 BODY:
In what could be his final break with Cleveland, Art Modell dismissed Coach Bill Belichick yesterday, saying that the team's relocation to Baltimore offered "a new beginning, a fresh start."
"We've had some success with Bill, including an 11-5 playoff team in 1994," Modell said in a statement. "However, I believe to get to the next level, a change at head coach is necessary. I've said this before, I have great respect for the effort Bill puts into his coaching and preparation." 
 Modell wants to hire a new coach as quickly as possible. One candidate is Ted Marchibroda, who was fired by the Indianapolis Colts last Friday and who coached the Baltimore Colts from 1975-79. Don Shula turned down Modell's offer to come out of retirement.
Belichack was at his office yesterday at the Browns' complex in Berea, Ohio, after his dismissal.
"I appreciate the opportunity to coach the Cleveland Browns for the last five years," Belichick said in a statement. "I will always cherish the many memories of being part of the rich tradition and history of the Cleveland Browns. This team has an excellent future and I wish them well."
Belichick, who was 37-45 from 1991-95 and had just one winning season (11-5 and a wi'd-card berth in 1994), won't be unemployed for long. Both New England Coach Bill Parcells, who worked with Belichick with the Giants, and Miami Dolphins Coach Jimmy Johnson are interested in Belichick to become their defensive coordinator.
The Browns got off to a fast 3-1 start in 1995, but things turned sour after Modell announced his intentions to move the team out of Cleveland. Belichick benched quarterback Vinny Testaverde for three games during the middle of the season in favor of the rookie Eric Zeier in an effort to spark the team. It didn't work. The Browns, 4-4 at the time of the announcement, dropped seven of their last eight games and finished 5-11.
Belichick's tenure with the Browns will forever be linked with his decision to bench Bernie Kosar, a Cleveland-area native and local favorite, for Testaverde in 1993. The fans began calling for his head after the Browns finished with back-to-back 7-9 seasons, 1992 and '93.
Modell responded to the criticism by giving Belichick a vote of confidence and a two-year contract extension. Somewhere between last year's playoff appearance and the move to Baltimore, Modell reconsidered his confidence in the 43-year-old coach.
Belichick got his coaching start in 1975 as a 23-year-old special assistant coach -- a gofer, more or less -- in Baltimore with Marchibroda. "He was a young man who was willing to work round the clock for nothing and learned everything he could about the game," Marchibroda has said.
 
 
 
Steelers Say Jets Tampered
 The Pittsburgh Steelers filed a formal complaint with the National Football League this week, charging the Jets with tampering with quarterback Neil O'Donnell. The charge stems from comments that Jets Coach Rich Kotite made about O'Donnell, a potential free agent, during a news conference last week to announce the hiring of the former Steeler offensive coordinatop Ron Erhardt.
Kotite was asked whether Erhardt's close relationship with O'Donnell might influence the quarterback to sign with the Jets as a free agent. Kotite's detailed response struck Tom Donahoe, the Steelers' director of football operations, as inappropriate.
Donahoe filed a similar tampering complaint against Carolina last year, regarding the Panthers' contact with the Steeler defensive coordinator Dom Capers. Later, Capers became the Panthers' head coach. Commissioner Paul Tagliabue agreed with the Steelers and the Panthers were fined $150,000 and lost second- and sixth-round picks in the 1995 draft.
 
 
 
Falcons' George a Team Player
 Jeff George said he wants to remain with Atlanta and is willing to take less money if it would help the Falcons keep other top free agents.
George and his agent, Leigh Steinberg, met with the team president, Taylor Smith, the vice president for personnel, Ken Herock, and Coach June Jones yesterday in Suwanee, Ga., in an effort to work out a deal.
"If it takes me taking less money to re-sign Bob Whitfield, Roman Fortin or Terance Mathis, I know what it takes to keep a team," George said. "Losing guys is not healthy for the team, and I want to do what is best for the Falcons." (AP)

HEADLINE: Washington's Mayor Wants to Cut City's Work Force by 25%

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. today offered his vision of the future for the nation's capital, an ambitious plan to reduce the size of the city work force by 25 percent and to privatize some operations that have contributed to the city's financial crisis.
In disclosing ideas to make the District more "competitive, business-friendly, user-friendly and people-oriented," Mr. Barry used some of his harshest language ever to condemn the way the government runs and to criticize employees whose skills and manners have undermined public confidence in and respect for government. 
 "Here in Washington, D.C., this government transformation comes none too soon," Mr. Barry said after distributing a 120-page report that outlines his strategies. "Too many services are being performed badly. Many have been discontinued. Far too much of our equipment is antiquated and is in sorry shape. Our management and financial systems are old-fashioned and out of step. The lines for service are too long."
He added, "The D.C. government as measured by any reasonable expectation of the residents comes up short and is headed in the wrong direction."
Symbolically, the plan is a major political shift for Mr. Barry, who has been Washington's Mayor for all but four of the last 18 years. His broad-based popularity has been built on creating jobs in the city government.
But as the employment rolls grew through the flush 1980's, so did the seeds of fiscal undoing in the 1990's. And neither Sharon Pratt Kelly, who was Mayor from 1990 to 1994, nor Mr. Barry, who won re-election after a six-month term in prison for using cocaine, took steps to reverse the pattern.
Now, with the city strained by a $378 million deficit and a law requiring the budget to be balanced by 1999, Mr. Barry said that within four years the government would reduce its work force to 30,000 from the 40,000 on the books last November.
The Mayor did not say when workers might be dismissed or how much the transformation process would cost. He promised those details on Friday, when he plans to discuss the budget for the 1997 fiscal year.
Under the plan, as many as 16 agencies would be combined into 6 under the Mayor's direct authority. Also, Mr. Barry proposed that the District prison system be privatized and that the Lorton Federal Prison, which the city runs, be shut down.
Mr. Barry did not second-guess his own management practices.
"It was right for the times," he said of his policies of the 1980's.
Mr. Barry said the people involved in developing the new plan, including local elected officials, business leaders and management consultants, started with the concept that no government existed. The model they developed characterized residents and visitors as "customers" and placed government functions in six "retail" categories that directly serve the public, like police and schools, and four "wholesale" categories, like legal services and financial management, that serve the government.
Mr. Barry stressed that no changes could proceed without support and approval from, for example,the City Council, the Control Board and Congress, which has the ultimate authority over all District operations.
Representative Thomas M. Davis 3d, the Virginia Republican who is chairman of the District Operations Subcommittee, said that he was "encouraged by what the Mayor had to say" but that he would not comment further until he knew more details.
The Control Board said it would not comment until after the budget is released on Friday.

HEADLINE: East's Coal Towns Wither In the Name of Cleaner Air

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: FAIRMONT, W.Va, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Charles Riley weaves his pickup through snow-coated hills spotted with the small farms and scattered homes of his fellow coal miners. He points to the mountainous gob heap of castaway shale and rock, to the tall concrete portals in the flanks of hills, to the five-story superstructure of the new, 320-foot elevator shaft.
Far beneath these roads lies the dank and eerie subterranean city that is the Tygart River Mine. The state of the art in coal mining, it spreads over more than 20 square miles with a grid of numbered streets and avenues, trolley tracks, pipes to drain off the sulfur- and acid-laced water and cables for running machines and computers. 
 "Last summer, management said there was another 15 or 20 years of coal in here," said Mr. Riley, 49, a son and grandson of miners, a high school graduate who put his three children through four years of college. "Everyone went and bought new homes, new cars. I bought a new Jeep Cherokee."
But the Peabody Holding Company, the nation's largest coal producer, shut down the Tygart River Mine and dismissed all 368 workers last December, making it one of hundreds of mines to close in a landscape altered by a single provision of the Clean Air Act of 1990. Tygart was the biggest operation in once-mine-pocked Marion County, and its closing leaves just one large mine open in Marion. Adjacent Monongalia County lost two of its five major mines last year, and a third that employs 500 miners is to close this year.
Conditions across most of the Eastern coal country are the bleakest since the Great Depression, largely because the coal here is too high in sulfur to easily meet the clean air requirements. Mines are thriving in the West and in eastern Kentucky and southern West Virginia, all producers of low-sulfur coal. But they are closing through most of Appalachia and in other coal-mining areas east of the Mississippi, and their loss is leaving huge gaps in the surrounding communities. It is the anguished human face of policies that even miners acknowledge have purified the air they breathe and the streams they fish in.
Since 1990, according to the National Coal Association, nearly 1,000 coal mines have closed in the United States, nearly all east of the Mississippi, leaving 2,500. The United Mine Workers of America says coal mine employment in Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, western Kentucky and northern West Virginia has plunged more than 30 percent since the start of the decade, to 25,906 workers, about half because of automation. In the highly automated, surface-mined states of Colorado and Wyoming, employment has grown about 2 percent, to 5,514.
The mines in the high-sulfur areas are shutting because when the coal they yield is burned, the sulfur produces sulfur dioxide, a cause of acid rain. Under the Clean Air Act, power plants were required to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions by half as of January 1995, and they must cut them further by 2000.
Utilities can install scrubbers to filter their smoke, but the scrubbers cost $100 million or more, so few have. Often at less cost, they can meet the air standards by blending high-sulfur coal with low-sulfur coal from Wyoming and Montana or from eastern Kentucky and southern West Virginia.
Either way, the Clean Air Act has cut demand for high-sulfur coal and driven down prices to a point where many mine operators say they cannot make profits.
"Because of market conditions and the Clean Air Act, it was a marginal situation to begin with," said Garry Groves, a spokesman for the Eastern Associated Coal Corporation, the Peabody subsidiary that operated the Tygart River Mine.
Then, in August, a roof caved in. Only one worker was injured, losing a finger. But preventing future damage was too costly in view of the low price of the coal. "That was the last straw," Mr. Groves said. Peabody is now turning more to low-sulfur Western mines.
Nationwide, coal production is headed for a record 1.05 billion tons, said John Grasser, a spokesman for the National Coal Association. In the 1990's production in the long-dominant East will have fallen 14 percent by the end of this year, to 542 million tons annually, while in the West it will have jumped 26 percent, to 504 million tons. "It's directly related to the low-sulfur coal out there," Mr. Grasser said.
With the shutdown here in north-central West Virginia, Peabody drove a spike through the heart of an economy whose gentry -- with cars bought for cash, backyard swimming pools, wives who stayed home -- consisted of the $50,000-a-year men who dug the coal.
What hurts the miners hurts the local economy in proportions far exceeding the effect of other jobs. In 1994, before the Tygart River Mine closed, Marion County's 1,342 coal miners made up 7 percent of the workers and collected 16 percent of the wages paid in the county. Companies that equip mines and service their gear, also high wage payers, are folding as fast as the mines.
Jobs in mining, manufacturing and construction energize an economy more than others. Economists call them primary jobs because they beget secondary jobs that cater to the primary employers and their workers. "They have a lot to do with driving a local economy," said Stephen Shackelford, an economist in the West Virginia Bureau of Employment Programs.
With the loss of the mines and of several factories as well, he said, Marion County has lost nearly 400 retail jobs in the first half of the 1990's and 27 of its 355 stores. A study done for the Marion County Chamber of Commerce says county residents are spending $90 million more a year outside the county than in it.
"It hurts," said Charles Reese, president of the Marion County Chamber of Commerce. Along with the loss of mines, the county, with a population of 58,000, is littered with the corpses of departed manufacturing companies, like Owens-Illinois, a glass company, and Sharon Steel.
Mr. Reese said the county's 9 percent unemployment rate, compared with the national rate of 5.6 percent, was actually higher because many workers had stopped looking for jobs and were not counted.
"Things are not balancing out," he said. "We are getting some high-technology jobs where the skills are high but the wages are low. I think sometimes we should yell and scream more. It's just not our style."
Miners tend to be among the brightest of the community's high school students because the wages for the jobs have given mine operators the pick of the lot. The average miner here today is in his late 40's.
Like Charles Riley, Michael Chefren, 50, went no further than high school but has put three children through college and into careers far removed from mining. He started at the Tygart River Mine 21 years ago, about a year after it opened, and became a surface maintenance supervisor earning $55,000 a year. The money enabled him to buy a 45-acre farm. His wife, Jean, does not work.
"Everything we own is paid for," he said. "No mortgage. If I buy it, I pay for it. The last thing I financed was a car, in 1985." He has savings, is taking federally financed courses and is thinking of starting a business.
Even if he could, he is not certain he would return to the mine. "I feel pretty good not getting up at 5 o'clock in the morning and putting in 12 and 14 hours a day," he said.
Rich Eddy of Fairmont, president of District 31 of the United Mine Workers of America, who oversees members in 31 of the state's 55 counties, says he is still skeptical that high-sulfur coal contributes to acid rain. But many miners welcome the changes that environmental regulation has brought.
"All of us grew up in coal camps and lived within walking distance of the mines," said Gary Pastorial, 46, who was laid off from Tygart. "Everyone burned coal in their homes, and when you went out in the evening, you couldn't see the air. One of my chores was to scrub the front porch with a mop every day because it was black."
Today Mr. Pastorial lives in a spotless ranch house he just built in an upper-income subdivision, and he looks upon a horizon of pristine air. "The West Fork River was dead," he said. "Now people fish in it."
Congress is helping to soften the blow of layoffs attributed to the Clean Air Act. Like most people who lose their jobs, the miners receive unemployment compensation for six months. But the Government also pays for them to go to school for up to two years to learn new skills and keeps paying them their unemployment benefit, typically $290 a week, for the duration.
But no training is likely to yield jobs like the ones these men have lost. Many are taking courses in the construction trades, which pay a little more than a third of the $17 an hour they typically earned in the mines. But a state analysis of the county economy says that in 1994 and 1995, there were 456 applicants for 21 construction jobs.
"If they don't go to school, they're going to be lucky to get $5 an hour," said Cathy Tarley, manager of Marion County office of the state job service. "If they do go to school for two years, they might get $8 to $10."
Most new jobs are in health care and in Government offices requiring clerical skills. "We're trying to get wives in for training," Mrs. Tarley said. "A lot of the jobs that are being created are more suitable for females."
John Beveridge spent 22 years in the mines, the last 13 at the Peabody mine. He is a roof bolter, a highly skilled worker who bores six-foot-long rods into the roofs of mines to keep them from falling. It is treacherous work; the driller must learn to read sounds and vibrations to know when a roof might crash. Mr. Beveridge said his worst injury was a broken leg.
As a youth, he completed three years of college, majoring in psychology. He also boxed professionally for 15 years as a hobby. But nothing paid like mining. "You could work seven days a week if you wanted to," Mr. Beveridge said. He made $48,000 last year in the mine before he was let go in early October.
"I'm scared to death," he said. "I'm 44 years old. I'd like to live another 50 years. What am I going to do?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

TV Networks May Rate Their Programs' Content
ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox are discussing the creation of a ratings system for the content of programs, similar to the one used for movies. The talks end years of protest that any attempt to regulate the content of their programs amounted to censorship.
Many people in the industry see the system as a way to preempt any effort to establish Government ratings. [Page A1.]
 
Stocks Catch Their Breath
Blue chips fell as profit-taking ended a seven-session run of consecutive closing highs for the Dow Jones industrial average. The Dow fell 21.68 points, to 5,579.55, and the broad market declined. [D10.]
 
Bond prices gave up some of their recent gains, as worries crept into the market in the absence of economic news. [D17.]
 
Deutsche Bank Appointment
Deutsche Bank North America named Carter McClelland as president. He had come to Deutsche Bank from Morgan Stanley, with a number of other highly paid investment bankers, as Deutsche Bank tried to build a Wall Street franchise. [D2.]
 
Gibson Greetings Dismisses Chief
Gibson Greetings, the third-largest greeting card company, dismissed its chief executive and said it was no longer for sale. [D10.]
 
Murdoch's Latin Plans Set Back
A Chinese rocket carrying a television satellite exploded after launch, dealing a potential blow to Rupert Murdoch's ambitions to offer programming in Latin America with three partners. His News Corporation insisted that the accident would not disrupt plans to offer 150 channels of entertainment, news and sports programming. [D8.]
 
Business Becomes a Target
Politicians in both parties are raising the issue of corporate responsibility, making a theme of what was barely a whisper a few months ago. "This is the big coming issue of American politics," said Robert Shrum, a Democratic consultant. [B15.]
 
Chip Industry at Crossroads
The chip industry is asking whether its fast growth can continue. The answer is far from certain, considering the fortunes of Cirrus Logic, which is forecasting a loss, and Applied Materials, which had record results. [D4.]
 
T.W.A. Trims Losses
T.W.A. greatly narrowed its losses for the fourth quarter and 1995, and had an operating profit for the first year since 1989. [D7.]
 
Anti-Counterfeit Notes
New Swiss banknotes are so technologically advanced that it has become a Swiss game to spot their anti-counterfeiting features. The 50-franc note was designed on a computer and a raised triangle at one end helps the blind tell its value. [D6.]
 
Home Banking, From Microsoft
Visa and Microsoft plan to collaborate on a system offering home banking and bill-paying services, dealing a blow to Intuit. [D4.]
 
A Cloud Over Turner Stock
The gap between what Time Warner is offering for Turner Broadcasting, and the price of Turner shares, suggests that arbitragers are waiting to see how the Government responds to the merger, and the resolution of a lawsuit by U S West to stop it. Market Place. [D10.]
 
British Give Up Tax Simplicity
The British are about to give up their system of having the taxman simply send them a bill, as they move toward the thicket of forms and rules common in the United States. Until now, British tax inspectors sent out notices advising people how much they owed. But in April, people will have to start keep detailed records. [D6.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: ON THE MOVE;
Fueled by Success, Buchanan Revels in Rapid-Fire Oratory

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 14

 BODY:
It was a blue-collar, red-meat moment in Patrick J. Buchanan's lyrically combative stump speech, and the crowd cheered each scrap as he spoke as the Republican Presidential candidate most eager to disparage Big Business.
"Look what's going on in our country, my friends," declared Mr. Buchanan, his voice energized by his surprising second-place perch in the Iowa caucuses and his promising chances here. "When AT&T lops off 40,000 jobs, the executioner that does it, he's a big hero on the cover of one of these magazines, and AT&T stock soars." 
 The candidate's perfect pitch of grievance and outrage keyed the partisan crowd to a din of sympathetic shouts and applause as he spoke for those 40,000, not the stockholders: "We've got to have a new conservatism of the heart that looks upon all Americans as brothers and sisters. We've got to be concerned about all of our folks."
The crowd packed into a restaurant banquet hall on Tuesday night alternated between booming approval and sharp attention as Mr. Buchanan, a politician near the top of his orating game, tore into "this idea of these new businesses, these cold-blooded characters with the green eyeshades."
"Yes!" shouted a listener in encouragement as Mr. Buchanan, his voice hoarse, his eyes merry with combat, roared onward: "That's not what conservatism is all about. That's arid, desiccated conservatism."
More cheers prompted a great grin from the candidate. As he was drenched in a chorus of "Go, Pat, go!" Mr. Buchanan cut off his followers with the cry of, "Let me tell you: Pat is going!"
Emboldened by what he terms a chain-lightning strategy of voter poll victories in Alaska and Louisiana and a finish within three points of Senator Bob Dole's Iowa victory, Mr. Buchanan has retooled his 1992 campaign speech into a kinetic, angry, optimistic sermon on "the new conservatism of the heart." Onto his moralizing base of anti-abortion social conservatism, he has grafted a sharp strain of economic populism, and the hybrid is proving attractive.
"A new conservatism of the heart that looks out for the right to life and the innocence of the unborn," Mr. Buchanan declaims. "A conservatism that speaks up for the working-class Americans who are betrayed by these trade deals that send their jobs over to Mexico, a new conservatism that's going to lift that burden of taxation and that burden of economic insecurity off the middle class. It's going to lift that burden of regulation and taxation off the small businesses that are the backbone of this country, that are creating the jobs when the big businesses are shutting them down."
Large audiences here and in Iowa across the last week have been delighting in his words, even as Dole strategists and other Establishment Republicans fret that the shadow of Mr. Buchanan as a kind of Beltway Huey Long will once more be cast across the party all the way to November. The best proof of his inroads is the fact that Mr. Dole has been hurriedly adapting his own stump speech with Buchanan-like jeremiads about cultural degradation and working-class despair.
"Change polls, change hearts, change minds, move forward," Mr. Buchanan intones, urging the upset of Senator Dole. "Accept your defeats. Get up. Go forward."
Bluff, affable and ever strategic, Mr. Buchanan mocks the distress of party warhorses as he seeks a coalition of the politically disaffected and displays his stump power as a polemicist. With his success thus far, Mr. Buchanan's talent for shrapnel-packed rhetoric has been easing into something more benign, even gracious at times. His ability to make a large crowd guffaw has rarely been as acute.
"Let me introduce to you the lady beside me last night who I finally decided I intend to nominate to replace Hillary Rodham Clinton," he says, always getting a laugh as he introduces his wife, Shelly, by taking double-barreled aim at the President's morals and the First Lady's talent for controversy.
Mr. Buchanan revels in skewering President Clinton's own instinct for political survival in having recently adapted to such conservative positions as praying in schools and renouncing Big Government. "Next week he'll be up here with the gun owners of New Hampshire," he says of the President, "holding an assault weapon over his head, wearing one of those camouflage outfits, saying, 'Don't try to take mah fah-arms away from me.' "
As the crowd fairly leers with pleasure, Mr. Buchanan adds, "This guy is shameless." Mr. Buchanan focuses more fire on the Republican front-runner, Mr. Dole, and is dismissive of other contenders like "Junior Forbes" and Lamar Alexander. "Look," he says of Mr. Alexander, "I've been a conservative for 25 years. He can't make up for that by walking across the state in a plaid shirt."
The candidate proudly tells of his political roots all the way back to the service of Richard M. Nixon's pre-White House strategy of 1966. "I was in training for break-ins at the time," says Mr. Buchanan, using a joke to get to the political crux learned from Mr. Nixon. "We talked together about Roosevelt's New Deal coalition, about how we could pull apart pieces of it and put together a new majority coalition."
Deadly serious, the candidate exhorts his audience to sweep New Hampshire byways for Reagan Democrats and Perot dissidents: "That's what we're building. This is an open movement."
Whether Mr. Buchanan can do more than roil the party's presumed center once more remains an open question until Tuesday, at least. Supporters prize his outspokenness but tend not to delve into any larger economic risks implied in his protectionist speechifying in behalf of worker-voters.
"Buchanan is the only man who will address the issue of the proliferation of gay legislation and say what he believes," said Dick Hugg, a farmer who heard Mr. Buchanan address the Knights of Columbus Saturday morning in Carroll, Iowa. There, the candidate, a Roman Catholic, twinned his main themes, moving from the "evil empire" of abortion to the papal encyclical, "Rerum Novarum," which a century ago stressed the moral right of workers to a living wage.
In the current shifting field, Mr. Buchanan appears to offer his signature anti-abortion position as a measure of political consistency as much as social conscience.
In the crowd's applause of the economic themes Tuesday night, Michael G. Biundo, a Buchanan voter from 1992, heard a difference. "This was more of a sprint in '92," said Mr. Biundo, now deputy director of the state campaign. "This time Pat senses it's only part of a larger mar

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ECONOMY;
Republicans and Democrats Jumping on the Issue of Corporate Responsibility

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts has always been considered a standard Republican fiscal conservative. But last month he gave his State of the State address a populist twist when he spoke of the "nagging fear" caused by corporate downsizing and lectured businesses that "you still have a responsibility for the good of the community in which you reside."
Far across the political spectrum, President Clinton's liberal Labor Secretary, Robert E. Reich, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts have called for using tax policy to encourage corporations to treat their workers better. Mr. Kennedy recently spoke of a "quiet Depression" and said government policies should provide "incentives for good corporate citizenship." 
 And now Senator Bob Dole, a traditional deficit-cutting Main Street Republican, has struck out against corporate greed, noting that "corporate profits are setting records and so are corporate layoffs" as he searches for a way to counter the economic nationalism of Patrick J. Buchanan.
Indeed, the call for corporate responsibility, which was barely a political whisper just months ago, has now become a theme of a crowded field of political figures.
The oratory does not necessarily lead Republicans and Democrats to the same places. Mr. Weld wants corporations to start hiring welfare recipients, while Mr. Reich suggests that corporate income taxes might be reduced or eliminated for companies that keep more employees on their payroll.
But major figures in both parties are being driven by the same concern about the political implications of a changing economy in which the gap between the well-to-do and the poor has been growing. The stock market hits new highs every day, yet median income is stagnant or falling.
President Clinton, for example, would love to take credit for the economic resurgence that has taken place since he took office. As he noted in his economic report to Congress today, the nation has nearly eight million new jobs, the budget deficit has nearly been halved, and the "misery index" that measures inflation and unemployment is at its lowest level in nearly three decades.
But in campaign speeches, he also acknowledges that "there is another side to America's economy: about half our people still haven't gotten a raise in terms of real purchasing power of their incomes in 10 or 15 years."
What has caught the eye of political strategists is that economic insecurity now afflicts two potentially volatile segments of the electorate: working-class Democrats who deserted their party in the Reagan years but then returned to Mr. Clinton in 1992 and a professional class of middle managers, among them Republicans and independents.
"An awful lot of Republicans have been losing jobs they thought would always be there in big corporations," said Kevin Phillips, a conservative political analyst.
In some ways, this could pose the greater challenge to the Republicans who have long held as central tenant the idea that "a rising tide lifts all boats" -- if businesses prosper, Americans prosper. But that axiom sounds less convincing when AT&T announces it is laying off 40,000 workers.
"What we've seen in the last 15 years is a whole Republican emphasis on markets and freeing up business and deregulation," Mr. Phillips said. "I think all of those trends have peaked and are in retreat and I think now even the Republicans are starting to understand that."
Other conservatives vehemently disagree. They find Mr. Buchanan's protectionist views abhorrent and say they believe that even Mr. Dole is treading on risky ground for a Republican when he points to high profits and stagnant wages.
"It plays into the hands of those who argue that there's something fundamentally wrong with the American economy, that there's market failure that government should come in and fix," said Stuart M. Butler of the conservative Heritage Foundation. "Countries that are entrepreneurial and have a dynamic economy clearly perform better than those that try to freeze change and give complete security."
For Mr. Clinton, these themes are also troublesome. He campaigned in 1992 on a pledge to make life better for the middle class. And voters, when judging an incumbent President, ask whether they are better off than they were four years ago. Does he want to tell them that they are not?
Mr. Clinton's advisers are divided into two camps. His team of pollsters and consultants argue that corporate downsizing is an overblown issue -- that the number of jobs created recently far outstrips those lost -- and that he should rally voters with optimism.
But another set of "paycheck" Democrats around Mr. Clinton, including liberals in his Administration and members of his 1992 camapign team, would like to see more emphasis on pocketbook issues.
So far he has restricted himself to calls for more education and training programs, for a higher minimum wage and the endorsement of a bill in Congress that would make health care benefits more available to people who change jobs or have pre-existing illnesses.
How this political dialogue develops over the next few months may depend less on Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole than on Republicans and Democrats who are not as concerned with hewing to the political center.
Several Congressional Democrats, fearful of losing their party's base, are drawing up initiatives to encourage companies to consider the well-being of their workers as well as their stockholders. And both parties are carefully watching how far Mr. Buchanan gets. In fact, the Clinton Administration included a lengthy defense of free trade in its economic report today.
While not naming Mr. Buchanan, the report argued with his assumption that increased foreign trade with low-wage countries has undercut the earnings of American workers. In almost all industries, Mr. Clinton's report maintained, the employment of skilled workers has increased even though they cost more.

HEADLINE: A Prominent Chicago Family Changes Course

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 14

 BODY:
The decision by the Gidwitz family to sell control of Helene Curtis Industries to the British-Dutch giant Unilever P.L.C., announced today, is as likely to be avidly discussed in social and political circles here, as on the business circuit.
"Chicago had its fair share of founding families in the 19th century, but in the 20th there have been few so intimately identified with the city as the Gidwitzes," said James Thompson, a former Governor of Illinois who is now managing partner at Winston & Strawn, one of the city's most influential law firms. "They are right up there with people like the Pritzkers and the Crowns." 
 The family's leading civic light is Ronald J. Gidwitz, 50, who is not only president and chief executive of Helene Curtis but is also one of Mayor Richard Daley's closest friends in the business community. Mr. Gidwitz is also a leading figure in local and state Republican party politics and a prominent member of numerous civic, cultural and educational boards.
Those boards that Mr. Gidwitz does not belong to often tap the fund-raising skills and enthusiasm of his wife, Christina Gidwitz. She is the daughter of James Kemper, founder of the Kemper insurance empire, and was already prominent locally as a fashion model when the couple married in 1975. The couple have two sons, 11 and 8, and live in the fashionable Gold Coast district near Lake Michigan, where Mr. Gidwitz served as a Republican ward leader for several years.
The Gidwitz family's involvement in Helene Curtis dates to 1927, when Ronald's grandfather, Jacob Gidwitz, invested $5,000 in what was then a struggling manufacturer of mudpacks and facial masks. Today, about 75 percent of the voting stock of the company is controlled by the Gidwitz family.
The company said today that Mr. Gidwitz intended to stay on as chief executive, which raised hopes here that the sale would not mean an end anytime soon to the company's commitment to manufacturing on the city's impoverished West Side.
Those who know Mr. Gidwitz will be watching to see how well he fares within the legendary bureaucracy of Unilever. "I think he likes running a company, and the influence being a C.E.O. brings is important to him," said David Paulus, a former senior executive at First Chicago Bank who became Mr. Gidwitz's friend when the two worked on political campaigns and school reform efforts here during the 1980's.
Mr. Gidwitz's civic background may have given him some helpful training for the corporate politics ahead. He has been prominent in recent years in his job as head of the troubled City Colleges, leading a series of cutbacks, administrative changes and tough union negotiations that have made him the focus of blistering attacks by local labor and education groups. That job, like an earlier position reviving the city's Economic Development Committee, at times consumed as many as 30 hours a week.
"He's very gutsy," said Grace Berry, executive director of the Economic Club of Chicago. "He's really tried to be the change agent in some tough situations."
