HEADLINE: POLITICS: BOWING OUT;
Big Budget, Early Start and the Candidate Are Figured in the Collapse of Gramm's Bid

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
He peaked too early.
A year ago, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas was assembling a campaign juggernaut. He declared for President before anyone else. He raised $4.1 million at a dinner in Dallas, one of the largest takes for a single campaign event in American political history. He spent a fortune winning dozens of straw polls, all nonbinding but all intended to bring an air of momentum and inevitability to Mr. Gramm's bid for the White House. 
 And while several big G.O.P. names like Kemp, Cheney, Quayle and Bennett skipped the race, bemoaning the logistical and gastrointestinal demands of the chicken-dinner circuit, Mr. Gramm said he just loved asking people for support.
But today, barely a week after voters started selecting actual delegates to the Republican convention, Mr. Gramm's $21.1 million offensive came to a screeching halt, in perhaps the most spectacular collapse of a Presidential campaign since Mr. Gramm's fellow Texan, John B. Connally, famously spent $12 million to capture one delegate to the 1980 Republican convention.
"When the voter speaks, I listen," Mr. Gramm said in Washington in withdrawing from the race today, two days after finishing fifth in the Iowa caucuses, "especially when the voter is saying someone else's name." But the Senator said he was not endorsing anyone today.
What went wrong in the Gramm campaign? Interviews with voters, and with political operatives in and out of the Gramm camp, point to a number of strategic missteps and an overarching conclusion that the campaign's organizational and fund-raising muscle, especially when boasted about by the candidate himself, backfired with the voters.
The strategic problems include a major failure to anticipate the serious and ultimately successful one-on-one challenge in last week's Louisiana caucuses from Patrick J. Buchanan -- "a tactical blunder of enormous proportions," said Senator John McCain of Arizona, Mr. Gramm's national chairman. Mr. Gramm also angered leading officials in Iowa and New Hampshire by backing other states' efforts to hold earlier primaries or caucuses.
And internal campaign memorandums suggest that even with ahuge budget for television commercials, Mr. Gramm had image problems with the voters.
"Thank God for the mute button," was one member of a New Hampshire focus group's response to an early spot featuring Mr. Gramm.
Of course, the most elemental conclusion remains that even when voters had ample opportunity to see Mr. Gramm's face and hear his voice, they did not cotton to the candidate.
The owlish, drawling Mr. Gramm delighted in telling audiences that his own wife's first reaction to him was "Yuck!" -- the real point being that in time, she came to discover his virtues and the American people would too. But voters spent far less time with him than Wendy Lee Gramm did.
"I don't think he could ever overcome the 'Yuck!' factor in this campaign," said Richard W. Murray, a political science professor and longtime Gramm observer at the University of Houston.
And another lesson of the Gramm campaign is that a huge financial war-chest will only bring a candidate so far, and can even amount to a turnoff. Mr. Gramm has probably lived to regret his eyebrow-raising remark to supporters at the glittering Dallas dinner: "Thanks to you, I have the most reliable friend you can have in American politics, and that's ready money."
The focus-group interviews, according to a September memo by a Gramm pollster named Linda DiVall, showed that a commercial trumpeting the Senator's successes to date actually made voters suspicious: "Iowa straw poll is meaningless," said one man, according to the memo. "It was bought."
Mr. Gramm said he would now concentrate on his re-election this fall. His negative ratings in Texas, however, are higher than either of the state's other leading Republicans -- Gov. George W. Bush and Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison -- and several well-established Democrats are vying in a March primary for the right to challenge him in November.
Still, for the moment, Mr. Gramm and his top advisers are clearly assessing just what happened to the campaign. As his campaign manager in New Hampshire put it: "The strategy could have gone off like a rocket, but it was one of those things that didn't go. It didn't take off."
The basic strategy was to establish Mr. Gramm early on, in his words, as "the conservative alternative to Bob Dole." The fund raising helped to scare off some competitors and the straw polls were intended to show that Mr. Gramm was more viable than other candidates.
But he invested millions early on and in securing the victories in what were technically meaningless contests, Mr. Gramm ultimately seems to have set the bar needlessly high for expectations about his campaign. Rather than casting himself as an underdog and rising up, he declared himself the big dog early on and went downhill from there.
Even in Louisiana, where he could have portrayed the contest as a dogfight between himself and Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Gramm insisted up until the end that he would win and win huge; in losing, his campaign was all but finished, with no momentum going into Iowa.
In Iowa and New Hampshire, where voters and state leaders alike jealously guard their first-in-the-nation voting status on the road to the nomination, Mr. Gramm's decision to enter the Louisiana caucuses alienated some people. "I think Phil Gramm made a big mistake playing footsie with Louisiana," said Iowa's Governor, Terry E. Branstad.
Several top officials in Mr. Gramm's campaign argued today that many economic conservatives found Mr. Gramm appealing but still believed that it was Mr. Dole's turn for the Republican nomination, and that conservatives who were focused on social issues had been drawn to Mr. Buchanan.
"It's kind of a game where being a lot of people's second choice isn't enough," said Charles Black, Mr. Gramm's chief strategist. Speaking of religious conservatives in Louisiana and Iowa, he said: "In the end, they opted for the more fiery, passionate presentation of their views that Buchanan gives."
Still, Mr. Gramm's credentials with these conservatives may have been suspect all along; early on in the campaign, he was widely quoted as having said, in explaining that economic issues were paramount in his campaign, "I ain't running for preacher."
The post-mortems on his campaign will continue to address the issue of whether the real problem was the messenger or the message. While many Republicans said that Mr. Gramm was simply neither telegenic nor personally appealing to voters, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Christopher J. Dodd, wasted no time in arguing that the real failure in the campaign was that of the message.
"Phil, probably more than any candidate in this field, took the Gingrich new Congress program on the road," Mr. Dodd said today. "On the economic, conservative message of the Gingrich Congress and the Contract with America, it doesn't fly."
After losing Louisiana, aides said, Mr. Gramm fully realized that his campaign was probably doomed, but he decided to soldier on into Iowa, and he did so not without humor or panache.
At one point last weekend, just before getting off the bus in Davenport, he stood and thanked his workers and, apparently inspired by the company of Charlton Heston on the campaign trail, suddenly intoned a close approximation of Shakespearean dialogue, from the Battle of Agincourt, from "Henry V":
"Men abed in England will think themselves accursed they were not here with us," Senator Gramm said before hopping off the bus and plunging himself before the Iowans, "and hold their manhood cheap while any speak who fought with us on St. Crispin's day."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE PRIMARIES;
New England Finds G.O.P. Trying Out New Tactics

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 14

 BODY:
Searching for an edge in the tight primary race here, the Republican candidates for President tested new tactics today.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas concentrated on foreign policy for the first time in weeks, criticizing President Clinton's stands in Bosnia and Haiti and emphasizing his opponents' lack of experience in this area. 
 Energized by a strong second-place showing in the Iowa caucuses on Monday night, Patrick J. Buchanan leveled the most savage attack he had ever tried on Mr. Dole.
Steve Forbes, coming off a poor showing in Iowa and dropping in several opinion polls, declared that he had made a mistake in recent weeks by broadcasting so many advertisements criticizing his opponents. Today, he turned to a new set of commercials that emphasize his advocacy of a low, flat tax and other issues.
Lamar Alexander, still in fourth place in the polls but apparently gaining new strength, campaigned with his newest champion, William J. Bennett, the conservative Secretary of Education in the Reagan Administration. Mr. Alexander's emphasis today was on his proposal to overhaul the welfare system.
In Washington, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas officially withdrew from the Presidential race. "When the voter speaks," Mr. Gramm said at a news conference, "I listen, especially when the voter is saying someone else's name."
Mr. Dole called Mr. Gramm this morning, and the word in political circles was that Mr. Gramm would endorse him. But Mr. Gramm withheld making an endorsement today, although he made it clear that Mr. Buchanan would not win him over. "I believe that Pat Buchanan's stand on protectionism is at variance with our party's commitment," he said.
With Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former representative to the United Nations, at his side, Mr. Dole displayed his grasp of foreign policy issues. He said that had he been President he would have lifted the embargo on selling arms to Bosnia but would not have sent American troops. He also said the Clinton Administration was wrong to send money to Haiti to support the former President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
The goal of Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader, was to draw attention to the fact that his rivals have had little experience dealing with such matters.
"My point is this," Mr. Dole, looking rested, told business leaders at a breakfast in Nashua, "I know foreign policy is rarely considered when you walk into the voting booth. You're worried about jobs and crime, education and the environment, Medicare, whatever, taxes. If a crisis occurs, maybe on the first days of someone's watch in 1997, or maybe the first week or the first month or the first six months, it's good to have somebody around the White House who's had some experience.
"It's not the place for on-the-job training," he declared.
Mr. Buchanan's first stop on Valentine's Day was at a company in Madbury that grows roses. He bought a dozen for his wife, Shelley, and used the occasion to reinforce his position in favor of trade restrictions. By lowering tariffs on South American flowers, he said, the United States is "killing one flower grower after another after another after another."
Then Mr. Buchanan went on the attack. He called Mr. Dole "the biggest taxer in the modern history of the Republican Party," "Mr. Nafta, Mr. Gatt and Mr. Mexican bailout" and "an Archer-Daniels-Midland Republican." The last snipe was a reference to the financial support Mr. Dole has received over the years from Dwayne O. Andreas, the chairman, and other executives at the giant agricultural conglomerate.
"Mr. Dole put the interest of the big banks -- Citibank, Chase Manhattan, Goldman Sachs -- ahead of the American people," Mr. Buchanan declared.
Mr. Forbes did not so much apologize for the pervasive negative commercials he has been broadcasting as indicate that he thought they had damaged his campaign.
Standing in the snow outside his bus in Milford, Mr. Forbes said: "Clearly, I spent too much time -- we spent too much time -- discussing the records of our opponents. I want to now concentrate on what I'm standing for, how I think America can have a chance to move ahead."
The Forbes campaign went on the air today with three new advertisements. In one, Mr. Forbes discusses on camera the economic benefits he believes the country will gain from his flat-tax proposal. In another, he advocates medical savings accounts. In a third, he calls for giving parents greater choices in schools for their children and Government vouchers to help parents pay for private schools.
Mr. Forbes even offered a new metaphor for the American tax system. He no longer called it "a playground for lawyers and lobbyists." Now, it is "a nauseating swamp of loopholes, a toxic cesspool."
The Alexander campaign said the former Tennessee Governor and Education Secretary would focus on a different issue each day this week. The issue du jour today was welfare, which meant that Mr. Alexander added a few paragraphs on the subject to his standard speech.
His position is that the main Federal welfare programs, Aid to Families With Dependent Children and food stamps, should be scrapped. Instead, he said, the money should be turned over to private charities and foundations in communities across the country to fulfill the functions now performed by Government agencies.

HEADLINE: With Prices Low, Gasoline Guzzling Makes a Comeback

 BODY:
More Americans are driving bigger cars and trucks longer distances -- and at faster speeds -- with scarcely a thought for mileage conservation or pollution.
With prices at the pump, when adjusted for inflation, at lows not seen since the 1950's, gasoline consumption is increasing. After declining slightly from 1989 through 1991, consumption rose by 1.1 percent in 1992, 1.4 percent in 1993 and 1.7 percent in 1994 before shooting up 2.5 percent last year, according to the American Petroleum Institute. And analysts expect the rise to continue. 
 With memories of the oil shocks of the 1970's fading, the oil cartel apparently broken and prices generally stable over the last decade, motorists have little incentive to conserve energy, analysts say. Indeed, the gas mileage of most of the popular sport utility vehicles and mini-vans is not much better than the monster gas guzzlers of old.
This fundamental shift in Americans' driving habits, however, is worrying environmentalists and strategic planners.
And some experts fear Americans are becoming complacent about the risk of becoming increasingly dependent on foreign oil supplies.
Article, page C1.

HEADLINE: 4 NETWORKS PLAN A RATINGS SYSTEM FOR THEIR SHOWS

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
After years of resisting as censorship any attempt to regulate the content of television programs, the four broadcast networks are seeking to establish their own ratings system, similar to the Motion Picture Association of America's code for movies.
In meetings this week in New York and Los Angeles, ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox have been discussing a system that would allow them to assuage growing public discontent over the violence and sexual content of some television programs and hold onto advertisers without jeopardizing the networks' longstanding argument that ratings constitute censorship. 
 The creation of the networks' own system is seen by many in the industry as an effort to seize the initiative and preempt any Government effort to establish content ratings, as permitted under a sweeping telecommunications bill that became law last week. Should the F.C.C. reject the industry's ratings as inadequate, a step that the law permits, the broadcasters would have firmer grounds for a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the new law, industry officials said.
But the networks have several other motives as well, people close to the talks this week said, including overwhelming pressure from the public and from politicians angered by the level of violence and sex on television and in films.
In addition, ABC and Fox have recently signaled that they favor a rating system for the networks. Fear that one or the other might create its own system and publicize it as "family-friendly" is putting pressure on NBC and CBS, several officials at the networks said. ABC, part of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., was recently acquired by the Walt Disney Company, a conglomerate whose success is built on its image as family entertainment.
Any rating system devised by the networks -- whether similar to that used for movies, or using a different code, or perhaps age classifications -- would eventually enable consumers to screen out certain programs by using an electronic blocking device known as a V-chip, with the "V" standing for "violence," industry officials said. The telecommunications act requires all new television sets to be equipped with the V-chip.
Objections to the amount of sex and violence on television and in the movies have come from all sides of the political spectrum, from President Clinton to Senator Bob Dole, the Republican majority leader; to William Bennett, the conservative former Education Secretary, to Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, the original champion of the V-chip.
President Clinton has invited the chief executives of the four broadcast networks and about a dozen cable-network executives to a meeting on Feb. 28 on the issue of television content. The broadcast network executives are hoping to reach a consensus on a ratings system before that meeting.
"Family values" and the entertainment industry's role in promoting or destroying them is a potent topic in this election year, as the network executives acknowledge.
At a closed annual meeting last week for top Capital Cities executives in Phoenix that was attended for the first time by Disney executives, Robert A. Iger, president of Capital Cities/ABC, told colleagues that the pressure for V-chip legislation reflected a wave of strong public opinion and that the company should find a way to allay that dissatisfaction, an industry executive said.
Fox's position in favor of a ratings system was less predictable, given that the network has often been criticized for broadcasting sexually explicit shows and that Rupert Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation, which owns the network, has generally fought Government regulation of broadcasting.
But officials at rival networks who insisted on anonymity suggested that giving such shows a rating would in a sense defuse criticism of them, because parents would be alerted to the content and could program their V-chip to block shows they found objectionable.
The same point has been made to explain the cable industry's receptivity to an industry-devised ratings system. Although shows with coarse language, excessive violence or sexually suggestive scenes are more common on cable than on broadcast television, there are so many cable networks -- some of them known for such content -- that the industry as a whole is less averse to labeling.
The broadcast networks, on the other hand, rely on a broader audience than cable does. Their revenue comes from advertising, while cable revenue comes partly from subscriber fees and partly from advertising.
Broadcasters have traditionally opposed content ratings and any sort of V-chip mechanism not only because of First Amendment concerns but also out of fear that advertisers will abandon shows that have been rated as violent or racy. For example, advertisers shied away from "N.Y.P.D. Blue," the ABC police drama, which contains coarse language and some nudity, in its first year. But many flocked to the program after it began receiving high ratings.
When the telecommunications law was being drafted last year, the networks believed they could challenge it as unconstitutional if it required a ratings system. Instead, the law requires manufacturers to install V-chips on new sets and states that if the networks establish ratings, they must transmit them through the V-chip.
The law urges the networks to devise their own ratings system within one year and requires the F.C.C. to review it. If the networks do not establish a system or the F.C.C. rejects it, the law permits the F.C.C. to choose a panel and develop a ratings system for the networks.
Although the networks would not be required by law to apply that system, many in the industry believe that if the cable industry used it, or one of the four broadcast networks broke ranks and used it, public pressure would grow on the other networks to go along as well.
"It puts them in an awkward position, of having to justify why they aren't making this useful information available to parents," said one F.C.C. staff member, Blair Levin.
But if they developed their own system and the F.C.C. rejected it, the networks would then have stronger grounds for a First Amendment challenge than the teleCommunications legislation now provides, said one network lawyer, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Officials at all four networks said they expected a consensus to be reached on an industry-devised ratings system but would not predict when. One said he expected it to be drafted this week; another said it could come any time "between now and the President's summit."
Executives at advertising agencies who help marketers decide where to place television commercials generally applauded the idea of a network ratings system and said it would not have much of an economic effect, at least not initially.
They said their agencies were likely to continue to screen programs or use screening services if asked to do so by clients that are concerned about the content of the programs in which their spots appear.
Many advertisers have compiled guidelines for buying commercial time that cover content issues like sex and violence. Such guidelines might require that a company's commercials be withdrawn from programs with plots that touch on a specific issue like mistreatment of animals, abortion or child abuse.
Arnie Semsky, executive vice president and director for media and programming services at the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group in New York, said of the networks' effort: "It's a step in the right direction. A ratings service would be handy as an indicator, as a guide, but I think we would still screen every episode."
"It's just the networks' judgment," he added. "What a network says is an R or a PG can't take into effect all the client considerations that we can." As a result, Mr. Semsky said, he doubted whether there would be "any advertising falloff." 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 17, 1996, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about discussions by the four broadcast television networks on a rating system for the violence and sexual content of programs misstated the date of a meeting to which network chief executives had been invited by President Clinton. It is Feb. 29, not Feb. 28.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Volatile Day Sinks Prices Of U.S. Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Technical selling and a large supply of new corporate and global issues combined to drive Treasury prices lower in volatile trading yesterday.
The price of the 30-year bond dropped 1 1/32 , to 97 25/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.16 percent, from 6.09 percent on Wednesday. On the short end of the market, the three-month bill rate was lower, at 4.76 percent, down 3 basis points, reflecting some movement from longer-term to shorter-term issues. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 The decline in the market came on the last full trading day before a three-day weekend. The market will be closed on Monday in observance of the Washington's Birthday holiday, and the Public Securities Association, which represents firms that buy and sell debt securities, has recommended an early close at 2 P.M. today, a recommendation that dealers usually follow.
While weak economic reports gave the market some support, they were not compelling enough to bring in buyers. Traders and analysts attributed part of the selling yesterday to new corporate and global issues that lured investors away from Treasury securities with their higher yields.
Argentina priced $1 billion in the global bond market yesterday, becoming the third government borrower to sell securities while rates in the United States are low and investor demand for higher returns is strong.
Argentina's five-year junk bonds were sold through Merrill Lynch and CS First Boston and were priced to yield 9.284 percent, or about 410 basis points more than a Treasury security with a similar maturity.
In another huge offering, Chase Securities led underwriters in a $1.474 billion sale of Chase Manhattan Bank auto loan asset-backed certificates with an average life of 1.592 years.
The triple-A rated issue, sold through specially formed Chase Manhattan Grantor Trust 1996-A, was given a coupon of 5.2 percent and priced at 99 31/32 , to yield 5.278 percent, or about 41 basis points more than the Treasury's 6 percent note due in August 1997.
The selloff in the Treasury market was also linked to technical factors. Such technicals -- which study the relationships between market variables like price levels, volume and movement and try to gain insights into supply and demand for securities -- pointed to declining prices ahead, analysts said.
In futures trading, which affects the cash market because it trades at what participants believe will be rate levels months from now, the March Treasury bond contract tumbled to a close of 119 5/32 , 1/32 off its low of the day. The high for the session was 120 8/32 . Declines could also be traced to investors and dealers who do not like to hold long maturities over long weekends, so they sell the long end and buy the shorter maturities. And the expiration of options compounded the selling pressure yesterday.
Several reports yesterday pointed to weak economic growth, which in other circumstances might have bolstered the market. The Government reported that orders for durable goods -- products ranging from washing machines to jet aircraft -- rose 2.1 percent in December, following a a decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent in November. In a separate report, factory orders increased 1.3 percent in December, after a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in November.
The data indicated a slowing pace of business activity, said Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities.
Noting that new orders for commercial aircraft dominated the gains in both durable goods and factory orders, Mr. Fine said aircraft orders "tend to be a lagging indicator and usually start to rise toward the mature phase of business expansion, and that seems to be the case currently as well."
Also yesterday, the Labor Department reported that initial claims for unemployment benefits rose by 21,000 in the week ended last Saturday, well above expectations. And the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia released its index of regional business activity for February. The index rose from minus 16.6 in January, which was hurt by a blizzard, to 3.8 -- a level, Mr. Fine said, that "is not exactly gangbusters."
"All of these numbers in consort certainly lend further credence to the view that the Federal Open Market Committee is likely to ease interest rates once again in the near future, with both timing and extent a function of the data to be released over the next five weeks," Mr. Fine said, referring to the Federal Reserve's policy-making group.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Angry Man

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Pat Buchanan is not likely to be the Republican nominee in the end. Too many influential voices in the party think that would deliver the election to President Clinton. But his strong showing in the Iowa caucuses still matters a lot.
It reminds us, first, of the strength of the Christian right in the country -- and its fixation on the issue of abortion. 
 In Iowa, Pat Robertson's Christian Coalition controls the Republican Party. Members were at first divided among the several far-right candidates. But by caucus day most were for Mr. Buchanan, with his call to outlaw abortion under any and all circumstances. In his view, if a woman who was raped has an abortion, both she and the doctor should be criminally punished.
Extreme opposition to abortion is of course not limited to conservative Christians in Iowa. That viewpoint has more influence in Congress now than ever before, with important consequences.
Last month, for example, in an action that has not had sufficient attention, Congress drastically limited American support for family planning in poor countries. The United States provided $548 million for population programs abroad last year. With many poor countries suffering under the burden of rapidly growing populations, those funds may be the most important part of American aid.
U.S. law already forbids spending aid money for abortions. But House Republicans attached to the aid bill a proviso barring funds for any family planning organization that gives information on abortion. The Senate rejected that amendment.
Then Congress passed and President Clinton signed a "compromise" that actually guts the population funding. No money can be spent until next July 1. In the 15 months that follow, the program is to have $356 million -- a cut of 35 percent from the last annual appropriation.
The bill would allow the funding cuts to be lifted if by July 1 Congress passes a foreign-aid authorization bill. But the insistence of House Republicans on anti-abortion language makes that unlikely; Mr. Buchanan's showing in Iowa will if anything stiffen their position.
The Iowa vote for Pat Buchanan was, second, a signal of economic distress. Iowa is actually hurting less than many other states from the slide in real wages and the downsizing of business. But there are evidently economic fears there as elsewhere.
Alone among the Republican candidates, Mr. Buchanan has been running as an all-out economic nationalist. He attacks free trade and says he would pull the U.S. out of the World Trade Organization. He sounds a populist cry against heartless corporations, and he calls for stopping all immigration for five years.
Republicans from Newt Gingrich to Bob Dole and Phil Gramm have opposed the notion that the United States can prosper by building economic walls around itself. Big businessmen who support and finance the party mostly disagree, too. But some voters respond when Mr. Buchanan says he will stop American jobs going to Mexico and China.
Of course there is more to Pat Buchanan than policy. There is anger. Like George Wallace 30 years ago, he expresses the resentments of some working-class people, mostly male and white, at those they consider the elite. Or perhaps a better comparison is with Howard Beale, the character played by the late Peter Finch in the 1976 movie "Network," with his cry: "I'm mad as hell, and I'm not going to take it anymore."
However Mr. Buchanan does in New Hampshire and after, he will be a force in the Republican campaign. Indeed, Bob Dole is already expressing more concern about economic losers. And in Iowa both he and Lamar Alexander, disgracefully, supported an anti-homosexual rally organized by Christian rightists.
At the 1992 Republican convention in Houston, Pat Buchanan and Pat Robertson made fire-eating right-wing speeches that turned out to hurt George Bush. Some party leaders had hoped to avoid such excesses this year, and to calm down the abortion plank, and thus appeal to moderates. But it looks now as though the two Pats and their ideas will play a prominent part in San Diego next August.

HEADLINE: Rea Irvin: Wry Spirit In the Age Of Gatsby

BYLINE: By DAVID IVES; David Ives is a playwright whose works include "All in the Timing."

 BODY:
NEW YORKERS have been spoiled for 70 years now by The New Yorker, which has arrived weekly like a string of perfect martinis on some ideal butler's tray. Adult and aware, sexy and stylish, flattering us with its wit, sometimes painfully in the know, this magazine has represented our town to the rest of the world since the days of the flappers as the place to flap. I wonder how many other writers have come to New York from places like Chicago, as I did, because as a mere slip of a sliver of a seminarian I thought that New York was like, well, The New Yorker -- which is not unlike goi'g to Casablanca for the waters. Ever since its inception, The New Yorker has been not so much a periodical as a personality, and what can beat it for flash?
Rea Irvin (1881-1972) was the man who created that personality along with Harold Ross, the magazine's founder and first editor. As The New Yorker's first art editor, Irvin designed and chose covers, selected the type (still known as "Irvin type") and The New Yorker logotype on the cover, gathered artists and cartoonists, and contributed illustrations and cartoons himself. Maybe most famously, Irvin drew Eustace Tilley, the Regency fop with the monocle who appeared on the cover of the magazine's first issue in 1925 and has reappeared yearly (with one exception, in 1994) ever since. Irvin played von Sternberg to The New Yorker's Dietrich and gave it its "look," once and probably forever. 
 Now there's a show of Irvin's work at the Museum of the City of New York, and the next time you're hanging out on Fifth Avenue checking out our new Michelangelo because you crave some art, you must hike on up to 103d Street and see the real thing. The trip is particularly recommended for those period junkies and lost souls (like me) who reread "The Great Gatsby" at every possible opportunity and who know that New York is still in its heart a place where jazz is played in Harlem, where Cole Porter has a new musical opening on Broadway, wher' men wear tuxes in the evening and women silk stockings, where Prohibition is still on, and where the Round Table is still getting sauced at the Algonquin.
Among the 83 drawings, cartoons, illustrations and covers, published and unpublished, the exhibition includes Irvin's original drawing of Eustace Tilley, and even for those of us who have never understood the charm of that insufferable twit, the kick is still palpable, like standing in front of our city's own Rosetta Stone.
Someday some expert will track the decline of our civilization in the passage from magazines with illustrations on the cover to magazines with Brad Pitt on the cover, or this week's Shannen Doherty. In this scheme, The New Yorker is practically the sole remain'ng upholder of the values of human talent and invention, while other magazines are like those people who seem to think that good conversation means asking what movies you've seen.
Irvin's own covers both set and continually hit a very high standard indeed, and one can tour them in pursuit of any number of amusements and interests: humor (two men passing each other in sailboats, each boat named after the same woman); wit (a woman making herself up as Shiva, with a tangle of arms carrying the necessary accessories); topical references (La Guardia's 1933 election, World War II); the risque (a nudist dining room); period styles and attitudes (those dowagers with pince-nez, those affectless socialites); sociological shifts (those very un-P.C. blacks); economic shifts (note that "Price 15 Cents" in the upper right corner); the satisfactions of solid composition, elegant line and piquant color. One plump, dull, gray matron eyeing an exotically colored senorita brings to mind Wallace Stevens.
After Ross's death in 1951, Irvin's place at the magazine declined sharply. His final published New Yorker cover, from 1958, has something valedictory and touching in its golfer and caddy, reflected in a water trap, looking in the wrong directions for the lost golf ball that floats before them in the pond.
Covers aren't all of Irvin's story. He also did caricatures, parodies of Diego Rivera, Picasso and Uccello, a satirical, pseudo-Audubon series called "Our Native Birds," and brilliant Hogarthian cartoons like "Pastimes of the Intelligentsia," in which the rich have nothing better to do than toss cards into a hat.
The show also includes peculiarities like two Hitler covers for The New Yorker, one published and one not, and the cartoon triptych "A Nazi History of the World," whose flipness can now, in retrospect, stop the heart and trouble the mind. A quoted note from Ross to Irvin shows how limited indeed their perspective was: "Who takes the risk of Hitler bumping off or resigning before we go to press? I am putting payment through in full but if anything happens to Hitl'r I guess it's partly your responsibility."
We go to certain artists because we like their spirit. Irvin's records are sparse, the number of people who knew him in his prime is declining, and his artwork is almost all the spirit we have left of him. It is a spirit largely of gaiety and joie de vivre, detachment and glee. A photo of Irvin in the exhibition shows him posing as a Buddha on a Bermuda beach, smiling and looking high as a kite. You have until the 5th of May to commune with his delightful spirit.
 
When and Where
"The Talk of the Town: Rea Irvin of The New Yorker," a display of 83 drawings, covers and cartoons by the first art editor of the magazine, will be on view through May 5 at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, Manhattan. Hours: Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M.; closed on Mondays; groups only on Tuesdays, 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. Suggested admission: $5; $3 for students, the elderly and children; $8 for families. Information: (212) 534-1672.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Finishes Up a Little On 'a Bit of Confusing Day'

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar closed slightly higher yesterday, though weakened late in the day by a drop in United States Treasury bonds.
Early in Asian trading, the dollar fell against the yen and other currencies on remarks by the Japanese Finance Minister that his country's interest rates could benefit from an increase. But those remarks were later countered by his deputy, leading to a strong rebound in the dollar. 
 Several hours later, in New York yesterday afternoon, the dollar slumped as the price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell sharply.
"The dollar had its move up and its move back down," said Wayne Grigull, director of foreign exchange sales at Merrill Lynch.
Late in the day, the dollar traded at 1.4665 marks, up from 1.4644 on Wednesday. It settled at 105.55 yen, up from 106.25. The British pound fell to $1.5375 from $1.5419.
During the Asian trading session, Finance Minister Wataru Kubo of Japan suggested to a committee of Parliament that Japanese interest rates were too low and were hurting retirees relying on interest income.
Japan's key lending rate is at a record low, one-half of 1 percent. Higher interest rates tend to make a country's currency more attractive to investors, but Japan has been trying to weaken the yen to bolster the sales of its exporters.
As a result, Mr. Kubo's remarks "introduced a new variable into the market" and sent the dollar down versus the yen, Mr. Grigull said.
But Mr. Kubo's suggestions were followed by remarks by his administrative vice minister, Tadashi Ogawa, that were interpreted as a rejoinder to what Mr. Kubo had said.
As Mr. Grigull put it, "The assertion by Ogawa that, in fact, interest rates were likely to remain low put the market back on its bullish bias toward the dollar versus the yen."
Analysts also said that the dollar had been helped by rumors that the Japanese central bank was preparing to intervene in the market.
Still, late in the day, the dollar began following the American bond market lower, as the price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell by more than a point. "The dollar's performance was adversely affected by the performance of the bond market," Mr. Grigull said. "It's been a bit of a confusing day."
In other trading, the dollar rose to 1.1970 Swiss francs, from 1.1955 francs on Wednesday, and to 5.0520 French francs, from 5.0460. The dollar also rose to 1,585 Italian lire, from 1,583 lire.

HEADLINE: Worth a Raise?

BYLINE: By James Lardner; James Lardner is the author of the forthcoming "Crusaders: The Hell-Raising Police Career of Detective David Durk."

 BODY:
Boiling mad over the passage of a sweetheart arbitration deal for New York City police officers, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has denounced the State Legislature and made unkind remarks about the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. He has reason to be upset, since the new law could mean big salary increases in the midst of a budget crisis. But he might also give thought to the long term -- to how the city could try to get a higher caliber of officer for its money.
The Mayor and the Police Commissioner, William Bratton, have already taken several steps to address what the Mollen Commission, in its 1994 report on corruption, called a widespread perception that "virtually anyone can become a New York City police officer." Most notably, they have imposed a requirement of 60 college credits and raised the minimum age from 20 to 22. 
 But in other ways recruiting remains a scandal -- one that helps explain some of the more attention-getting police scandals of recent years.
We give officers the power, under certain circumstances, to take human life. We send them into situations that call for courage and an ability to calm people down and mediate differences. We insist that they respect people's legal rights. And we choose them by a process that takes none of these considerations into account.
The principal screening device for applicants is still a Civil Service exam, which has been made only slightly more rigorous in the decade since Mayor Edward Koch dismissed Judith Piesco, the deputy personnel director, for telling a State Senate committee that a "functional illiterate" could pass it. Invariably, most applicants do pass -- 31,000 out of nearly 39,000 the last time around, in 1993. After that, the process has resembled a lottery, with only the most glaringly unfit candidates eliminated.
Perhaps the key qualification is prolonged availability. Three years will have passed before the department hires the first batch of people from the last exam. By then, many of the top scorers won't be around. "The cream gets skimmed off by other careers, and the people you get are the people who are unemployable elsewhere," said Michael Julian, who retired last year as the N.Y.P.D.'s chief of personnel.
The new emphasis on raising standards is welcome, but, having been a police officer in Washington, D.C., in the early 1970's, I can testify that some of the best and most decent officers I worked with didn't have a college credit to their names. I can also recall a few real incompetents who had graduated with honors. On balance, a better-educated force is a good idea. But if the goal is to hire intelligent, capable and dedicated people, why not actually look for those qualities?
The N.Y.P.D. could start by closely interviewing applicants who have successfully completed every other stage of the selection process, and by taking into account such now irrelevant factors as knowledge of foreign languages, volunteer work and reputation in the community. And hiring the best people -- fast.
Reform along these lines would of course present its own obstacles, like the inevitable litigation by rejected candidates. The city is facing such a suit from applicants who complain that the college requirement was unfairly added since they took the entrance exam. Yet it is on such arguments that the woefully lax system has thrived for many years. Surely New York deserves better.

HEADLINE: A Plan to Save the New York Region

 BODY:
In the last couple of years, the political leadership in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut has been enthralled by tax cuts as the primary means to revitalize economic growth. Now comes a different idea from the Regional Plan Association, which called this week for no less than $75 billion in public expenditures to upgrade urban centers, open spaces, highways, rail lines and schools throughout the New York metropolitan area. At stake, the association said, is whether the New York area is to prevent the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs and remain relevant to the highly competitive economic forces sweeping the globe.
The cry of alarm from the Regional Plan Association, an independent group supported by foundations and private contributions, provides a timely reminder that the area's future cannot be taken for granted. Whereas the association's two previous reports on long-range planning, in 1929 and 1968, saw uncontrolled growth as the region's greatest threat, the latest report sees a risk of outright decline. The basic principle that the economy must be saved by investment in education, training and infrastructure is powerfully argued and persuasive. The main problem with the association's report is that it throws in almost every big planning idea that has been on the books for years, without establishing clear priorities. 
 A major reconstruction of the area's transportation arteries makes sense. It is surprising to learn that a mere 25 miles of new albeit very expensive rail lines would largely knit suburban commuter and city subway lines together more effectively. But the price tag for such rail routes connecting Long Island, the airports in Queens, Grand Central Terminal, lower Manhattan, New Jersey and the suburbs north of the city may prove too high to justify. Since the economic base is likely to remain relatively static, it may be hard to persuade taxpayers to foot the bill for a gigantic new system, along with the considerable expense of maintaining what is there now. But let the debate begin.
The association proposes that some sort of a regional bank be established, possibly financed by increased tolls, highway fees, gasoline taxes and other payments made by automobile owners. That is also a sensible idea. But one can argue whether a new tristate regional transportation authority is needed or whether the authorities that built the existing systems should simply be given the right leadership.
Another sound proposal is to build in the area's urban centers instead of chewing up more countryside with suburban sprawl and commercial centers. The region's open spaces are in danger of being engulfed by development. It will be an uphill battle to get people and businesses to settle in such currently bleak places as downtown Trenton or Bridgeport or depressed areas of New York City, but the battle is worth fighting.
The association's forward-looking report lays down a challenge in an era when local leadership seems determined to shut down or privatize public institutions instead of adapting them, to cut budgets rather than focus public spending creatively and to divide people rather than unite them around broad visions that could benefit everyone. The Regional Plan Association has performed a service by setting visionary goals and stirring public debate about how to get there.

HEADLINE: Labor Leader Plans Little Steps to Big Economic-Political Goal

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Aides to John J. Sweeney swear that as the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new president he has the vision thing, but Mr. Sweeney certainly seems to try his best to hide it. In his soft, matter-of-fact voice, he talks not in visions but in bits and pieces.
He talks about hiring 1,000 organizers to pull a million more workers into unions. He talks about creating a pro-labor research center to counter the Heritage Foundation and other conservative policy organizations. 
 He talks about recruiting more than 1,000 college students to work as interns this summer, helping organize workplaces and campaign for union-backed candidates. He talks about labor's plans to focus on 75 Congressional races and spend $35 million this year, far more than in the past, to help the Democrats keep the White House and win back the House.
Put all these pieces together, his aides say, and a vision emerges, one that calls for remaking the country's economic and political landscape. That vision would create, from labor's point of view, a virtuous circle in which union membership would climb and labor would move from the margins of the nation's discourse back to the center. This would not only give labor more leverage at the bargaining table but also enable it to elect more pro-union lawmakers.
They would in theory pass labor-friendly legislation, which would make it easier for unions to enlist even more workers, and this would in turn increase labor's clout in bargaining and elections and so on.
But to hear Mr. Sweeney tell it, his role in all this is mere blocking and tackling and not carrying out an ambitious political-economic vision that some labor experts say is as likely to succeed as a Hail Mary pass.
"My primary function is to rebuild the American labor movement," Mr. Sweeney said in a recent interview in a visit to New York. "If in that process, I can do some other things that will benefit the American labor movement and workers, then I will be involved there, too."
Many labor leaders and experts agree that Mr. Sweeney has an ambitious agenda and that it might take time for him to show results.
"He is not the kind of leader who will just by his very presence stir things up," said Richard W. Hurd, a professor of labor studies at Cornell University. "It's going to be his actions that stir things up."
Within the world of labor, it is widely agreed that Mr. Sweeney has not taken the world by storm since assuming the helm of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in late October. Part of the reason is his style. He is more tortoise than hare. He comes across as a genial Irish uncle and not as a firebreather like John L. Lewis, the tempestuous titan who built the Congress of Industrial Organizations, which merged with the American Federation of Labor in 1955.
Another reason for his slow start, aides say, is that Mr. Sweeney inherited a giant, lethargic bureaucracy that will take months, maybe years, to invigorate. Moreover, the aides say, after his narrow victory in the first contested election for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s presidency, he feels the need to move cautiously and heal the wounds. So he is seeking to manage by consensus, not an easy thing to do when the federation's executive council has 57 often-headstrong officials from different unions, many of which opposed his candidacy.
"It's a very complex bureaucracy," Mr. Sweeney said. "It's not like heading up an individual union or individual corporation. It's a federation with strong affiliates."
Mr. Sweeney has criss-crossed the country since October, giving speeches to city and state labor federations and newspaper strikers in Detroit and Boeing strikers in Washington. His favorite line has been, "America needs a raise."
But it remains unclear how such an applause line will translate into raises for the federation's 13 million members -- or for the nation's more than 100 million nonunion workers.
Mr. Sweeney acknowledges that he has no magic formula for raising wages. On one level, he is resorting to moral suasion, appealing to the consciences of business executives as he rails against "the greed of corporate America" and against companies' failure to share the good times with their workers despite record profits and surges in productivity.
But Mr. Sweeney recognizes that moral suasion will not be enough. The federation, he said, will back strikes as a way of pressuring management and is beefing up its "strategic department" to help unions outsmart and outmaneuver management in economic showdowns.
Key to his ambition of giving America a raise is electing a labor-friendly Congress, one he hopes will address the growing income gap between the richest 5 percent and the average working American.
"We need labor, business and government together at the table to address the seriousness of this wage problem and to find solutions" he said. "We can start by supporting an increase in the minimum wage."
The Republican Congress appears unlikely to enact a higher minimum wage, now $4.25, and that is one reason Mr. Sweeney wants to help the Democrats win back the House. When the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive council meets next week in Bal Harbour, Fla., a main item on the agenda will be to pick the 75 Congressional races on which to devote resources.
That is just part of the federation's expanded political program. It plans to train 2,500 union advocates to spread labor's message during the campaign. It has pledged to send 100 union advocates into each of the 435 Congressional districts during the campaign's last six weeks. As for its $35 million war chest, most of that will go not to candidate contributions but to get out the vote and educate voters on where candidates stand on issues dear to workers' hearts.
The federation hopes to replicate its recent work in Oregon, where scores of union activists campaigned to help Ron Wyden, a Democrat, win a Senate seat.
"The A.F.L. is committed to putting more into the political campaign than we have ever put before," Mr. Sweeney said. "We're very encouraged by the results of the Oregon race. It's just the first, and we expect many more victories."
But many political experts predict that Mr. Sweeney will fall short of his political goals.
"What he's trying to do is replicate the conservative success of the past two years," said Marshall Wittmann, an analyst at the Heritage Foundation. "The major difference is the general political trend in the country is in a conservative direction, and the conservatives harnessed that political trend."
As the campaign gathers steam, Mr. Sweeney voices far more enthusiasm about President Clinton than about the Republican Presidential field, even though Patrick J. Buchanan and Senator Bob Dole seem to have stolen his oratory about how corporations are giving their workers a raw deal.
Mr. Sweeney is decidedly unsympathetic to Republican economic proposals: cutting taxes and spending and building protectionist walls.
"I wish there was a Republican who was trying to find solutions for the problems that American workers are facing," he said.
As for the Republicans' idea of the month, he said, "the flat-tax proposal is unfair to middle-income and low-income workers." "I think it favors the wealthy," Mr. Sweeney added.
Although the federation has not yet endorsed a candidate, Mr. Sweeney was not shy about tipping his hand.
"I think the courage the President has displayed in standing up for some basic programs such as Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment indicates how dedicated he is to supporting programs that are important to American workers."
Part of Mr. Sweeney's agenda is to make the Democratic Party identify more closely with unions. He recognizes that many Democrats have distanced themselves from organized labor, viewing it as just another special interest group.
He said such a characterization was terribly unfair, but added: "I don't get upset being referred to as representing a special interest. If representing American workers is a special interest, then I'm proud to represent that special interest."

HEADLINE: Fresh Data Indicate Economy Could Be Heading for a Stall

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Evidence mounted today that the economy, whose growth has been slowing markedly in recent months, could be approaching a stall.
Only a small minority of economists and business leaders are predicting recession, but many believe that growth in the January-March quarter will be at a rate of 1 percent or less, roughly half what the economy could produce without causing inflation. 
 "What we're looking at is a clear progression toward weaker growth," said Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist at ASB Capital Management, a large Washington investment firm. He predicted little, if any, economic expansion in the current quarter, citing Northeast snowstorms and the partial shutdown of the Government as only two of several factors.
One of the half-dozen economic gauges published today was the Labor Department's report that first-time claims for unemployment benefits surged by an unexpectedly large 21,000 last week. That brought the average number of claims being filed in the last four weeks to 388,500, the highest in four years, except for one week last July when it was inflated by seasonal layoffs in the automobile industry.
This "is very clearly depicting intensified deterioration in the labor market," Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the brokerage firm, told its clients.
In a second Government report, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said its index of general business conditions rebounded from a dismal, weather-related January reading of minus 16.6, but only to a positive 3.8 in February. Economists said that hardly portrayed economic strength.
They also cited companion indexes pointing to lower employment, a shorter workweek and a drop of two price indexes to 28-year lows.
Still another Government report found that orders to factories climbed 1.3 percent in December and fell one-tenth of 1 percent in November, both results having been delayed by the Federal shutdown.
Analysts tended to disregard these figures as too old to provide much insight and as highly distorted by a bunching of orders for aircraft, an erratic component involving a product that may not be produced until years later.
Not counting aircraft and military orders, economists at Merrill Lynch noted that most industries producing durable goods had fewer orders in December and that many posted November declines as well.
Today's outpouring of data -- there were at least four private-sector surveys in addition to the three Government reports -- came as politicians as well as economists cast an anxious eye at the economic weather.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas this week joined his rival Patrick Buchanan in focusing on pocketbook concerns in the campaign leading to next week's New Hampshire primary.
Many of the signs of a weakening economy have until recently been at least partly offset by a solid performance in manufacturing, though the Northeast blizzard contributed to a substantial contraction of factory payrolls in January.
But consumers, whose spending accounts for two-thirds of national output, have become increasingly pessimistic, raising the possibility that their retrenchment could hold economic growth well below par or perhaps bring on a recession.
An ABC-Money magazine survey of consumer confidence showed a decline to minus 18 last week from minus 16 the week before, it was reported today, reflecting further gradual deterioration.
The National Association of Home Builders said its housing market index for new, single-family homes edged down 1 point, to 50, in February, a reading that means the number of positive responses from builders about equals the negative responses. Present sales fell 3 points, sales expectations for the next six months were 1 point lower, while traffic of prospective buyers climbed 2 points, to 39, the association said.
Mortgage applications for home purchases fell last week to the lowest level since August, though refinancing activity was still strong, the Mortgage Bankers Association reported.
The National Association of Manufacturers said a poll of its members taken last Friday found more than 75 percent of executives favored further relaxation of monetary policy to overcome "sluggish growth" this year. More than 90 percent of its board members, however, said there was little chance of recession.
Still another survey, by Dun & Bradstreet of 1,000 manufacturers, found them "optimistic about short-term economic conditions" through April despite "nearly stagnant" conditions over the latest three months. The company's industrial sentiment index for the coming three months climbed 2 points, to 20, in January. In January 1993 the index registered 23.
The Commerce Department's report on factories showed orders for durable goods up 2.1 percent in December following declines of eight-tenths of 1 percent in November and 1.5 percent in October.
But orders for nonmilitary capital goods other than aircraft fell four-tenths of 1 percent in December and 2.4 percent for the fourth quarter of 1995.
Shipments of factory goods over all rose 1 percent in December, while unfilled orders rose three-tenths of 1 percent and inventories edged up one-tenth of 1 percent, the report found.

HEADLINE: U.S. Aid Cutbacks Endangering Population Programs, U.N. Agencies Say

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 15

 BODY:
In the latest tactical victory by a resurgent anti-abortion movement in the United States, Congress has forced a drastic cut in aid that is the mainstay of family planning programs around the world.
Recent legislation, intended to punish the Clinton Administration for allowing aid for family planning groups involved in abortions overseas, cuts 35 percent from the population and family planning budget of the Agency for International Development, the largest supporter of such programs in the world. 
 Experts at the agency and at many of the private organizations who depend on the funds say the cut will be crippling, not only to birth control programs but also to related activities like maternal health care and AIDS prevention.
The measure was part of a foreign appropriations bill attached to legislation to prevent another Government shutdown, and was signed by the President.
Sponsors of the measure, led by Representative Christopher H. Smith, Republican of New Jersey, wanted a complete ban on aid to organizations that perform or promote abortions abroad -- in effect a reinstatement and a strengthening of Reagan and Bush Administration anti-abortion policies that were overturned by President Clinton.
Although American law still prohibits using aid money for abortion services abroad, many family planning and women's health groups receiving American support provide a range of services that may include abortion counseling, especially in cases of extreme poverty where additional births could weaken a mother's health or add unendurable financial burdens.
"The fiction advanced by the other side -- that international population-control agencies can use bookkeeping devices to spend 'their' money on abortions and 'our' money on everything else -- ignores reality," Mr. Smith said in an interview. "If population-control organizations insist that they want population money only for family planning activities unrelated to abortion, they could do so under the House provisions by getting out of the abortion business."
When the Senate balked at this blanket prohibition, House Republicans agreed instead to the 35 percent cut, combined with a delay in dispensing funds that will make the cutbacks this year even more severe.
If Democrats agree to reconsider their opposition to the anti-abortion measure, the delay in dispensing of funds could be lifted, somewhat easing the impact, but both sides consider this very unlikely.
Measured in dollars, the cut would reduce A.I.D. funds for family planning to $360 million in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, from $550 million the previous year. Over all, the United States now provides 45 percent of all international aid for population programs. Beyond these cuts, Washington is also sharply reducing its support for the United Nations Population Fund.
Estimates of how the cutbacks will affect family planning efforts vary wildly, but most experts agree the impact will be severe.
Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, an outspoken abortion critic who has long advocated family planning, said the reduction in appropriations meant the agency would have only 14 percent of what was available in the fiscal year 1995 to spend on such programs this year.
"What we did is bar access to family planning services to approximately 17 million couples, most of them living in unimaginable poverty," he said in a statement.
At the United Nations Population Fund, Nafis Sadik, the executive director, said, "The way U.S. funding is going, 17 to 18 million unwanted pregnancies are going to take place, a couple of million abortions will take place, and I'm sure that 60,000 to 80,000 women are going to die because of those abortions -- and all because the money has been reduced overnight."
The agency, which received $35 million in 1995 from a separate State Department budget, is to get $22.5 million over a 15-month period beginning in July, which in effect provides the agency with only $4.5 million in the current fiscal year.
But Mr. Smith added, "It is impossible for either side in this debate to prove how many 'unwanted' pregnancies will or will not occur at a given level of funding for population-control programs.
The Representative said that too much money was being spent on population programs, and that the figure had risen rapidly over the past three years. He said foreign aid would be better spent on "programs that save the lives of children, protect refugees fleeing persecution and create free and self-sustaining economic systems."
Echoing arguments made by some third world leaders, he questions the cultural implications of family planning.
"Is there really a population crisis?" he asked at a Congressional hearing last year. "Is there any hard evidence that we are in imminent danger of not having enough resources for the world's population? Or is fewer people just an aesthetic preference of the West?"
But family planning advocates say that regardless of arguments about global population and resources, efforts are needed to give more women choice in contraception for reasons of health and personal freedom.
Even while voting to cut money for family planning, Republican House members point out that they have protected funds for child survival.
"But family planning has always been controversial and is even more so with the Republicans in charge," said Jo Bonner, staff director for Representative Sonny Callahan, Republican of Alabama and chairman of the foreign operations subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee. He said it would be difficult "to ask the American taxpayer to support an increase in foreign aid when we're cutting back on domestic programs."

HEADLINE: Trenton G.O.P. Leaders Agree on a Charity Care Plan

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
On the day the state first missed its monthly payment to reimburse hospitals for providing medical treatment to the poor, Republican legislative leaders agreed today to pay for the state's charity care program by continuing to use surplus revenues from the unemployment insurance fund.
Hospital officials had feared that they would have had to begin laying off workers and closing wards if the state had not taken steps toward resuming payments. Today, the state had been scheduled to distribute $33 million to 84 hospitals. 
 The state stopped payment after its authority to rely on the Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund ended on Dec. 31. State officials have not come up with a replacement for the expired system.
But the agreement, reached by the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican from Scotch Plains, and the Assembly Speaker, Jack Collins, a Republican from Salem County, would provide $300 million to hospitals this year, a $100 million reduction from what was distributed to hospitals last year. The plan proposes to phase out dependence on the unemployment insurance fund over five years and eventually pay the entire cost of charity care from the state budget's general fund by the year 2000.
"We are obligated to take care of everybody who walks in the door," said Dr. Jonathan M. Metsch, president and chief executive of the Jersey City Medical Center. "It is time to stop the political posturing and solve this problem."
Under pressure from businesses and organized labor to stop draining the unemployment insurance fund, Legislative leaders and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman agreed last year to consider alternatives. Governor Whitman proposed to increase the cigarette tax by 25 cents last November, but the Legislature rejected that idea. Since then, state legislators have floated more than a dozen other proposals, varying from using unspent Medicaid dollars to raising money from video poker games. Today's plan, however, was the first proposal made by the leaders of the Republican-controlled Legislature.
Governor Whitman withheld comment on the plan, which has to be passed by both houses and signed by her before it can take effect. "We are certainly going to take a serious look at this," Becky Taylor, a spokeswoman for the Governor, said.
While hospital officials said they were relieved that the legislative leaders had finally agreed on a proposal, business officials expressed disappointment that the plan would still depend heavily on the state's Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund. Since 1993, the state has financed the charity care program by diverting almost $1.6 billion from the state fund, wiping out much of the fund's surplus.
"Based on the numbers we have seen, we are very disappointed with this proposal," said Edward Rogan, a spokesman for the New Jersey Business and Industry Association. "It continues an unacceptable raid on the unemployment insurance fund. Our goal was to end the diversion as soon as possible."
Under the plan, the state would take only $13 million from the state budget's general fund this year, but $68 million next year. In 1998, the state would use $168 million from the general fund, $268 million in 1999, and $400 million in the year 2000.
State officials would spend a total of $400 million this year for medical treatment of uninsured families and individuals. The plan would distribute $300 million to reimburse hospitals that care for the poor, a $100 million cut from last year.
The plan also would provide $50 million to partly replace a $75 million cut that Governor Whitman has proposed in the state's Hospital Relief Fund. In addition, the plan would reduce spending from $100 million to $50 million for a year-old health insurance plan for people who meet certain income eligibility requirements and are not eligible for employee-sponsored health insurance coverage or Medicaid.
Because the state had failed to come up with a way to replenish the state fund that expired Dec. 31, hospital officials around the state, particularly in urban areas, had been worried about how they would continue to provide medical treatment for the poor without any reimbursement. The State Health Department has stopped taking applications from hundreds of New Jerseyans seeking health insurance under the state-subsidized program.
Dr. Metsch said that Jersey City Medical Center received $25 million a year in state funds for charity care. He said that about one-third of the 18,000 admissions last year were people who were not covered by health insurance or Medicaid.
At University Hospital in Newark, which receives $48 million annually to treat thousands of charity care patients, William Vazquez, vice president and chief executive, said that he had ordered a hiring freeze last month because the state had not yet come up with a solution. Today, his hospital failed to receive $4 million from the state that it had expected before the old system expired.
"Our bank account is short $4 million," Mr. Vazquez said today. "What it means is that once again we will be providing more care than we are reimbursed for."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

STATE: NEW JERSEY, USA (92%);

HEADLINE: Hasidic Volunteers Help Find Suspect in Beating

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
A combination of basic detective work by a Hasidic volunteer patrol and the chance presence of a police car outside a Lower East Side bagel shop led to the capture yesterday of a Hasidic man whose estranged wife was found beaten unconscious on Saturday in her Monsey, N.Y., home.
While groups like the Shomrim Volunteer Patrol have sometimes been criticized by those outside Hasidic communities for vigilantism, the Shomrim patrol this time helped track down a member of its own community -- one charged last night with attempted murder. 
 Scores of Shomrim, Hebrew for "guardians," had been hunting for the suspect, Joseph Zitrenbaum, in the Jewish neighborhoods of Williamsburg and Borough Park, in Brooklyn, and the Lower East Side since the assault on his wife, Blima Zitrenbaum, 33. They distributed fliers with the picture of Mr. Zitrenbaum, who is unemployed, figuring he would need to beg for food and money among the area's merchants. Tipped that Mr. Zitrenbaum was seen without a beard, they distributed a beardless photograph on the flier.
As it turned out, Mr. Zitrenbaum, wearing traditional black garb but clean-shaven except for a mustache, was spotted not by a Shomrim member but by Michael Fleischer, 52, the owner of a takeout store, G & M Kosher Caterers, at 41 Essex Street. Mr. Fleischer, who lives in Monsey and knew that Mr. Zitrenbaum was wanted, saw him eating a bagel with a cup of coffee at Motty's Bagels at 39 Essex Street.
Mr. Fleischer said he had first spotted Mr. Zitrenbaum on Tuesday, when Mr. Zitrenbaum was walking through the neighborhood, but he lost him after trailing him for six blocks.
This time, Mr. Fleischer hurriedly yelled to a neighboring merchant, Zachariah Eisenbach, a Torah scribe, to call the Shomrim while he flagged down a police car on the other side of Essex. Police Officer Robert Pandolsi strode into the bagel shop and arrested Mr. Zitrenbaum, who was described as pale and shaken but did not resist.
David Wieder, a Shomrim volunteer, said he was already in the store when the police entered and was blocking the doorway in case Mr. Zitrenbaum tried to get away. Other Shomrim streamed toward the store, alerted through two-way radios by their dispatcher in Williamsburg.
Mr. Zitrenbaum, a 36-year-old former furniture salesman with what the police and neighbors described as a drug problem, had been wanted for questioning by the police in Ramapo, which embraces Monsey, since Saturday. That morning, Mrs. Zitrenbaum, who had obtained an order of protection against her husband, was found unconscious, her face and head bloody, by one of her seven children. The police said she had been beaten with a hammer-like instrument. She has been hospitalized in critical condition, unable to talk, although neighbors said yesterday that she seemed to be increasingly alert.
The case drew attention within the metropolitan area's large Hasidic community because family violence requiring police intervention is rare. Mr. Zitrenbaum was returned to Ramapo yesterday afternoon. He is to be arraigned today on a charge of attempted murder, the police said.
No warrant had been issued in his wife's beating, so the New York City police based their arrest on three outstanding warrants, including one from Fort Lee, N.J., charging him with carrying a hypodermic needle and resisting arrest.
Isaac Abraham, a spokesman for the Shomrim, said the group was founded 15 years ago in Williamsburg and had since branched out to other Orthodox Jewish areas. It has 250 members, he said. They do not carry guns or wear uniforms and respond when help is needed for anything from burglaries to lost children.
The Shomrim actively worked to locate Mr. Zitrenbaum, Mr. Abraham said, because "we don't think the Ramapo police have the capability of doing this kind of search and the precincts in New York have their own guys they're looking for."
