HEADLINE: Report on Port Authority Says It Favors New Jersey

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Adding statistical weight to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's assertion that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey slights New York City, Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate, said yesterday that the authority favors New Jersey in its capital spending and transportation services.
Mr. Green said that half of $7.4 billion spent on capital projects from 1980 through 1994 went to New Jersey, which has fewer than a third of the residents of the metropolitan area served by the Port Authority. On that basis, the analysis found that the authority spent $851 for each New Jersey resident, compared with $485 for each New York resident. 
 The Green analysis found that the agency made $1.2 billion in that period, but that the profit was dragged down by $3.2 billion in losses that came primarily from the New Jersey PATH system, the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan and other operations "overwhelmingly engaged in transporting New Jersey residents," the report said.
"Fifteen years of data confirm that the Port Authority is a giant transfer machine that forces New York to cross-subsidize New Jersey's economic development and low taxes," Mr. Green said.
A Democrat who was elected in 1992 as New York City's first Public Advocate, Mr. Green holds a post that puts him in almost inevitable conflict with the Mayor. But in the Port Authority report, Mr. Green gave Mr. Giuliani a rare endorsement. That is because the Mayor has been harshly critical of the Port Authority's financing, even threatening to pull out of the two-state partnership under which the authority has functioned since the 1920's.
"Giuliani got it right, and here is the data to prove it," Mr. Green said.In a news conference, he said his staff had been at work for a year on the Port Authority analysis, and had begun the work before the Mayor had criticized the agency's finances.
Port Authority officials dismissed the report, saying it was politically biased and skewed because it reflected unusually large short-term investments made during the 1980's to upgrade the PATH system and Newark International Airport. The authority's capital spending plan for the next five years calls for devoting 67 percent of its financing to New York City operations, particularly Kennedy International Airport.
The report also praised a 25-year master plan for the New York region, proposed on Tuesday by the Regional Plan Association. It envisions the creation of a Regional Transportation Authority, taking charge of all suburban commuter trains, New York City subways and buses, and the bridges and tunnels the Port Authority owns, leaving only the region's airports and marine terminals under the authority's control.
While saying that he would support such a regionwide agency, Mr. Green said yesterday that he also favored more narrowly focused alternatives, including raising fares on the PATH system by 50 cents, to $1.50, equal to a New York City ride, and increasing the tolls at New Jersey bridges and tunnels operated by the authority by $2, to $6, the same as charged by the city's Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
The increased proceeds should be used to pay for improvements at some of the authority's New York City properties, Mr. Green said, including Kennedy Airport.
The analysis by Mr. Green's staff comes six months after another, by the New York City Planning Department, that also found that the authority was losing money on the PATH system and other New Jersey operations. But yesterday's report went further, examining capital spending on projects considered of more direct benefit to New Jersey residents and commuters than people in New York state.
"These things are cyclical," said Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who responded to Mr. Green's report late yesterday at a news conference after she met with Gov. George E. Pataki to discuss a range of issues affecting their states. "We've gotten a lot of Port Authority spending lately, but five years from now New York will probably be in the same position."
Governor Pataki, however, was less dismissive of the report. When asked if New Jersey was being favored by the authority, he said, "I think so, yes." But he said he would oppose dismantling the agency.
H. Claude Shostal, the president of the Regional Plan Association, said: "We are delighted with Mr. Green's support, but it is unfortunate that it is couched in rivalry between New York and New Jersey."

(Source: Mark Green, Public Advocate for the City Of New York)

HEADLINE: Board Delays Ban on Affirmative Action, but Discord Persists

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The University of California's deeply divided Regents compromised today and set spring 1998 as the date for putting into effect their much-disputed ban on race and sex preferences in undergraduate student admissions.
But the fight over affirmative action did not end there for the university, a 160,000-student, nine-campus system that is one of the nation's largest and most respected educational institutions. No sooner was the new date agreed upon, and passed on a voice vote at a monthly meeting of the 26-member Regents board, than both sides on the issue began squabbling anew over just what policy was to be put into effect. 
 A task force established earlier this year by the board was already at work trying to sort this out -- thus far, without success.
The ban on race and sex preferences, narrowly passed last summer during a tumultuous Regents meeting, was originally scheduled to take effect on Jan. 1, 1997. But the university president, Richard C. Atkinson, argued that it would take at least until mid-1998 to work out new policies on admitting students. Mr. Atkinson briefly attempted to delay the ban unilaterally, but the board objected.
With the strong support of faculty and students, Mr. Atkinson also questioned the wisdom of the ban, given that California is the nation's most ethnically diverse state.
He reiterated his position today, again putting himself in direct confrontation with Gov. Pete Wilson, who not only sits on the board but is one of the most outspoken opponents of affirmative action in the nation.
Today's compromise, involving the timing of when the new policy would govern admissions, came relatively easily. But the fight over defining the policy itself seemed no closer to resolution than when the ban was first proposed and passed. And the chasm between the Governor and Mr. Atkinson seemed at least as wide and deep as ever.
The ban states that the university "shall not use race, religion, sex, color, ethnicity or national origin as a criterion for admission to the university" or "as a criterion in its employment and contracting practices." But it says social and economic disadvantages can be taken into account.
Some board members, led by Mr. Atkinson, maintained today that the wording of the new policy was loose enough to allow some consideration of race.
"At the level of outreach and financial aid, I'm of the opinion we could still be race-attentive," Mr. Atkinson said at an impromptu hallway press conference.
But other board members, including Mr. Wilson and Ward Connerly, the author of the ban, contended that the affirmative action proponents were being semantically disingenuous. They insisted that the intent of the ban was clear, although some, Mr. Connerly among them, acknowledged that the language did not specifically forbid "outreach" to various ethnic groups in admissions and granting financial assistance.
"It's complex and needs further study, but it's nevertheless clear what we seek to do," Mr. Connerly said.
With Governor Wilson, Mr. Connerly is also leading an effort to put affirmative action up for a statewide yes-or-no vote on the fall election ballot. Affirmative-action defenders contend that Mr. Connerly and the Governor deliberately sought the campus ban to gain attention for the ballot initiative and to raise Mr. Wilson's political profile.
Before today's Regents meeting, on the San Francisco campus, Governor Wilson and President Atkinson held a private meeting that aides to both described as polite but tense.
In other board business, the Regents received the resignation, effective in mid-1977, of Chancellor Charles E. Young of the University of California at Los Angeles. In 25 years in that post, Mr. Young oversaw the campus's growth in size and reputation. He has strongly supported affirmative action.
Mr. Young said it was time to turn over the chancellorship, including the affirmative-action dispute, to someone else. But he did not imply that the contentiousness of the affirmative action issue had weighed heavily in making his retirement plans.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Forbes's Three-Pronged Approach

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

 BODY:
There are two new 30-second television advertisements that have begun appearing in New Hampshire for the final week before the primary. One is titled "Education" and the other is "Parents." They are being broadcast along with a third commercial, called "Healthcare," that was also shown in Iowa. 
 All three show Steve Forbes involved with subjects other than his proposal for a flat income tax, the issue that thrust him into the first-tier of contenders for the Republican nomination. The ads' messages are generalized ones in which Mr. Forbes tries to demonstrate his understanding of the concerns of ordinary voters.
 
PRODUCER Our Towns Films.
 
ON THE SCREEN In two commercials, Mr. Forbes is in a shirt and tie, sitting in a warm and clubby looking study with photographs of his children behind him. In "Education," an announcer says, "For 30 years, Washington politicians have tried to run schools -- and failed. Test scores have dropped. Three out of four eighth graders are below grade level in math."
Mr. Forbes then appears to denounce the Federal Government's role in education. "Hi, I'm Steve Forbes," he says. "Today, local schools have to fill out 173 Federal forms. Washington is out of control. We should restore control of our schools to parents."
In "Parents," Mr. Forbes comes closer to expounding his economic theories, although they are referred to only vaguely. He tells viewers that even families with two incomes can barely make ends meet.
"If we change Washington," he says, "we can cut taxes and mortgage rates. Wage earners can save more, and parents can devote more time to their children."
"Healthcare" features some of the plaudits for by the health care plan at Mr. Forbes's magazine company.
 
ACCURACY Mr. Forbes's use of education as a tool to attack at Washington is questionable. Although most functions of government are a blend of national and local, education is an area in which the Federal role is decidedly subordinate.
In "Parents" Mr. Forbes suggests that following his economic policies will not only make people more prosperous but also better family members. This assertion rests on the hard-to-prove assertion that wage earners will respond to lower taxes by spending more time with their children.
 
SCORE CARD The advertisements are collectively intended to show that Mr. Forbes is something other than a single-issue candidate. They also feature him on camera in a kind of straining-to-be-comfortable look. Focus groups have shown that some people find his nonpolitician appearance appealing, while many find it disconcerting. NEIL A. LEWIS

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
2 Canadian Banks Buy or Raise Stakes in Bancomer and Inverlat

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Two of Canada's largest banks, the Bank of Montreal and the Bank of Nova Scotia, are betting on a recovery of Mexico's economy and currency by investing in Mexican financial-services companies.
The Montreal institution, Canada's third-largest bank, said today that it would acquire a 16 percent equity interest and a 20 percent voting stake in Grupo Financiero Bancomer, Mexico's second-largest bank, for a price between $425 million and $475 million. 
 The Bank of Nova Scotia, Canada's fourth largest, said it would increase its current 5 percent stake in Grupo Financiero Inverlat S.A. to 16 percent by investing $50 million more in the financially shaky bank. It also said that it might increase its stake to as much as 55 percent in the next four years.
"They want to be the first to capitalize on any opportunities" from the North American Free Trade Agreement, said Enrique Gelbard, a senior economist for the Royal Bank of Canada. "Mexican companies are very attractive investments right now, since any Mexican investment is undervalued because of the low value of the peso."
The peso is recovering from a several-stage decline over a period of about a year after its devaluation in December 1994, closing in trading today at 7.525 to the dollar. This represents a modest improvement from the peso's low point late in 1995, when it reached intraday lows of more than 8 to the dollar.
Beyond that, Mexican interest rates have declined some in the last two or three months, as the Government repaid or rolled over some United States debt and Mexican bond and note prices rose. And the Mexico City stock market has been rising.
The Bank of Montreal said it expected to close its purchase of the Bancomer stake by March 31, with the final price subject to fluctuations in currency and share prices.
Its strategy is to be a significant participant in both Mexico and the United States, Canada's partners in the North American Free Trade Agreement, said Jeff Chisholm, the Bank of Montreal's vice chairman. The bank also owns Chicago-based Harris Bancorp.
The Bank of Nova Scotia, which is based here, acquired a 5 percent equity interest in Inverlat, Mexico's fifth-largest bank, in August 1992 for $75 million (U.S.).
It also owns $46.4 million of Inverlat bonds that can be converted into 3.1 percent more, for a total just over 8 percent.
The Bank of Nova Scotia said it would acquire a further $125 million of Inverlat bonds, which mature in eight years. There were conflicting reports as to whether the bonds were convertible into Inverlat equity.
Inverlat has been among the most troubled of Mexican banks with overdue loans representing 16 percent of its portfolio, compared with 10.7 percent for the Mexican banking system on average.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: IN THE PACK;
Alexander, the Contender, Says He Avoids the Negative

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: PETERBOROUGH, N.H., Feb. 15

 BODY:
In the three days since he became a contender, Lamar Alexander has asserted in every speech that voters in Iowa rewarded him on Monday for rising above the negative tactics employed by his rivals.
But while campaigning in New Hampshire, much of Mr. Alexander's message has itself been a negative one. While the former Tennessee governor does not shun discussion of his policy positions, the essence of his strategy here has been to convince voters that his primary rivals, Senator Bob Dole and Patrick J. Buchanan, are both fatally flawed as candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination and as challengers to President Clinton. His goal, it often seems, is election by process of elimination. 
 But unlike many modern-day candidates, Mr. Alexander swipes at his opponents with a velvet touch, not brass knuckles. He emphasizes his respect for Mr. Dole before suggesting that the majority leader is past his prime and has no vision. He praises Mr. Buchanan for his energy before dismissing him as a protectionist with "wrong ideas."
He denies that his negative ads are negative, including the one that labels Mr. Dole as "a Washington insider for 35 years" and Steve Forbes as "a Wall Street insider his entire life."
Asked on Tuesday what was wrong with Wall Street, Mr. Alexander said: "I didn't say it was a bad thing. I just said it was a fact."
Growing support for him in polls seems to suggest that Mr. Alexander's strategy -- executed against the backdrop of relentless negative advertising from his competitors -- is working.
"He doesn't take underhanded shots," said Gordon L. Kemp, a 71-year-old retired truck mechanic who said he was leaning toward Mr. Alexander here after hearing him today. "He doesn't devote a whole 30-second blob on TV to saying the guy did wrong."
Today, Mr. Alexander paid a left-handed compliment to Mr. Dole by describing him as "our most respected legislative engineer."
"We must bring ourselves to say to Bob Dole, 'We appreciate your long service in the Senate but you're not the right man to have that debate with Bill Clinton and you're not the right man to be the first President of the next century,' " he told several hundred listeners today at the Peterborough Town Hall. "It's time for new leadership. It's time to move on."
In criticizing Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Alexander, and his surrogates, like the former Education Secretary, William J. Bennett, have taken to depicting the television commentator as an economic liberal who masquerades as a conservative.
"We don't think on economic issues that Pat Buchanan is on the right," Mr. Alexander said at a news conference with Mr. Bennett on Wednesday. "He has Robert Reich's industrial policy. He has George McGovern's foreign policy."
Today, Mr. Alexander criticized Mr. Buchanan without naming him. "Some people want to keep their focus on the job drain," he said. "They know we're nervous about our jobs. They want to build a trade wall around American and that won't work."
Mr. Alexander said today that his campaign "represents new ideas," while adding that "Senator Dole represents not very many ideas and Pat Buchanan represents the wrong ideas."
And in the last two days, surrounded at every appearance by a scrum of cameramen, he has taken advantage of his newfound media attention to spell out positions on welfare and education in an effort to establish conservative credentials.
Speaking at a forum on Wednesday in Laconia, Mr. Alexander said, "What I would do is to cancel the Washington welfare and take the same amount of money that Laconia sends to Washington, that Nashville sends to Washington, and spend it at home through neighborhood charities, through boys' and girls' clubs, through the emergency shelters. It takes a much bigger heart to say I will help you than to say, I will hire the Government to help you."
At appearances today, Mr. Alexander proposed abolishing the Federal Department of Education, sending Federal education dollars back to the states, and establishing a "G.I. Bill for Kids" that would provide $1,000 scholarships for poor and middle-income students in areas that promote school choice.
"It would help those families take back their schools and give their children more good education by allowing them more choices of schools," he said at Keene State College. "The surest ticket for the future is to help a poor child go to a good school."
In addressing many social problems, Mr. Alexander avoids Government prescriptions altogether and calls for families to take more personal responsibility.
In a favored anecdote, he tells of carrying a pocketknife to school every day while a boy in Maryville, Tenn., an act that he says would be prohibited today under Federal law. No one ever thought of actually using the weapons against another student, he says.
"It had everything to do with the families we came from, the nosy neighbors who tried to keep us out of trouble, the algebra teacher who kept her eye on us, the scout leaders who kept us busy, whoever it was that drug us to church three times a week because it was good for us," he said in Laconia on Wednesday.
Mr. Alexander acknowledges that times have changed. "But we've spent 40 or 50 years trying to invent substitutes for strong families, strong neighbors, strong churches, strong synagogues, strong schools, and we've flunked. We haven't found any. So what I think we need is a President who leads us into the next century with a conservative vision of the future. Strong defense, good new jobs, controlling our borders, yes. But more importantly, asking less of Washington and more of ourselves."

HEADLINE: Fed Nominee Offered No New Direction;
Proved to Be Right

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "White House Rebukes G.O.P. for Scuttling Nominee to Fed" (news article, Feb. 14): 
 When the Republican politicians in power said they would not allow Felix G. Rohatyn to serve as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve because they were afraid his economic views might vary from theirs, they confessed again to what has become obvious.
Their rigid, simplistic ideology abhors subtle intelligence and intellectual integrity.
Mr. Rohatyn has proved himself to be right while helping to save New York from fiscal and economic chaos, and predicting the course of the national economy over the last 20 years. Some of the smartest Republican business leaders seek his counsel because they trust his judgment.
Maybe the Republican politicians in Washington should learn a little more respect for the private sector. Their shortsightedness has denied the United States a valuable public servant.
 
MARIO M. CUOMO
New York, Feb. 14, 1996
 
The writer is the former Governor of New York.

HEADLINE: In Quick Tour, Clinton Touches Critical Base

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

 BODY:
The Clinton-Gore campaign and the two men who happen to head it came barnstorming into New York and New Jersey yesterday, shaking the money tree, touching political bases in a pair of states vital to their re-election and offering a vigorous defense of Felix G. Rohatyn and pro-growth economic policies.
In a packed fund-raising dinner in midtown Manhattan, Mr. Clinton was well into a half-hour recitation of his record in office when he lashed out sharply at Republican Congressional critics who had led Mr. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker, to withdraw his candidacy for nomination as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. 
 The President denounced such attacks as "outrageous political treatment," asked the audience to applaud Mr. Rohatyn -- who was in the ballroom of the Sheraton New York -- and said that the Government should vigorously debate how fast the economy could grow without prompting too much inflation.
"That's what I wanted to see done," Mr. Clinton added. "And that's why I wanted to put Felix Rohatyn on the Federal Reserve. But the politics of Washington said, no, we insist on the conventional wisdom, we insist on holding people down, we don't even think it's worth debating -- over and out. That is wrong, and we must end that kind of thinking if we want this country to grow and prosper and become what it ought to be."
Mr. Clinton spent a good part of the day trying to insure that his own re-election campaign would grow and prosper. Together with Vice President Al Gore, he stopped at the Christopher Columbus middle school in Union City, N.J., to tout computers in schools, then plunged into Manhattan through the Lincoln Tunnel in a rare, time-saving trip in the same black armored Cadillac, with all the tubes closed to other traffic.
Hours later, with the help of celebrities like James Earl Jones, Kathleen Turner, Billy Baldwin and Lesley (no relation) Gore, the campaign raised more than $1 million for the re-election effort in a $1,000-a-plate gala at the Sheraton, and a lower-priced party at the Webster Hall nightclub sponsored by the nationwide network of young Clintonians known as the Saxophone Club.
In 1992, Mr. Clinton won New Jersey for the Democrats for the first time since 1964, and pulled just over 50 percent of the vote in New York, the only state besides Arkansas where he won a majority. This one-day whirlwind visit -- sandwiched between tours of flooded areas in the Pacific Northwest and Pennsylvania -- was a preseason twofer, proof that his campaign is leaving nothing to chance.
The President's remarks about Mr. Rohatyn were by far the most pointed anyone at the White House has yet made. By praising Mr. Rohatyn so strongly, Mr. Clinton seemed to imply at least mild criticism of the stringent tight-money policies of the current Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, whom the White House has acknowledged he intends to re-appoint.
But after the speech, the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, took some pains to insist that Mr. Clinton had meant no criticism of either the chairman, or of the Federal Reserve Board's independent deliberations, and was only saying that "the Fed needs to take those pro-growth arguments into account."
The President's remarks were also clearly intended to appeal to Mr. Rohatyn's hometown crowd, and the ballroom was filled with prominent business and political figures from former Mayor David N. Dinkins to Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire chairman of Revlon, and his wife, Patricia Duff, who sat at Mr. Clinton's table.
Earlier, in his hotel suite, the President also met privately with Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, and with black and Hispanic elected officials from around New York City, including State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx (a fellow client of Mr. Clinton's political strategist, Dick Morris).
In New Jersey, Mr. Clinton announced a plan to set aside $2 billion in Federal education funds over the next five years to help match state, local and private sector efforts to bring computers to schools.
"When I was young, I thought the future was there for every American who would work for it," Mr. Clinton told students, teachers and parents from Christopher Columbus, a gritty urban school in the heart of Union City where a pilot project in computer education sponsored by the Bell Atlantic Corporation has put test scores 10 points above the statewide average and sent attendance rates soaring.
"It turned out to be true for my generation. It will be true for this generation, too, and it will be a bigger, brighter, broader future, but only if we bring the benefits of the information revolution to every single one of them."
Harold M. Ickes, the New York labor lawyer and veteran Democratic campaign operative who is now a deputy White House chief of staff, said of the two-state visit, "We're not taking anything for granted."
Other campaign aides noted that Mr. Clinton has been in New York often in recent years, but usually to raise money or campaign for other Democrats like Mr. Dinkins or Mario M. Cuomo, and had not had a plain old-fashioned political chat with local Democrats for some time.
Mr. Ferrer said the meeting with Hispanic officials, which also included the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Henry Cisneros, lasted about two hours, and covered a range of topics, from welfare reform to politics.
The event last night at Webster Hall -- a mecca for the hip and happening in the East Village where Madonna once paraded in her pajamas to promote her album "Bedtime Stories" -- was intended to appeal to younger supporters, who paid $150 to $250 to eat garlic shrimp, listen to a jazz band and cheer Mr. Clinton.
A saxophone was propped up onstage in case Mr. Clinton decided to reprise his musical performance from the Arsenio Hall show, but the President settled for a lot of hand-shaking and a call for younger voters to make their voices heard.
"This election is about you and your future," he said. "It's about what kind of America you're going to live in."
The scenic highlight of Mr. Clinton's visit came earlier in the day, when his motorcade decended from the heights of Union City into the Lincoln Tunnel. The route he used was by far the most direct into Manhattan, but a great rarity for Presidents, because the Secret Service and New York City police much prefer the isolated security of helicopters and the solitary splendor of the East River Drive. In this case, that method would have meant an hour-long trek through Newark International Airport to the Wall Street heliport.
Instead, Mr. Clinton was in his suite at the Sheraton New York in midtown within 15 minutes of leaving Union City, after a triumphal progression along West 42d Street and up the Avenue of the Americas to West 53d Street, as midday passersby milled behind block after block of blue-and-white police sawhorses. On 42d Street, the motorcade passed the cleaned up marquees of the former pornographic theaters that once lined the block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
"It's been sort of v-chipped!" Mr. Ickes marveled of the street, referring to the device that can be installed in television sets to block violent programming and that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore support.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Judge Approves Settlement Of Drug Price-Fixing Suit
A Federal judge gave preliminary approval to a $409 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit that charged drug makers and wholesalers with conspiring to fix prices on sales to independent pharmacies. The decision cleared the way for notice of the settlement to be mailed to the 40,000 pharmacies in the class.
The settlement with 15 of 23 defendants in the case against most of the world's major drug makers calls for them to pay nearly $389 million over three years. [Page D2.]
 
2 Bidders Quit Wireless Auction
As the auction of new wireless communication licenses heated up, two leading bidders dropped out. U.S. Airwaves, which has backing from MCI, Sony and Hyundai, gave up on its hopes of buying up licenses covering much of the country, and Craig O. McCaw also stepped back from the aggressive bidding. [D3.]
 
Another 24-Hour Sports Station
Turner plans to start a 24-hour-a-day sports news channel on cable, combining elements of the Cable News Network and Sports Illustrated magazine, according to a Turner executive. [D4.]
 
Clinton Backs Growth Policies
President Clinton, in New York, vigorously defended pro-growth economic policies and Felix G. Rohatyn. He said the investment banker, whom Mr. Clinton wanted to name to the Federal Reserve Board, had received "outrageous political treatment." [B1.]
 
A Back-to-Back Drop in the Dow
Blue-chip stocks fell as investors continued to cash in profits after the market's recent string of records. It was the first back-to-back decline in the Dow Jones industrial average in three weeks. It ended down 28.18 points, at 5,551.37, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also fell, though the Nasdaq index, weighted with technology stocks, edged up. [D6.]
Bond prices slumped, largely on technical factors. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell more than a point. [D13.]
 
Hoffenberg Is in Custody
Steven Hoffenberg, the New York financier who ran what securities regulators have called the largest Ponzi scheme in history, turned himself in to Federal agents after he failed to meet bail terms. [D3.]
 
Bribery Accusation in Tokyo
A property tycoon told a Japanese Parliament hearing that a former personal secretary to Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto tried to solicit a $400,000 bribe several years ago. The accusation could complicate a solution of Japan's debt crisis. [D6.]
 
$1 Billion Offer for Journal Company
Journal Communications, which owns the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel and other interests, said it had rebuffed an inquiry about a possible $1 billion offer from an investment group in New York, Sextant Partners. [D3.]
 
Waste Haulers Change Practices
Waste Management and Browning-Ferris, the largest haulers of solid waste, agreed to change their contract practices, settling Justice Department charges. [D3.]
 
Canadian Banks Invest in Mexico
The Bank of Montreal and the Bank of Nova Scotia are betting on a Mexican economic recovery, buying or increasing stakes in Bancomer and Inverlat. [D6.]

For No-Glitz Skin Care
Advertising for skin care and cosmetics has long featured glamorous, emotional appeals, but that is changing as new products, some sold only by prescription, are offering more efficacious ingredients. And typically they are being marketed without glitz and glitter in a low-key, sensible-sounding approach. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Metro Digest

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
Democrats Unveil Schools Plan
 The Democratic leaders of the State Assembly proposed abolishing New York City's Board of Education, as well as its 32 community school boards. They called instead for a new board, most of whose members would be chosen in elections, and for a chancellor with broad powers and even greater independence from City Hall. [Page A1.]
 
One-Officer Patrols Denounced
 The issue of one-officer patrol cars remains one of the most emotional in local law enforcement, and now may pit a law-and-order Mayor against a police force that has contributed to the city's sharp drop in crime. [A1.]
 
New Victim of City Neglect
 Bolaji Odebayo, the 11-year-old Brooklyn boy who was found Tuesday night burned, broken and petrified, was as much a victim of indifference and neglect by city investigators as Elisa Izquierdo or any of the other abused children who did not survive. [B1.]
 
President Barnstorms Region
 The Clinton-Gore campaign and the men who head it came barnstorming into New York and New Jersey, showing off the information superhighway, shaking the money tree, touching political bases and generally raising their profile in two states vital to their re-election. [B1.]
 
Selling or Saving the Parks?
 To offset dwindling financial resources, the Parks Department has embarked on a new path: an aggressive pursuit of profit. In May, the department hired a marketing director to find money-making opportunities and corporate sponsors to finance recreational events in city parks in return for publicity. Parks advocates fear that the city is selling off its parks, piece by piece. [B1.]
 
Testing Boxers for H.I.V.
 Spurred by the case of Tommy Morrison, the former heavyweight champion who recently tested positive for H.I.V., New York has joined the handful of states that require boxers to be screened for H.I.V. This latest headache for boxing comes just as the sport is making a comeback at Madison Square Garden. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
New Questions for Judge
 Judge Lorin Duckman, the Brooklyn judge who has been sharply criticized for his handling of a domestic violence case that ended in murder, allowed a Brooklyn man to go free last summer just hours after a jury found him guilty of attacking his former girlfriend. And early yesterday, the man was arrested and charged with pushing his ex-girlfriend down two flights of stairs. [B3.]
 
REGION
 
Report Sees New Jersey Bias
 Adding statistical weight to Mayor Giuliani's assertion that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey slights New York City, Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate, said that the authority favored New Jersey in its capital spending and transportation services. [B5.]
 
Man Arrested in Wife's Assault
 A Hasidic man whose estranged wife was found beaten unconscious in her home in Monsey, N.Y., was arrested outside a Lower East Side bagel shop by the police and a Hasidic volunteer patrol, and charged with attempted murder. [B5.]
 
Juggling Pay for Charity Care
 On the day that New Jersey missed its first payment to reimburse hospitals for providing medical treatment to the poor, Republican legislative leaders agreed to pay for the state's charity care program by continuing to use surplus revenues from the unemployment insurance fund. [B5.]
 
Data Deepen Crash Mystery
 Information collected by a recorder on a New Jersey Transit train in the seconds before last week's fatal collision is garbled in places, investigators said, and it appears to contradict some of their early beliefs about what happened. [B4.]
 
Upset in Republican District
 Democrats won an Assembly seat in a heavily Republican district in Rochester during a special election widely viewed as a referendum on Republican policies in New York State. [B6.]
 
 Democratic candidates won decisive victories in special elections to fill a State Assembly and a State Senate seat in the Bronx as well as a State Senate seat in Brooklyn. [B6.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1190 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEBATE;
G.O.P. RIVALS CLASH OVER ATTACK ADS

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 15

 BODY:
In a nationally televised forum five days before Tuesday's primary, the Republican Presidential candidates quarreled over trade, health care and welfare tonight and vied for the title of most true conservative. But they spent much of their time attacking one another over attack advertisements.
The most vivid moment occurred when Senator Bob Dole, reaching over Representative Robert K. Dornan, handed Steve Forbes photographs of himself with his wife and dog. Mr. Dole called on Mr. Forbes to use more flattering photographs if he wanted to broadcast negative commercials. 
 "That's Elizabeth on the right," Mr. Dole said, handing over one picture. "And here's my little dog, Leader."
As Mr. Forbes, looking flustered, tried for a rebuttal, saying, "Senator, no pretty picture can get around. . . ." Mr. Dole cut him off sharply. "I know your problem," he said. "You have a lot of money. You want to buy this election. But this election is not for sale."
Beyond the personal jabs, the contenders repeatedly clashed over jobs and trade policies, themes that have marked the candidates' speeches here since the campaign shifted this week from Iowa.
The eight candidates, standing side by side at lecterns, appealed to voters' concerns about economic insecurity. Several challenged Patrick J. Buchanan's advocacy of trade restrictions. Senator Dole, for example, said that many of the high-tech jobs that have allowed much of New England to prosper had resulted from international trade agreements. And he said Mr. Buchanan was on "an isolationist kick."
But most notable about the 90-minute forum at WMUR studios here, carried live nationwide on CNN, was how the candidates jumped into the donnybrook over negative advertising.
The event descended into a free-for-all, with candidates cutting one another off and trying to put down their most threatening rivals. Mr. Buchanan took on Mr. Dole. Mr. Dole attacked Mr. Forbes and, to a lesser degree, President Clinton. Former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee ignored Mr. Buchanan and aimed his fire at Mr. Dole. But Mr. Forbes went after Mr. Alexander, with whom he is vying to be considered the outsider in the race.
The forum turned negative almost immediately, when Mr. Alexander, seconds into his opening statement, sought to set himself apart by accusing Mr. Dole of running negative television commercials.
Turning to Senator Dole, the majority leader, Mr. Alexander said: "You're better than negative ads. Why don't you pull them?"
Mr. Dole shot back, telling Mr. Alexander, "I didn't know about negative advertising until I saw you do it against Pete Wilson." Indeed, Mr. Alexander ran negative commercials against Gov. Pete Wilson of California, who later withdrew from the race, in this state last year. Mr. Alexander did little negative advertising in Iowa.
Mr. Buchanan then took up the attack, scolding Mr. Dole for a new negative commercial that accuses him of extremism. Mr. Buchanan, a former commentator, also accused the Senator of mimicking his ideas even as he painted Mr. Buchanan as out of step with the mainstream of America.
"If I am an extremist, why are you pirating my ideas and parroting my rhetoric?" he asked. "Pat Buchanan is not an extremist." He also accused Mr. Dole of orchestrating a phone campaign against him.
Mr. Buchanan's frequent attacks prompted Mr. Dole at one point to turn to the former commentator and say: "Pat's really gotten carried away tonight. I don't know what happened. Did you have a bad day or something?"
Behind their endless volleys at Mr. Dole were efforts by Mr. Alexander and Mr. Buchanan to emerge as the Senator's chief competitor. Mr. Dole won a narrow victory in the Iowa caucuses last week; Mr. Buchanan ran a close second, followed by Mr. Alexander.
In Iowa, rivals had accused Mr. Forbes, the publisher, of running a negative campaign. But Mr. Forbes was no longer the central target -- as he was in the last televised forum in Iowa -- because he has slid in the polls after finishing fourth in the caucuses. He said tonight that he regretted that "I spent too much time discussing my opponents."
Mr. Dole, the favorite target of Mr. Forbes's advertisements, interjected, "Too much money."
Tonight, Mr. Forbes, struggling for attention, tried to return to his message of "hope, growth and opportunity" and said he was the candidate running "to do something" rather than "to be something." He also sought to portray his controversial flat tax as only one element of his agenda. He said voters would be empowered by his proposals for medical savings accounts and the privatization of Social Security.
But it did not take long for Mr. Forbes to go on the attack, either. He went after Mr. Alexander, comparing his lucrative investment history with that of Hillary Rodham Clinton and implying that he had got a sweetheart deal. He said Mr. Alexander "turned one dollar into $620 million."
The longer shot contenders -- Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana; Alan Keyes, a former talk show host; Morry Taylor, a tire manufacturer, and Mr. Dornan -- chastised the leading candidates for not running more positive campaigns.
Mr. Dole tried to stay on a positive note, asserting: "I will be the next President of the United States. I'll be a good mainstream American President with a lot of good ideas about America's future."
The candidates talked so much about protecting markets that Mr. Keyes observed at one point that his opponents "sound like a bunch of socialists, not Republicans."
And Mr. Lugar said, "We will lose jobs if we go isolationist, protectionist."
The health care issue brought a sweeping reply from Mr. Dornan to exempt physicians from malpractice suits. "Take the lawyers out of it," he said.
Mr. Alexander offered two ideas, proposing greater flexibility in Medicare, moving "the decision-making and the money out of Washington."
Mr. Buchanan said people were losing their health care because of massive layoffs by corporations. "We've got to get those good-paying jobs back in the United States," he said, arguing that would bolster health care systems. "The eagle will soar," he said, moving the issue to his protectionist theme.
Mr. Dole said a pending bill would ease the problem by allowing for coverage of pre-existing health problems, insurance portability and a dozen other provisions. "We need to give tax credits to families with children," he added, so they can better provide their own health care.
On the matter of negative advertisements, which have been pervasive in New Hampshire this year, Mr. Forbes, who has broadcast the most negative commercials, said he thought it was "legitimate discussion for debate" when candidates like Senator Dole broke promises about not raising taxes.
Mr. Dornan, who voted for the North American Free Trade Agreement, dealt with the protectionist question by denouncing the Mexican Government. "Mexico is in sad shape," he said. "The problem is corruption under one-party rule."
Mr. Forbes said he supported the trade agreement but blamed the Clinton Administration and the Mexican Government for not living up to Nafta.

HEADLINE: Level Field or Uneven Results?;
Tallying Up the What Ifs in the Flat-Tax Proposals

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
A year ago, it is safe to say, not one American in 100 knew much about the flat tax. But after Steve Forbes spent tens of millions of dollars from his fortune espousing it endlessly in the Republican Presidential campaign, the flat tax has become fodder for talk radio and stand-up comedy.
And while Mr. Forbes, who will be pushing the idea in debates leading up to the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, is expected to fade from the picture, the concept has generated enough attention to make it likely to be kicking around for some time to come. 
But familiarity does not necessarily breed understanding. For what appears to be a straightforward modification of the Federal income tax in fact amounts to a radical revamping of the tax system. If adopted in anything like the form proposed by Mr. Forbes or another important advocate, the House majority leader, Dick Armey of Texas, it would be a change so sweeping that the consequences would be difficult, if not impossible, to predict.
It might well, as Mr. Forbes and his supporters say, be the key that unlocks an era of of lower tax rates, higher tax revenues and faster economic growth that eluded the Reagan Administration. Or it may, as many mainstream economists maintain, simply turn out to be a windfall for the richest Americans, making it even more difficult to tame the Federal budget deficit without hurting the poor and the middle class.
"This is uncharted territory," says Bill Gale, an economist at the middle-of-the-road Brookings Institution in Washington, "a no-man's land of possibility and wishful thinking."
The central appeal of the flat tax to ordinary Americans is the simplicity that would make it possible to reduce the tax form to the size of a postcard -- or to describe the tax system in a few paragraphs. The personal and corporate income taxes, with their multiple brackets, myriad deductions and ambiguous definitions would be abolished. In their place would be a tax on wages and other labor compensation collected from individuals and families, and a tax on the return to investment collected from businesses.
Under the Forbes plan, starting in 1998 a family of four would pay no tax on the first $36,000 of wages and pensions. The tax on labor compensation exceeding $36,000 would be 17 percent. (Comparing with present law, in 1994 -- the most recent year for which figures on tax liability are available -- the inflation-adjusted income level at which the flat tax would kick in is $31,750.) Representative Armey, who has offered a more fleshed-out proposal, would follow a slightly different pattern.
In both versions, the tax on investment income -- interest, dividends, capital gains -- would no longer be levied against households. But there would be no deductions for mortgage interest, state and local taxes, costly medical treatments or charitable contributions. And a range of employee benefits, from flexible spending accounts for child care expenses to company-paid health insurance, would no longer enjoy tax-favored status.
Businesses would pay the same flat tax rate on revenues, after subtracting outlays for wages (but not fringe benefits) along with other purchases -- everything from staples to warehouses to computers. But in figuring their taxes, corporations would no longer be able to deduct interest payments on debts.
Mr. Forbes, along with those economists who believe that taxes are a strong disincentive to work and saving, extol the greater efficiency of a flat tax. With a maximum tax rate on wages of 17 percent instead of the roughly 40 percent under current law and no household tax at all on investment income, flat-tax enthusiasts see a bonanza of enterprise, investment and economic growth.
The simplicity and transparency of the tax will appeal to corporate managers, who must now spend almost as much of their time worrying about the tax consequences of business decisions as they do about the nuts and bolts. But some businesses, notably those in mature, capital-intensive industries like autos and steel, may well end up paying more tax, while businesses that are growing will pay less. Note, too, that a flat tax would force a revolution in corporate finance, making it far more expensive to raise capital through loans or bond sales.
For most Americans, though, the immediate appeal is no doubt what they see in it for themselves. The struggling lower middle class may see redemption in a hefty standard deduction that frees it of all income tax liability. Middle-income Americans may focus on the low, flat rate that looks a lot better than the 28 percent tax rate most now pay on their last dollars of income. And the most successful Americans dream of a world without taxes on dividends, interest and capital gains.
It is not quite that simple, though. Most low-income Americans pay no Federal income taxes, anyway. And under Mr. Armey's proposal, they would no longer be eligible for the earned-income tax credit, a cash rebate from Uncle Sam that amounts to a negative income tax for the working poor. Mr. Forbes would preserve this tax credit, but he would have to pay for it with Federal spending cuts, higher flat tax rates or bigger budget deficits.
Middle-class Americans -- those with family incomes between, say, $40,000 and $100,000 -- presumably like the look of that 17 percent flat rate. But for many of them, the loss of deductions for mortgage interest, charity and local taxes could outweigh the benefits. Note, too, that employers would no longer be able to deduct outlays for medical insurance from their taxable revenues. Since economists generally assume that employers look at total compensation in setting wages, this tax would effectively fall on workers.
Then there are the wheels within the wheels. Neither Mr. Armey nor Mr. Forbes's tax plan would generate as much revenue as the income tax unless economic growth exploded. Shvetank Shah at Price Waterhouse's Economic Policy Consulting Service expects that it will take a 21 percent flat tax to sustain revenues if the earned-income tax credit is abandoned, as Mr. Armey advocates, and 23 percent if it is retained, as it is under Mr. Forbes's proposal.
While most taxpayers would enjoy a tax cut if the flat rate was set at 17 percent, those with the highest incomes would gain the most. And under a truly revenue-neutral flat tax, middle-income Americans earning less than $50,000 generally would do worse while those above that level would tend to do better. But differing individual circumstances -- mortgages, local taxes, contributions, investment income -- would determine individual outcomes.
By contrast, what the well-to-do see in the flat tax is pretty much what they would get. Lower tax rates on salaries combined with no personal tax on investment income, should mean higher after-tax income for nearly every rich family. Price Waterhouse estimates that a typical household with $250,000 in income would save 46 percent on its Federal income tax bill under a 23 percent flat-tax regime and even more if the rate was set at 17 percent.
But even here individual circumstances could prove decisive. Earning from investments would still be taxed at the corporate level. Some kinds of businesses would pay considerably more tax than they do today, some less. And since a tax on business is widely assumed to be a tax on the owners of the business, in some cases the gain from lighter taxation of affluent households, which hold most of the corporate assets, would be lost in heavier taxation of corporate revenues.
Also, while the focus has been on the flat tax's impact on after-tax income, wealth would be affected, too. Indeed, Lawrence Kotlikoff, an economist at Boston University, thinks the indirect levy on existing wealth associated with higher business tax liability and the elimination of the mortgage interest deduction would help offset the rich-get-richer features of the flat tax on earnings. Here, much depends on how the transition from the current system is handled -- in particular, what happens to the trillions of dollars in future deductions for capital depreciation that businesses have on the books for equipment already bought.
Many economists have long been intrigued by the simplicity, efficiency and intellectual elegance of the flat tax, particularly the way it would encourage investment and savings by eliminating the double taxation of corporate earnings at both the business and personal level.
But the attraction for voters may well be the notion of something for nothing. While some of the Republican candidates have nodded in the direction of a flatter tax system, several of them, including Lamar Alexander and Pat Buchanan, have already attacked Mr. Forbes's proposal, pointing out that any pure flat tax would further widen the gap between the rich and the middle class. And they note that Mr. Forbes's contention that nearly everybody would be better off under his plan relies on keeping the rate unsustainably low in hopes that a supercharged burst of economic growth would prevent the budget deficit from exploding.
If Mr. Forbes's star does not burn out soon, you can count on some of his opponents to step up their challenges to his claims.
"Once the romance ends," says Joel Slemrod, an economist at the University of Michigan's Business School, "we'll find out what the flat tax looks like without makeup."
 The chart also misstated the effect of a 23 percent flat tax on a family with a $100,000 income. It would pay $750 more, not $700.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 23, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day last Friday with an article about proposals for a flat tax misstated the effect of a 23 percent version on a married couple with two children and a $75,000 income. Such a family would pay $625 more than under the current tax system, not $750.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Suffer a 3d Day of Steep Losses

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell sharply for a third consecutive session yesterday, weighed down by talk of selling by large funds and by concerns that the supply of securities might be larger than the demand. Trading was choppy in a session that ended early ahead of the Washington's Birthday holiday weekend.
The sharp decline in prices came even though Government reports in the last two days showed that the economy was slowing at a more pronounced pace than had previously been thought. The indications of weakness that were found in reports on durable goods and factory orders on Thursday were echoed in reports yesterday on industrial production and construction spending. In the past, the bond market has often rallied on such reports, with their portents of continued mild inflation. 
 But analysts said they were not surprised that further evidence of a slowdown failed to bolster bond prices.
"You have to remember that the market has been bullish for a very long time, trading in a range of between 6 and 6.25 percent," said Ken McCarthy, the founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a market resarch firm. "A lot of optimism has already been built into prices, so it's going to take something else to take it out of its range."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell nearly a point, to 9624/32, driving its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, to 6.24 percent, from 6.16 percent on Thursday. The 30-year bond yield, a closely watched barometer for consumer interest rates, is now up sharply from 6.02 percent on Tuesday, and is at its highest since the Thanksgiving Day weekend.
The market opened yesterday to carry-over selling from Thursday, with additional losses tied to talk of more selling by some large hedge funds. Those reports raised investor concern that supply would outstrip demand. In addition, a large amount of new corporate and global issues with higher yields than comparable Treasury securities lured buyers away from Treasuries this week.
Traders said a brief comeback attempt, in the form of a short-covering rally, soon fizzled. Short-covering occurs when traders who have sold securities short -- that is, sold borrowed securities in hopes of a decline in price -- buy securities to cover their bet and reduce their exposure to loss should prices rise instead of fall.
Mr. McCarthy of Economic Intelligence noted that market participants were reluctant to hold long-term securities in advance of Congressional testimony next week by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Trading ended at 2 P.M. yesterday; the Treasury market will be closed on Monday in observance of Washington's Birthday.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said the economic reports released yesterday confirmed the market's view of a slowing economy. The Federal Reserve reported that industrial production fell six-tenths of 1 percent in January, the steepest decline since March 1991.
While the extent of the slowdown in January was clearly exaggerated by the blizzard that hit the East Coast early in the month, Mr. Fine said, "the fact remains that not all of the sales and production lost in January will be recouped."
The Commerce Department's report on construction spending in December also gave no hint of a pickup in economic growth, he said, since December's gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent simply reversed November's decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent. Also, October's gain was revised from a rise of 2.7 percent to one of only five-tenths of 1 percent.
Mr. Fine also pointed to the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index, which fell, he said, to 86.6, its lowest since November 1993. The index is released only to subscribers.
"All these statistics did nothing to alter the view that the Federal Open Market Committee is still leaning toward further accommodation," he said, referring to the Fed's policy-making panel.

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Plunges, With Bad Weather Cited

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities took its biggest plunge in January since the nation was struggling to emerge from the last recession nearly five years ago, a Government report showed today. But bad weather was cited as a major factor.
The report provided further evidence that the economy slowed sharply in the first quarter. Many economists expect that the growth rate will be 1 percent or less for the first three months of the year. 
 The Federal Reserve reported that industrial production fell six-tenths of 1 percent in January, the steepest decline since output slid eight-tenths of 1 percent in March 1991, the final month of the 1990-91 recession.
Although the drop reflected continued weakness in the manufacturing sector, the central bank said it was aggravated by a blizzard that hit the East Coast in early January and forced the closing of many plants.
"The industrial production report is not a report about the economy," said Robert Brusca, an economist with Nikko Securities Company International in New York. "It's a weather report."
But Jerry Jasinowski, an economist and president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said that in addition to the severe weather, the report "reflects ongoing problems such as weak spending and clearly points to a poor first quarter."
The Commerce Department reported that construction spending rose nine-tenths of a percent in December, wiping out a similar loss a month earlier.
But spending on single-family housing fell for a second consecutive month.
While construction outlays for all of 1995 were up 4 percent, the advance was less than half the 9.1 percent increase the previous year.
Analysts did find a glimmer of hope in a second Commerce Department report today. It said business inventories in November edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent, the smallest increase since a similar rise in March 1994. The modest increase points to a possible pickup ahead in orders and production as businesses successfully clear their shelves and backlots.
At the same time, business sales rebounded seven-tenths of 1 percent in November after slipping three-tenths of 1 percent a month earlier.
The Fed also reported that the nation's industries were operating at 81.9 percent of capacity, down from 82.7 percent in December and the lowest since an 81.8 percent use rate in November 1993.
That portends continued moderate inflation, because the falling rate suggested a lack of production bottlenecks that could increase prices.
Factory output fell six-tenths of 1 percent, erasing a slight gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in December. Mining production slipped three-tenths of 1 percent on top of a fall of one-tenth of 1 percent in December. Output at the nation's utilities also fell, down nine-tenths of 1 percent after rising six-tenths of 1 percent. The increase caught many analysts offguard, since they were expecting a sizable gain because of increased power use during January's stormy weather.
In its construction spending report, the Commerce Department said outlays for residential, nonresidential and government projects totaled a record $537.5 billion annual rate, up from $532.9 billion in November, when spending dropped nine-tenths of 1 percent. Spending had risen half of 1 percent in October.
Residential spending rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in December, to a $241.2 billion rate, but the strength was in the multifamily sector. Single-family spending fell 1.2 percent on top of a six-tenths of 1 percent drop in November.
Multifamily spending, which is not as sensitive to interest rate changes as spending for single-family homes, jumped 11 percent in December, the second straight advance.
In its other report, the department said inventories totaled a seasonally adjusted $981 billion in November, up from $980.3 billion a month earlier. Manufacturing inventories were unchanged in November.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Hewlett's Shares Surge on Strength of Earnings Report

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16

 BODY:
The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that its earnings spurted 31 percent in the latest quarter. The increase was far bigger than expected and sent the company's shares soaring nearly 10.5 percent on a day when the broad market fell back.
In the first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31, Hewlett-Packard earned $790 million, or $1.50 a share, up from $602 million, or $1.15 a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Analysts had been expecting about $1.35 a share. Revenues grew 27 percent, to $9.29 billion from $7.30 billion. The increases lifted the company's shares $9, to $95.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Analysts said the company's performance had been strong across all product lines, especially servers, which are computers shared by multiple users across a network, and printers, where Hewlett-Packard dominates the market. In nearly every category, the company's business units grew faster than their markets.
"They've got great momentum; they're really firing on all cylinders," said Stephen Smith, an analyst with Paine Webber. In addition to strong results in servers, printers and personal computers, "there has been a miraculous recovery in H.P.'s traditional business of test and measurement equipment" for electronics, he said. "This quarter it grew 30 percent; they've taken it from a mature business to a high-growth business," he added.
Hewlett-Packard said orders for the quarter rose 29 percent, to $10.1 billion. Domestic orders grew 24 percent, to $3.9 billion, while orders from outside the country climbed 32 percent, to $6.2 billion, representing 61 percent of the total.
"We're extremely pleased to start the year with these results," Lewis E. Platt, Hewlett-Packard's chairman, president and chief executive, said in a statement. "Very strong acceptance of our products, as well as outstanding growth in international markets, drove order and revenue increases that were ahead of our plan," he said. "Our businesses executed very well, and we strengthened our competitive position in key markets."
So consistently has Hewlett-Packard exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates each quarter that it runs the risk of seeing its stock drop should it simply meet expectations. Mr. Platt made a point of adding cautionary notes to his prepared statements and to a conference call with analysts.
"We're starting the second quarter in an excellent competitive position, but there are many challenges in the markets we serve," Mr. Platt said. "Competition remains intense; pricing pressures are persistent, and customer expectations continue to rise," he said. "In addition, there are signs of slowing in some major economies, including the United States and Western Europe."
Mr. Smith of Paine Webber said the company had increased profit margins in the quarter after seeing them drop in the fourth quarter of last year. "There's a fundamental shift to the commodity products, but they've pretty much gotten through that transition," he said. "They don't have much fat left."

HEADLINE: On Riverside South, It's Time to Break Ground

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Feb. 15 photo of the rally for the proposed Riverside South complex on Manhattan's Upper West Side:
Several thousand union workers -- not the half-dozen shown -- gathered to support a project that will create 21,000 jobs, 5,700 units of housing (20 percent for low-income families) and 25 acres of open space and parks on the Hudson River. 
 Riverside South has been approved by New York City in a process upheld by the New York State Court of Appeals, leaving no further local obstacles to breaking ground. It has also been endorsed by a strong alliance of civic organizations, environmentalists and developers.
Representative Jerrold L. Nadler stands virtually alone in opposing a project that will start in a matter of months. Until he presents a plan to bring $4 billion of economic opportunity to the area this year, he should get out of the way and let us go to work.
 
EDWARD J. MALLOY
New York, Feb. 15, 1996

HEADLINE: I Want My HDTV

BYLINE: By Richard E. Wiley; Richard E. Wiley, former chairman of the F.C.C., was head of its Advisory Committee on Advanced Television Service. Now a Washington lawyer, he represents communications companies.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After an eight-year cooperative effort between the Government and industry, the United States leads the world in the development of digital high-definition television.
But Congressional concerns, arising in connection with enactment of the new telecommunications act, may derail the careful transition that the Federal Communications Commission has planned from our existing video system to the new technology. 
 HDTV will provide viewers with dazzlingly clear, wide-screen TV pictures and CD-like sound. But such a technical advance is not just about prettier TV. What beckons is a new era in which digital TV receivers, incorporating computer intelligence, will provide easy access to the information superhighway and its advanced digital services.
The United States' role in HDTV began in 1987 when the F.C.C. organized an industry advisory committee to help establish a new broadcast transmission standard (the existing standard was set in 1941). After reviewing numerous proposals, it determined that systems using digital transmission were superior to the older analog technology. It then urged the remaining proponents to switch to digital and ultimately merge into a single consortium.
After exhaustive testing, this system has now been recommended to the F.C.C. as the basis of a new national standard. It represents a tremendous advance in TV technology that will allow broadcasters to deliver not only HDTV but, in different times of the day, multiple lower resolution programs and data services. The system also works with computers and other imaging technologies.
To bring about digital TV, the F.C.C. has planned to lend a second channel to each TV station, employing frequencies reserved for broadcasters but unused because of signal interference. Fortunately, digital transmission will permit much more efficient use of this spectrum. The F.C.C. intends a gradual transition to the new service, enabling viewers to use their analog sets for a number of years. When the transition is completed, the existing channels would be returned to the Government for other uses.
Critics on Capitol Hill and elsewhere have raised a number of objections:
* That it represents a giveaway of valuable frequencies to broadcasters. But in reality it is only an exchange of one block for another, with the public getting a greatly enhanced service. Broadcasters would not be allowed to retain two channels permanently.
* That new legislation should require an auction of the HDTV spectrum. But this would disrupt the F.C.C.'s planned transition to digital broadcasting and likely lead to HDTV's development as a subscription service, offered only by cable and satellite. A better alternative is to auction the existing channels, which, when returned in a concentrated spectrum block, should be more valuable than the dispersed digital frequencies.
* That broadcasters should be given less than a full second channel. But the consortium system cannot be so divided, requiring the lengthy design and testing of an entirely new transmission system.
* That lower resolution digital TV is as good as HDTV. But hundreds of advisory committee experts did not agree, judging HDTV as a quantum leap forward.
Government leaders must determine where the public interest lies in this debate. But it is essential that they understand the technical, economic and social benefits in digital TV and its many spinoff services.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: New York 2020

BYLINE: By Robert R. Kiley; Robert R. Kiley is president of the New York City Partnership, an alliance of corporate executives.

 BODY:
It is the year 2020 and residents of the once vibrant New York region are stuck in apartments they cannot unload in crumbling urban centers. Suburbanites are faring no better. This is one bleak scenario presented in "A Region at Risk," a five-year study by the Regional Plan Association.
This picture cannot be dismissed: Too many of the region's core industries lost ground between 1982 and 1992. But there is far more reason to believe, as the association does, that long-term planning and a relatively modest investment will enable the region to retain its status as the global capital. 
 Boosterism? Hardly. No other region in the United States can match our muscle in financial and business services, in culture, tourism, information technology and fashion, despite some slippage in these industries.
Chicago is our nearest American rival in financial services, but not a close one. London may trade a greater volume of foreign currencies and Tokyo has larger banking assets, but neither has the diversity and the vitality of the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut region.
These capital cities have an advantage, however. Their national governments invest in them. Also, they are more resourceful in attracting private capital to maintain roads, subways and other infrastructure. Washington, however, treats New York as a stepchild. We send the Government billions ($18.9 billion in 1994) more in tax revenues than we get back in outlays. Washington's myopia need not be fatal -- if something is done starting now. One of the region's fundamental economic assets is its transit system. Our 1,250-mile rail network has enabled New York to attract and keep a highly skilled and increasingly mobile work force. But it was designed in the 19th century and needs to be updated for the 21st. Tokyo, Paris, London and Los Angeles are building or planning integrated regional rail systems; we have been at a standstill.
The association prescribes a $21 billion, 25-year transit plan. It recommends taking advantage of 25 miles of unused and underused rail segments to connect the region's far-flung systems. The Long Island Railroad, Metro-North, New Jersey Transit and New York City's subway system would be linked. Commuters from Teaneck, N.J., could get to Wall Street in 30 minutes; a trip from midtown to Kennedy Airport would take 29 minutes, and people who live in Laurelton, Queens, and Co-op City, in the Bronx, and who have no access to mass transit would be given service.
Twenty-one billion dollars is a huge amount, especially when the city, state and Federal governments are struggling to reduce budget gaps. But spread over 25 years, it is not daunting. In fact, taken together New York, New Jersey and Connecticut spend, in unproductive border warfare, about $1 billion a year providing tax incentives to attract businesses or keep them from moving next door.
Barring sudden enlightenment in Washington, the $21 billion would have to be raised locally. This should not be impossible. Paris built its $30 billion rail system by imposing a payroll tax. A gasoline tax of a few cents a gallon could raise the necessary capital here. Electronic toll collections on the East River bridges could generate hundreds of millions of dollars annually. The Hudson River bridges and tunnels could be transferred to an expanded Metropolitan Transportation Authority and subsidize its transit operations.
All of these approaches would require some sacrifice and must be debated. But the Regional Planning Association's report is the handwriting on the wall. Our political leaders and citizens should take heed.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Flight From South African Rand Helps to Push the Dollar Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Big sell orders sent the dollar lower against the Japanese yen and German mark yesterday in a drop accelerated by a flight from the South African rand linked to rumors that President Nelson Mandela had suffered a heart attack.
The rand was also hurt by talk that the South African central bank was about to relax remaining exchange controls, an action that might encourage investors to move capital out of the country. 
 Mr. Mandela appeared at a picture-taking session with President Sam Nujoma of Namibia and dismissed the rumors, but the rand lost much of the support that had been driving it higher lately.
"The popping of a speculative bubble in South Africa led to sharp dollar declines," said Tom O'Malley senior foreign exchange analyst at Technical Data.
Investors have recently been taking advantage of low interest rates in Japan and Switzerland to borrow yen and francs, then put the money in rand-denominated South African bonds paying about 14 percent.
With the rand falling, investors retreated to repay the borrowed yen and francs, lifting those currencies.
Lower American bond prices also helped pull the dollar lower.
Trading was thin ahead of the Washington's Birthday holiday in the United States and the New Year holiday on Monday and Tuesday in much of Asia. Also, a snowstorm in New York sent many traders home early, leaving the market vulnerable to a large order at 2 P.M. to sell dollars and buy marks.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar was trading at 1.4535 marks, down from 1.4656 on Thursday. It finished at 105.20 yen, compared with 105.55 the day before. The dollar rose to 3.78 rand, from 3.6620 rand on Thursday. The British pound rose to $1.5520 from $1.5375.
The day began with hedge funds making huge sales of the dollar and large purchases of the yen; analysts estimated that one order alone involved $1 billion.
"The market was pretty nervous this morning" over the stockpiling of dollars that had occurred during the dollar's recent run-up, said Margaret Kudarauskas, another senior foreign exchange analyst at Technical Data.
As they had done with the rand, investors had been borrowing yen at extraordinarily low Japanese rates then buying dollars to invest in higher-yielding United States Treasury securities. But the dollar's recent rise made that strategy more risky and led many, including big hedge funds, to unwind their moves by selling dollars and buying yen.
